HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Providing Some Guidelines On Campaigns for Children

BYLINE: By Kim Foltz

 BODY:
ADVERTISING to children is anything but child's play, and the Children's Television Workshop, which produces the "Sesame Street" television show and a number of children's magazines, wants to help advertisers learn the ropes.
This help for advertisers, offered at a meeting on marketing to children sponsored by General Foods, comes when a number of critics say some advertising to children is practically a form of child abuse. Congress last week restricted the amount of advertising allowed on children's television programming, and some consumer advocates and lawmakers are seeking stricter limits on what can be advertised to children and when.
"We've been trying to help set the standards for advertising to children," said Dr. Renee O'Leary, the director of research for the Children's Television Workshop. "Depending on their age, children have varying abilities to discriminate about advertising and that makes them very vulnerable."
The Children's Television Workshop, a not-for-profit organization based in Manhattan, has an interest in helping advertisers. It accepts advertising for its magazines, which include 3-2-1 Contact, Kid City and a Sesame Street parents' guide. The Sesame Street show, which is broadcast on public television, does not accept ads.
"Children change so quickly, the only way to know what appeals to them and what they will understand is to continually talk to them," Dr. O'Leary said in a recent interview.
Her research has found that in some ways, children are more sophisticated than many people would imagine. A recent survey of children 6 to 10 years old found they were concerned about the possibility of war in the Middle East, AIDS, crime and the economy, as well as the lastest adventures of the Teen-age Mutant Ninja Turtles. Most considered the environment the most important issue.
Dr. O'Leary cautioned that advertisers should not try to appeal to children by trying to be hip. Ads that show children who have "super cool" spiked hair and clothing to match may misfire. "Children generally aren't as hip as the media makes them out to be," she said. "We've found they aren't growing up faster today than in the past."
Using the slang common to rap music lyrics may also be a mistake. Dr. O'Leary said that surveys found that children like rap music because of the beat, but many have no idea what the lyrics are about.
Children also have a hard time understanding ads that rely on parody. They usually do not get the joke at first, Dr. O'Leary said, and when they finally do, they feel betrayed. She said it was generally best to signal children that there was a joke. "Irony won't work on a lot of children," she said. "They take things too literally because they're trying to figure life out."
When it comes to print ads, the simplest approach is often the best, she said. The company's research has found that many children are intimidated by large blocks of type and complicated layouts.
The company's researchers also found that the growing use of so-called kids' clubs in ads -- like the one for Burger King -- may create problems because it can take unfair advantage of most children's natural tendency to want to feel they belong.
Not surprisingly, the images children respond to most readily are cartoons, Dr. O'Leary said. But studies found that what is even more appealing to most children is a combination of cartoon and real-life images. "They like the mix because it's like their lives," Dr. O'Leary said, "a combination of the real and the imaginary."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Who Will Pay For the Big One?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
THE earthquake that slammed through the San Francisco Bay area in October 1989 killed 62 people and destroyed $5 billion worth of property. The next time the earth's giant tectonic plates slip a few yards, both people and property may be at far greater risk.
By Government estimates, a quake hitting the wrong place at the wrong time of day could kill up to 95,000 and leave a $100 billion cleanup bill. Los Angeles and San Francisco are prime targets, of course. But the peril is hardly confined to California: the Federal Emergency Management Agency believes that Seattle, Salt Lake City, Memphis and Charleston, S.C., are also at "major" risk.
If the Big One hits -- make that "when" it hits -- who will pay? Even in California, relatively few property owners are covered by earthquake insurance. But Robert E. Litan, an economist at the Brookings Institution, estimates that damage from quake-related fires and injuries could still result in up to $50 billion in insurance claims. Honoring these claims, he argues, could severely deplete insurers' reserves, driving some into bankruptcy and turning others into risk-taking zombies.
Mr. Litan's preferred fix, described in the latest edition of The Brookings Review: mandatory Federal earthquake insurance, with premiums set to cover actuarial risks.
Just one California property owner in four carries earthquake insurance; nationwide, the figure is below one in 20. If such insurance is available and most people choose not to buy it, why should the Government insist?
One reason, Mr. Litan suggests, is that the private market overprices the product. Only those atgreatest risk currently buy coverage, and insurers are apparently unwilling or unable to attract lower-risk customers with lower premiums.
Another reason is that owners have insufficient incentives to pay for insurance because the Federal Government stands ready to reimburse them for a portion of their losses. American taxpayers, Mr. Litan reckons, shelled out $17 each for disaster relief in last year's San Francisco quake.
Uncle Sam could play hardball, giving legal notice that in the future the Treasury would help only those who help themselves. But the threat would probably not be credible: Americans are no more likely to deny relief to uninsured victims of an earthquake than they are to deny medical care to injured motorcylists who did not wear helmets.
A third and perhaps most compelling reason is that casualty insurers are poorly geared to bear the earthquake risks already on their books. A not unlikely $50 billion hit, Mr. Litan calculates, would drain the industry of about 40 percent of total reserves. Some insurers would go bankrupt; others would be forced to raise rates sharply to meetregulatory requirements.
The process might be manageable in theory, but would certainly be problematic in practice. Mr. Litan, a longtime analyst of the savings and loan debacle, worries that earthquake losses would be injurious to the casualty insurers' financial health, much the way the interest rate squeeze of the early 1980's started savings and loan associations down the path to collective ruin.
When faced with the alternative of double-digit premium increases, he believes, vote-conscious regulators might allow insurance companies to operate with low (or negative) net worths. And once insurers were deep in a financial hole, they would have powerful incentives to generate premium revenues by taking ever greater chances.
Mr. Litan favors legislation that would effectively require anyone who wanted a home mortgage to buy Federal earthquake coverage. The bill, sponsored by Representative Al Swift, a Washington Democrat, and David Dreier, a California Republican, would set premiums according to actuarial risk. Buildings designed or modified to minimize quake damage would get a break on rates.
The average premium in California for a no-deductible policy, Mr. Litan believes, would run between $104 and $194. In Memphis and Charleston, the same coverage would run from $15 to $28.
Federal earthquake insurance would still leave private insurers with enormous exposure to quake-related claims for fire, disability and death losses. The Swift-Dreier bill would cover the gap with Federal reinsurance, giving private insurers years to spread the costs across their premium base.
Federal involvement is no panacea. If Washington's record in insuring farm crops is a precedent, setting premiums at actuarily sound levels would prove very difficult. But one way or another, Mr. Litan argues, Washington is going to bear a lot of the cost of the Big One. Any step that forces property owners to protect themselves is probably a step in the right direction.

HEADLINE: In Lean Times, Caterers Trim Parties to Fit

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
AT a black-tie benefit at the Plaza Hotel last week, a $750 ticket bought a three-course dinner featuring beef Bourgignon, a dish also known as stew; at the same March of Dimes benefit last year, the same price brought four courses, including salmon and duck.
Also this month, a group of formally attired revelers who paid $200 or $350 ate white-bean salad and chicken with tapenade at a benefit for the Prospect Park Alliance in Brooklyn. 
 In an era of fiscal sobriety, organizers of benefits and bashes have had to rethink not only the menus but every aspect of the catered affair, and caterers have been more than accommodating.
Many caterers, but especially those in the East, report that after a slow start, bookings for the fall and winter social season are ahead of last year but that their clients -- corporations, charities, arts organizations, politicians and social groups -- are spending less on parties. "People are more price-conscious than ever," said Sandy Sobel, director of catering sales in Lincoln Center for Restaurant Associates . "They want to spend $60 or $65 a person on the same menu that cost them $75 last year, and we're trying to accommodate them in order to keep the clients."
One of the cost-conscious is Pam Sarnoff, who is the chairwoman of the Winter Antiques Show preview party, to be held on Jan. 25 in New York for the benefit of the East Side House Settlement, a South Bronx social-services organization. While the ticket prices, $500 and $250 each, are the same as last year, Mrs. Sarnoff said, "This year we're hoping to spend less on a per-person basis, but we want to make it just as good as in the past. It's up to the caterer to make it happen."
Caterers say they have had to be more creative. "You cut costs, shave your profit, because you want to do the business no matter what," said William Homan, an owner of Design Cuisine in Washington. "I want to be here for them now, so they'll be back when they have a lot of money."
But some caterers have seen clients who once entertained generously go out of business or try to weather tough times. Several caterers on both coasts lamented the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert. "Losing Drexel Burnham and a major retail client was real blow," said Dounia Rathbone, an owner of Remember Basil Ltd., which catered the Prospect Park party.
"I feel something of the same impact as the restaurant industry," said Henry Dinardo, owner of Windows Catering in Rosslyn, Va., just outside Washington. "Instead of a four-course rack-of-lamb dinner for $40, they'll go with three courses and roast breast of capon for $30 or $35."
But unlike restaurants, caterers, even hotel banquet departments, can be flexible about pricing. Their overhead for rent, utilities and payroll are lower. And they have more options than just food and wine for adjusting the price. For example, if a restaurant changed glassware it would not affect the cost of dining there, but a caterer can trim as much as $4 a person by using plain stemware instead of cut crystal.
"We're in a value-oriented economy and a caterer can deliver what a client needs by individualizing," said Steve Zagor, a former caterer who is manager of restaurant consulting for Laventhol & Horwath, an accounting and consulting firm.
Charities and arts groups in particular have much tighter budgets. "They can't raise the ticket price in this economy and they're having a harder time selling tickets, so they have to cut costs in order to have a successful fund-raising event," said Liz Neumark, owner of Great Performances, a New York caterer.
Carlyn Berghoff, owner of Carlyn Berghoff Catering in Chicago, said some clients are delaying commitments. "People are booking their parties later, no more than three months in advance, compared with as much as a year in the past," she said. "They obviously do not want to submit that 50 percent deposit so far ahead, and they're waiting until they have a better fix on what they can afford."
Some caterers have already seen evidence that many companies are thinking twice about Christmas parties. "Instead of a $25,000 Saturday-night bash, they're going to arrange a party in-house with the secretaries ordering the food, and they're spending one-tenth as much," said Cynthia Colman, a corporate-event planner in San Francisco.
Harriette Rose Katz, a party planner in New York, said she has already had Christmas party cancellations.
Most businesses still have to do some entertaining, though, and some caterers are finding that this creates opportunities if they can meet the need for simpler, less expensive fare. Chip Fisher, an owner of Fisher & Levy, which specializes in delivering elegant sandwich and salad platters to offices in midtown Manhattan at lunchtime, said his business is up. "We've replaced the business lunch in a restaurant for a lot of companies," he added. "The most you can spend with us is about $22 a head."
Changing tastes have made tailoring the cuisine to the budget perhaps the easiest adjustment of all for caterers.
"It's now the rage to do simple but tasty food," Mr. Homan said. "You do not have to serve the most expensive veal and lamb anymore. You make up for it with style, by serving stuffed capon over polenta, and by calling the beans flageolets." In fact, he added, "It's more interesting for us when the client is willing to bend."
Paula LeDuc of Paula LeDuc Catering in Oakland, Calif., said, "Food has changed. People want more for their money and we're serving abundant Mediterranean-style food instead of skimpy designer nouvelle things."
But typically, food accounts for no more than 50 percent of a catered party's costs, and often only about a third. Labor is a major expense and Nancy Kirby Harris, owner of Aller Cuisine Ltd. in Chicago, said clients have asked her to cut back on staffing. "One woman suggested her husband could be the bartender," she saId. "Then I reminded her that we were talking about 150 people and he was also supposed to be the host."
Most caterers are reluctant to cut their staffs. "Without adequate staff, the affair will not run smoothly and we'll lose the client," said Ms. Rathbone of Remember Basil.
Many clients are instead changing the formats of parties. "With some of our corporate and private clients, cocktail buffets are replacing seated dinners," Miss Harris said.
In Washington, Mr. Homan reported, clients are sometimes giving a single reception for 400 people instead of two or three seated dinners for 150 to 200 people each.
Caterers are also compromising on equipment, wine, flowers and music. "Some people are thinking twice about gold chairs at $10 each and ordering something simpler, going with plainer tablecloths, and making do with a five-piece orchestra instead of seven," Miss Harris said.
Ms. Neumark said, "We are pouring a lot of Hawk Crest these days," referring to a well-made California wine that sells for around $6 a bottle.
Miss Colman in San Francisco said some clients are saving up to $1,000 by eliminating valet parking.
Becky Tiegler, a flower arranger in Chicago, said she was sometimes able to halve the price of the flowers for a party by changing the design. She buys her flowers wholesale, and said the price of imported flowers has escalated in the last few weeks because of the increase in fuel prices to the airlines. "This season, people have started calling me wanting to buy the flowers but saying they will do their own arranging," she added. "I won't do that."
Robert Isabell, who handles the floral decorations for some of New York's most highly publicized parties, said he was frequently substituting less-expensive but excellent California-grown flowers.
Not all parts of the country or all segments of the industry have been hit hard. In Oklahoma and Texas, some caterers say business has improved. "Since the price of oil started going back up, things have started picking up and it's better than it was the past couple of years," said John Bennett, a caterer in Oklahoma City, who also does parties in Texas.
There has also been no limit on lavishness when it comes to parties in the entertainment industry. "They're still throwing extravaganzas," said Julie Loshin, president of Parties Plus Inc. in Los Angeles.
And people are still pulling out all the stops for weddings, bar mitzvahs and similar private celebrations as well. "Families have long budgeted the money for these once-in-a-lifetime events and they're prepared to go ahead as planned," said Mrs. Katz, the New York party planner. Ms. Rathbone agreed that many caterers "can still make good money on outrageous events like weddings."
Perhaps there is another explanation for why some people are entertaining as if there were no tomorrow, suggests one caterer.
"Maybe what we're seeing is the Titanic effect," Mr. Zagor suggested. "Having one big bash before things really get bad."

HEADLINE: Environmental Bond Means Too Much Pain for Too Little Gain

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The New York Farm Bureau, with 23,000 members, New York State's largest farm organization, urges New York City voters to reject the 21st century environmental quality bond. Though our farm families strongly support efforts to safeguard the environment, we believe this $2 billion bond is long on debt and short on quality. 
 Proponents of the environmental bond fail to mention that it will cost taxpayers in excess of $1.5 billion in debt service. The state-level debt, for which taxpayers are directly or indirectly responsible, has already reached $25 billion. The state is placing an incredible tax burden on both current and future taxpayers, by this "run to the bank" fiscal policy we practice.
In addition, I'm certain that New Yorkers will not soon forget the fiscal crisis that the state experienced last spring. It took nearly $2 billion of new taxes and fees to cover the budget shortfall. Early reports indicate that last year's fiscal woes will likely rear their ugly head again next year.
 New York State can ill afford a further decline of its economic position. This state's credit rating is the third worst in the nation -- only the financially distraught states of Massachusetts and Louisiana have a lower standing.
The overwhelming majority of the borrowed dollars, $800 million, would go to buy more land. New York State already owns four million acres, or about 13 percent of the state. Simply buying more land is not necessarily the best or most efficient way to protect the environment.
This environmental bond is misleading. It would allocate $201 million to maintain environmental and recreational facilities. Going deeper in debt to paint picnic tables and other caretaker chores is not good fiscal policy. These dollars were diverted from the budget when the state fiscal crisis was in full gear this year.
Protecting the environment is important. However, the dollars that would go for debt service and land acquisitions dwarf the environmental-quality programs, like solid-waste management and water-quality activities.
To retard the growth in the tax burden and in state debt, tough fiscal management is needed. New Yorkers should vote "no" on this bond and send Albany a clear message -- enough is enough.
 
CHARLES WILLE
President, N.Y. Farm Bureau Inc.
Glenmont, N.Y., Oct. 5, 1990

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Racism Has Always Been an Economic Issue;
Forgotten Inventor

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Inspirational Black History Draws Academic Fire" (front page, Oct. 10), you treat "black history" as "inspirational," rather than of value for the school curriculum. This dismisses the many African challenges to the Eurocentric curriculum and their vast documentation, and leaves the impression that they are exaggerations or fibs. This is a disservice to the truth and racial harmony. 
 Let's take one example. You appear to scoff at the statement that Lewis Howard Latimer had "drawn up the plans for Bell's telephone." Later you call "farfetched" the "implied suggestion that he invented the telephone." No such suggestion was made. In a glowing tribute issued on Latimer's death on Dec. 11, 1928, the Edison Pioneers gave him full credit: "It was Mr. Latimer who executed the drawings and assisted in preparing the applications for the telephone patents of Alexander Graham Bell." Latimer was an inventor to be remembered, yet how many high school graduates have ever heard of him?
The attack on the multicultural curriculum comes at a time when the public is beginning to learn that large numbers of African-Americans were cowboys on the frontier, members of great Indian nations and brave Union soldiers in the Civil War. Tens of thousands of African-Americans may have actually turned the tide of battle because they arrived when both sides had used up their white reserves. President Abraham Lincoln thought so and said so, but until the movie "Glory," few had any inkling of this.
Eurocentric public school history courses are filled with lies and exaggerations of the role of whites and omissions about the role of nonwhites. Indeed, the school curriculum itself has been a major if subtle obstacle to racial unity and peace in this country. Whites learn each day that nonwhites were evil redskins, sullen slaves or ghetto gangsters. Why should they not drift toward the David Dukes of this country? Nonwhites learn their ancestors never did anything anyone would respect.
We need a curriculum of inclusion and truth, that does not exaggerate anyone's role.
 
WILLIAM LOREN KATZ
New York, Oct. 15, 1990
 
The writer is author of "The Black West" and "Black Indians: A Hidden Heritage."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Racism Has Always Been an Economic Issue

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In assessing David Duke's defeat in Louisiana (Op-Ed, Oct. 9), Leonard Zeskind observes: "Mr. Duke's campaign themes echoed those of George Wallace in his 1968 Presidential bid: racism combined with a resentment of white elites." 
 It would have been more accurate to say "racism as an expression of resentment of white elites." Caste and class have consistently been confused on this issue.
Historical evidence supports the argument that the origins of slavery lie not in racism, though in the 17th century the English saw Africans as different from themselves, but rather in an effort by the white elite of Virginia to rid itself of the social turmoil that was created by land-hungry young white males who had served their indentures and called for economic compensation (not unlike the young white males in Louisiana of whom Mr. Zeskind speaks).
If more black servants were imported and their servitude was lifelong, the problem of lower-class white demands could be eliminated. (Of course, the willingness of Virginia's leaders to take this tack demonstrates their placing self-interest before the interest of black labor, not a classic racist stance.)
Although there was obviously a contradiction between the egalitarian ideals of the United States and the reality of slavery, a contradiction that helped create the Republican Party, nevertheless Abraham Lincoln's major concern about the extension of slavery seems to have been its threat to free white labor. With his typical clarity, Lincoln recognized the importance of the class issue.
The emancipation of the slaves did not lead directly to segregation, as it should have if American society was primarily and fundamentally racist. Rather, segregation arose in response to a threatening biracial political challenge from black and white farmers in the 1890's to the white elite -- which capitulated to racism after paternalism failed. Segregation collapsed in the face of a civil rights movement sustained by post-World War II prosperity, while racism is now resurgent in an era of economic decline.
This oversimplified summary is meant to document the assertion that racism has been and continues to be fostered by competition for limited resources, that is, it is primarily a class issue. It can best be fought by policies for economic and, hence, social justice.
 
JOSEPH E. ILLICK
San Francisco, Oct. 9, 1990
 
The writer is professor of history at San Francisco State University

HEADLINE: About New York;
Landlord's War For Enterprise In East Harlem

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
Harley Brooke-Hitching looked, well, different from most attending Monday's luncheon at the Women's National Republican Club. She wore jeans and a baggy sweatshirt. Two young employees accompanying her wore the same.
"We're not going to steal nothing," one of the employees told a nervous woman at the front desk. 
 Make no mistake, Mrs. Brooke-Hitching was more than welcome in this staid bastion. She had arranged the refinancing of the club when its books were shaky. The Republican women had figured that if Mrs. Brooke-Hitching could secure loans to buy dilapidated buildings in East Harlem, she just might do the same for anybody.
The red-haired, 45-year-old whirlwind isn't a registered Republican, but vehemently supports business enterprise. Her mission for the last five years has been to try to make money renting decent apartments to some of New York's poorest people. She owns 180 units of low- and middle-income housing, mainly on 111th Street between Second and Third Avenues.
She had come to hear Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown speak. The Commissioner declared the root of the crime crisis is "the pervasive use of illegal drugs." Not news to Mrs. Brooke-Hitching.
Drugs are pandemic and pernicious on East 111th Street. She has found windows broken, been threatened and been hit in the face. So she compiled a list of drug dealers and drug apartments in her and others' buildings and sent it to city officials, including Mr. Brown.
There was the name of a man who holds drugs and guns, a woman who holds drugs for street runners (her children) and a man who sells drugs on weekends when he is released from jail. Despite her specificity, months have passed with no action.
Mrs. Brooke-Hitching mentioned this to the Commissioner after the speech. He thanked her and suggested she call her precinct.
"We're in contact with them a lot," she said wearily. "We just don't get any response."
 That morning, in her Upper East Side apartment, it had become clear that Harley Brooke-Hitching is an almost indescribable woman. There were exquisite antiques, leather-bound books, row upon row of fine wine. Country music, Don Williams to be specific, filled the room. Four large cats, once strays, lounged about. The coffee was instant.
One set of great-grandparents had been in the Oklahoma land rush; another carried British titles. She was educated in Britain, France and Italy -- that being "what a young girl did." At age 24, she was managing Sotheby's Amsterdam branch. There was marriage, divorce and one son, now 17. She lived in Bangkok, made a bundle from Asian art. A decade ago, she came to New York in search of "a bigger pond."
She couldn't find an apartment as large as the one she had left in Chicago. So she used her savings as a down payment on an entire building, converted it to co-ops and made a killing. She did even better with a bigger one.
In 1985, Mrs. Brooke-Hitching decided to invest in East Harlem. Part of the reason was economic: the real-estate boom had wildly inflated prices but the tawdry area remained cheap. Part was trying to link profit and altruism: That this landlord is of good heart is evident in her 1982 founding of City Harvest, which distributes food to the hungry.
There was a third factor. "I must say it's exciting," she said. "The adrenaline pumps."
Mrs. Brooke-Hitching had no illusion about her purchase. Not only did some of the 11 buildings not have locks, they lacked doors. "I was buying garbage."
But she scrambled and got financing. She painted the walls fanciful colors. Then, the value of her investment climbed. New tenants seemed more responsible. Her vision was confirmed: "Things can work for everybody."
Lately, though, she has become pessimistic. Drugs and crime are the most obvious scourge. But taxes, utilities and oil are going up faster than income. And she has learned to gripe the gripes of landlords. One is that no matter what a tenant does to your property, he is almost impossible to evict. Another is that housing court is "a zoo."
Unexpected expenses have included recycling fines. "I am now responsible for the recycling of the garbage of people who defecate in hallways," Mrs. Brooke-Hitching sighed.
All this comes while property owners' assets are crumbling in front of them. Her once pristine hallways are now marked by grafitti and dirt. She frets about banks' patience. She is tired of fighting City Hall.
But she hasn't given up. This unlikely landlord treasures remembering climbing Kilimanjaro on the morning of her 43d birthday. Just as she reached the top, the sun popped out.

HEADLINE: Durable Goods Orders Fell by 1.7% Last Month

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Orders to factories for "big ticket" durable goods fell 1.7 percent in September from August, the Government said today. Analysts said the report foretold a further slump in production and employment in the industrial sector, which has lost 500,000 jobs since January 1989.
"It was another report indicating the economy is slowing down," said Elliott Platt, director of economic research at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, New York. He added that it probably showed "that we're in a recession -- but probably indicating the recession will be mild." 
 The Commerce Department said the value of orders for durable goods -- items expected to last more than three years -- totaled a seasonally adjusted $124.9 billion last month.
 
 Slump in Vehicles
 Transportation orders slid 6.8 percent, to $32.8 billion. Declines in motor vehicles more than offset an increase in aircraft.
"The main message is that dealers are not ordering 1991 model cars," said Cynthia Latta, an economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill, Lexington, Mass.
Durable goods orders have fallen three times in the last four months and the Commerce Department said today that the August decline was even steeper than previously reported: eight-tenths of 1 percent rather than five-tenths of 1 percent. In the first nine months, it said, orders were off five-tenths of 1 percent compared with the first nine months of 1989.
Durable goods orders are a key barometer of the manufacturing industry's plans for production. A decrease in orders can result in production cutbacks and layoffs.
 
66,000 Jobs Lost
 In fact, the Labor Department reported earlier that 66,000 factory jobs were lost in September. Since reaching a post-recession peak in January 1989, the manufacturing sector has lost 500,000 jobs.
"The industrial sector is just muddling along," Ms. Latta said. "I expect industrial output to decline in the fourth quarter because of a lack of orders."
But Samuel D. Kahan, chief financial economist with Fuji Securities Inc. in Chicago, said that while the report reflected continued softness in the manufacturing sector, it contained no "confirming" evidence that things would get worse.
He noted that excluding the transportation category, orders actually inched up three-tenths of 1 percent.
Orders in the key category of nondefense capital goods jumped 6.3 percent, to $38.2 billion, but failed to regain the 9.9 percent loss of August. While these orders are often a barometer of business plans to expand and modernize, Mr. Platt suggested that many of them might have come from overseas.
"The strength in exports probably will be one of the factors that will keep a recession relatively mild," he said.
Orders for nonelectrical machinery rebounded 5.4 percent, to $22.5 billion, from a 5.1 percent drop in August. Office and computing equipment had the largest gain.
But orders for electrical machinery fell 7.7 percent, to $19.1 billion, after advancing 2.2 percent the previous month. Both communications equipment and electronic components were down sharply.
Orders for primary metals also declined, by eight-tenths of 1 percent, to $11.4 billion. They had fallen 2.5 percent in August.
The often-volatile military orders were off 9.6 percent, to $7.6 billion, following a 12.5 percent increase the previous month.
Shipments of durable goods were down 3 percent, to $124.7 billion, losing a 2.8 percent advance in August. Unfilled orders were unchanged at $499.5 billion, following a three-tenths of 1 percent loss the previous month.

GRAPHIC: Chart: Manufacturers' total new orders for durable goods, in billions of dollars. (source: Commerce Dept.)

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
U.S. Joins in 2d Vote At U.N. to Criticize Israel Over 21 Slain

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 24

 BODY:
The United States voted with the rest of the Security Council tonight to deplore Israel's refusing to cooperate with an investigation of the killing of 21 Palestinians in a clash with Israeli security forces two weeks ago.
The unanimous council vote, the second to criticize Israel in 12 days, had been postponed for 24 hours at the request of the United States so that President Bush could send an appeal to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel to reconsider his Government's refusal to cooperate with the United Nations inquiry into the Oct. 8 killings. 
 Israel rejected the appeal today, and after promising members to make "another serious attempt" at changing Israel's position, the United States representative, Thomas R. Pickering, returned to the council chamber empty-handed.
Diplomats said that as with the earlier council resolution against Israel Washington's vote was largely influenced by its desire to preserve the international coalition opposing the seizure of Kuwait by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
On Oct. 12, the Security Council voted unanimously to approve a resolution condemning Israel for using excessive violence four days earlier in suppressing stone-throwing demonstrators at Al Aksa Mosque in the Old City of Jerusalem.
The new resolution "deplores" Israel's refusal to receive an investigative team that Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar planned to send to Jerusalem at the Security Council's behest. The mission was to report on the Oct. 8 incident and suggest ways to protect Palestinians in the occupied territories from further violence.
The new resolution urges Israel to reconsider its refusal and "insists that it comply fully" with the Oct. 12 resolution, which authorized the inquiry.
Last week, the Israeli Government said that although the United Nations investigators could come to the country it would not receive them or give assurances that its members would be able to meet Palestinian leaders. Mr. Perez de Cuellar responded by saying that he would not send the team.
 
U.N. Role on Israel Seen
 The resolution adopted today instructs the Secretary General to submit his report by the end of the month as planned even though his team will not be visiting Israel. The council "affirms its determination to give full and expeditious consideration to the report."
This means that later this month the Security Council will begin discussing possible new ways that the United Nations could help protect Palestinians against Israeli mistreatment.
Though it voted for the resolution tonight, the United States has said that in its view the process outlined by the Security Council does not give it the right to involve itself in the quest for a permanent peace settlement in the area.
But most other members see the Secretary General's report as opening the door to precisely such United Nations involvement. Some are likely to argue that the best way to protect Palestinians from further violence is to summon an international conference under United Nations auspices to settle the Palestinian question -- a gathering the Israeli Government has long opposed.
While irritation with the present Israeli Government's policies may partly explain the Bush Administration's endorsement of two anti-Israeli resolutions this month, diplomats believe another powerful factor is the need to preserve the unity of the moderate Arab coalition Washington has built up against the seizure of Kuwait by Iraq.
An American veto would embarrass the Arab states by casting the United States in the role of Israel's protector. It would also allow President Hussein to present himself as the true ally of the Palestinians.
As a result, the Security Council's campaign to oust Iraq's forces from Kuwait is becoming linked with the Palestinian question in the minds of most council members. They accept the Arabs' contention that the council cannot preserve its credibility if it punishes Iraq's aggression while turning a blind eye to Israel's continued occupation of Arab lands.
In a bitter address tonight, Israel's acting representative, Johanan Bein, accused the Palestine Liberation Organization of deliberately sidetracking the council from the Persian Gulf crisis by involving it in the Palestinian question. "It appears Saddam Hussein has been let off the hook," he said.
But Yemen's representative, Abdullah Saleh al-Ashlaf, the council's only Arab member, said the council should impose trade sanctions on Israel if it continues to disobey its orders just as it imposed them against Iraq.
The P.L.O.'s acting observer, Nasser al-Kidwa, also asked the Security Council to institute a stronger link between its handling of Iraq and Israel, saying it should be prepared to impose economic sanctions on Israel.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
In Case of War, Congress Wants Right to Meet

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Congressional leaders said today that they would reserve the right to reconvene Congress in case the Bush Administration decides to go to war against Iraq after the current Congressional session ends.
Under usual procedures only the President can call lawmakers back to Washington. But the House Speaker, Representative Thomas S. Foley, and the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, said that a provision would be included in an adjournment resolution allowing them to reconvene the Congress. 
 They also said that an 18-member bipartisan group of lawmakers was being set up to consult with President Bush after the session ends, probably before the end of the week.
Some members of Congress have expressed strong concerns about the prospects for war in the Persian Gulf as a result of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait . The Bush Administration has repeatedly refused to yield to demands by lawmakers that Congress should have a say in its decision on whether or when to initiate military action against Iraq.
 
'Only Thing We Can Do'
 "I think it is about the only thing we can do at this point," said Representative Les Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the House Armed Services Committee.
"It does not exactly do the trick, but it is as close as we can get," he added.
The Congressional steps were suggested by Representative Dante B. Fascell, Democrat of Florida, who is chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney declined to make any commitments to lawmakers on consultation over possible action in the gulf at unusual closed-door meetings with House and Senate members today.
Even though Administration officials have suggested that they are emphasizing economic sanctions and that war is not imminent, some lawmakers believe that there are increasing pressures for war against Iraq.
 
'Headed Toward Conflict'
 Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, senior Republican member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said today that the United States and other members of the multinational force were moving toward war with Baghdad.
"The fact is that we're headed toward conflict," Mr. Lugar said on the NBC News program "Today."
At the meetings on Capitol Hill, Mr. Cheney said that the Administration was considering whether to send additional troops to the Persian Gulf, what rotations to establish for American troops in the region and what to do with the Army's 82d Airborne Division.
Some Army officials believe that two more divisions should be sent to Saudi Arabia if the United States decides to take offensive. And some military planners say that the 82d Airborne, which was deployed early in the American operation to protect airfields in Saudi Arabia and get troops on the ground in a hurry, should be replaced by a heavier, mechanized unit.
 
Baker Tells of Overtures
 Mr. Cheney reportedly also told House members that the Pentagon would be prepared to send combat reserve units to the Persian Gulf, as some lawmakers have demanded, if Congress would amend the law so that the units could be called up for more than six months.
Mr. Baker said at his meetings on Capitol Hill that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq had made a number of overtures to Western officials in an effort to split the coalition against him.
Mr. Baker said President Hussein had invited the German Foreign Minister and Canadian officials to Baghdad, suggesting that they would be rewarded with the release of German and Canadian hostages. Mr. Baker said that the Germans and Canadians had refused the overtures.
Iraq announced today that all 327 French citizens in Iraq and Kuwait could leave within days and recently allowed the departure of 33 Britons and 14 Americans.
 
Arms Sale Details Disclosed
 In other comments, Mr. Baker emphasized that American and other hostages were being poorly treated by the Iraqis and added that President Bush takes very seriously his responsibility to protect American citizens. Mr. Baker's comments on this point were so strong that some lawmakers later said they wondered if he was stating a rationale for military action.

Smith; Dante B. Fascell, the committee chairman; William S. Broomfield, and Benjamin A. Gilman. (Michael Geissinger for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. Raises a Question IN Brazil's Dept Talks

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
A top United States Treasury official told Brazil's central bank president yesterday that he was worried about the more than $8 billion in unpaid interest owed to commercial bankers.
The remark is an indication that Brazil cannot expect to get approval of a $2 billion emergency loan until it reaches an acceptable arrangement with the banks to pay the arrears. 
 The dispute over the unpaid interest is also souring the debt negotiations with Brazil's commercial bankers, which began earlier this month. Bankers were angered to find out that the Brazilian Government was quietly buying back its debt at a huge discount in the open market, using money that could be used to pay interest on its loans.
 
 World's Biggest Debtor
 Continuing problems with unpaid interest, as well as with proposals made by Brazil and rejected by its bankers, could mean the negotiations will be long and drawn out. Brazil is the developing world's biggest debtor, with a total debt of about $113 billion, including $60 billion owed to commercial banks, and difficulties in the negotiations would undermine the Bush Administration's debt strategy of the last year and a half.
In addition, if nothing is resolved on the loan interest, which Brazil stopped paying in April 1989, American banks could be forced by Federal banking regulators to write off an additional 20 percent of the value of their loans to Brazil, which could force losses at a time when bank earnings are already declining.
David C. Mulford, Treasury Under Secretary for International Affairs, made the comment about the unpaid interest in a meeting with Ibrahim Eris, the president of the Brazilian central bank, Mr. Eris said in an interview. Mr. Eris also met with the heads of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank and the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
The comment appeared to reflect a feeling in Washington that Brazil's reluctance to make a substantial commitment to erasing the arrears is sending a bad signal to other debtor nations.
Although the I.M.F. and the World Bank modified their policies in 1989 to allow debtor countries to get some financial assistance while still in arrears on bank loan interest, Brazil's position now seems to be pushing this accommodation too far, officials said.
But Mr. Eris said Mr. Mulford did not directly say that Brazil had to pay more of its arrears.
Mr. Eris said he came to the United States to explain the Brazilian proposal, convince officials that the country is serious about negotiating and "win hearts and minds for the Brazilian case." He said Brazil could make limited interest payments because the Government could raise the money only by cutting spending and increasing revenue.
But the bankers argue that Brazil has at least $8.5 billion in dollar reserves, generated through trade, which means it can make larger interest payments.
 
'A Positive Attitude'
 Mr. Eris also said Brazil was "open to any proposal" from its bankers on the interest arrears. One banker suggested that remark reflected "a positive attitude."
William R. Rhodes, senior executive-international at Citibank and the head of the bank negotiating committee, said its economic subcommittee would return from Brazil tomorrow. He said the full committee would then meet.
In the first proposal made to commercial bankers when negotiations began earlier this month, Brazilian officials said that they could pay no more than $1.4 billion in interest next year and that there would be no payments until January. The banks have rejected this proposal.

HEADLINE: Fernandez and Teachers Union: Are 2 Sides Too Close?

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
As New York City Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez has maintained a relationship with the teachers union that strikes some educators as uncommonly close and visible given the city's history of often-fierce labor-management wars.
The alliance has benefited both sides, and it may also benefit the education of New York's children through more attractive salaries for teachers, cooperation in decision-sharing programs between teachers and principals and a number of legislative changes that could improve the accountability for all professionals in the system. 
 But some city officials and educators are concerned about possible perils, saying that the salary increases that this alliance negotiated may strain the city's finances and that Mr. Fernandez will not work hard enough to remove ineffective or abusive teachers.
At no time has the alliance seemed stronger than since a new one-year contract gave teachers a 5.5 percent raise. On Tuesday, when an article in The Daily News suggested that the economic pain unleashed bythe contract might lead to teacher layoffs, both Mr. Fernandez and a spokesman for the union reacted with the same angry tone and both blamed City Hall.
"The story coming out of City Hall is not accurate," Mr. Fernandez said.
"This kind of game playing goes to the heart of why the City Hall budget people have no credibility with us," said Bert Shanas, a spokesman for the United Federation of Teachers.
Mr. Fernandez, aides said, has also called City Hall to complain that he is receiving mixed signals about the merits of a contract both he and the administration helped negotiate. Aides said the Chancellor was being told to promote the contract publicly even though newspaper stories stemming from City Hall suggest that it was too generous. Yesterday, Mr. Fernandez, after being asked by City Hall to prepare $94 million in possible cuts from the board's $6.5 billion budget, said he had decided to offer roughly half the cuts he was asked for, without, he pointedly said, a single teacher layoff. His position was endorsed by the Board of Education last night in a letter sent to Mayor David N. Dinkins.
For now, Mr. Dinkins appears not to see Mr. Fernandez's attitude as one of defiance but rather as a desire for more time to work with the numbers.
"A program that gives you only half the cuts that you are responsible for probably will not get you a passing grade," said Lee Jones, a spokesman for the Mayor. Robert F. Wagner Jr., former president of the Board of Education, says that while Irving Anker, who was Chancellor in the mid-1970's and Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, who was Chancellor in the mid- and late 60's, had closer but less open friendships with the union, Mr. Fernandez's alliance with Sandra Feldman, the union's president, is perhaps the most visible in memory.
"Joe has not been afraid to be public with the U.F.T. as opposed to other chancellors," Mr. Wagner said.
In some ways, the relationship is a marriage of convenience. Noreen Connell, executive director of the Educational Priorities Panel, a coalition of advocacy groups, pointed out that the city government and the Board of Education depended on the union, with its 107,000 politically astute members, to get their programs and financing schemes approved in Albany, and that the union depended on the board to treat its teachers kindly and pay them well.
Charles I. Schonhaut, a former deputy chancellor who is now dean of the Long Island University School of Education, said the relationship had enabled Mr. Fernandez to win enactment of laws limiting tenure for principals and abolishing the Board of Examiners.
"Realistically, the most powerful group in education today is the U.F.T., so by making them his allies he got their support for legislation," he said.
 
'Enlightened New Management'
 Ms. Feldman applauds her working relationship with Mr. Fernandez and argues that "all enlightened new management is involving its workers in decision-making."
James S. Vlasto, press secretary to the Chancellor, asserted that the relationship had given Mr. Fernandez "a lot of strength in relating to teachers." He said Mr. Fernandez had extracted more than 200 changes in the contract, "all positive," laying a contractual groundwork for school-based decision-making and tightening discipline. The relationship, he said, will make it easier for Mr. Fernandez to get teachers to work a longer day.
Mr. Fernandez won the union's backing as the leading candidiate for chancellor largely because of his warm relationship with labor as superintendent of Miami's schools. Indeed, Mr. Fernandez sometimes reached for a joke to deflect criticism of his tight bond with Pat Tornillo, the head of the teachers union there.
"I want to reassure you that because we wear the same color suits, the same color socks and because I roll over in the morning and say, 'Pat, what are you wearing today?' doesn't mean we are in bed together," he was reported -- by Mr. Tornillo -- to have said in jest.
 
Variety of Issues
 Returning to New York City with few powerful acquaintances, Mr. Fernandez has had to rely on the union as his political bedrock. But Mr. Fernandez and Ms. Feldman also came to their relationship with a strong convergence of philosophies: a desire to give teachers a greater voice in the running of schools through the plan, which Mr. Fernandez started in Miami, called school-based management.
But the union has gone out of its way to support him, even on issues that may not affect teachers directly. On Tuesday, both Mr. Fernandez and a union representative testified at an Assembly committee hearing in favor of a greater role for the chancellors in the selection of superintendents. The proposal will have no immediate benefits for teachers, though ultimately, its advocates claim, it will improve management systemwide. It threatens to alienate school board members who were elected with union support.
"It shows the union's trust in him," Mr. Schonhaut said.
 
Matter of Timing
 By contrast, the principals union, the Council of Supervisors and Administrators, has been arguing that the Chancellor should only set minimum qualifications for superintendents and not be allowed to veto candidates.
"From our point of view," said Donald Singer, president of the principals union, "there are going to be issues which you don't agree about."
The relationship between the teachers union and Mr. Fernandez was made possible by fortuitious timing. Under Mayor Edward I. Koch, Mr. Schonhaut says, the city administration dictated management terms in labor negotiations, regardless of what the Board of Education's members or the chancellor wanted to do. Mr. Koch believed that all unions should get equivalent raises, with no preferences for teachers.
In 1984, Mr. Schonhaut recalled, Chancellor Nathan Quinones testifed at a City Council hearing in favor of pay raises for teachers. "City Hall jumped all over him," saying. " 'That's not your business. We will decide what the raise will be,' " Mr. Schonhaut recalled.
 
Misgivings About Alliance
 But under Mr. Dinkins, Mr. Schonhaut said, Mr. Fernandez was able to take "a role in the negotiations which no chancellor had taken before."
Even those who see benefits in the alliance between the central school administration and the teachers union have some misgivings about it. One former board official who asked for anonymity said Mr. Fernandez did not receive anything in return for the pay raise. A key concession by the union -- a new binding-arbitration procedure set up to speed the handling of disciplinary cases against teachers -- turned out to be not compulsory, but an option that teachers facing charges could choose.
Disappointed, Ms. Connell contends that Mr. Fernandez "could be very much more tough about" seeking the ouster of incompetent teachers. Although she sees many merits in the amicable relationship, she worries that even when Mr. Fernandez takes a principled position he will be seen as currying favor with the union.
She noted that the Chancellor, in seeking 5.5 percent pay raises, was genuinely concerned about the drain of experienced teachers to higher-paying suburban districts. But again, she says, his position happened to converge with that of the union and the perception of its integrity was undercut.

HEADLINE: Bankers Face Increasing Skepticism Among Investors

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla., Oct. 24

 BODY:
The high dividend that Citicorp was forced to pay today on a preferred stock issue served as a reminder that many investors are skeptical about the strength of large banks despite assurances by bankers and regulators that they are solvent.
Bankers gathered here for a meeting of the American Bankers Association noted that data of the Federal Reserve through mid-October show that Citicorp and other large banking companies like Chase and Chemical have not been hit with enough deposit withdrawals to force them to borrow at the Fed's discount window. 
 But problems with bad real estate loans and weak earnings at the large banks have made investors and depositors more nervous than at any time since the Federal deposit insurance program was created in 1933.
Short-term deposit ratings for the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the Chemical Banking Corporation and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company are all lower than the highest grade assigned by Moody's Investor Services, which many investors require. Citicorp, however, still has a top Moody's rating.
 
 Demanding Higher Yields
 In the financial markets, corporate treasurers are demanding high yields in return for taking the risk of holding bank securities, whose values might decline in the current weak banking climate. Still, analysts are not predicting that any large banks will become insolvent anytime soon.
Corporate treasurers are not the only American financiers to feel uneasy about large New York City banks. The chief credit officer at one large regional bank with more than $15 billion of assets said he recently stopped making overnight and short-term loans to some New York banks and has sharply cut back lending to weaker New York banks with which he does large amounts of other business. "I don't get paid enough to take the risk," he said, adding that there are many lower-risk alternatives.
Michael Esposito, chief financial officer at Chase Manhattan, said that "some lines have been cut," referring to credit lines from banks that in years past routinely lent their excess cash to Chase. In the Eurodollar market, where large New York banks are heavy borrowers from foreign institutions, Mr. Esposito said interest rates paid by Chase had moved up relative to that paid by some other banks. Things have jumped around for a month or two, he said, "but they will come back to normal."
Bankers and regulators meeting here also expressed concern that talk about changing the Federal Deposit Insurance System could intensify the fears of depositors, possibly prompting them to withdraw their funds from banks. About 35 percent of the public believes that the banking system is unhealthy, according to a recent survey by the American Banker, the trade newspaper.
 
Regulator Calls for Caution
 "In this environment, we need to be awfully careful when talking about deposit insurance reform," said Robert L. Clarke, Comptroller of the Currency, the top regulator for most of the nation's largest banks. "Let's not spook people, depositors, into making irrational decisions," he said in an interview here.
Many recent proposals, like cutting the amount of deposits covered by insurance or requiring automatic losses for large depositors at failed banks, can be dangerous, Mr. Clarke said. "They all sound like a pulling away of the support system that traditionally existed for the banking industry," he said.
Robert H. Smith, chairman of the Security Pacific Corporation in Los Angeles, said that "if there is change in deposit insurance, it is important that it be done with a great deal of caution, and over time."
A key aspect of deposit insurance for large banks is the extent to which Federal insurance protects deposits above the ceiling of $100,000 per account. Last month, Federal Reserve officials urged the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to protect all foreign deposits at the failed National Bank of Washington. If those deposits were not fully protected, Fed officials said, foreigners might be prompted to withdraw a large part of the $380 billion they have on deposit in American banks.
 
Concern at Small Banks
 Smaller banks are also concerned that changes in deposit insurance could disrupt their business. "Deposit insurance is our biggest advantage when it comes to competing with the money market mutual funds," said Robert E. Marling, executive vice president at the Woodforest National Bank, Houston.
Proposals to limit coverage to a total of $100,000 a depositor rather than $100,000 an account "would chase a lot of people away from the bank" to investments like Treasury bills, Mr. Marling said.
David W. Mullins Jr., a Federal Reserve governor, said the Treasury might propose next year that bank customers be limited to no more than three insured accounts of a maximum of $100,000 each, rather than the unlimited number of $100,000 accounts at present.

HEADLINE: THE STRUGGLE IN CONGRESS;
Aides Say Bush Faced Choice: A Deal on Taxes, or a Fiasco

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24

 BODY:
In a tense Oval Office meeting late Tuesday night, the Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, and the House Republican leader, Robert H. Michel of Illinois, bluntly told President Bush that he had to choose between a deal or a fiasco.
The President's advisers and Cabinet were split on whether to stop talking to the Democrats or continue the search for a path out of the budget impasse. 
 According to officials close to the White House budget deliberations, a number of White House figures, including Vice President Dan Quayle, had recommended that the bargaining be halted. In earlier meetings and discussions, they argued that the President had given too much ground and that no deal was better than a bad one.
 
Arguments for a Deal
 But weighing in on the other side were the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu; the budget director, Richard G. Darman, and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, who attended the meeting with the Republican leaders. Too much was at stake, they contended, to pull the plug on the negotiations over the issue of how to tax people with adjusted annual incomes above $1 million.
Mr. Dole then gave the President a general description of a plan that appeared to offer a way out. The plan, which is incorporated in the current compromise, would combine a smaller limit on itemized deductions for taxpayers making more than $100,000 with a phaseout of personal exemptions for that income group.
Mr. Dole knew that such a plan had the backing of the Senate Democratic leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, and that he stood a fair chance of persuading other Democratic leaders as well as the chairmen of the two Congressional tax committees to go along if the President would also agree. He also knew that the plan had passed political muster with Mr. Darman.
If the deal being negotiated tonight holds together, officials said, the Tuesday night meeting will be looked upon as a watershed. In any event, it provided a clear picture of the intense political pressures generated by the budget crisis and the growing willingness of Congressional leaders to confront Mr. Bush.
Armed with counts from party whips of how the House and Senate votes would line up, the Republican leaders made clear that a surtax on the very rich, favored by Democrats and some House Republicans, could not pass the Senate and that a stiff limit on itemized deductions for the wealthy, favored by the Administration and the Senate, could not pass the House.
"I gave him the whole picture," said Mr. Michel. "The President has to know that, not just what the numbers are, but how members feel. I spelled it all out to him."
Administration and Congressional officials said another factor was that, at some point in the preceding 24 hours, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, who had until that time steered clear of involvement in the budget, added his voice to the faction advising the President to make a deal. Several officials suggested that Mr. Darman, a former top aide to Mr. Baker in the Reagan Administration, may have had something to do with enlisting Mr. Baker as a political counselor.
 
Baker Warns Bush of Damage
 Officials said that Mr. Baker told the President that he faced considerable political and economic damage if he did not find a way to make a deal.
On Tuesday night, as Mr. Dole and Mr. Michel were meeting with the President at the White House, House Democratic leaders were mulling the possibility of proceeding with their own budget package, surtax on millionaires and all, even if it meant rejection by the Senate and the White House.
With that prospect in mind, Senator Dole laid out the possibility for a face-saving compromise involving the phaseout of the exemptions taxpayers can claim for themselves and their dependents.
The phasing out of personal exemptions, dubbed PEP by the Democrats and POPE by Mr. Dole as it began to take on life today, was the brainchild of Lindy Paull, the chief tax aide to Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, the senior Republican on the Finance Committee. Mr. Packwood said he began looking at the idea late last week, before it had become clear that budget negotiations between the House and the Senate were bogged down over the issue of a surtax on millionaires.
His first thought was to try the idea out on William Diefenderfer, the deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget who is a former chief tax counsel to the Finance Committee. When Mr. Diefenderfer signaled that the Administration response would be positive, Mr. Packwood broached the plan with Senator Dole.
 
'Fly in the Ointment'
 "I saw it as a way to raise taxes on the wealthy that was workable," Mr. Packwood said. "But there was one fly in the ointment. It took all day Monday to get estimates for how much revenue it would produce." According to Congressional Democrats, the initial estimates were hardly promising, showing that the exemption phaseout would raise only $2 billion over five years, far short of the amount that could be produced by placing a surtax on people earning more than $1 million a year or limiting itemized deductions.
Although Mr. Mitchell was quick to endorse the plan, or some variation of it, as the basis for a compromise, other Democrats, including Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, and Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, who heads the House Ways and Means Committee, were skeptical.
Among the White House figures who lobbied against a deal were Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher; the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Jack F. Kemp, and the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, Michael J. Boskin.
By Tuesday, the prospects for a deal appeared to be deteriorating in both the House and Senate alike, and while leaders in both chambers were aware of Mr. Packwood's plan, rank-and-file members were not even aware that such an idea had been floated.
Mr. Dole made his final pitch to House Democratic leaders at a meeting this morning, armed with both the President's consent for the plan to phase out exemptions and revenue estimates showing that at least one variation of it could produce as much as $8 billion in new revenue over five years. Mr. Packwood said it was all a question of timing.
"When you're looking for the piece that puts the deal together," he said. "You don't want to come too early."

HEADLINE: THE STRUGGLE IN CONGRESS: Shooting Their Feet;
Sure, Some Officials Can Exult Now, But Government Itself Lies Wounded

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24

 BODY:
The Democrats won the political battle over the budget, almost all the Washington score-keepers were saying tonight, and gave President Bush some nasty bruises in the process, but in the deepest sense, there were no victors.
 The shaky compromise that apparently ended five months of confusion and conflict between the White House and Capitol Hill, between Democrats and Republicans, came far too late to avoid severe damage to the reputations of President Bush, the Congress and the Government itself. To a degree unparalleled since the late 1960's, the ability of Washington to discern and promote the common weal -- in effect, to govern -- is being widely questioned. 
 The doubt is demonstrated in the proliferation of proposals to limit the terms of legislators, but also in the election-season comments of voters.
A Democrat in Pensacola, Fla., challenged a visitor from Washington this month to "name a single person up there who really cares about helping the average guy," and a Republican in Cleveland argued that "if every public official in the city lost his job, and every job was filled by someone just out of college, the government couldn't be any worse than it is right now."
 
Anti-Government Bandwagon
 Even Mr. Bush, whose flip-flops on tax policy over the past few weeks helped to deepen the evolving crisis of confidence in government, has been trying to identify himself with the heartland and not the capital. A man who has spent most of his adult life on a governmental payroll, the President exclaimed the other day that it was wonderful to be out campaigning among "real people" who had nothing to do with politics.
The constant denunciation of politicians and process -- by journalists, scholars, the public and even by politicians themselves -- can only weaken the already feeble public inclination to participate in politics by voting.
But in the short term, the President and his party were clearly more heavily damaged than the Democrats.
With the mid-term elections less than two weeks away, Republican candidates are reeling. Republican Senators Jesse Helms of North Carolina, Rudy Boschwitz of Minnesota and Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon, all of whom had seemed headed for easy re-election a couple of months ago, are all in peril now, at least partly because of the events in Washington. Representative Tom Tauke of Iowa, who had been given a good chance of ousting Senator Tom Harkin, a Democrat, appears to have fallen back in the latest polls.
 
An Image That Hurts
 David Keene, a Republican political consultant, said "the bottom has dropped out" for G.O.P. candidates.
As Bob Dole, the canny Kansan who leads the Republicans in the Senate, foresaw weeks ago, the Democrats have succeeded in reviving the imagery of the 1930's, when Herbert Hoover and the Republicans were stigmatized as the party of the rich. Sensing a populist rebellion against the easy money and ostentation of the 1980's, the Democrats have seized upon the code word "fairness" and painted themselves as the champions of the middle class.
President Ronald Reagan's political alchemy -- persuading almost everyone that lower taxes meant more money for almost everyone -- appears to have lost its magic with Mr. Reagan's retirement.
Inevitably, opposition control of both houses of Congress, by a larger margin than faced by any other incoming President, meant that Mr. Bush would have to yield some ground if he wanted to push through a deficit-reduction package. Although many Republicans still dispute the point, others believe he had no choice but to abandon his cherished "no-new-taxes" pledge.
 
Bush's Unruly Troops
 But tactical ineptitude has meant he had to abandon more than that. He fell back from his insistence that there could be no tax increases unless there was a cut in capital gains taxes, then from his insistence upon some other sort of "growth initiatives," then from his bottom line that while he could accept other tax rises, there could be no increase in basic income tax rates.
By this morning, his negotiators were reduced to negotiating not about the substance but about the form of a "soak-the-rich" element in the package. A White House aide commented sourly, "The Democrats have redrawn the battlefield so thoroughly that we couldn't fight for the millionaires any more."
Mr. Bush's job was made much harder by his inability to control the Republicans in the House, who voted against the first package he helped to negotiate and showed little sign today of backing the latest one. Their willingness to defy the President in an election year was greatly increased by the defection of Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, a crucial figure in the Republican leadership in the House, who made it all too clear early on that he, leadership or no leadership, would support no tax increases at all.
Mr. Bush let him get away with it, in a way Lyndon B. Johnson or Richard M. Nixon would never have dreamed of doing. They would have been on the phone themselves, threatening unspeakable sanctions; this time, the White House has said little beyond the mild comment today by his press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, that there would be penalties for the rebels. What kind of penalties? "Can't tell you," he said. "If we told you, it wouldn't be a surprise."
 
Democrats Elated, for Now
 The President's strength on other issues will undoubtedly be affected by his leadership failures on the budget. Today, for instance, he barely mustered a third of the Senate, losing a half-dozen Republicans as he averted an override of his civil-rights veto.
The budget compromise finally became possible because the Democrats, none too early, realized that they had won and had better declare victory. Their mood was nicely caught by Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Suffolk County, who commented, "It's one thing to tax people's pocketbooks, another to tax their patience."
It is a heady moment for the Democratic leadership on Capitol Hill, which has been ridiculed in the last few years for inept tactics of its own. In particular, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, have enhanced their reputations.
But the partisan tides will ebb and flow often between now and Mr. Bush's re-election campaign in 1992. What happens in the Persian Gulf and what happens to the economy as a whole will probably have more to do with his prospects than what has happened in Washington this summer and early fall; indeed, some Republican members of Congress suspect that he purposely has invited opprobrium now to get the budget fracas behind him and give the economy every possible chance to rebound by 1992, putting his own re-election interests ahead of theirs.
Still, it seems unlikely that Mr. Bush will ever recover the aura of omnicompetence that he had for his first 18 months in office -- one of the longest Presidential honeymoons on record. And it seems equally unlikely that the American public will quickly regain faith in the competence of their government and its leaders.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 10.15; High-Tech Stocks Strong

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stock prices were mixed yesterday, although a sharp rise in profits at Compaq Computer, a high-tech favorite, gave several technology stocks a lift.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 10.15 points, to 2,504.21, while the broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose just 0.24 point, to 312.60. 
 The disparity suggests that traders and investors, still wary of third-quarter earnings reports, were concentrating on the blue chips and on a few other stocks likely to weather a market selloff.
Compaq jumped 4 1/8, to 47 1/2; Honeywell 4 1/4, to 83 3/4; I.B.M. 1 7/8, to 108 5/8; Digital Equipment 1, to 51 3/4, and NCR 1 5/8, to 51 1/4.
Program trading was heavy but moved the market ahead less than a point, Birinyi Associates said.
In the wake of a big drop in durable goods orders in September, sentiment grew that inflationary pressures were weakening and could mean that short-term interest rates would be coming down soon.
Of course, nothing is likely to happen on interest rates until some kind of budget package is adopted. But while traders long ago gave up trying to guess when that would happen, "we know it'll happen one of these days," one trader remarked.
That sentiment helped lift the Dow a bit but gave little help to the rest of the market.
While several market technicians are beginning to talk of the market touching bottom soon and then starting to build for an upturn, many still saw yesterday's rise as just another rally in a bear market.
 
 Volume Rises to 149.3 Million
 Volume rose to a relatively slow 149.3 million shares, from an even slower 146.3 million on Tuesday. Advances barely outnumbered declines, 762 to 728, and 10 stocks reached new highs while 95 fell to new lows.
With investors watching bank stocks closely in the wake of weak earnings, mounting real estate difficulties and big job cutbacks, Chase Manhattan and Citicorp, two leading money center banks, topped the Big Board's list of the 10-most-active stocks.
Hibernia, the Louisiana and Texas banking company, was the sixth-most- active stock. Among the three stocks, nearly 13 million shares changed hands.
Chase fell 3/8, to 11 7/8, on 5.7 million shares. Citicorp fell 3/4, to 11 7/8, on 5.3 million. Although Hibernia recently trimmed its dividend to 60 cents a year from $1, its stock rose 3/8, to 7 1/8, on 1.7 million shares. Traders said a brokerage firm, possibly Japanese, had bought two big blocks to get the dividend and would probably resell the stock.
Although oil prices ended the day ahead $1.71, to $31.08, analysts said traders had anticipated the increase along with continuing delays on the budget, both of which have been big factors in the market.
More important yesterday, traders said, was that durable goods orders continued to drop, reinforcing Wall Street feelings that the economy is now in a recession.
A recession would bring lower interest rates, a rise in bond prices and a better stock market.
"That's why the selling dried up and buyers are nibbling," one trader said.
In other moves, General Electric, the third-most-active Big Board stock, fell 2 1/8, to 51 7/8, in what appeared to be continued reaction to an article in Barron's on Monday saying it could be vulnerable because of its huge real estate portfolio. G.E. called the article misleading and said it expected double-digit per share growth this year.
On the Amex, Continental Airlines Holdings plunged 1 5/8, to 4, in heavy trading after S.& P. cut its debt ratings because of higher fuel prices and a heavy debt schedule. Reports had also circulated that the company had considered, but rejected, a bankruptcy filing. It was the day's most active stock, on 904,000 shares.
 
NIKKEI INDEX RISES
TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 25 (Reuters) -- Stocks in Tokyo were higher at midday today, helped by a stronger yen. At the end of the morning session, the 225-share Nikkei index was up 319.87, or 1.3 percent, to 25,196.75.
