HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Post Small Gain

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved slightly higher and interest rates dipped in light trading yesterday, as dealers bought some securities on signs that agreement on the Federal budget was imminent.
The generally positive news on the budget outweighed a rise in oil prices. 
 "It was a mirror image of Tuesday," said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. "The news on the Middle East and the budget has been contradictory on an almost daily basis, and that has sort of frozen investors and the dealer community. People just don't know what is going to happen."
On Tuesday dealers sold securities when it appeared Congress had reached another intractable impasse over the budget.
It was unclear late yesterday whether Congress would approve yet another stop-gap increase in the Federal debt ceiling that would allow the Government to continue its operations. Unless it does so, the Government will be shut down today.
Failure to raise the debt ceiling yesterday forced the Treasury to postpone an auction of $12 billion worth of new two-year notes. Traders were struggling to compose a strategy to use once the new budget is passed and a flood of new Treasury issues hits the market.
"People are grappling with what to do once a budget gets passed," said James R. Capra, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Goverment Securities.
"Because of the on-coming supply, the consensus says sell. But I'm not sure that's the right thing to do, because it is virtually certain the Fed will ease policy after the budget gets passed."
In that regard, Robert Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, commented yesterday that any significant move by the Fed to reduce short-term interest rates would probably cause long-term bond rates to rise. Mr. Capra and other market participants interpreted those remarks to mean that the Fed is not likely to move the overnight Federal funds rate down by more than 25 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, once a budget agreement is signed.
Mr. Parry was speaking to a business group in Stockton, Calif.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds were offered in late trading at a price of 99 3/4, up 5/32, to yield 8.77 percent, compared with 8.79 percent late Tuesday.
Among note issues, the 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 25/ 32, up 5/32, to yield 8.62 percent. And the 8 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 18/32, up 1/32, to yield 7.80 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were unchanged to down slightly. Traders said bills might have been helped by yesterday's auction of Citicorp 49-day money market preferred stock, where yields skyrocketed to 12.50 percent.
"There could well have been a flight to quality into bills as a result of the Citicorp sale," Mr. Sullivan said.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.21 percent, unchanged on the day. Six-month bill rates dipped by one basis point, to a late offered rate of 7.16 percent. And one-year bill rates slipped by two basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.02 percent.
In the corporate bond market, Merrill Lynch Capital Markets acted as lead manager for two offerings of asset-backed securities.
In its first asset-backed deal ever, First Interstate Bancorp offered $623 million worth of securities backed by retail auto loans.
The 9 percent securities were priced at $99.687, to yield 9.14 percent, 1.30 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent two-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation, based on a surety bond issued by the Capital Markets Assurance Corporation.
In addition, a subsidiary of the Chrysler Financial Corporation priced a $500 million offering of floating rate securities backed by auto loan receipts.
The securities have a final maturity of April 10, 1996. Interest rates were set at 17.5 basis points, above the 30-day commercial paper rate. The initial rate for the securities will be set tomorrow.
The securities are rated AAA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
Also in the corporate bond market, Dow Chemical B.V. offered $150 million of three-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Lehman Brothers.
The 8 3/4 percent notes, which mature Nov. 1, 1993, were priced at $100, or par, 77 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent three-year notes at the time of pricing.
The issue, which is noncallable for life, is rated A-1 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, the Texas Public Finance Authority sold $138 million worth of serial bonds at competitive bid.
A group led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets won the bonds, which range in maturity from 1991 to 2010. The securities were priced to yield 5.80 percent in 1991, 6.30 percent in 1995, 6.80 percent in 2000 and 7.30 percent in 2010.
The issue is rated AA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said prices of most issues had risen by about 3/8 of a point.
In the secondary tax-exempt municipal bond market, prices of most widely quoted issues moved higher by about 1/8 of a point, market participants said.

HEADLINE: Skills-Training Policy Opening Doors to Jobs

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., Oct. 17

 BODY:
For the last eight years researchers have clocked and gauged the experiences of several thousand single mothers here and in three other cities, trying to answer one of the most elusive questions in social policy: how to turn welfare recipients into workers.
As a result they are praising the approach of a San Jose program that stresses tangible job skills, rather than the popular back-to-basics regimen of remedial English and mathematics. No matter how well the women here are able to read or compute, they quickly get their hands on circuit boards, printing presses, typewriters and frying pans. 
 This approach is markedly different from the one that most states are using to carry out the Federal welfare-to-work law that took effect this month.
Early reports show most states are emphasizing basic education. The backers of the experiment here say the basic-education approach may prove less productive and undermine the efforts at welfare reform.
 
Praise for the Approach
 "There's something that's so motivating about thinking you are going to be in the real world, doing a real job, earning a real wage," said Phoebe Cottingham, an associate director at the Rockefeller Foundation, which paid for the $12 million study. "That, to an adult, is so much more important than going back to a situation where you've failed before: sitting in a classroom."
Ms. Cottingham said the San Jose program in some ways recalled the vocational training in vogue decades ago, before the rise of the basic-education movement. But the program eliminates aptitude tests, she said, and offers counseling, child care and other supportive services that help disadvantaged adults adapt to the workplace.
Three of the four cities' programs supported by the Rockefeller Foundation stressed the basic skills, but made no difference in the women's lives, according to an independent evaluation. Those programs were run by private organizations in Atlanta, Providence, R.I., and Washington. The single mothers there who received the training were no more likely to be employed, or to see their earnings rise, than a control group of similar women who did not join the program.
By contrast, women at the Center for Employment Training in San Jose were 27 percent more likely to have jobs a year later than those in a similar group who received no training. And their earnings were 47 percent higher.
The women in all four programs were members of minorities, and all had young children.
The San Jose gains are much larger than those reported from welfare-to-work tests in the early 1980's that were hailed as successes and were used to garner support for the training requirements in the law passed by Congress in 1988 to overhaul welfare.
 
Wide Latitude for States
 That law, now being carried out, requires that by October 1990 each state enroll some welfare recipients in training or education programs. But states have wide latitude over the kind of training or education they provide.
Many experts have called the San Jose results impressive, but caution that they may be difficult to replicate. The program may have benefited, for instance, from being in Silicon Valley, where narrow vocational skills may be more marketable than in other regions with fewer jobs.
The women trained here were disproportionately Hispanic, like Maria Melendez and Marie Guzman, and many had substantial work histories. It is unknown whether the same approach would work as well for women of other ethnic groups or women more accustomed to long-term dependency on welfare benefits.
The researchers acknowledged these factors, but argued that the stress on particular job skills was decisive.
Among the success stories is Francisca Covarrubias, 42 years old, who enrolled three years ago after a separation from her husband forced her and her four daughters onto welfare.
While she had little English and few skills, Ms. Covarrubias, a Mexican immigrant, had much determination. She had received welfare for only two months when she sought the training and she had a work history that included seven years in a laundry.
The San Jose program put her directly in a vocational class -- for sheet metal workers -- despite deficiencies in English and math resulting from a Mexican education ending in the sixth grade. Rather than pursue a full-time study of remedial education, she fit it in for two hours a day, between stints on sheet metal machines.
"If I study English, it takes me two years maybe -- I like to work," she said this week, in a fluency subsequently achieved in night school.
After six months Ms. Covarrubias graduated to a $5.25-an-hour job at Saucedo Metal Products, making parts for computer cabinets. She now earns $9 an hour as head of the stockroom there.
Some welfare experts, particularly liberals, argue that the remedial education is important because the modern economy needs workers who are literate and can adapt to changing technology. But in the Rockefeller study, many women in basic education classes grew discouraged and dropped out before the job training.
 
Difference in the Approach
 Some others have argued that actual work, even at low-paying, unskilled jobs, is preferable since it provides motivation and forces people to come to terms with the reality of the workplace. They say basic education or skills training should come later.
A year after joining the San Jose program, 46 percent of the women had jobs, according to Mathematica Policy Research Inc., a private company that evaluated all four sites. By contrast, the employment rate was only 36 percent for those San Jose women who applied for the program but were assigned at random to a control group and given no training.
The trained women earned an average of $416 a month, as against $283 for the others, or an hourly wage of $6.11, as against $5.39.
Some analysts speculate that stress on vocational education produces higher short-term gains while those given remedial education may thrive more in the long run. But the researchers say early studies show that the pattern persists after 30 months.
The center started in 1967 with a small grant from a church. Now it operates out of a sprawling former junior high school with a budget of $17 million and an alumni list reported at 50,000.
Its courses, which are supported by a variety of Government grants, include carpentry, child care, microelectronics assembly, printing, typing, cooking and shipping and receiving. Russell Tershy, who started the center and still runs it, lists several other keys to its success beyond the immediate immersion in tangible training, which costs about $3,500 per person.
 
Strengths of San Jose Method
 One factor, he said, is the reliance on an industrial advisory board, with representatives from dozens of the valley's top corporations. They keep the program current on what skills are needed and how to teach them. They also form a de facto placement network.
A second strength is the counseling and placement services, and here Ms. Covarrubias's experience is instructive.
Intimidated by the difficulty of running the sheet metal machines, she told her counselor, Ted Gonzales, that she wanted to try something easier. Mr. Gonzales, who has applied his you-can-do-it ethos here for two decades, told her she couldn't give up.
Ms. Covarrubias caught on.
Six months later, Mr. Gonzales donned the hat of the deal maker, inviting a supervisor from the metal products company to the school where he observed Ms. Covarrubias at work.
She was hired the next day.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Costly Citicorp Move To Win Over Investors

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
In another sign of investor concern over the safety of investments in many major banks, Citicorp said yesterday that it would pay an unprecedentedly high rate on an important part of the capital it needs. The move will raise the company's costs substantially.
In agreeing to pay a dividend rate of 12.5 percent on a $100 million issue of preferred stock, the nation's largest banking company accepted a rate that is far higher than the dividend it was legally required to pay. The move was aimed at bolstering investor confidence, but it led to another drop in the company's stock price, to an eight-year low. 
 Concerns over real estate loans that might go bad if the nation enters a substantial recession have raised doubts about the credit quality of many major banks in recent weeks, and the rate action yesterday showed that those qualms have not receded. At the American Bankers Association meeting in Orlando, Fla., bankers said they were aware of a rising sense of unease among investors and depositors. [Page D2.]
 
High Rates Might Spread
 Citicorp has almost a billion dollars of such preferred shares outstanding, and the high rates are likely to spread to other Citicorp issues durng the next two months.
The 12.5 percent rate was set on an issue of "auction rate" preferred stock, and will remain in effect for seven weeks, when a new auction to reset the rate on that stock will be held. Had Citicorp wished to do so, it could have paid only 9.75 percent, but that would have meant that some investors who already owned the security would have been unable to sell it, angering those investors and damaging Citicorp's reputation.
Instead, Citicorp changed the rules of the auction, so that it could have been forced to pay a dividend rate as high as 16.25 percent. The auction produced a rate of 12.5 percent, which was well below the maximum level but still extraordinarily high. Since investments in preferred shares have tax advantages for corporate investors, the 12.5 percent rate is equivalent to a taxable rate of 17 percent.
By contrast, J. P. Morgan & Company, deemed by investors to be the healthiest of the major bank holding companies, auctioned a similar preferred issue yesterday at a rate of 6.069 percent, less than half the rate Citicorp will pay.
A Citicorp official called the 12.5 percent rate "a little high," but said the company would make a similar change in the rules on another preferred stock issue, whose rate is to be reset tomorrow. "We raised the cap to respond to investor concerns and see what would happen," said Nancy Newcomb, a senior corporate officer. "I think it will take some time for the markets to settle down."
The fact that Citicorp paid substantially less than the ceiling it had set was an indication that investors are not totally unwilling to accept the risk of investing in Citicorp. Yesterday's move will help to reassure investors that they will be able to sell such preferred stock at face value at the end of every seven-week period, because the company appears to be able to attract new investors at rates well below the new ceiling.
The Citicorp move was remarkable in that it represented an offer to pay more than it was contractually obligated to pay. It is roughly equivalent to Citibank, the banking subsidiary, telling an owner of a long-term certificate of deposit that the bank would raise the interest rate, out of the goodness of its heart.
If a similar policy is extended to all the company's preferred issues and Citicorp's credit standing continues to deteriotate, the additional annual dividend expense could be about $60 million, based on $950 million of such preferred outstanding. During the next seven weeks, yesterday's auction will cost Citicorp about $365,000 more than it was contractually obligated to pay on the $100 million issue.
Ms. Newcomb said Citicorp would "keep its options open" regarding whether it would make a similar offer on other issues. But the company is expected to do so.
In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, shares of Citicorp fell 75 cents, to $11.875, after trading as low as $11.75, the lowest level for the shares since 1982.
What Citicorp did yesterday was announce plans to raise the maximum dividend rate on $100 million of auction rate preferred stock. Previously, that maximum was 1.2 times the commercial paper rate; the new limit is two times the commercial paper rate. Yesterday's auction resulted in a rate of 1.54 times the effective commercial paper yield of 8.128 percent. By contrast, the Morgan rate was only 0.75 times the commercial paper yield.
Here is how auction rate preferred stock works: The stock itself is perpetual, meaning the issuer has no obligation to redeem it, at any time. But holders are expected to view it as short-term paper, because the interest rate is reset at an auction every 49 days. At that auction, new buyers are supposed to indicate the minimum rate they would accept for the following 49 days, and the rate that is actually set is the lowest one that attracts buyers for all the stock at face value. Current holders have the choice of accepting the new auction rate or of selling out at face value.
That is, they have that option unless the auction fails, in which case the new rate is set at the maximum allowed under the auction rules. In such a case, some or all of the old holders would be unable to sell the paper.
On Monday, a Citicorp auction came very close to failing, as the auction produced a yield of 9.4 percent, or 1.15 times the commercial paper rate then prevailing. The belief in the market is that the auction probably would have failed had not the original underwriters of the issue, Goldman, Sachs & Company, stepped in and bid.
The reason that auction rate preferred stock has a 49-day reset period is to allow corporate holders to gain tax advantages that come only if stock is held for at least 45 days. With those advantages, a corporation pays only a 10.2 percent tax rate on the dividend, far below the 34 percent tax rate on regular corporate income.
Because of the tax aspects, the usual buyers of such securities are corporate treasurers, but in recent weeks they have shied away from the auctions, apparently because of fears about deteriorating credit quality at Citicorp and worries about liquidity if an auction should fail.
Although yesterday's auction was a success in that the Citicorp securities found buyers, the rate of 12.5 percent was above the range of 11 percent to 12 percent that had been cited by traders as the probable rate.
In the stock market, bank shares have been falling since early summer as worries over real estate loans have increased, but Citicorp's preferred stock auctions had gone relatively smoothly, with dividends of about 0.8 times the commercial paper rate until mid-September. But then, as Citicorp halted public auctions of its own commercial paper, and Chase Manhattan suffered the indignity of having to pay 13 percent on a bond issue that had a similar auction procedure, buyers began to back away.
Citicorp was forced to pay dividends that were higher than 0.9 times the commercial paper rate at several auctions from Sept. 19 through Oct. 10. On Oct. 12, the rate moved above the commercial paper rate. Market sources say that at all the auctions since then some of the shares were bought by investment banks that did not wish to see harm done to their customers who had previously bought the shares. In most cases, the investment banks later found other buyers. In addition to Goldman, the original lead underwriters of various issues were Lehman Brothers and Merrill Lynch.

HEADLINE: In Connecticut Race for Governor, the Focus Is Economic

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Oct. 24

 BODY:
In speech after speech the candidates for governor talk about Connecticut's bleeding economy, often to the exclusion of all else.
It is an obsession, they say, that reflects reality: nothing else comes close in importance, especially in the minds of voters, to the question of which man is best equipped to lead during the recession that all three major candidates agree is here or probably soon will be. 
 Economists say balancing the state budget alone will present a herculean task. With companies earning less and peoplespending less, tax revenues have plummeted. This week, legislative analysts projected a shortfall of $1.5 billion over the next 18 months, or about 20 percent of the state's budget of just over $7 billion.
Housing starts continue to fall, down 34 percent in August from the same period a year ago; banks and insurance companies have been hit with stunning losses from real-estate investments, and defense contractors, a major part of the Connecticut economy, have laid off hundreds of workers. Defense industry forecasters see little likelihood of a return to the spending that marked the Reagan years.
A constant refrain from all the candidates is that Connecticut lost its competitive edgein the 1980's as a desirable place for companies to expand or relocate. And all three candidates portray themselves in varying degrees as the answer to the mistakes of the past.
 
'Tomorrow Is Here'
 "The crises that we confront today in the state of Connecticut are that everything was postponed until tomorrow, and tomorrow is here," said former Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a Republican who is running under his own Connecticut Party banner. "I don't know whether the person on the street is prepared for what needs to be done."
Mr. Weicker and his opponents -- Representative Bruce A. Morrison, the Democrat,and Representative John G. Rowland, the Republican -- agreed in a series of interviews with The New York Times that some pain will be necessary next year, in terms of spending cuts or tax increases or perhaps both. But there were sharp disagreements about where the next governor should start and what rays of hope could reasonably be expected.
Economists and business leaders similarly disagree about what the candidates have proposed, though most people who have analyzed the state's budget say whoever is elected will almost certainly have to go beyond what has been said in the campaign, given the depth of the state's problems.
"They're not open, and to tell you the truth, I don't think they know what they'll do," said Jean-Paul Valles, a senior vice president at Pfizer, one of the state's largest employers.
Among the main points of dispute are how best to protect and create jobs in the state, and halt the rising unemployment rate, which hit 5.1 percent in August, up from 3.7 percent in the summer of 1989.
The three candidates are running to succeed William A. O'Neill, the Democratic Governor, who decided not to seek re-election.
 
First Priority
 Mr. Morrison, who has represented New Haven and the Third Congressional District since 1983, said his first priority would be to stimulate the availability of credit and increase local business lending, which he believes has been restricted too harshly by Federal bank regulators called in to supervise the region's troubled banks.
His mechanism would be a partnership between banks and the state, which would guarantee some loans issued by the banks to businesses.
Without credit, he argues, businesses cannot expand and the recession spiral will deepen. He said he would also consider short-term borrowing, through bond sales, to bridge the state's budget gap next year.
Mr. Rowland and Mr. Weicker, by contrast, reject the idea of selling short-term bonds to tide the state over. Mr. Rowland, who has represented Waterbury and the Fifth Congressional District since 1985, said deep cuts in state spending, including renegotiation of all state-labor union contracts, must be the first order of business. He said the only alternative was to raise taxes, which he fears would deepen the recession and drive employers from the state.
Mr. Rowland specifically argues that state employee health benefits, which now pay 100 percent of a worker's medical expenses, are too generous. Reducing the state's portion to 80 percent, he said, would save hundreds of millions of dollars. If the unions refuse the givebacks on health care and other issues, including an extended workweek, thousands could be laid off, he said.
 
Corporate Tax Reduction
 Mr. Weicker, who was defeated for re-election in 1988 by Joseph I. Lieberman after 18 years in the United States Senate, proposes as his "first steps" a reduction in corporate taxes, which are the highest in the nation. He said immediate tax cuts, even if not financially significant, would send the message that the state wants to help employers weather the "economic winter" that he envisions.
All three candidates said they would put into place other mechanisms to ease the burden on businesses during the downturn -- like Mr. Rowland's pledge to businesses that "we'll leave you alone for two years" through a moratorium on new state business regulations -- and all three men said they would vigorously oppose any increase in taxes.
But Mr. Weicker appeared to come closest to saying tax increases of some sort might be required if the situation reached extremes. If the rising price of heating oil threatened poor families with freezing, for example, he said, "the decision is either to do nothing and allow that tragedy to occur or turn to the state and say, 'Here's the situation, will you support me?' "
Both Mr. Morrison and Mr. Rowland said cuts in business taxes, while a long-term goal in both their camps, were impractical for a least a year or perhaps longer. Cutting the rate sooner, as Mr. Weicker has suggested, would balloon the deficit further, they said.
Economists differ on whether Connecticut will be in better or worse shape than the rest of the region over the next few years. The state's economy, for example, has a greater diversity in its employment than much of the rest of New England, with major manufacturing plants existing alongside corporate headquarters and insurance towers. Unemployment, though rising, has still, except for one month earlier this year, been below the national average, as well as below the rate in New York City, which hit 7 percent this summer.
 
Risky Measures
 Many Connecticut residents also believe that new leadership in Hartford will in and of itself be a boost because a new governor could be more likely to take risky measures that just might work.
Then there is the theory that greater gloom could be good.
"One of the better things that might happen for Connecticut is an impending national recession," said Edward J. Deak, a professor of economics at Fairfield University. "If the whole United States economy were in recession, there would be efforts to prop it up by the Federal Government -- no action is going to be taken on just a regional basis."

HEADLINE: Southland In Chapter 11

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: DALLAS, Oct. 24

 BODY:
The Southland Corporation, owner of the 7-Eleven convenience-store chain, filed today for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, clearing the way for a takeover by the Ito-Yokado Company, a Japanese grocery chain, for $430 million in cash.
The filing came after seven fruitless months of trying to lighten Southland's massive debt load, taken on in the $4.9 billion leveraged buyout by its founding Thompson family in 1987. 
The Dallas-based company's drive-up stores will remain open as it tries to win approval from a bankruptcy court for a bankruptcy reorganization plan. In a Chapter 11 filing, a company wins protection from its creditors while it works up a plan to cut its debt.
The sale of 70 percent of Southland's stock to Ito-Yokado, which operates Southland's 7-Eleven stores in Japan, is contingent on completing the reorganization plan by next March 15.
As part of the plan, the company had been trying to get its bondholders to approve trading $1.8 billion in debt for stock and new bonds with lower interest rates.
But despite months of meetings, full-page newspaper advertisements and warnings that bankruptcy could not be avoided, holders of only 80 percent of the company's outstanding debt agreed to a swap, short of the required 95 percent.
Company officials said they believed the Bankruptcy court would approve its restructuring plan because it had secured enough exchange offers from bondholders to satisfy most court requirements.
Southland has asked that a bankruptcy court hearing for the confirmation of the plan be scheduled for Dec. 10. But analysts cautioned that once the court gets involved, the plan could be derailed.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Disney Forecasts Park Plan's Impact

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 24

 BODY:
The Walt Disney Company projected today that a proposed ocean theme park would attract 10 million visitors in its first year and employ 12,400 people. The expected economic impact of a park in Long Beach was detailed in an independent analysis delivered to city and port officials. The Long Beach complex would include at least 3,700 hotel rooms and 250,000 square feet of retail space, the report said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops Amid Pressure On Oil and Budget Fronts

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply yesterday against major foreign currencies after a string of recent gains.
"It was another failure for the dollar in its great struggle to go higher," said Robert White at First Interstate Bank. 
 The dollar bought 1.5055 German marks late in New York, off from 1.5190 late Tuesday. It fell to 126.50 Japanese yen from Tuesday's 128.15 yen.
The dollar came under pressure on several fronts: fresh signs of economic weakness, signs of progress on the budget in Washington and uncertainty in the Persian Gulf.
The belief that a Congressional pact to cut the Federal deficit would soon be reached pushed the dollar lower. A budget pact is expected to lead to lower interest rates, which would tend to make the dollar less attractive to foreign investors.
The Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, has said the Fed will ease its grip on credit if a credible budget pact is reached.
Signs that the economy is weakening also put pressure on the dollar. The Government's report that durable orders tumbled 1.7 percent last month was also seen as increasing the need for lower interest rates.
"You really can't look for any reasons to buy dollars," Mr. White said.
After dropping sharply for several weeks, the dollar began to bounce back last Friday. But the rebound halted early yesterday, as traders began selling dollars, especially against the yen.
The dollar also weakened against the British pound, with the pound rising to $1.9595, from $1.9430 Tuesday.
The dollar fell against the Swiss franc, to 1.2695 from 1.2825, and the French franc, to 5.0400 from 5.0850.
The currency slipped to 1.1685 Canadian dollars, from 1.1720 on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Copper Prices Fall Sharply As Precious Metals Rally

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Copper futures prices fell sharply yesterday, ending a four-day run-up, and precious metals rallied as a bounce in oil prices rekindled worries about the economy.
Copper futures settled 1.4 cents to 3.5 cents lower on New York's Commodity Exchange, with the contract for spot delivery at $1.29 a pound, down 3.2 cents.
The selloff erased more than half of Tuesday's gains, which had been fueled by fears of a tight supply and perceptions that a drop in crude oil prices meant the United States economy might not be heading into a severe recession.
 
 Responds to Signals
 The copper market tends to respond to economic signals because copper is used widely in construction and manufacturing.
But oil prices leaped yesterday on several factors, including a reaffirmation by United States and Saudi Arabian leaders of their position that Iraq must withdraw from Kuwait unconditionally.
Tim Evans, a copper trader with Deak International Inc., said copper's decline also reflected profit taking after a gain of about 9 cents a pound in four days.
Anne Orton, Deak vice president, said Far East demand for precious metals had increased as the dollar declined in value against other major currencies in the last few weeks.
 
 Spot Gold at $373.50
 Gold futures settled $2.10 to $2.30 higher on the Commodity Exchange, with the spot price at $373.50 a troy ounce, up from $371.20 on Tuesday; silver was 0.2 cent to 0.4 cent higher, with October at $4.223 a troy ounce.
Orange juice futures rose sharply in their fourth straight daily advance on the New York Cotton Exchange as the market continued to rebound from a collapse precipitated by an Oct. 11 prediction for a bumper Florida orange crop.
Orange juice rallied despite a prediction from the Florida Department of Citrus that retail prices for orange juice would drop nearly 12 percent in the coming year because of high Florida production and record world supplies.
Frozen concentrated orange juice futures ended 3.25 cents to 4.10 cents higher, with November at $1.19 a pound.
 
 Rumors Lift Grain Price
 Export sales rumors lifted corn and wheat futures on the Chicago Board of Trade but soybean futures fell slightly.
Reports that the Soviet Union has chartered freight vessels were regarded as an indication that Moscow will soon be shopping for grain, said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago.
Wheat futures settled unchanged to 1 3/4 cents higher, with December at $2.64 3/4 a bushel. Corn was 1 1/4 cents to 2 1/2 cents higher with December at $2.33 a bushel. Oats were 1/4 cent lower to 1/4 cent higher, with December at $1.24 1/4 a bushel. Soybeans were unchanged to 3 3/4 cents lower, with November at $6.10 3/4 a bushel.
Cattle futures rose on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, helped by strong cash fundamentals including reports that steers fetched prices as high as $80.50 a hundredweight in western Kansas.

HEADLINE: The Bleak Numbers at Continental

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Even as Continental Airlines appears at last to be overcoming a reputation for bad service, financial problems are catching up with it.
The airline, the nation's fifth largest, built up a large debt in the mid-1980's as its parent company acquired troubled carriers, including People Express, Frontier Airlines and Eastern Airlines. But business was good enough for Continental to carry the burden of high acquisition costs, huge expenses to integrate the carriers, the defection of many travelers exasperated by lost bags and canceled flights, and employees still bitter about the mergers. 
 Now, however, industrywide problems are taking their toll. Fuel prices have more than doubled in the last two months, summer traffic was unusually slow and the parent company, Continental Airlines Holdings, was forced to pay $80.5 million last month as part of a settlement on liability for Eastern's pension plan.
Suddenly, the airline's $2.2 billion debt looms larger; it is about twice that of each of the three largest United States carriers, American, United and Delta, which are as much as twice Continental's size.
Among the alternatives the airline has considered was to file for protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code. But at a meeting on Monday, the board of the parent company rejected a bankruptcy filing. Hollis Harris, the president and chief executive of Continental Airlines Holdings, said yesterday that the board had unanimously rejected a bankruptcy filing and was now committed to exploring ways to cover additional expenses. In the short term, he said, Continental may borrow against aircraft orders; later, it may sell assets, like international routes.
Continental's worsening financial numbers stand in contrast to its improving figures for service. The complaint rate as compiled by the Department of Transportation has fallen from 38.6 per 100,000 customers in August 1987 to 9.74 in 1988, to 3.14 in 1989 and to 1.71 last August. In one category, baggage handling, Continental had the second-lowest complaint rate in August; it ranked sixth in August 1988.
Chris Witkowski, the director of the Aviation Consumer Action Project, a Washington group that deals with complaints and issues of airline passengers, said that a few years ago Continental had the highest complaint rate but that it has dropped noticeably.
With such progress, Continental has in the last year or two won back a growing number of business passengers, having earlier attracted pleasure travelers through low fares. Among those business travelers is William S. Holland, who is in charge of international sales at Telesystems Source, a communications company in New Jersey. Until a year ago, he said, he tried to avoid Continental whenever possible. Now, said Mr. Holland, who travels about 100 days a year, he seeks out the airline.
"They have the best on-time record for my flights," he said. The service on board, he added, is now comparable to that of such carriers as United and American.
 
 The Food Wins Praise
 David Iby, another businessman who was picking up his bags at Newark International Airport, said he had also begun to take Continental whenever possible. "The girl was nice," he said, referring to the flight attendant in first class on his flight from Fort Lauderdale, Fla. "The food was excellent, the flight was on time." Several other business travelers, who asked that their names not be used, also praised the carrier's service.
Continental's strategy of growth through the acquisition of ailing airlines was the work of Frank Lorenzo, who stepped down as chairman in August and sold his stock to Scandinavian Airlines System. Mr. Lorenzo won bankruptcy-court protection for the airline in 1982 and brought it out as a mostly nonunion carrier with lower operating costs.
The acquisitions have provided Continental with assets that have enabled it to remain in the race with the major carriers.
The acquisition of Eastern gave Continental access to a computer reservation system called System One. Continental's parent company, formerly the Texas Air Corporation, recently agreed to sell System One to Electronic Data Systems for $250 million; Eastern's unions are contesting the deal.
The acquisition of People Express gave Continental a major hub at Newark.
 
 A Link With S.A.S.
 The airline has linked up with S.A.S., which now owns 16.8 percent of the parent company. The link has borne results. Continental now brings connecting passengers to S.A.S. flights that leave from Newark's Terminal C.
Since the link with S.A.S., many of Continental's employees have attended the Swedish carrier's Quality Service Institute for two days of seminars and training on serving the traveler.
But Continental's growth has come at a price. The airline's annual interest cost is about $475 million while that of American, which is twice the size of Continental by revenue, is about $300 million.
It does not help Continental that much of its debt stems from acquisitions of other carriers; by contrast, American's debt is mostly for the purchase of new planes that are more fuel-efficient and can expand the carrier's service.
Mr. Harris would not disclose the airline's cash position yesterday, but said the carrier would have enough money to keep operating.
He said the cost of fuel for Continental was $80 million more than expected this month and had become a larger operating expense than labor. If fuel prices continue at present levels, he said, the airline would consider selling assets like some international routes.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 31, 1990, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article and a table in Business Day on Thursday about Continental Airlines misstated the estimated interest cost this year for ContinentalHoldings Inc., the airline's parent. It is $300 million, not $475 million.

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Stay Strong, Up 10.9%

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Sales of domestic vehicles rose 10.9 percent in mid-October, in sharp contrast with other indicators that point to a softening economy.
Several analysts said they continued to be puzzled by the relatively strong sales of vehicles since August, particularly when the economy appeared to be slowing down, based on economic indicators like declining disposable income and a sharp drop in housing starts. 
 On a seasonally adjusted basis, cars sold at an annual rate of 7.2 million, well ahead of the 6.1 million rate recorded in the period last year, and slightly ahead of the 7 million trend for 1990 to date.
Ten manufacturers sold 183,316 cars between Oct. 11 and 20, up 15.4 percent from 158,863 last year. Auto makers sold 98,633 light trucks, including mini-vans and four-wheel-drive vehicles, a gain of 4.3 percent over last year's sales of 94,543. The figures exclude sales of imported cars and trucks, which are reported at the end of each month.
 
 Slump Did Not Materialize
 When the Persian Gulf crisis caused a run-up in gasoline prices and hastened a decline in consumer confidence, many analysts expected sales of cars and light trucks to deteriorate.
Instead, demand for new vehicles has remained fairly robust since mid-August. Vehicle sales have been helped by cash rebates and favorable financing, fleet sales and relatively modest price increases on 1991 models. Many people who bought vehicles in 1985 and 1986, when sales were strong, are in the market to replace their cars and light trucks.
But analysts said none of those factors fully explained the current strength.
"We don't know what is keeping the market up," said Harvey Heinbach, an analyst with Merrill Lynch & Company in New York. "It goes against every indicator we are looking at."
Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber Inc. in New York, said he believed the soft economy would eventually cause auto sales to turn down. "We've seen a major deterioration in consumer confidence, and job formation has ground to a halt," Mr. Harris said. "But spending does not respond simultaneously to these factors. Historically, when these economic fundamentals go down, the demand for autos weakens. There's no reason that won't happen this time around."
 
Big Three Share Erodes
 The Big Three domestic auto makers continued to lose market share to Japanese auto makers with factories in the United States. The share of the car market claimed by the Big Three in mid-October fell to 84.7 percent from 87.7 percent last year.
The General Motors Corporation sold 80,571 cars, a gain of 15.1 percent from last year. G.M.'s light-truck sales rose 7.5 percent, to 40,691 units. Among G.M.'s divisions, Oldsmobile and Buick both posted sizable sales gains over last year, an increase that analysts attributed to new models and aggressive customer rebates offered on many 1990 and 1991 model cars and trucks.
The Ford Motor Company sold 51,357 cars in mid-October, up 9.3 percent from last year. Ford's light-truck sales increased 11.4 percent, to 34,707 units, carried by strong sales of its Explorer four-wheel-drive vehicle and Aerostar van.
 
Ford Cut Rebates
 Ford cut customer cash rebates to an average of $500 a model on Oct 1. Many Ford dealers complained that the move hurt showroom traffic and sales, and Ford subsequently offered dealer cash incentives on many cars and trucks. "There is still a large incentive for dealers to spur their sales by returning cash to customers," said Bill Carroll, a Ford spokesman.
Aggressive rebates lifted the Chrysler Corporation's car sales 5.6 percent over last year's levels, to 23,581 cars. But Chrysler's light-truck sales plunged 18.7 percent, to 18,631 units.
Chrysler said sales in its light-truck category were hurt by the changeover to new mini-van models, which caused the supply of Chrysler minivans to dwindle while factories shut down for retooling. Chrysler has also suffered a sharp drop in Jeep sales. Sales of Jeep's flagship Cherokee model are down 21 percent this yer, while sales of Ford's Explorer are 52 percent ahead of the Bronco II, the model that the Explorer replaced.
The Honda Motor Company sold 12,037 cars made at its factory in Marysville, Ohio, an increase of 44.1 percent over last year. The Toyota Motor Corporation increased sales of cars made in its Georgetown, Ky., plant by 47.3 percent, to 9,213 cars.

HEADLINE: Profit Slips 2.6% at Du Pont

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 24

 BODY:
E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company today reported a 2.6 percent drop in its third-quarter earnings, with increases in its petroleum operations offset by slower growth in the company's chemicals businesses.
The company reported net income of $533 million in the quarter, down from $547 million a year earlier. Earnings per share were flat at 79 cents and reflected the lower number of shares this year because of a stock-buyback program.
Revenues for the quarter were up 15.6 percent, at $9.93 billion, compared with $8.59 billion in 1989.
"Third-quarter results reflect strong performance from our petroleum operations," Du Pont's chairman, Edgar S. Woolard Jr., said. "At the same time, earnings in several of our chemical businesses continued to be adversely affected by the slowdown in the U.S. economy."
Du Pont said the improvement in petroleum earnings was partly a result of higher oil prices, which soared after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. The company said 70 percent of the overall improvement was a result of operations overseas, where there was a strong demand for petroleum products and greater efficiency at the company's refineries.
Du Pont also said its quarterly results included gains of 8 cents a share from the sale of an interest in a North Sea oil property and an instrument systems business.
The company's shares were unchanged today at $34.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Ford's Credit Rating Drops a Notch

 BODY:
Moody's Investors Service yesterday lowered by a notch the long-term rating on about $45 billion in securities issued by the Ford Motor Company, the Ford Motor Credit Company and subsidiaries.
The change leaves the car maker's rating at a high investment grade, but still serves as a signal that Moody's is concerned about the weakness in auto operations, the company's large capital requirements and the sizable acquisition debt that Ford accumulated during the year. 
In the last year Ford acquired the Associates Corporation of America for about $3.5 billion and Jaguar P.L.C. for about $2.5 billion. Moody's had placed Ford under review with negative implications on Sept. 18.
Moody's said the deterioratiing economic outlook in North America and the continuation of buyerincentive programs in the United States, expectations of continued soft demand in several European markets and the effect of volatile fuel prices heightened uncertainties about Ford.
Moody's said it had lowered the senior debt rating of the Ford Motor Company, the Ford Motor Credit Company, Ford Holdings Inc., Ford Capital B.V. and Ford Credit Funding P.L.C. to Aa-3, from Aa-2.
Analysts at Moody's said they do not have the General Motors Corporation or the Chrysler Corporation under review. The last rating change on Chrysler debt was in June, when it was downgraded to Baa-3, from Baa-2.
The Standard & Poor's Corporation said it does not have Ford under review. It lowered the auto maker's unsecured debt to AA-, from AA, in June.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money-Fund Yields Mixed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday.
Analysts at Donoghue's said investors appeared to be unwilling to invest until a Federal budget was wrapped up. Then, they said, investors will likely wait for some interest-rate direction from the Federal Reserve in the form of some action on short-term rates. 
 Managers of tax-exempt money market funds said the average number of days that securities are held in portfolios remained at 56, where it has hovered for the last month.
Assets declined by $31 million, to total $82.7 billion, as the average seven-day tax-exempt compounded yield dropped 7 basis points, to 5.48 percent. The decline in yields is the result of a number of factors, analysts said, but mostly it is short-term rates have been softening, aided by a general relaxation of tension in the fixed-income market, by lower oil prices and by less negative news from the Middle East. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The 30-day compounded average yield slipped 3 basis points, to 5.66 percent. The equivalent taxable seven-day compounded yield is 7.61 percent for investors in a 28 percent tax bracket, and 8.44 percent for investors in the 33 percent bracket.
Among tax-exempt funds with assets of better than $100 million that are monitored by IBC/Donoghue's, the Calvert Tax Free Reserve California portfolio fund produced the best return for the week, with a compounded average yield of 6.20 percent. The fund is distributed by the Calvert Group, Washington, D.C.
Elsewhere, assets of taxable funds rose by $802 million, to $407.7 billion, with institutional funds off by $2 million, to $87.9 billion, and consumer funds up by $804 million, to $319.8 billion. Analysts said that virtually all the gains in the taxable categories were in Treasury funds, where investors sought the soundness and stability of Government securities over the uneasiness of financial sector.
The average days to maturity of securities held in managers' portfolios rose one day, to 46.
Donoghue's said the seven-day compounded average yield for a taxable money market fund rose 2 basis points, to 7.73 percent, while the 30-day average yield is unchanged at 7.74 percent.
Of the general-purpose money market funds with assets of more than $100 million, The Alger Money Market Portfolio had the best return for the second consecutive week, with a yield of 8.56 percent, up 3 basis points. The fund is managed by Fred Alger & Company, Jersey City.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Times Mirror Net Off 40.2%; Knight-Ridder Slides 3.2%

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The Times Mirror Company said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings dropped 40.2 percent from a year before, while Knight-Ridder Inc. reported its profit for the period slipped 3.2 percent from 1989 results, which included a one-time gain.
Times Mirror cited falling classified and retail advertising at The Los Angeles Times as well as at its newspapers in the economically troubled Northeast. 
 Knight-Ridder said that its newspaper operations were softer than expected and that newspaper ad revenue had worsened steadily. The company said its earnings from continuing operations were up from last year, excluding one-time gains on asset sales in 1989.
Following are details of the companies' results:
 
Times Mirror
Times Mirror, which is based in Los Angeles, earned $41.9 million, or 33 cents a share, on revenue of $895 million for the three months. That compared with $70.1 million, or 54 cents a share, a year earlier.
Revenue for the quarter rose 2.4 percent, to $895 million, from $873.9 million in last year's third quarter.
In addition to the ad decline at The Los Angeles Times and the continuing softness of advertising at newspapers in the Northeast, the newspaper publishing division had higher newsprint costs, said Times Mirror's chief executive, Robert F. Erburu.
"Our non-advertising-dependent businesses, led by our professional publishing operations, turned in solid third-quarter performances and should achieve revenue and earnings growth through the remainder of the year," Mr. Erburu said.
 
Knight-Ridder
Knight-Ridder, which is based in Miami, earned $36.6 million, or 73 cents a share, in the three months, compared with $37.8 million, or 72 cents a share, a year earlier. Earnings per share were up because there were fewer outstanding.
Revenue rose 5.5 percent, to $570.5 million, from $541 million a year earlier.
The 1989 results included a $4.2 million gain from the sale of television stations. Earnings from continuing operations this year were up 7.7 percent if that gain is excluded from the comparison.
Operating profit in the newspaper division was up 5 percent, to $82.4 million, while the business information services division had an operating profit of $3.9 million compared with $2.5 million a year earlier.

HEADLINE: 'Great Books' Takes In Moderns and Women

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Almost 40 years after the "Great Books of the Western World" was published to wide critical acclaim, the collection of many of the seminal works of almost 3,000 years of Western civilization has been given an editorial facelift. Homer, Shakespeare, Plato and John Stuart Mill are still represented, but for the first time they will share the grandeur with 20th-century writers. And for the first time, women will be included. The 60 volumes that make up the revised "Great Books," published by the Encyclopaedia Britannica , is to be introduced this morning at the Library of Congress. Later today, William F. Buckley Jr. is to lead a panel of scholars in a discussion of the impact of 20th-century authors on Western thought. 
 But with no blacks represented among the 130 authors and only 4 newly chosen women -- Jane Austen, Willa Cather, George Eliot and Virginia Woolf -- the revision seems likely to intensify criticism that any such claims to greatness are expressions of Western cultural bias by and in behalf of white males.
Of the 20th-century authors chosen for the "Great Books," 43 are men, including Albert Einstein, Bertrand Russell, Alfred North Whitehead, William Faulkner, Samuel Beckett, T. S. Eliot, James Joyce, Franz Kafka, F. Scott Fitzgerald, Thomas Mann, George Orwell and Ernest Hemingway.
 
Twain and Nietzsche Added
 The revised "Great Books" also adds 15 notables who were passed over last time, among them Mark Twain, Charles Dickens, Anton Chekhov, Henrik Ibsen, John Calvin, Friedrich Nietzsche, Alexis de Tocqueville and Voltaire.
"It distresses me that the editors couldn't find more women and persons of color to include in this new edition," said Henry Louis Gates Jr., a professor of English literture at Duke University. "Especially after all of the debates over the last few years about the relationship of historically excluded voices to the reshaping of the canon for the 21st century. Obviously, there's still a 'whites only' sign on what precisely constitutes a great thinker."
Professor Gates said he was especially disturbed by the failure to include W. E. B. Du Bois. "He was not only one of the pioneering figures in the creation of American sociology," he said, "but he was arguably the most important African-American intellectual in history."
Mortimer J. Adler, the editor in chief of the "Great Books," agreed that Du Bois was a prominent intellectual. "But his most important book, his autobiography, does not meet all three of the criteria established for inclusion," he said.
Those criteria are that the books be relevant to the contemporary world, be worth re-reading and deal with the great ideas that confront mankind in every age. Those ideas are arranged in 102 categories in 2 volumes titled the "Syntopicon," a word chosen by Dr. Adler meaning a collection of topics. The categories range from angel to world, and include democracy, infinity, life and death, metaphysics, punishment, theology and war and peace.
 
Denies Elitism
 Dr. Adler pointed out that books by Du Bois, James Baldwin, Richard Wright, Alice Walker and other black writers are cited as recommended reading at the end of many chapters in the "Syntopicon." He predicted that blacks will be represented in the "Great Books" themselves in subsequent editions, and women in larger numbers. "But they came very late into the picture," he said. "Before the 19th century, for instance, there were almost no women and black writers."
Dr. Adler also denied that the selection was elitist, but said that it was Eurocentric, reflecting much of the accumulated wisdom of the Western world. "In the 22d or 23d century," he said, "we may get around to publishing the Great Books of the World."
The revised edition drops four people: Henry Fielding and Laurence Sterne, the English writers; Apollonius, the epic poet of Alexandria and Rhodes, and Jean Baptiste Joseph Fourier, the French mathematician and physicist. It also offers newer translations of 57 works by 13 authors, including "The Iliad" and "The Odyssey" by Homer.
Until now, the "Great Books of the Western World" was unchanged since its original publication in 1952. That edition was edited by Dr. Robert Maynard Hutchins, the president of the University of Chicago, with the assistance of Dr. Adler. It consisted of 54 volumes, 74 authors and 443 works.
Reviewing the original edition on the front page of The New York Times Book Review, on Sept. 14, 1952, Gilbert Highet, a professor of Latin at Columbia University, wrote, "Taken all together, they are a noble monument to the power of the human mind." But he said that it was an "arbitrary collection." And as if anticipating present-day criticisms, he wrote, "In times like ours it is plainly impossible for 10 or 12 men, working in one single tradition, to select and to explain all the greatest books of the 3,000-year-old and 10,000-mile-wide West."
 
Editorial Advisers
 That first edition evolved under an advisory board of seven American scholars as well as one consultant each from Canada, England and Australia. The editorial board for the current "Great Books" was Douglas Allanbrook, senior tutor and associate dean of St. John's College, Annapolis, Md.; Jacques Barzun, provost emeritus of Columbia University; Norman Cousins, professor of medicine, University of California at Los Angeles; John Kenneth Galbraith, professor of economics, Harvard University; Heinz R. Pagels, who died in 1988, director of the New York Academy of Sciences, and Lord Quinton, former chairman of the British Library in London. Clifton Fadiman and Philip W. Goetz served as associate editors.
The current 16-member committee of consultants includes Mr. Buckley, Stephen Jay Gould, Daniel Bell and Isaac Asimov, as well as Octavio Paz, the Mexican poet and writer who earlier this month won the Nobel Prize in Literature, along with scholars from England, Australia, Canada, France and Japan. Among the consultants is a woman, Dame Leonie Kramer, professor of Australian literature, University of Sydney, and an African, Prof. Alexander A. Kwapong, a Ghanian who teaches international development at Dalhousie University, Halifax, Nova Scotia.
The books, sold only in sets, cost about $1,400 in their least expensive binding. Like the Encyclopaedia Britannica, they are sold by subscription and will also be sold by Britannica representatives in many supermarkets and in about 120 stores of the Waldenbooks chain.

HEADLINE: Give Tax Incentives to Hire the Unemployed

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Figures released by the Bureau of Labor Statistics through August 1990 show 1.842 million white-collar workers unemployed, an increase of 364,000 in 12 months. With an average wait between jobs of 7 months, the prospect for most of an early return to employment is not good.
These figures show a large continuing waste of the country's trained intellectual talent. Much of this talent has been fine-tuned over the years to meet the needs of a particular corporate situation. This specialization makes job changing at the same level of skill difficult.
The obvious reason for the slow return to employment is an economy in the doldrums, without clear movement toward growth. The deeper reasons for prolonged unemployment are important to grasp, if the United States is to set its course toward full employment of both white-collar and blue-collar workers.
To be kept in mind are implications of the familiar truism in economics that corporations are governed by short-run self-interest. With a slump in sales, streamlined operations from mergers or improved technology, corporations cut their employment to make as much profit as they can. They are unmoved by the problem of those pushed into prolonged unemployment or by the economic principle that such cuts bleed the purchasing power that generates full employment and prosperity.
Why should corporations share economic opportunity with those out of work unless it is profitable to do so? Somehow, in the decade of the 1990's, we must develop a strategy for using our full work potential within the framework of self-interest.
What started pulling the economy out of the Great Depression was sharing enough money with the jobless through unemployment compensation and made-work projects for consumer spending to rise, and thatbrought the jobless back to their regular work. Then World War II generated full employment.
Giveaways or wars are costly ways of getting out of a recession. The same result can be gained by providing immediate incentives for each corporation to hire those out of work and qualified to work. Such employer incentives are easily understood and readily enacted as part of tax laws.
(1) The incentive can take the form of giving the employer credit against the tax for unemployment insurance for each unemployed person hired.
(2) Or, as a stronger incentive, let the employer receive a tax-credit amounting to 10 percent or 20 percent of salaries paid to the unemployed people they hire. This credit can be provided as a deduction allowed from the tax on corporation profits during the first year of fresh employment.
The costs of such incentives are not much more than the costs of prolonged unemployment, not to mention the human price paid by families thus unjustly devastated.
In the tax-offset proposal, instead of money handed out to those who are idle, people are paid for productive work, increasing the security and prosperity of others. What is paid out in increased payrolls generates increased purchasing power and comes back to producers in a rising spiral of corporate profits and higher incomes for people generally. With a happy, industrious and creative work force, the United States can meet and excel business competition elsewhere on the globe.
 
PURNELL BENSON
Madison, N.J., Oct. 10, 1990
 
The writer is professor emeritus of management at Rutgers Graduate School.

HEADLINE: Coleman's Agent Reports Accord With Nets

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 24

 BODY:
The Nets and Derrick Coleman have agreed in principle to a five-year, $15 million contract that will make Coleman the highest-paid rookie in the history of the National Basketball Association, Coleman's agent said tonight.
 Harold MacDonald, Coleman's agent, said that the two sides would make the contract language final on Thursday, and added that his client must also pass a physical examination. 
 "It's done," he said. "It's business and it's not fun, but it's done."
Willis Reed, a Nets senior vice president, said tonight when reached at home: "I'm not going to say 'yea' or 'nay' until it's done. We can't comment on that."
The agent said the first four years of the proposed contract were guaranteed and the Nets had an option for the fifth year. He said Coleman could wind up making as much as $16 million with incentives for benchmarks such as being voted the league's rookie of the year and his totals for blocked shots and rebounds.
"We have basically come to an agreement in terms of economics," said MacDonald in a telephone interview from his Bloomfield Hills, Mich., home tonight. "It's just lawyers talking to talking lawyers now. There shouldn't be any sticking points."
Coleman, the No. 1 selection in the college draft this year, missed rookie camp and the first 19 days of training camp while disagreeing with the Nets over his contract. The team was reluctant to pay an unproven rookie $3 million per year, but MacDonald said he and Jerry Cohen, one of the Nets' owners, agreed to the economic terms of the contract this afternoon.
John Mertz, a Nets spokesman, said team officials were wary of making any statement because they thought Coleman had been signed on two other occasions.
MacDonald left no doubt that Coleman would soon be on his way from his home in Detroit to East Rutherford, N.J.
Reed, Cohen and Bob Casciola, another senior vice president, were supposed to attend tonight's exhibition game here with Minnesota. When the executives did not arrive at Knickerbocker Arena, it signified that something was in the air.
Bill Fitch, the Nets' coach, hinted at a possible Coleman signing after a 90-83 victory.
"They're not down here, which means they're working," Fitch said. "I take that as a good sign."
MacDonald said Coleman had an offer from Europe that would have paid him $1 million per season after taxes but that the former Syracuse star was intent on playing in the N.B.A.
"At this point, it's a good contract," MacDonald said. "It gets him his $15 million. and he could get another million with incentives. It's what we've wanted all along."
If the contract details are sorted out by Thursday, Coleman will accompany the Nets to Calgary, Alberta, where they have preseason games against the Los Angeles Lakers on Friday and Saturday nights.
"He's ready to get fitted for a uniform and get on a plane and go to Canada," MacDonald said. "We got him the best deal possible."

HEADLINE: Boat People Lacking in Teachers of English

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A few days ago I visited the Pillar Point camp in Hong Kong, which houses 5,000 Vietnamese boat people who have qualified for resettlement in the West.
It seems probable that the great majority of the Vietnamese living at Pillar Point will almost certainly be resettled in English-speaking countries. Between Jan. 1 and Sept. 1, 4,100 of the 5,100 refugees who left Hong Kong for settlement in the West went to English-speaking countries -- Australia, Canada, Britain, New Zealand and the United States.
The accommodation at Pillar Point is adequate, and many of the refugees have obtained temporary jobs in Hong Kong for wages that are opulent by Vietnamese standards. Unfortunately, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees is facing a severe financial crisis in Hong Kong, and all adult education at the Pillar Point camp has stopped.
Many future readjustment problems could be eased if the Vietnamese refugees at Pillar Point could be given training in English. Many of them are eager to learn, but they have no teachers.
In the past, a number of American organizations concerned with the plight of the Vietnamese boat people have been critical of the way in which the camps in Hong Kong have been run. If these organizations were now to help finance the provision of a few competent teachers of English at Pillar Point, they would be making a constructive gesture that would help smooth the path of many men, women and children who are going to live in America.
The Government of Hong Kong is otherwise heavily committed to providing basic education in its other camps for the Vietnamese boat people.
 
(Sir) PHILIP GOODHART
Member of Parliament
London, Oct. 18, 1990

HEADLINE: After Nearly 2 Years on a Tightrope, Elizabeth Dole Resigns Labor Post

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN

 BODY:
There were not many workplace issues that Labor Secretary Elizabeth H. Dole failed to make a speech about: the rights of women and minorities, pension rights, child labor abuses, worker safety, worker training, the minimum wage. And to proponents of workers, she said most of the right things, too. But little of what Mrs. Dole said before she resigned yesterday as the highest-ranking woman in the Bush Administration brought noteworthy changes in Government policies.
Mrs. Dole, who will become president of the American Red Cross, was caught up in the conflict between being part of a pro-business Republican Administration, on the one hand, and the head of a department that historically has served as an advocate for organized labor. She set a warmer tone toward labor and its Congressional partisans, who saw Mrs. Dole, rightly or not, more as one of themselves than the White House would let her be. 
 The president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, Lane Kirkland, said yesterday that Mrs. Dole "did her best to represent the working people and their unions in a Republican Administration."
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, chairman of the Senate labor committee, praised her for many worthwhile achievements and said, "It cannot have been easy serving as a pro-labor Secretary in an anti-labor Administration."
Mrs. Dole is receiving such salutes even though she resisted organized labor's appeals to intervene in two bitter strikes, at Greyhound and Eastern Airlines. She intervened in just one, the Pittston coal strike in Appalachia last year, and was instrumental in helping to settle it. But she ignored labor's biggest complaint: strikebound management's growing use of substitute workers to replace permanently those who walk out.
 
Rapport With Labor
 Perhaps it is more her manner than her views that accounted for her easy rapport with labor. In dealing with organized labor, she said in an telephone interview today. "There are issues where you have to disagree. But there's a lot of common ground."
William H. Wynn, president of the United Food and Commercial Workers Union, said, "She's the type to sit down with you and give you an opportunity to change her mind."
The issue that Mrs. Dole considers the most important of her 21-month tenure is the quality of the American work force and evidence that American youth have fallen behind Japanese and European youth in skills. This topic is also one that opens her to criticism for more talk than leadership.
Since midway through the Reagan Administration, Cabinet agencies have been studying the issue, and Mrs. Dole has appointed yet another commission. "So far," said Gary Burtless, a labor economist at the Brookings Institution, the research organization, "that issue has not resulted in any concrete or specific policy proposals." But Mrs. Dole said her commission was now about to produce "actionable items and concrete proposals."
Labor leaders and Congressional aides say that Mrs. Dole, despite a low profile, led the Administration in negotiating last year the increase in the hourly minimum wage from $3.35 to $3.80, which took effect in April, and to $4.25, effective next April. But the increase was far less than Democrats and organized labor had sought -- so small, indeed, that few workers have been affected.
Women's groups say that while Mrs. Dole shows a sound grasp of the problems facing them -- the cost of child care, the average gap of 30 percent between women's pay and that of men, a family's cost of having children -- she has taken little initiative to help. Heidi Hartmann, director of the Institute for Women's Policy Research in Washington, said the White House had steadfastly opposed helping out in those areas.
"I sort of think she could have done more," Ms. Hartmann said. "We would have wished she had been more effective in arguing for these policies, but that might have been an awful lot to expect of this Administration."
Where Mrs. Dole could use the administrative powers of her office, she was able to be more responsive, many people said. She moved women, blacks and Hispanic people into the top levels of the Labor Department. An official there said today that more than 60 percent of the department's 200 or so political appointees were women.
Mrs. Dole strengthened enforcement of the child labor laws with four nationwide raids on employers to uncover cases of children's working excessive hours or with dangerous machines, and she increased the fines for violations. She also increased the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's corps of compliance officers, the first additions in nearly a decade, and proposed the biggest fine ever for a company's abuses of safety regulations: more then $7 million against the USX Corporation.
To the praise of women's groups, Mrs. Dole recently started an initiative to use the the civil rights laws and the Government's power to award and withhold contracts to induce businesses to move more women and minorities into the upper reaches of management.
Mrs. Dole declined to say whether the frustrations of getting such initiatives off the ground drove her out. The presidency of the Red Cross, she said, provided an opportunity to make a difference in people's lives. "It's an opportunity that's here, right now," she said. "It won't be here next year."
 
Speculation on Candidacy
 Mrs. Dole and President Bush appeared together yesterday in the White House briefing room, where Mr. Bush announced that he was accepting her resignation "with real deep regret." The President praised Mrs. Dole, saying that as Secretary of Labor, "she's made the workplace safer, healthier and more secure."
After Mrs. Dole thanked Mr. Bush for his "faith and confidence," she was asked if she was now going to run for governor of North Carolina, as has been speculated. "I am on my way to the Red Cross," she said. "I have no plans to run for anything."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Elizabeth H. Dole announced her resignation yesterday as Secretary of Labor. She appeared at a news conference with President Bush. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)
