HEADLINE: Chicago Opera's Chief Has a Mission

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
Last October the Lyric Opera of Chicago shocked the American opera world with a bold announcement. Starting this season -- on Saturday, to be exact -- the company would present a decade-long "celebration" of 20th-century opera, offering 20 major scores from both Europe and the United States, including three commissioned American world premieres.
The program, entitled "Toward the 21st Century," was a shock because for most big American opera companies, dependent on presumably conservative subscribers, innovation beyond tokenism has been very rare. The Houston Grand Opera has a reputation for boldness, but not on this scale. For the most part, it has been left to such compact, festival-like operations as Santa Fe and St. Louis to carry the torch for operatic innovation. 
 None of which daunts Ardis Krainik, who has spent her entire professional life with the Lyric Opera. Its general director since 1980, she is an old-style operatic impresario, meaning that she and no one else makes the final artistic decisions. She has an artistic director, the Italian conductor Bruno Bartoletti. But it is the 61-year-old Miss Krainik at whose desk the buck stops. Such centralized authority compares sharply with the situation at New York's Metropolitan Opera, which aside from its genteel conservatism of policy has had to contend with a muddled administrative structure in recent years.
Miss Krainik's initiative involves both the main company and its adjunct Lyric Opera Center for American Artists. The center has already presented Hugo Weisgall's "Six Characters in Search of an Author," in June, and in the spring will perform a commissioned world premiere of its own by Bright Sheng, the company's composer in residence.
 
Argento Work Is First
 But it is the main-stage activity that naturally commands the greater attention. That gets under way on Saturday evening with a new production of the Minnesota composer Dominick Argento's 1976 opera, "The Voyage of Edgar Allan Poe." The first of the big company's commissioned premieres, William Bolcom's "McTeague," is scheduled for the 1992-3 season.
In person, this innovative impresario hardly seems an avant-garde firebrand, determined to ram 20th-century opera down the unwilling throats of a dwindling band of disgruntled subscribers. She was raised in Manitowoc, Wis., and attended Northwestern University. She also studied singing, to the annoyance of her parents, and signed on as a secretary at the fledgling Lyric Opera in the hope of being allowed to sing. She did sing, in the chorus and in small solo parts, but she soon discovered she had a flair for administration.
By 1975, she had become artistic administrator under the general director, Carol Fox. But in 1980, with Miss Fox ill and the company in financial straits, Miss Krainik almost became the director of the Australian Opera in Sydney. At the last moment -- to hear her tell it, she was poised on the tarmac, Qantas ticket in hand -- the Chicago board pursuaded Miss Fox to retire and offered Miss Krainik the chance to stay at home.
In talking with her, one gets the impression that while the 10 European operas on her docket are important, that her heart is with the American scores.
"I want American opera to reach its zenith," she said, almost as if she were leading a pep-talk at a business seminar. "I think it can blossom in the next 10 years. We have to have our own, unique American opera, not just a hashed-over European art form. I think now is the time, and I want to be behind making it flower."
 
Challenges Audiences
 American opera impresarios, bereft of the government support and innovative tradition that their European counterparts enjoy, typically justify their conservatism by portraying themselves as the humble servants of their audiences.
Miss Krainik will have none of that. She has already offered her audiences challenging novelties, from operas by Alban Berg and Philip Glass to productions by Peter Sellars and, this year, Robert Wilson.
"I don't think of myself as a humble servant," she said. "I want to bring this public along. After 'Satyagraha' and 'Lulu,' they're ready for this program. 'Poe' is a good show; people are going to come as if it were 'Les Miserables.'
"I want my audience to be happy with what I do; I want them to have a good time. That's the only hope for American music -- that audiences will love it. My job as the steward of this company is to present to Chicago audiences the best in this field. If I don't do that, I'm cheating my public. I turn handstands to get the best people here, following the principle that the audience must be served, and that way you serve your art form."
 
Barenboim and Mehta
 Although "Toward the 21st Century" is conceived as a 10-year program, only the first few years have been announced. In addition to "Poe" and "McTeague," Miss Krainik will offer a new production of Samuel Barber's "Antony and Cleopatra." Plans for the European portion of the venture include Prokofiev's "Gambler," Debussy's "Pelleas et Melisande," and a Berg 'Wozzeck' to be conducted by Daniel Barenboim, the music director-designate of the Chicago Symphony, and staged by Patrice Chereau. Miss Krainik calls that one "hands across the Loop." Almost in passing, when she announced this project last fall, she also mentioned that there was to be a new Wagner "Ring" cycle conducted by Zubin Mehta.
Beyond that, however, she has kept her cards close to her vest. That reflects in part a desire to keep her options open. But it also counts as a reality check in a recessionary economic climate.
"Every smart manager has to have a fallback position, and we do," she said. "No matter what happens, we will still have an opera company, and I don't think anything will happen to this initiative, either, because we have it funded already for the first four or five years." That financing includes an unusually large $1 million challenge grant from the National Endowment for the Arts.
With the acclaim her company's success has brought her and with her growing impact in the cultural life of Chicago and the nation (she is the new president of Opera America, the organization of American opera companies), one might think Miss Krainik would betray hints of arrogance. She fights against that, and her weapon is religion. Since 1961, she has been a devout Christian Scientist, and she is eager to tell listeners of her faith.
"In every opera company, there are things over which you have no control," she said. "When a crisis comes along, you listen to your colleagues, but you also listen to that still, small voice. It's leveling. You don't think you're the big cheese, because the big cheese is up there."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ardis Krainik, general director of the Lyric Opera of Chicago. (Steve Kagan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
New Group Makes the Case for Black Agencies and Media

 BODY:
SOME of the biggest black-owned advertising agencies and media companies have formed a trade organization, the African American Marketing and Media Association, hoping to increase advertising to black audiences, alter what it sees as stereotyping and find more work for its members.
The group plans to get in touch with advertisers that it thinks could use black representation on the account and creative sides. 
 "We know instinctively what will offend our audience, because we are our audience," said Ken Smikle, president of the organization and publisher of Target Market News, a national trade publication about black marketing. "What works creatively for whites won't necessarily work for blacks. It's time to say we are the experts and will no longer be ignored."
The members of the Chicago-based organization include New York and Chicago advertising and public relations firms, as well as publishing houses and black radio networks.
Through its research, the organization hopes to encourage advertisers to place more advertising in media intended for black audiences.
"Our media has always been underutilized," said the association's chairman, Clarence O. Smith, president and co-founder of Essence Communications. "There probably is no media more persuasive with its audience than black media."
The group will soon begin substantial research about black consumers that it plans to disseminate widely. "The data on black consumers has been no more than an asterisk," Mr. Smikle said. "You cannot go to a mall and interview a thousand consumers and have the 10 percent who happen to be black reflect accurate information about the group."
Black Americans spend an estimated $63 billion annually.
"The need for this organization was exacerbated by the growing number of so-called experts who have no track record in this area of marketing," Mr. Smikle observed.
He mentioned BBDO, which released a report last year entitled "Black Readers of Consumer Publications" that drew what he thinks were inaccurate conclusions.
"The BBDO study concludes that advertisers can reach black consumers just as effectively with white publications such as Parade as they could with such publications as Ebony," Mr. Smikle said. "As in most studies of the black consumer, their methodology is inadequate. There's no psychographic data that gets to the heart of why black consumers make certain purchasing decisions."
Doug Alligood, vice president of special markets for BBDO, New York, who was in charge of the analysis for the study, denied it undermined the importance of black media. "What we found was that Parade reaches as many black readers as Ebony, but that it wouldn't make economic sense to use just Parade if you want to reach black consumers exclusively," he said. "We freely acknowledge that it was an analysis of numbers only."
Another goal of the new organization is to find ways to combat sterotypical portrayals of blacks in advertising or what some executives at black-owned media companies see as insidious racism in advertising.
"For example, there is a Nike public service anti-drug ad that features basketball player David Robinson," Mr. Smikle said, "in which words like stupid and garbage are used to describe people in the target audience. We would never speak to ourselves like that."
Liz Dolan, a spokeswoman for Nike, denied the ads were patronizing or the language even accidentally inappropriate. "We were trying to be very strong and we wanted the ad to be strong," she said. "The ad is powerful because it's clear how David Robinson personally feels about how dangerous drugs are.
"The ad is addressed to anyone who watches television. None of our ads are targeted at a specific racial group. The appeal of athletes is universal."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Clarence O. Smith is the chairman of the Chicago-based African American Marketing and Media Association. (Essence Communications)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Bell Atlantic Plans Earnings Charge

 BODY:
The Bell Atlantic Corporation said it would take a one-time charge against its fourth-quarter earnings of about $40 million, or 10 cents a share. The charge will reduce the value on Bell Atlantic's books of the company's non-telephone financial services, which include equipment leasing and lending to other companies and real estate projects.
Bell Atlantic, based in Philadelphia, said that the businesses were doing well and had no credit problems but that their market value had fallen. Marion M. Boucher, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., said Bell Atlantic's investments outside the telephone industry now appeared more vulnerable to an economic downturn than many investors had thought. Bell Atlantic's stock fell 87.5 cents yesterday, to $50.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A Budget Accord None Too Soon

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
PRESIDENT BUSH and the leaders of Congress have decided to end the bruising battle of the budget, though some right-wing guerrillas have vowed to take to the woods and go on fighting against any tax increases as long as they can hold out. But the President and Congressional leaders have grown increasingly wary of the anger of voters over the inability to reach agreement on governing the nation's finances. And they are worried about the danger that the protracted political warfare poses for the weakened national economy.
Legislators who vote for this legislation will do so holding their noses for varying reasons. Some will say it raises gasoline taxes too much, others that it raises them too little to improve conservation and reduce dependence on foreign oil. Some dislike the plan because it hits Medicare too hard, others because it does not hit Medicare and other entitlement programs hard enough. And the plan defers the question of how to reorganize the military budget in light of the reduced Soviet threat and new threats like those in the Middle East. 
 Nevertheless, the budget agreement does deal with one of the most serious threats to the American economy: rising uncertainty that the United States has the will to tackle the deficits that have undermined its productivity and growth, hampered its ability to finance its commitments and made it dangerously dependent on foreign capital.
By reducing Government's drain on national savings, this budget plan will curb the upward pressure on interest rates. The Federal Reserve is now in a better position to ease monetary policy and help bring down interest rates. The ability of the Fed to move fast is complicated by the weakness of the dollar, the rise of interest rates abroad and inflationary pressures from higher oil prices. Still, the Fed may wait for the markets' response to the budget agreement before it steps in forcefully to relax monetary policy.
But if the markets do register approval of this move as a decisive step toward fiscal discipline, the ability of American banks and corporations to finance their heavy debts will be markedly enhanced, and interest rates will begin to fall.
The budget agreement, assuming it is voted into law, will eliminate only one of the big uncertainties hanging over the domestic and world economy. Another is the crisis in the Persian Gulf and the oil shock. It is hard to foresee an early return to normalcy that would bring oil back to its pre-invasion average price of $16.40 a barrel. The oil price has become a yo-yo, jerked up and down by rumors of war or a peace that might flow from an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait.
Anxieties are widespread inside the Government that if a deal is made that permits Saddam Husseinto remain the leader of Iraq, he would use the next few years to strengthen his position and his weapons, and would continue to use the oil weapon. But war would be economically costly, too. It would send the price of oil soaring -- to $65 a barrel, according to one World Bank study, and to $100 or more, according to some oil experts, who fear the threat to Saudi oilfields and refineries.
The United States military buildup in Saudi Arabia is intended, in part, to safeguard the world's oil supply at prices that would not wreck the world economy. In addition, Washington could use the Strategic Petroleum Reserve to keep oil prices from going to the sky.
So the United States is still keeping the war option open. Some officials maintain that a war, drawing on overwhelming American military strength, would quickly eliminate the Iraqi threat. The effect on oilfields in the area, they say, would not be long-lived. Nevertheless, the uncertainties about American intentions are likely to keep the oil market nervous and jumpy for months.
Differences with France and Germany over how to handle Iraq together with trade conflicts are straining American relations with Europe. The Uruguay Round of trade negotiations, under the General Agreement on Tarriffs and Trade, is in jeopardy mainly as a result of the European Community's opposition to changing its agricultural policy as well as Japan's resistance to importing rice. If the Europeans and Japanese refuse to move on agriculture, American officials foresee a "bumpy" end to the talks in two months -- and powerful pressures for protectionism in Congress.
A deep recession and mounting unemployment would worsen protectionist pressures and deal a severe blow to world trade. That is why the budget agreement, in clearing the way for lower interest rates, is so crucial as a counter-recessionary force and a measure to build confidence in America, here and around the world.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
Moody's Upgrades Debt of Duquesne

 BODY:
The rating on about $2 billion of debt issued by the Duquesne Light Company, Pittsburgh, was raised yesterday by Moody's Investors Service Inc.
The company's first-mortgage bonds and secured pollution-control securites were increased to Baa-1, from Baa-2.
Moody's cited a strengthening of the company's financial picture and its belief that Duquesne's earnings were likely to remain above the level needed to finance the company's modest construction program and permit steady reductions in outstanding debt.
The rating agency said diversification in the company's service territory should counter the potential effects of a weak economy.

HEADLINE: Plant Sale Aids Whirlpool Net

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BENTON HARBOR, Mich., Oct. 25

 BODY:
The Whirlpool Corporation said today that its third-quarter profits rose 27.6 percent but that the gain resulted from the sale of a Kentucky plant.
For the quarter that ended on Sept. 30, the appliance maker said net income totaled $60 million, or 86 cents a share, up from $47 million, or 68 cents a share, from the comparable period a year ago.
Without the sale of the vacuum cleaner plant in Danville, Ky., profits would have plummeted 21 percent, to $37 million, the company said. The plant is now part of a venture between Whirlpool and the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company.
Revenue in the quarter grew 10.6 percent, to $1.66 billion, from $1.5 billion in the 1989 period.
David R. Whitwam, Whirlpool's chairman and chief executive, attributed the decline in profits to the weakening North American economy, which has softened the demand for appliances. He expects industrywide United States shipments of appliances to be down about 8 percent for the year.
Whirlpool's stock fell 12.5 cents today, to $19.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Auctions

BYLINE: By Rita Reif

 BODY:

Poor Results in Two Sales
 The auction results at Sotheby's and Christie's in New York this week were up one day for jewelry and way down on another day for 19th-century European art. For the first time in years, in fact, dealers described the art sales at the major New York houses as "disasters."
The numbers were indeed grim: the totals realized for the European art auctions at both Sotheby's and Christie's were about half or one-fourth of what these houses had estimated they would be. 
 At Sotheby's, two 19th-century art sales of almost equal value were held on Tuesday, offering European paintings, drawings and sculpture in one and Scandinavian art in the other. These sales were expected to bring, in all, $29.4 million to $39.3 million; the combined total was $7.7 million. Of the two, the Scandinavian sale was more disappointing: 28 works were sold of the 107 offered, for a total of $1.5 million in a sale that was expected to bring $15.2 million to $20.3 million.
Hans Dylens, who heads Sotheby's office in Stockholm, attributed the problems of the sale to the sharp downturn in the Swedish economy in recent weeks. "Inflation has increased 5 percent in recent days," he said. "Wages are up, foreign trade is down."
Christie's auction of 19th-century art on Wednesday offered 356 works estimated by the house to bring $9.5 million to $13.8 million. At the sale, 191 works were sold for a total of $4.9 million.
"A lot of speculative 19th-century pictures have met their maker," said Guy Stair Sainty, a New York dealer. "The speculators have disappeared like the sun goes down at night. This is a great time to buy. Now you no longer have to double the top estimates to buy what you want."
Mr. Sainty questioned the presale estimate of $400,000 to $600,000 on Jean-Leon Gerome's "Marcus Botsaris," a painting in Sotheby's sale that did not sell on Tuesday. "The owner bought it a few months ago in Chicago for $250,000," Mr. Sainty said. "There is obviously a feeling of caution in the market. You can sell great international masters -- Corot and Delacroix. But Gerome is very much a second-rate painter. He has a certain place in 19th-century art, but it is nonsense that a Gerome should be estimated to bring $400,000 to $500,000."
Diana D. Brooks, the president of Sotheby's North America, said one major problem at this sale was that dealers did not support this market. "Right now they do not want to invest in inventory," she said. "They are not going to buy unless they have a buyer for a painting."
What will Sotheby's do about future sales of such art? "They will be much smaller," Mrs. Brooks said. "People aren't going to be as willing to sell in this market."
"Most of the pictures were known to the trade," said Adam Williams, the director of Newhouse Galleries in Manhattan. "They were offering second-rate pictures with ridiculously high estimates. Business is still very good for something that is good. Scandinavian art is, quite frankly, a very small market. There are no real collectors of Scandinavian art outside of Scandinavia, where the whole economy is in appalling condition."
Polly Sartori, who heads 19th-century art sales at Christie's, said she had been disappointed by the auctions -- especially when the Geromes failed to sell: "I don't think the market for 19th-century European art will be volatile in the future. If very good pictures by very good artists are offered, they will do well and find homes."
The good news for the auction houses came in the jewelry sales. At Christie's sale on Tuesday, 298 of the 362 pieces of jewelry offered were sold for a total of $31 million, a record for such a sale at this house. The total was above the estimate of $23 million to $29 million. At Sotheby's, 143 of the 156 jewelry lots offered were sold for a total of $2 million in the first sesssion of a sale that was estimated to bring $1.4 million to $1.8 million.
 
Photos in the Forefront
 Sotheby's and Christie's in New York had their ups and downs last week as well. At the photography auctions held at both houses, high prices were paid for a few images in sales that otherwise did not do well for the auctioneers or consigners. The highest price realized was $126,500, paid at Christie's on Oct. 17 for Man Ray's 1920's Rayograph of a double brush, an image that looks like a ragged bowtie, suspended over a candle. The price, a record at auction for any photograph, was paid by a New York collector and dealer, Michael Senft of the One Bond gallery.
Other works did not command high prices at Christie's auction, in which only 497 of the 769 offerings were sold, for a total of $1.6 million. The house had expected the sale to bring $2.2 million to $3.6 million. Claudia Gropper, who heads photography sales at Christie's, said: "The main problem was there were far too many images presented to the market in a four-day period. It's a clear indication that we have to cut back."
At Sotheby's on Oct. 16, an Alfred Stieglitz portrait of Georgia O'Keeffe was sold for $99,000 to the SoHo dealer Min-Lowinsky Ltd. The price paid was a record for a photograph by Stieglitz. Sotheby's sale otherwise was a disappointment for the auction house. Of the 748 lots offered, only 465 were sold for a total of $2.3 million in a sale that was expected to bring $2.9 million to $4.3 million.
"They shouldn't have had such gigantic sales," said Timothy Baum, a New York photography dealer. "To have 700 and 800 lots is totally unnecessary when you have such a small audience. What good is volume if the percentage of what is sold is so disappointing?"
Beth Gates-Warren, who heads photography sales at Sotheby's, said: "It makes sense to approach the market selectively now. But this was the first sale in which this was the case. Our sales have doubled in size in three years. Until this sale, the material was easily absorbed into the market. I think in the future we have to be more selective, do smaller sales and concentrate on material that is fresh to the market."
 
Kennedy Jottings
 On Flag Day in 1947, John F. Kennedy addressed the Boston chapter of the Jewish War Veterans on "The Flag's Meaning in the Postwar World." His penciled draft of that speech, written on 15 yellow legal-pad pages, is one of the rare offerings in an auction of Americana manuscripts and printed material to be held at 2 P.M. on Tuesday at Sotheby's in New York. The presale estimate is $35,000 to $50,000.

HEADLINE: Staten Islanders Brace for Vote on Secession

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

 BODY:
Waiting in line to drive onto the Staten Island ferry and go home, Gene Redondo drummed his fingers on his steering wheel and offered one indisputable fact about the island's referendum on secession that will take place Nov. 6. "Maybe it won't lead to secession," Mr. Redondo said, "but it will at least excite people to pay more attention to us."
The "us" Mr. Redondo referred to are the nearly 400,000 people of Staten Island who on Election Day will share a cathartic experience all too rare in political life -- a Declaration of Independence that the signers can retract if they later determine that they don't like the terms.
After decades of feeling neglected and exploited, New York City's most isolated borough will for the first time measure how most residents really feel about secession, a move that has been opposed by officials in the rest of the city as long as island residents have dreamed of it.
 
Long March to Freedom?
 But because Staten Island will be obliged to reconsider independence three years down the road, the true weight of marking "yes" on the ballot next month is largely in the eye of the voter.
To some, choosing "yes" would be the first step in a long march toward independence. For others who fear the economic consequences of secession, "yes" would provide a relatively safe means of expressing disdainfor the rest of the city -- a Staten Island version of a Bronx cheer.
Yesterday, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo told a group of Staten Island citizens, "It's very simple: you deserve the right to study and say whether or not you wish to secede." He explained that as Governor, he would not take a position on secession until a charter, approved by Staten Island, was presented to the State Legislature. "Should you?" he asked himself, "I don't know."
Mr. Cuomo, who was speaking at a forum on secession at Wagner College sponsored by The Staten Island Advance, also warned his audience that they should not assume that New York City would freely hand over city prop erty to a newly independent Staten Island. "The city will be furious with you if you secede," he said, "why should they make it easy for you? Why wouldn't they come down on you like an absolute ton of coal and say you can't have anything?"
Staten Island, which refers to itself as the forgotten borough as automatically as Indiana answers to the name the Hoosier State, has long simmered with discontent. Residents complain about problems like tolls, unreliable bus service and the presence of the Fresh Kills landfill, the world's largest outdoor garbage dump.
The island and the city seem to be forever at cross-purposes: City Hall recently enraged Staten Island by trying to block the Navy from building a port for warships there in the belief that some vessels would be nuclear-equipped; currently, Staten Island residents are outraged by the city's plan to build a new jail on the island.
The most popular refrain echoed throughout the island's mainly white, middle-class population, is "Why us?"
 
'Let's Dump the City'
 John McLaughlin, a 25-year-old trading floor reporter for the New York Stock Exchange, called it, "the dumping issue." He said caustically: "Whatever the city doesn't want gets dumped here. I say, let's dump the city."
If, as is widely expected, voters reply affirmatively to the question, "Shall a charter commission to provide for the separation of the Borough of Staten Island be created?" theirs would not necessarily be a binding cry for secession. Many consider the referendum as clearing the way for a serious examination of the merits of independence.
The 13-person commission would have three years to draft a new charter for the City of Staten Island. Three subcommittees would study the impact on finances, education and municipal employment. Even then, if Staten Island were to vote in favor of a new charter, independence would have to be approved by the State Legislature. New York City, moreover, maintains that any legislation putting secession into effect would first have to be approved by the City Council.
"The referendum will only raise false hopes among the people of Staten Island -- secession will not occur," Victor A. Kovner, the city's corporation counsel, said sternly, "That's why it is such an unfortunate misappropriation of public funds." The charter commission's work is expected to cost the state hundreds of thousands of dollars.
The secessionist movement on Staten Island gained noticeable momentum last year when the United States Supreme Court ruled that the city's form of government was unconstitutional because it gave Staten Island, the least populous borough, as much power on the Board of Estimate as Brooklyn, the most populous. Staten Island residents feared changes in the city's charter that would reduce their voice in municipal affairs.
"It's the same as the Revolution in 1776 -- taxation without representation," said Michael Biondo, a sanitation supervisor at the Fresh Kills landfill. Mr. Biondo, 55, who has lived on Staten Island for 25 years, said he thought his tax dollars were being sucked up by the city, instead of improving the quality of life in his borough. "Staten Island is putting a lot of money in the pot, and we're not getting anything back."
Maria Dawson, a 37-year-old hairdresser who works in a salon in the Staten Island Mall, echoed Mr. Biondo's sentiments, but proved less eager to gamble on independence. "Secession would be great, if all our problems could be solved -- but they never will be," she said, "I'll stay undecided until the economics of it are studied further."
 
Cost of Freedom Unclear
 There are no widely accepted assessments of what secession would cost Staten Island -- or the city and state.
Nor are there sure answers to questions about how services, like transportation, or police and firefighting protection, currently provided by the city, would be managed by an independent Staten Island. The charter commission would be responsible seeking some solutions, but the city would not be included in the process.
Some residents say they are sanguine about the cost of freedom. "I would be willing to pay more taxes," said Mr. Redondo, a director of facilities at New York University, "if it would prevent the overflow of city crime and homelessness from washing onto the island."
Even the most ardent secession advocates say they prefer to wait for the charter commission to outline realistic plans before leaping. "I don't even know if secession is a good idea," said Daniel Singletary, a Staten Island painter who created the Secession Party in 1989. "I'm just damn sure we should take a look at it."
Mr. Singletary has seceded from the Secessionist Party -- complaining that his grass-roots organization has been taken over by political candidates -- but he remains an advocate of the referendum. "We are saying that middle-class voters have a right to study the issue for themselves."
Mr. Singletary's assumption that Staten Island could have the final say in its destiny is bitterly disputed by opponents of the referendum. Brendan Sexton, a former city sanitation commissioner, who is now a professor at the Wagner Graduate School of New York University, called the Nov. 6 vote, "an exercise in wishful thinking" that would only lead to disappointment.
"The State Legislature will determine the terms of the separation, and I cannot believe they would be advantageous to Staten Island." he said. "It's like thinking that Flushing could secede and take Shea Stadium with them."
Mr, Biondo was not as cynical. "I look at this vote as a pressure-valve release," he said, "for once, and at last, Staten Island will have its say."

HEADLINE: POP/JAZZ;
Tuning In on College Radio Bands at Clubs Around Town

BYLINE: By KAREN SCHOEMER

 BODY:
The college-radio industry is something like a small town: it's an insular, self-sufficient community with its own trends, rules, economy and morality. Within that community, there are different subgroups of musicians who find different ways of addressing what they feel is their particular audience. This weekend, the College Media Journal Music Marathon, an annual convention focusing on college-radio issues, brings dozens of college-radio bands to clubs throughout New York City. Some of them, like Redd Kross and Bob Mould, are favorites on the scene; others, like the Shams and Blackbird, are still at its fringes.
Redd Kross, a trio from Los Angeles, is perhaps the archetypal college-radio band of 1990. Originally formed as a punk band in 1978 when the McDonald brothers were 11 and 14 years old, Redd Kross now plays Monkees-style pop with a harder post-punk guitar edge. The group's third album and major-label debut, "Third Eye" (Atlantic), is stocked with in-jokes about pop culture that will appeal almost exclusively to people who grew up in the 1970's. 
 The three band members, the brothers Jeffrey and Steven McDonald on guitar and bass, and the guitarist Robert Hecker, have long, straight hair that comes straight from Marcia Brady of the television series "The Brady Bunch." They wear platform shoes, floppy hats and colorful shirts with designs that look like linoleum. The songs on the album are piled with references to 60's and 70's trash culture: "1976" describes "afros and apple pie/Camaro sports cars and gasoline lines," while "Zira (Call Out My Name)" is a love song directed to the heroine of the science-fiction film series "Planet of the Apes."
As silly as they seem, Redd Kross's incessant allusions are not the mindless retro posturing of current English groups like the Soup Dragons; rather, Redd Kross is attempting to make sense of its own cultural condition. To the band, the 70's represents a time of youthful innocence, when children were encouraged to watch "The Brady Bunch" instead of the Learning Channel. It was only in the 80's that such styles and entertainment were reinterpreted as "trash." The jokes and references on "Third Eye" are meant as a bond for those who still feel a connection with the passe, and to exclude those who don't share the experiences. Redd Kross never explains its jokes. "Zira (Call Out My Name)" will be understandable only to those who remember the names of the characters in "Planet of the Apes."
"We didn't want to say 'ape,' " said Jeffrey McDonald in a recent phone interview from Michigan. "We wanted it to seem like a regular love song, but the people that were cool enough would figure it out."
 
Three-Part Harmonies
 If Redd Kross's music is generation-dependent, then the songs of the Shams, a trio from New York City, are perhaps more sex-dependent. The Shams are a kind of post-modern Roches, minus the cabaret stylings; the group consists of three women who sing in delicate three-part harmonies (accompanied by guitar, bass and drums) about the peculiar problems facing the post-adolescent female. Although currently without a label, the Shams have released a single on S.O.L. (Singles Only Label), "3 A.M.," which contains the chorus, "It's only 3 A.M./The baby's waking up again/And I just want to smoke and drink and stay out late with men again."
Other Shams songs, like "File Clerk Blues" and "Texaco," their ode to a gas-station attendant, also combine description and delicate irony with mundane situations, giving them a vindication and realism not often heard in pop music. "I think a lot of people don't write about these things because they don't fit into the perfect fantasy of what a girl should be," the principal songwriter, Amy McMahon Rigby, said in a recent interview. "Either you're free and easy-living, or you're a boring, drab housewife, as though there's nothing in between. These things just aren't as easy for people to think about or hear about."
 
Personal Questions
 The singer and songwriter Bob Mould's second solo album, "Black Sheets of Rain" (Virgin), also touches on some difficult personal issues. Mr. Mould has earned a place in the college-radio pantheon based largely on his work with the Minneapolis punk trio Husker Du, which underwent a traumatic breakup following the release of its 1987 album "Warehouse." Much of Mr. Mould's first solo album, "Workbook," in 1989, was a musical reaction against his previous band, substituting acoustic guitars and cello for Husker Du's brusque, flat guitar noise. "Black Sheets of Rain" is something of a reaction against "Workbook," going back to Husker Du's forceful approach and fitting it into a more straight-ahead rock context.
The songs on "Black Sheets of Rain" use almost exclusively private metaphors. Each is a detailed account of a particular state of emotional turmoil bred by isolation. In "Hanging Tree," the narrator drives around alone trying to regain his balance after a relationship disintegrates; "Stand Guard" recounts a man's attempt to protect the few shreds of truth he has left in his life. In Mr. Mould's universe, the only audience that exists is the self. "Most of the songs are born from frustration," he said in a recent telephone interview from Massachusetts. "Some are just me trying to find out something that's wrong with my life, or somebody else's life that I see going on. The songs are always questions; some have better answers than others."
 
Guitar Noise and Pop Chords
 Like Mr. Mould's work, the albums by the Los Angeles duo Blackbird (the independent label Fundamental has just released a compilation of the two) are reactions to the band members' history. Made up of Chip Kinman on guitar and vocals, his brother Tony Kinman on bass, and a drum machine, Blackbird plays sub-rock -- an epic, enthralling tonic of guitar noise melded into broad pop chord progressions.
Although Blackbird has only existed since 1987, the Kinman brothers have been musically active since the late 70's. They began in a punk-rock band called the Dils, which released three singles before evolving into the country-rock band Rank and File. With its supple melodies and leathery twang, Rank and File's 1982 debut album, "Sundown," was a critical and cult success. But by 1987, record-company disputes, internal disagreements and creative lethargy had sapped the band; all the early promise had come to nothing, and the group broke up.
"We did the last Rank and File tour, and it was basically miserable," said Chip Kinman in a recent telephone interview from Los Angeles. "Tony and I had done van tours since 1977, and we thought to ourselves, 'Why are we playing every empty club in the United States?' We got back home and formed Blackbird. Musically, it was like, 'Let's do something decidedly alternative.' "
Blackbird caters to no particular audience: not the insular college-radio crowd, nor mainstream rock, nor even the underground noise scene. The albums have no titles and few graphics; the songs, which run into each other without a break, are structured on simple chord changes repeated with bulldozing power, over which Chip Kinman intones spare pop lyrics about love and desire. "We're way into minimalism," he said. "We're just trying to reconstruct and deconstruct pop music. We've learned a lot about the music industry the whole time. The things that new bands are told they can and can't do are just incredible. With Blackbird, we just decided to forget all that."
Redd Kross will perform tonight at the Ritz, 254 West 54th Street (956-3731). Show time is 9 P.M.; tickets are $14.50 to $15.50. The Shams will perform tomorrow night at Maxwell's, 1039 Washington Street, Hoboken, N.J. (201-798-4064). Tickets are $10; show time is 11 P.M.
The Bob Mould Band will perform tonight and tomorrow night at the Marquee, 547 West 21st Street (982-3686). Show time is 9 P.M.; tickets are $15. Blackbird will perform tomorrow night at CBGB, 315 Bowery at Bleecker Street (982-4052). Show time is 8:30 P.M.; tickets are $10.

HEADLINE: Bank of Boston Reports Large Loss

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BOSTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
The Bank of Boston posted a loss today of $254.9 million for the third quarter, as it continues to experience declines because of the deteriorating Northeast economy and a weak real estate market.
For the corresponding quarter last year, the Bank of Boston's loss was $125.1 million. 
 The banking company last month predicted a heavy loss of at least $200 million in the quarter that ended on Sept. 30.
The company said it had set aside $200 million for bad loans in the third quarter, bringing its total loan-loss provision this year to $450 million. That compareswith a $370 million provision for 1989's third quarter and $442 million over all last year.
Bank officials said most of the bad loans were for real estate.
The Bank of Boston, New England's largest bank, had shown signs of recovery earlier this year. After posting huge losses last year, it turned a slight profit in the second quarter of this year, and officials said the volume of its bad loans decreased.
But last month, the bank cut its dividend to 10 cents a share, from 31 cents, as have other banks.
Bank of Boston slipped 25 cents yesterday, to $6.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Diner's Journal

BYLINE: By Molly O'Neill

 BODY:

Can
 New York restaurateurs sound a little like politicians these days. They bridle at the word "depression," preferring instead to describe the dwindling number of guests in their dining rooms and the new abstemiousness of diners as a "restaurant recession." By any name, the change in the prevailing winds has stirred up wildly varied responses in the form of recently opened dining spots.
Can, which opened two weeks ago in SoHo, is a Spartan, tony place whose artful French-Vietnamese cooking (and steep prices) defies the current belt-tightening, back-to-basics trend. With its white-washed brick walls and contemplative jazz, the dining atrium looks more like a West Broadway art gallery than a restaurant. The art buyers and gallery owners who are beginning to trickle in to claim the 65 black lacquered chairs must feel right at home; certainly the food-serious do. Can's fare is cerebral, carefully crafted and, even for a non-aficionado of East-meets-West cooking, often very good.
At a recent lunch, the translucent rice dumplings were tender and tasty. Squid was perfectly sauteed on a mound of lettuces, fresh dill and opal basil, tossed with little taste-shocks of shredded ginger. The spring roll flanked a food sculpture of all its pure-tasting contents: carrots and bean threads, lettuce, shrimp and omelet. Unfortunately, the tuna-sushi pizza on a Jackson Pollock squiggle of yellow and red pepper puree was a flat-tasting, thick-crusted disk. Chicken, marinated in orange and raspberry vinaigrette, was nicely grilled. Smoked salmon was delicious, wrapped around a mousse of fresh salmon, crab meat and shrimp with a caviar sauce. Lunch, with coffee and dessert, was $140 for two. (Can, 482 West Broadway, at Houston Street, is open for lunch and dinner Tuesday through Sunday; 533-6333.)
 
Cafe Cassis
 In closer concert with the current no-frills mood, Cafe Cassis, a Provencal remake of the former Carolina, opened two weeks ago and offers a variety of lusty charcuterie as well as decent pizzas, roast chicken, fish stew and cod cakes at moderate prices (about $60 for two with wine, tax and tip) for pre- and post-theater dinners. (Cafe Cassis, 355 West 46th Street, is open for lunch and dinner Monday to Saturday; 245-0058.)
 
Vince & Eddie's
 Farther uptown, a similar back-to-basics mode reaches its apogee at Vince & Eddie's, a cozy neighborhood spot that opened last week. Mussels baked in garlicky herb butter and a lusty white-bean-and-ham soup recalled simpler times (and less-threatening prices: dinner for two is about $50, with wine, tax and tip).
The soggy crusted onion tart and misbegotten squid salad were forgiven, in fact forgotten, at the first bite of the main courses. Lamb shank, stewed with dried cherries; garlicky fried pork chops; pan-roasted chicken on a bed of cabbage and a waft of garlic and herbs could not have been better. (Vince & Eddie's, 70 West 68th Street, is open for lunch and dinner daily; 721-0068.)

HEADLINE: Home Resales Decline 8%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Sales of existing homes in September fell 8 percent, to their lowest level in nearly three years, a real estate trade group said today. It attributed the decline to faltering consumer confidence in the economy.
"Consumers don't know what to expect," said Norman D. Flynn, president of the National Association of Realtors. "When people don't know what's coming, they tend to delay big-ticket expenditures."
The realtors said house resales totaled a seasonally adjusted 3.22 million, slowest since a 3.2 million rate in January 1988. The August rate had been 3.5 million. All regions posted sales declines except for the Northeast, which was unchanged.
The median price of an existing home nationally fell 2.9 percent in September, to $94,300. The median means half of the homes cost more, half less.
Fixed-rate 30-year mortgages averaged 10.19 percent to 10.22 percent in September, generally higher than in the first half of the year.
Sales fell 10 percent in the South in September, to an annual rate of 1.26 million units. The median price of a home in the South was $85,900, down 1.2 percent from August.
The West posted a resale rate of 520,000 units, down 8.8 percent. The median home price was $134,700, a 3.9 percent decline from August.
Sales in the Midwest were off 7.1 percent, to 920,000 units. The median price was $74,000, a 1.7 percent drop.
Sales in the Northeast remained unchanged at 520,000 units, despite a 5.6 percent drop in the median price to $137,100.

HEADLINE: Drexel Deal Is Described By Witness

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
A former salesman of high-yield "junk bonds" with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. testified yesterday that Michael R. Milken once told him that securities owned by the firm were sometimes secretly held by the Columbia Savings and Loan Association, one of Drexel's largest clients.
The testimony by the salesman, James Dahl, came in the pre-sentencing hearing for Mr. Milken and was the first public evidence that Columbia may have "parked" securities for Drexel. 
 According to the testimony, Columbia held securities for Drexel's "undisclosed economic benefit" shortly after the arrest of Dennis B. Levine, a former investment banker with Drexel, on insider trading charges.
 
No Other Transactions
 But Mr. Dahl, who represented many of the large savings and loans that worked with Drexel, said he did no similar transactions with any other institutions.
Columbia is now struggling to avoid being seized by the Government as part of the savings bailout. Thomas Spiegel, a close friend of Mr. Milken's, resigned last year as chairman of the California savings institution.
Mr. Dahl also provided vivid testimony about a meeting he had with Mr. Milken after the announcement that Ivan F. Boesky, the former arbitrager, had agreed to settle insider trading charges and cooperate with the Government in its investigation of Wall Street abuses. At the meeting, held in a Drexel bathroom, Mr. Milken told Mr. Dahl, cryptically, "Do whatever you need to do."
The testimony came as the Government presented evidence in the last of three transactions it says were part of a pattern of securities violations by Mr. Milken. In this last transaction, the Government contends that Mr. Milken used inside information in the purchase of bonds in Caesars World Inc., which was readying a debt-for-equity exchange at the time of the purchase with Drexel as the underwriter.
Although a series of possible crimes were described yesterday, the testimony was the murkiest about the Government's allegation of insider trading in the Caesars World bonds. Mr. Dahl testified that although Mr. Milken told him to purchase the bonds, he could not say when that directive was given. Further, the trades by Mr. Dahl that were the focus of testimony yesterday took place several days after Mr. Milken left the country for a vacation.
Also, under cross-examiniation, Mr. Dahl said that he had done the Caesars World trade as part of a debt-swap with clients who needed cash to purchase two new issues of junk bonds. Mr. Dahl said he had not remembered that the purchase of the Caesars bonds were part of a debt-swap until he saw all the trading tickets from the transaction yesterday.
 
Contradictions in Testimony
 In addition, the two Government witnesses who testified on the transaction contradicted each other on key elements, such as whether Mr. Dahl told clients there was a market rumor that Caesars World would do a debt-for-equity swap.
Testimony on other issues, however, were damaging to Mr. Milken and included a number of apparent references to illicit activities similar to those he has already admitted.
Prescott Crocker, a portfolio manager with Colonial Group Inc., testified that Mr. Milken had offered to do a series of compensatory trades after Mr. Crocker complained that he believed Drexel had used inside information in its purchase of Caesars bonds from him. Mr. Crocker said that he did not do the compensatory trading because it "is an irregular practice and it is perhaps illegal."
 
Called on Sunday
 In his testimony, Mr. Dahl said he was called at home on a Sunday by Mr. Milken, who summoned him to Drexel's office in Beverly Hills, Calif. Mr. Dahl testified that after arriving, he sat across from Mr. Milken for several hours waiting to speak to him.
The former salesman said that when he indicated that he wanted to leave, Mr. Milken took him to the men's room and began running water at a sink. Leaning closely to the sink, Mr. Milken was said to have then told Mr. Dahl in hushed tones: "There haven't been any subpoenas issued, so whatever you need to do, do it."
Under cross-examination, Mr. Dahl said that he did not think Mr. Milken was asking him to destroy documents or not to cooperate with the Government's inquiry.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 1, 1990, Friday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of a transmission error, an article in Business Day on Friday about the pre-sentence hearing of Michael R. Milken misstated the period during which an illegal securities trading scheme was said to have taken place between Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and the Columbia Savings and Loan Association. A witness said it began before 1983 and ended shortly after the 1986 arrest of Dennis B. Levine, a former Drexel investment banker, on charges of insider trading.

HEADLINE: Laventhol & Horwath Seeks 10% Pay Cut

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
Laventhol & Horwath, the nation's seventh-largest accounting firm with $345 million in revenues last year, told its nearly 3,500 employees yesterday that they would have to take a 10 percent pay cut for three months because the firm is under financial pressure.
The cuts come when several mid-sized firms are struggling under unusual competitive pressures. Spicer & Oppenheim, a New York firm with $75 million in revenues last year, is said to be reeling. 
 "My understanding is that the firm is breaking up and partners are seeking new alliances," said a partner of a competitor, who spoke on condition of anonymity. He said he had been been interviewing Spicer partners looking to leave the firm. The partner added that Spicer, the nation's 17th-largest, would probably last no more than three weeks.
Although Laventhol blamed the deteriorating economy for its salary request, it is well known that the Philadelphia-based firm has seen its profits hurt in recent months by adverse judgments or settlements in various lawsuits contending that the firm had performed poor audits, only some of which were covered by insurance.
Earlier this week, for instance, a multimillion-dollar lawsuit against Laventhol and Deloitte & Touche over their role as the former auditors of the PTL ministry, which was founded by Jim Bakker and later collapsed, went to trial in Charlotte, N.C. Some people in the profession say that an adverse judgment in the case could cause Laventhol to shut down.
"What Laventhol & Horwath has instituted is simply a sound and prudent business policy," the firm explained in a statement yesterday. "The softening economy may affect our projected future revenues, and we, like hundreds of other firms, are making adjustments to preserve the financial integrity and underlying strengths of the firm.
"Our policy is to avoid terminations whenever possible, and we think this 2.5 percent of annual income taken out over a three-month period is a much better solution than across the board job cuts," the statement said.
Because the 2.5 percent cut in annual pay is being withheld in the next three months, employees will see their net pay drop by 10 percent, starting immediately.
 
Firm Is 'Optimistic'
 Louis J. Grossman, a spokesman for the firm, said Laventhol was optimistic that improved conditions would allow the firm to restore pay levels by February. He declined to say whether the firm's partners were experiencing any decline in their take-home pay.
At Spicer, the chairman, Stephen Oppenheim, denied yesterday that his firm was about to break up, but he and two other members of the firm's senior management were said yesterday by several senior partners of other accounting firms to be talking seriously about joining a Los Angeles firm, Kenneth Leventhal & Company, in anticipation of Spicer's imminent breakup.
Spicer, with headquarters at 7 World Trade Center, where it occupies nearly three floors and employs about 500 people, is late in paying its rent, but its partners have guaranteed the obligation, bankers and real estate executives confirmed yesterday.

HEADLINE: THE STRUGGLE IN CONGRESS;
Lawmakers Take Stock Of Winners and Losers

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
As their leaders put finishing touches on the deficit-reduction compromise, rank- and-file members of Congress today began toting up the winners and losers in the five-month struggle to make the deal.
Although House Democrats loyally praised their top leadership -- the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley, and the majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt -- many thought the clearest Democratic hero was Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, who heads the House Ways and Means Committee. 
 A year ago, Mr. Rostenkowski faced open rebellion on the panel and suffered a humiliating defeat on the House floor over the question of cutting the capital gains tax rate.
This year, as chief architect of a tax-the-rich plan for deficit reduction, he was a leader in helping the Democrats reassert themselves as protectors of middle-class economic interests. Not surprisingly, the most effusive praise for the Ways and Means chairman came from members of his own panel, particularly liberals who shared the embarrassment of last year's capital gains debacle.
 
Praise for Rostenkowski
 "It was Rosty's plan and Rosty's strategy to focus on fairness," said Representative Marty Russo, an Illinois Democrat. "We've shown the difference between our party and the Republicans, and we're finally beginning to change what's been happening over the past 10 years."
Representative Thomas J. Downey, a Long Island Democrat and another Rostenkowski protege on the committee, put it more broadly: "After years of trying and failing, we have shifted the debate from whether to tax to who to tax. The bottom line is that a Democratic candidate can now be a Democratic candidate in the true sense of the term."
Among Democrats, Mr. Gephardt, of Missouri, also fared pretty well. As chairman of the Congressional team that negotiated the budget package with the White House, he passed his first real test of leadership, demonstrating that he could keep the process moving, hold the warring factions together and bring the deal to a close on terms satisfactory to most of the party.
That has clearly raised his stock among Democratic colleagues who feared he would never leave the campaign trail, but it is not yet clear whether the institutional victory translates into brighter Presidential prospects down the road.
 
G.O.P. View on Gephardt
 "In the extreme short run, Gephardt's stature is enhanced," one Republican strategist said a little grumpily. "But if the recession is deep and people blame the Democrats for raising taxes, by 1992 he may be damaged goods."
In the eyes of some Democrats, Mr. Foley, of Washington, was mildly tarred by his association with the failed budget summit. While liberals give him grudging credit for doing what he had to do to make a deal with the White House and the more conservative Senate, they remain uneasy with his conciliatory approach and suspicious that he would have settled for less in the final deal if those with more partisan instincts had not weighed in.
"There is no question that the leadership is hurt by its commitment to the summit," said Representative George Miller, a California Democrat. "I think next time they try to tell us about doomsday scenarios, they won't be able to convince us so easily. They lost credibility on that and on stragegy."
The Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, a Democrat of Maine, whose aloof public manner irritated many House Democrats during the months of budget negotiating, nonetheless got high marks from his party colleagues for being a tough partisan behind closed doors.
 
Dole, the Deal Maker
 On the Republican side, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, stands out as Mr. Rostenkowski's counterpart as a consummate deal maker. But his hopes for cutting into the Democratic majority are slim in 1990 and perhaps for 1992 as well.
"The Democrats have had the advantage so far, but if we can make the case that they are raising taxes and not cutting spending, it will be to our advantage in the long run," said Senator Don Nickles, the Oklahoma Republican who heads the National Republican Senatorial Committee.
In regard to political reputations, the major development on the Republican side came in the final, bitter weeks of budget negotiating. The White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, and the budget director, Richard G. Darman, settled firmly into their roles as the pair that everybody on Capitol Hill loves to hate. Much of the animosity has less to do with politics than with personalities that lawmakers find arrogant and abrasive.
Privately, some Republicans now say that the President's men were only doing his bidding. "You can quibble with the execution here and there, but I don't think the President's agents ought to be held accountable for carrying out the President's instructions," said one House Republican strategist.
 
Bush as Possible Winner
 Senator Phil Gramm, a Texas Republican who was part of the original budget negotiations, but who now says he has not made up his mind about whether to support the final package, said even the President might eventually come out a winner. "In the short run, the Democrats have benefited, but in the long run, the President has put behind him the only real threat to his Presidency -- a huge and growing budget deficit," he said.
Conservative House Republicans, who torpedoed the initial budget compromise that would have given their President more of what he wanted, were less convinced and less forgiving.
"Our people are distancing themselves from Medicare cuts and tax increases," said Representative Vin Weber, a Minnesota Republican.
He added: "Everybody loves George Bush, but unfortunately George Bush has been identified with those policies. Two weeks before the election, you don't want to be associated with unpopular policies."
For Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip and the leader of the rebellion, the reviews of his colleagues are mixed. In the corridors of the Captol today, some Republicans talked of the "Gingrich tax," convinced that his disloyalty cost the President crucial leverage that could have produced a better deal.
On the other hand, Mr. Gingrich has earned the kind of national name identity that is beyond the fondest dreams of most House members. Some House Republicans who already feel themselves irrelevant to the legislative and political process say the gamble may have been worth it.

HEADLINE: Some Tax Analysts Doubt Rich Would Be Hard Hit

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
A number of independent tax specialists who have reviewed the budget package negotiated by Congressional Democrats and the Bush Administration said today that the "soak the rich" rhetoric accompanying it was largely a misrepresentation.
These experts did not dispute figures, provided by Congressional tax specialists on Wednesday, showing that the package would raise the level of all Federal taxes on those earning $200,000 or more annually by an average of 6.4 percent, a larger increase than for the average of any income group below them. 
 But the experts said that only those whose earnings run substantially into six figures would be likely to suffer a major blow and that the complexity that the plan would add to individual returns meant so many fluctuations that even among this group, some people would actually receive a tax cut.
They also stressed an element of the plan that has not been nearly so widely publicized as the taxes on the rich: that most middle-income people would pay more than they do now.
 
No Dearth of Variables
 The tax practitioners cautioned that the new package, whose final touches were still being applied today, would affect taxpayers in a variety of ways, so that whether a couple paid more or less would depend not only on the amount of income received but also on such factors as family size, the source and division of income, and whether one is salaried or self-employed.
But rough calculations performed today by the accounting firm of Arthur Andersen & Company showed that for two hypothetical families, neither an extreme case, the effects of the new package were not as advertised by many of its advocates.
A two-earner, childless couple with adjusted gross income of $184,200 and $20,000 of itemized deductions, for example, would find their Federal income tax levy falling by $1,136 and their Medicare taxes rising by $1,183, a net tax increase of only $47.
A one-earner couple with two children, earning $83,400 and claiming deductions of $8,300 would see no change in their income tax but would see their Medicare levy rise by $465, according to the calculations, which were performed by Marc D. Levy, a member of the accounting fir's Washington office of Federal tax services.
 
'That's Where It Is'
 The talk about the Treasury's obtaining big revenue from the rich "is all garbage," asserted Norman Ture, a Reagan Administration official who now heads the Institute for Research on the Economics of Taxation. "You've got to get it out of the middle-income people, because that's where it is."
Citizens for Tax Justice, a labor-oriented group, said that by its calculations, a family of four with gross income of $300,000 could, through heavy deductions, wind up with a tax cut of $5,000. The reason is that the deductions could push such a family's taxable income down to a level that now falls within "the bubble" -- the portion of income, roughly $80,000 to $200,000, that is currently taxed at 33 percent. Under the new plan, the top tax rate would be 31 percent (a two-point drop for such a family) and the ceiling on the capital gains tax would be 28 percent (a five-point drop).
Robert S. McIntyre, director of Citizens for Tax Justice, said the plan would cut the taxes of "well-off doctors, lawyers and executives" -- and those of Congressional and Administration negotiators as well.
 
One Firm's Calculations
 The calculations by Arthur Andersen assume 4 percent inflation and place at $81,550 the level at which the 28 percent income tax rate would end and the new maximum rate of 31 percent would begin. They ignore capital gains, whose rate preference, eliminated by the Tax Reform Act of 1986, would be restored in a small way by capping the tax on gains at 28 percent. But the calculations do take account of the plan's other major tax provisions: limits on the value of itemized deductions and the phasing out of the value of personal exemptions.
The family with $184,200 in income would lose the value of $1,026 in itemized deductions -- 3 percent of the amount exceeding $150,000. (The cut-off for single filers would apparently be $100,000.) This family would also lose $115 from personal exemptions, now $2,050 each, which would be worth progressively less for joint filers with incomes between $150,000 and $275,000. But, being within the bubble, where income is now taxed at 33 percent, this couple would benefit from the new top rate of 31 percent.
Over all, including their Medicare increase, their tax levy would rise only slightly, though it would increase somewhat more if the couple were self-employed or one partner earned far more than the other.
The $83,400 family -- which is assumed to have $8,300 in itemized deductions, about the same percentage of income as the wealthier family -- does not earn enough to be affected by the deduction limits or by the changes in personal exemptions or tax rates. But it would pay $465 more over all than at present because the 1.45 percent Medicare tax would be levied on its entire income instead of only the first $51,300. The new plan's maximum base for the Medicare tax is said to be $125,000.
There are other anomalies as well in the plan. While the top income tax rate would nominally be 31 percent, some people might find themselves paying a somewhat higher rate on their last dollars earned.
For example, the limitation on exemptions for high-income families means that for each child or other dependent, the marginal rate would in effect be raised by half a percentage point. As a result, a family of 10 could find itself paying 36 percent of its final earnings in taxes. It was not clear tonight whether there would be any limit on how much a high-income couple might be disadvantaged by having a large family.
Further, the limitations on itemized deductions would raise the statutory 31 percent maximum rate to an effective 31.93 percent and the new 28 percent capital gains rate to 28.84 percent, according to Randall Weiss, director of tax economics at Deloitte & Touche and a former top aide to the Joint Tax Committee of Congress.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
U.S. DECIDES TO ADD AS MANY AS 100,000 TO ITS GULF FORCES

BYLINE: By MICHAEL GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
The Bush Administration has decided to expand the number of American forces in the Persian Gulf and may send as many as 100,000 more troops to the region, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today.
The United States has sent more than 210,000 troops to the gulf, as part of a planned deployment of 240,000 troops. In announcing that more forces would be sent, Mr. Cheney said the exact number had not been worked out, and he gave no date for completing the American military buildup in the region, the largest since the Vietnam War. 
 Mr. Cheney said some of the additional forces might be drawn from among the 50,000 American troops that are being withdrawn from Western Europe.
 
Seeking to Increase Pressure
 Officially, the Administration maintained that the move did not signal a policy change. But by announcing that it was sending more combat forces and that the complement might be substantial, the Pentagon seemed to be trying to increase pressure on President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait and accept a peaceful settlement on United Nations and American terms.
The additional deployment of large numbers of troops would transform the American ground force in Saudi Arabia from a largely defensive military formation to one better suited for offensive action. Some military planners, including Army officials, have been saying for weeks that the United States should deploy two additional heavy divisions if it wanted to open an attack to evict Iraqi troops from Kuwait, which Iraq invaded on Aug. 2.
 
Little Boycott Effect Seen
 The decision to send more troops came as William H. Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, said the economic sanctions imposed by the United Nations have had little effect on the Iraqi military. Answering questions after a speech in Washington this morning, Mr. Webster said he had "no real confidence" that stability could be achieved in the Middle East if Mr. Hussein remained in power -- unless Iraq disarms or is constrained by a regional military alliance.
Taking note of the large number of Iraqi troops in Kuwait, Mr. Webster said that President Hussein's strategy "is to sit tight if he can unless he is threatened with imminent peril."
Mr. Cheney, who met with President Bush on Wednesday, disclosed the decision to send more combat troops in a series of morning interviews with four television networks, and his spokesman reaffirmed the decision at the regular Pentagon briefing for reporters.
Mr. Cheney said the United States had never set an "upper ceiling" on the number of troops that would be sent, and he added that the Pentagon had not formally decided precisely which additional units to send.
Asked on the CBS News program "This Morning" whether the Administration might send 100,000 more troops to the Persian Gulf, Mr. Cheney said, "It's conceivable that we'll end up with that big an increase."
Pete Williams, the chief Pentagon spokesman, reaffirmed that statement at the Pentagon's regular news briefing for reporters today, saying a deployment of that magnitude was possible.
The units to be sent will be selected after Mr. Cheney confers with Gen. Colin L. Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, who met with military commanders in Saudi Arabia this week. Officials said additional units would augment the troop total in the region, and would not end up simply substituting for American forces recalled home as part of a troop rotation.
 
Original Ceiling of 240,000
 The Pentagon's original plan, decided on in August, called for sending about 240,000 troops, a force that include four and a half Army divisions and 45,000 marines, some 11,000 of whom are on ships for a possible amphibious landing.
That deployment is nearing completion, and the Pentagon has said that more than 210,000 American troops are already in the region, including Navy and Air Force personnel.
The last Army combat unit that was previously scheduled for deployment, the last elements of the First Cavalry Division, arrived in Saudi Arabia this week, and only support troops and logistical items remained to be sent until today's announcement.
The original Pentagon plan to send about 240,000 troops was based on earlier contingency planning by Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the commander of all American forces in the region, for defending Saudi Arabia against a possible Iraqi invasion.
 
Attack Plan Was Missing
 General Schwarzkopf's contingency plans were not complete when Iraq invaded Kuwait, said a military official who asked not to be identified. He said one missing element was a plan for an American counterattack against Iraqi forces.
Iraq has had about 430,000 troops in Kuwait and southern Iraq for more than a month. Administration officials have said the Iraqis have been strengthening their position by laying mines, building sand barrers and digging in their tanks, a development that Mr. Cheney suggested has encouraged the Pentagon to send more troops.
Explaining why the Administration was continuing the buildup, Mr. Cheney said the United States needed to have enough forces in the gulf "to deal with any contingency."
Reiterating Administration policy, the Defense Secretary said that American forces were sent to Saudi Arabia to deter Iraq from invading Saudi Arabia, to prepare to defend the Saudi kingdom in the event of an attack and to enforce the United Nations sanctions against Iraq.
 
Seeking 'Range of Options'
 But he added that the deployment of American forces was also intended "to give the President a range of other options should another option be necessary," an apparent reference to possible offensive American action to drive the Iraqi forces out of Kuwait.
"The fact is that Saddam Hussein has continued his buildup in Kuwait," Mr. Cheney said on the CBS program.
"He's dug in in a very permanent-looking sort of way, gives no indication of being willing to withdraw from Kuwait," he added. "And we think that it's necessary to make certain that we've got the forces over there to deal with any contingency."
There are a number of ways to build up the American force in the region. Mr. Cheney suggested that the Pentagon would replace the lightly equipped 82d Airborne, which was deployed early in the operation, with a heavier mechanized division, a move long advocated by military planners.
Both Mr. Cheney and his spokesman said the United States might send some of the 50,000 troops to be withdrawn from Europe this year to Saudi Arabia. This announcement surprised some Army officials, according to Pentagon officials.
 
Europe Units Called Unready
 The officials said the Army units being withdrawn had already stopped some combat training, were not at full strength, and might not be the best suited to build up American military power in Saudi Arabia.
Mr. Cheney's disclosures also surprised some members of Congress. The Defense Secretary had only hinted at the moves at a closed-door meeting with House members on Wednesday, saying the Administration had set no upper limits on American forces.
Administration officials said that Washington was still committed to using economic sanctions to try to compel Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, and that the decision to send additional forces did not mean that the Administration had decided on military action.
Mr. Webster said economic sanctions against Iraq were having little visible effect on President Hussein's military and probably would not for some time.
 
Iraqi Stockpiling Described
 "The sanctions are beginning to have an effect in a number of areas, but very few of them are in the military," Mr. Webster said, "He knows the value of stockpiling, and has done so."
The steps taken by the Iraqi military, like retreading truck tires, may be efforts to avoid shortages and not a reaction to them, he said.
Intelligence data suggest that some of Mr. Hussein's military advisers may be starting to chafe under his leadership, he said, but Mr. Webster held out little hope for either a revolution or a high-level coup in Baghdad.
"We had all that in place in Panama," he said, "but it took something else." He referred to the American invasion to remove Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega from power in December.
 
Deployment Compared
 Pentagon officials have repeatedly described the dispatch of more than 210,000 American soldiers, marines, airmen and sailors in the gulf as the speediest military deployment in history. In the Vietnam conflict, the United States had dispatched 23,000 advisers by 1964; by the end of 1965, it had 184,300 troops in Vietnam, excluding sailors in the South China Sea. By the end of 1966, the total had risen to 385,000.
In addition to the American forces, close to 200,000 troops from Saudi Arabia, Britain, France, Egypt and other nations allied with the United States are also in the Persian Gulf. Arrangements have been made in recent days to transport a Syrian armored division to Saudi Arabia.
Iraq has steadily expanded its forces in Kuwait and southern Iraq, reaching a level of about 430,000 troops more than a month ago.
