HEADLINE: THE STRUGGLE IN CONGRESS;
Experts Expect Stimulus to Economic Morale but Little Else

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The budget agreement now before Congress might make the hard times engulfing the American economy slightly harder next year, economists say. But the damage will probably be too small to measure.
What many experts hope is that the budget agreement will have a psychological impact far beyond the economics involved. Should confidence be restored in the Government's ability to control the budget deficit, this in itself might stimulate the economy, some economists argue. The stimulation would come in part because lenders, being more optimistic about the economy's health, would demand lower interest rates. 
 "The biggest problem with the budget deficit is that we have lost public confidence and trust," said Representative Lee Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana, chairman of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress. "This five-year agreement should restore that trust; it is a genuine, creditable attack on the deficit problem."
 
 Hoping for Action
 In the view of Mr. Hamilton, other politicians and economists, the Federal Reserve should regard the agreement as credible and behave accordingly, pushing down interest rates. That would more than offset any negative effect of the budget agreement.
Lower rates encourage people to borrow for consumer spending and investment, canceling out the Government's reduced role as a source of spending and economic stimulus.
Federal Reserve officials declined to say whether they considered the latest budget agreement acceptable. "We have no comment," said Joseph Coyne, a spokesman for Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve.
Mr. Greenspan has suggested in the past that a "credible" deficit reduction package -- one that reduces the Government's borrowing requirements -- would automatically ease the pressure on interest rates and thus permit the Federal Reserve to hasten the process by using its power to manipulate rates.
 
 The Arithmetic of Rates
 Many economists say that to reverse the economy's slide toward recession, the Federal Reserve would have to be more decisive in reducing interest rates than it has been over the past year, as the economy weakened. Specifically, the Federal Reserve would have to shave at least one percentage point off the charges now imposed on many loans. Consumers, for example, pay 10 percent or more today for most auto loans, home mortgages and other financing.
"Most people feel that the contractionary impact of the budget agreement, if there is to be any, will come in the first year," said Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office. "The reason is that the Fed will have less leeway to push down rates and more room to adjust its policies in the ensuing years."
If Mr. Reischauer is correct, then any recessionary impact of the budget package would be greatly reduced in 1992, a Presidential election year.
So far this year, the Federal Reserve has shown more concern about controlling inflation than avoiding recession. Although the economy was weakening when the Middle East crisis began in August, Fed officials said they would hold rates unchanged because they considered the inflationary potential from the crisis a greater immediate problem than any recessionary impact.
The central bank fights inflation by raising interest rates or keeping them high, which discourages the borrowing that finances spending and puts pressure on prices.
 
 Concerns About Weakness
 If the Federal Reserve does not act, some economists and politicians worry that an economy already close to recession would be further weakened as the Government reduces its role in an effort to cut the budget deficit.
But the new proposals to lower spending and raise taxes would reduce the deficit by only $35 billion over the next 12 months. That is a minuscule amount in an economy that will generate $5.4 trillion in new wealth this year.
The budget deficit in the 1990 fiscal year, which ended Sept. 30, was about $220 billion, or roughly 4 percent of the $5.4 trillion gross national product. And the budget deficit at the end of fiscal 1991, even if Congress and President Bush approve the new package, would be $250 billion to $260 billion -- still 4 percent of the G.N.P.
Budget deficits as a percent of the total economy often rise during economic downturns and then shrink as the economy recovers and once again produces growing quantities of wealth and tax revenue to pay for Government spending. The 1981-82 recession, for example, pushed the deficit to 6.3 percent of G.N.P. in 1983. The deficit then slowly declined to 3 percent in the late 1980's before rising again as the economy weakened in 1989 and tax revenue began to fall.
 
 Reducing Government's Role
 The budget agreement might change this pattern over a five-year period by steadily reducing the Government's role in the economy through $500 billion in spending cuts and tax increases. The shrinkage might indeed reduce the budget deficit to 2 percent or less of G.N.P., the levels that prevailed until the early 1970's -- unless the cure removes so much stimulation from the economy that recession develops.
Mr. Reischauer and many other economists are counting on the private sector to prevent this from happening. As they argue, a lower budget deficit means the Government can cut back on its borrowing to finance the deficit. The reduced borrowing, in turn, frees national savings for use by the private sector, which then borrows the money, at relatively low interest rates, for investment and spending.
That is the theory that Congress, the Administration and many economists often invoke to help justify proposals that would sharply reduce the budget deficit. But the problem is that the Federal Government has operated in deficit almost every year since World War II, and during this period, interest rates, investment and savings have often failed to behave according to theory, economists note. As the deficit rose in the mid-1980's, for example, interest rates fell and investment by the private sector rose, although the Government was commandeering ever larger portions of the nation's savings.
The connections might break down again, economists say, for several reasons. One is that the savings and loan bailout accounts for 30 percent of the deficits in 1990 and 1991. Many economists argue that the bailout has an essentially neutral effect. The Government, according to this view, is borrowing from the savings of some Americans to replenish the savings of others, who had kept their money in savings institutions that failed.
 
 'A Stabilizer'
 "You would think that a deficit that has pushed above $200 billion would have a dramatic impact on the economy," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Prudential-Bache Securities. "But mostly the deficit is acting as a stabilizer, offsetting the shrinkage in national savings that would have occurred without the thrift bailout."
The tax proposals in the budget agreement also ameliorate the impact on the economy by putting a big portion of the new tax burden on people with high incomes. Some economists say that when a wealthy person pays slightly higher taxes, the impact on his income is too small to inhibit spending.
"To the extent that the tax pain is spread across income groups, the negative impact on the economy should be fairly limited," Mr. Yardeni said.

HEADLINE: THE STRUGGLE IN CONGRESS;
ELDERLY SHIELDED FROM BIG INCREASE IN MEDICARE COSTS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
House and Senate budget negotiators said today they had agreed on how to shield the elderly from any large increase in Medicare costs, one of the last outstanding issues in the deficit-reduction package Congress and the White House have been laboring on for nearly two months.
The agreement involves only a modest increase in Medicare costs for the elderly but substantial cuts in Medicare payments to doctors and hospitals. 
 The negotiators also agreed on a significant expansion of Medicaid to cover all poor children through the age of 18 by the year 2001. Many governors have opposed Federal requirements for Medicaid expansion, fearing they would saddle the states with enormous new costs, but Congress concluded that poor children are entitled to health insurance coverage even in a time of austerity.
 
Compromise Nears Completion
 The agreements on Medicare and Medicaid came as Congressional leaders neared completion of a compromise tax-and-spending package in preparation for votes Friday on the largest deficit-reduction plan in history. [Page A20.]
At the White House, Marlin Fitzwater, the press secretary, said President Bush was satisfied with the overall measure, which is supposed to cut the deficit by $40 billion this year and $500 billion over five years. But a senior Administration official attacked the Democrats, asserting they had forced the President to raise taxes. And the White House objected unsuccessfully to "the mandatory expansion of Medicaid" to cover additional poor children.
The relatively favorable terms toward beneficiaries, particularly the elderly, in the agreements on Medicare and Medicaid were essential to win political support among Democrats, the Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley, said.
 
Higher Payroll Taxes
 Over all, the changes in the Medicare program would save roughly $43 billion over five years, substantially less than the $60 billion target in the budget summit agreement negotiated by White House officials and Congressional leaders at Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland. But much of the extra cost would be offset by new revenues, resulting from a dramatic increase in the amount of earnings subject to the Medicare payroll tax.
Mr. Foley said the agreement would include provisions of the House-passed budget bill intended to "reduce the burden on Medicare beneficiaries." The summit agreement and a budget bill passed last week by the Senate would have required the 33 million Medicare beneficiaries to share more of the program's costs. Democrats, who often campaign as protectors of the elderly, demanded a reduction in that burden as a condition for supporting the deficit-reduction plan.
Ronald F. Pollack, executive director of Families USA, a lobby for the elderly, said, "The compromise on Medicare is beginning to look much more like the House package than the Senate package, and that is good news for Medicare beneficiaries of moderate income."
Under the tentative agreement, the monthly Medicare premium for insurance covering doctors' bills, now $28.60, would rise gradually over five years to $46.20, as provided in the House bill. The $75 Medicare deductible, which is paid once a year by users of physician services, would rise to $100 in 1991 and would stay at that level in later years. The summit plan called for further increases in the deductible, to $125 in 1992 and $150 in 1993.
 
Doctors to Get Less
 While the elderly would pay less than envisioned in the summit plan, doctors and hospitals would pay more. The new agreement would save $32 billion to $33 billion over five years by paring Medicare payments to such health-care providers, as against $30 billion envisioned in the budget summit accord.
Lawmakers and lobbyists are still fighting over details of payments to doctors and hospitals. But they said it was clear that the final bill would trim reimbursements to them in myriad ways: reducing the inflation adjustment in hospital payments, reducing the allowance for the cost of hospital equipment and construction, cutting payments to doctors for "overpriced procedures" and freezing payments for physician services other than primary care.
Authoritative studies done for the Government concluded that Medicare payments for primary care, such as routine office visits, were inexplicably low when compared with national norms for all physician services.
As an example of the payment cuts to doctors under the compromise emerging from Congress, reimbursements to radiologists would be cut 6 percent to 7 percent below the amounts they would otherwise receive for treating Medicare patients in the current fiscal year.
 
Power of the Elderly
 Gary W. Price, director of government relations at the American College of Radiology, said, "When members of Congress decided it was impossible to raise Medicare beneficiary premiums much, they looked to health-care providers for additional savings."
"Our group, with slightly more than 20,000 members, and other health-care providers do not have nearly as much influence as a group like the American Association of Retired Persons, with more than 30 million members," Mr. Price said.
House and Senate negotiators have tentatively agreed to mandate Medicaid coverage of poor children through age 18. Current law requires coverage of poor children through age 5. Starting in 1991, state Medicaid programs would have to cover poor children 8 years old and under. The pool of eligible youngsters would expand gradually over the next decade until it includes all poor children through age 18.
 
An Extraordinary Coalition
 Federal and state governments share Medicaid costs, with states paying an average of 44 percent of the total. The National Governors Association has argued against mandatory expansion of Medicaid. But an extraordinary coalition of doctors, hospitals, insurers, business groups and children's advocates lobbied for it.
"This is exciting, more than we could have hoped for, and we are very pleased," said Kay Johnson, director of health issues at the Children's Defense Fund, a private group that lobbies for assistance to children.
The House-Senate compromise on Medicaid would also permit states to cover children through the age of 5 in families that are not poor but have incomes no more than 85 percent above the official poverty level. That would permit coverage of a family of three with income up to $18,287 this year. (A family of three earning less than $9,885 in 1989 was classified as living in poverty.)
 
Fast-Growing Program
 Even with the proposed cutbacks, Medicare would remain one of the fastest-growing programs in the Federal budget for several reasons: The elderly population is growing, health care costs are rising faster than the Consumer Price Index and the volume of physician services is growing even as the Government controls prices by limiting Medicare fees to doctors.
The new budget agreement continues the trend of the last eight years toward mind-boggling complexity in the formulas used to calculate Medicare payments to doctors and hospitals. House and Senate negotiators have tentatively agreed to reduce the inflation adjustment in payments to hospitals for in-patient care by 2 percentage points this year, 1.5 points next year and 1.4 points in 1993. At the same time, they would pay hospitals only 95 percent of the recognized costs of out-patient services.
A volatile political issue, still unresolved, is how to compensate inner-city hospitals and isolated rural hospitals that have exceptionally high costs. House negotiators are fighting for $2.5 billion in extra Medicare payments to urban hospitals, while Senate negotiators want to distribute $1.4 billion to rural hospitals.
Members of Congress said they had made progress in settling disagreements between the House and the Senate over a proposd child-care program, which would provide $2.5 billion in Federal grants to the states over three years. Negotiators have agreed on who will be eligible for the program, meant to help low-income families. But they have yet to work out such details as how to expand the Federal income tax credit for low-income working families with children.
Many Democrats contend that an increase in the tax credit is essential to make the overall deficit-reduction package more progressive.

HEADLINE: Ex-Owner Of S.& L. Is Indicted

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Oct. 25

 BODY:
The former owner of the Western Savings Association, who led the Texas institution through a period of stunning growth in high-risk ventures, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on 37 charges of bank fraud, misuse of funds and conspiracy. The failure of the savings institution is likely to cost taxpayers more than $1 billion.
The criminal charges against Jarrett E. Woods, who controlled Western between 1982 and 1986, were announced late this afternoon in Washington, nearly a week after Federal regulators filed a sweeping civil lawsuit seeking $560 million in damages from Mr. Woods for what it said were actions that defrauded the institution. 
 The damage amount listed in the civil case against Mr. Woods is one of the largest sought by the Government from former owners or executives of failed savings institutions. The civil case was filed in a Dallas Federal court last Friday, but its contents were not disclosed until this week.
 
Biggest Savings Bandits
 "The indictment of Jarrett Woods means that we have corralled one of the biggest savings and loan bandits in Texas," Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said. "The free-wheeling life style and fraudulent management practices that led to Western's collapse helped set the trend for our national thrift crisis."
A lawyer in Dallas representing Mr. Woods, Shirley Baccus-Lobel, said she was under a Federal court order not to discuss the criminal charges announced today.
Like dozens of Texas savings institutions that grew rapidly on savers' deposits attracted by high interest rates and gathered through brokerage firms, Western Savings had modest roots. Mr. Woods acquired its predecessor, Gatesville Savings, a small institution with $34 million in single-family mortgages, with a $2 million loan in 1982.
 
Real Estate Projects
 He changed the institution's name to Western Savings and began pouring deposits by the millions into several commercial real estate projects. Before Western was seized by regulators in 1986, Mr. Woods controlled nearly $2 billion in deposits.
The civil suit accused Mr. Woods of taking $7 million from Western's deposits in the waning months of his rule and using it to refinance his home, place money in his children's trust funds, retire a personal loan and pay himself an $800,000 bonus and a monthly salary of $41,667.
Western was closed by regulators in August 1988, and merged along with four other crippled institutions into Sunbelt Savings. Sunbelt, with more than $10 billion in assets, is now operating under the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's control.
The charges focus on four transactions, continuing a strategy adopted by Federal prosecutors to present narrow, reasonably straightforward cases that they believe will persuade jurors. The maximum penalty on the 37 counts brought against Mr. Woods amount to 185 years in prison and $8.3 million in fines.
In one transaction, Mr. Woods was accused of diverting $15.8 million from a $60 million loan intended for the purchase and development of Houston properties through Baypointe Investments Inc., a company operated by one of Western's large borrowers, James Reagin. Instead, the $16 million was transferred to Mr. Reagin who used that money to meet payments on several delinquent loans at Western and other financial institutions.
In another case, Mr. Woods is said to have diverted $2.6 million in profit that Western was to receive from a property sale in Cedar Hill, a suburb of Dallas, to make additional payments on overdue loans held by Mr. Reagin.
Marvin Collins, the United States Attorney for Northern Texas, said Mr. Reagin's troubled loans of $64 million would have been sufficient by themselves to collapse Western in 1985 if the deficiencies had been found by Federal regulators.
"The indictment shows the great lengths to which people will go to deceive regulators," Mr. Collins told reporters.
 
Borrower Cooperates
 Mr. Reagin was not in the indictment. Richard Fishkin, the Government lawyer who heads the Dallas Bank Fraud Task Force, said Mr. Reagin had agreed to cooperate with Federal prosecutors after pleading guilty to six charges involving savings institutions in Illinois and Wisconsin, as well as Western Savings.
In another dealing described by Government lawyers, Mr. Woods was accused of directing a subsidiary of Western Savings to pay a $48,000 commission to a company that had done nothing to earn the money. The payment covered a gambling debt Mr. Woods owed to that company's president, the Government said.
Mr. Woods is the 90th person formerly affiliated with savings institutions and banks accused of illegal activities by the Dallas task force since the group was organized in 1987.
In two years, the Justice Department has obtained convictions of 338 defendants in the largest savings industry prosecutions in the nation. Of those, about 255 have received jail sentences as well as court orders to repay $208 million to the Treasury.
Mr. Thornburgh applauded Congress for increasing the department's budget for pursuing savings-and-loan fraud and related crimes to $160 million for the 1991 fiscal year, a threefold increase over the $50 million committed in the last fiscal year.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING - ADDENDA;
Magazine Ad Pages Fell Again in September

 BODY:
Magazine publishers anxious about ad dollars have received more bleak news: Advertising pages for magazines monitored by the Publishers Information Bureau continue to decline.
In September, ad pages fell 4.5 percent. For the first nine months of this year, ad pages dropped 3.3 percent from a year earlier. 
 "We see that the softness has bottomed and that the top 10 advertising catagories are growing significantly," said James R. Guthrie, executive vice president for marketing development for the Magazine Publishers of America, which runs the Publisher Information Bureau.
"My guess is that by the end of this year ad dollars will be up about 3.5 percent," Mr. Guthrie said. "We're on an upswing with pages, which will probably be off between 2 and 2.5 percent for the year. As long as the economy doesn't get any softer, next year will be a slow-growth year."
Even as ad pages go down, ad rates continue to rise, so revenues for magazines measured by the Publishers Information Bureau were up 2.6 percent for the first three quarters, and 4.8 percent for September.
The revenue leaders for the first nine months were, in order: Time, TV Guide, People, Sports Illustrated, Newsweek, Business Week, Good Housekeeping, Fortune, Forbes and U.S. News & World Report.

HEADLINE: THE 1990 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Trail;
Democrats See Gains In the Polls

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Around the country poll takers are recording a swing to Democrats in the closing days of the election.
Incumbent Republican senators in Minnesota and Oregon, who seemed safe a few months ago, are suddenly threatened. Harvey Gantt, the Democrat seeking to unseat Senator Jesse Helms in North Carolina, was ahead in one recent poll, although the poll takers said skepticism was advisable in this race, as in others where a black candidate faces a white one. 
 Some Republicans talk about the "bottom dropping out" and fear double-digit loses in the House, where just a few weeks ago, buoyed by the Iraq confrontation, they had hoped to hold their own against the normal midterm losses of the party in the White House.
"I think it's going to be an anti-Republican vote, not anti-incumbent," said Curtis Gans of the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate.
Some of the shift reflects the historically predictable response to rising economic anxiety. But the budget debacle has worsened the situation, shifting attention to economic issues at the worst possible moment for the Republicans.
President Bush is going out on the road, hoping he can stop the slide.Some Republican poll takers say their candidates hit bottom a few days ago and are bouncing back. But Representative Beryl Anthony Jr. of Arkansas, chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, said, "The tone has been set for this election cycle."
Candidates for governor get more individual attention, and campaigns usually focus on more local issues.
But in Ohio, the Democrat, Anthony Celebrezze, has gotten back in the race with a campaign that echoes the national theme that the Democrats are being so succesful with: the Republicans are unfair to the middle class. Mr. Celebrezze attacks his opponent, former Cleveland Mayor George Voinovich, for approving tax breaks for wealthy real estate developers.
In Texas, a spokesman for Clayton Williams, the Republican candidate for Governor, says the budget battle in Washington has hurt Mr. Williams and other Republicans. Ann Richards, the Democratic candidate, has pulled even with Mr. Williams in one new poll. She had been trailing badly a few weeks ago.
 
Cuomo Becomes A Punching Bag
 Maybe it's because things are not going so well for the Republicans in this year's elections that the chief party spokesman took an early swipe Wednesday at a potential Presidential contender in 1992, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York.
Charles Black, who is also a White House political adviser, said that Mr. Cuomo's record as Governor was filled with potential for the Republicans. "Cuomo looks like Dukakis without the competence," Mr. Black told a group of reporters at breakfast.
In Albany, Mr. Cuomo's chief spokesman, Gary Fryer, said Mr. Black was just the latest in a series of Republicans, including Vice President Dan Quayle and William J. Bennett, Director of National Drug Control Policy, to criticize the Governor.
"Based on the frequency with which this has happened in the last five or six months and based on the diversity of people involved this is clearly not a coincidence," Mr. Fryer said. "I think they're just trying to think of anyone to talk about other than them."
 
 Political War Erupts In Chicago Streets
 Has politics become too rough? Try the South Side of Chicago, where a dispute over campaign posters turned into a street brawl. One campaign worker was shot three times and then run over by a van.
The police say the argument was "politicially motivated," an outgrowth of a bitter race for sheriff of Cook County.
Supporters of Alderman Michael Sheahan, a Democrat who is challenging Sheriff James E. O'Grady, a Republican, were working on South Halstead Street early in the morning. Depending on who is telling the tale, they were either putting up Sheahan posters or tearing down O'Grady posters.
A group of O'Grady supporters spilled out of a local establishment, the Surf Lounge. Bottles and other projectiles were exchanged. O'Grady's camp says one of the Sheahan men swung a tire iron. The police say one of the O'Grady supporters drew a pistol from an ankle holster. Shots were fired.
Irving Bell, A sheriff's department guard who is supporting Mr. Sheahan, was hit three times. As he staggered down the street he was struck by the van, driven, depending on the version, by his friends trying to escape or by O'Grady backers. Three men, including a sheriff's deputy who supports Mr. O'Grady, were questioned in the shooting.
Mike Royko wrote in his columan in The Chicago Tribune on Wednesday: "We've been told that politics have become nothing but slick commercials, fast sound bites and mind manipulation by poll-juggling media advisers. Maybe so. But this is still Chicago. So once in a while we see the return of true grass-roots involvement."
From Gun Opponent To Gun Backer
 When she was in the Washington State Legislature, Jolene Unsoeld received failing grades from the National Rifle Association for her stands on gun control. But as a freshman Democratic Rrepresentative, struggling to keep her seat in a district that supports gun ownership, Ms. Unsoeld embraced legislation to insure the continued domestic production of semi-automatic rifles. The N.R.A. changed its view of Ms. Unsoeld, endorsing her in her tough re-election fight and contributing $5,950 to her re-election campaign. "We always accept battlefield conversions," said Jim Baker, the association's director of Federal affairs.
 
 Republicans Face Replacing Atwater
 Lee Atwater, the ailing Republican National chairman, continues to battle a brain tumor. His condition is improved, but leading Republicans say that after the election both Mr. Atwater and President Bush will have to face the question of whether a new chairman will be needed to handle the party's public duties through the 1992 Presidential campaign. Some names mentioned: Lynn Martin, who seems to be losing her bid to unseat Senator Paul Simon in Illinois, and Robert A. Mosbacher, the Commerce Secretary who is one of Mr. Bush's big fund-raisers. If the change is made, Republicans said, Mr. Atwater would be given a new title.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Oil-Related Inflation Fears Push Gold Prices Up Again

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold prices continued to climb yesterday as the resurgent oil market fanned inflation fears.
But platinum prices dropped sharply, reflecting declining Japanese investor interest and worldwide economic jitters. 
 Gold futures settled $2.30 to $2.40 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange, with the contract for spot delivery at $375.80 a troy ounce, up from $373.50 on Wednesday.
The increase marked gold's sixth daily advance in the last seven sessions, following a plunge to a three-month low of $360 on Oct. 16.
Silver futures settled 1.9 cents to 2 cents lower, with the spot price at $4.204 a troy ounce in lackluster trading on the Commodity Exchange.
Platinum was $6.60 to $8 lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with the spot price at $415.80 a troy ounce.
Analysts said demand for gold had increased as a result of lower prices for the metal and higher prices this week for crude oil, which has bounced back sharply amid intensifying Middle East war rhetoric.
"The war drums were beating today," said William O'Neill, a precious metals expert with Merrill Lynch.
Higher oil prices could portend higher inflation, which typically spurs investor demand for gold.
Higher oil prices also could tip industrialized nations into recession and reduce industrial demand for platinum, which is widely used in automobile pollution-control systems.
James Steel, an oil and metals analyst with Refco Inc., a commodities brokerage, said platinum was also under pressure from lower Japanese stock prices. The Japanese value platinum as an investment and jewelry metal.
In petroleum trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, light, sweet crude oil settled $2 to $3.17 higher, with December at $34.25 a barrel.
Grain and soybean futures prices fell modestly in light trading on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting slack export demand and harvest pressure.
Speculation about possible Soviet purchases of United States corn cooled amid reports from Moscow indicating the Soviets might not make any more purchases to fulfill a one-million-ton corn agreement by the end of the year without United States credit.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Securities Prices Up Slightly

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
With a batch of weak economic data and Congress approaching agreement on a new Federal budget, credit market participants were persuaded to buy Treasury securities yesterday. Another sharp rise in oil prices was all but ignored.
While market participants fully expect the Federal Reserve to ease short-term interest rates once the budget is passed and signed into law, traders yesterday did not provide a ringing endorsement of the pact. Bond prices rose only slightly, and long-term interest rates dipped. 
 Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, has said recently that the Fed will fashion its response to the budget on how the credit markets react to a credible agreement.
The economic reports issued yesterday, which showed a sharp rise in initial unemployment claims for the week ended Oct. 13 and an 8 percent decline in existing home sales in September, helped to lift prices early.
So, too, did a slight dip in a key inflation measure, the Employment Cost Index. The figures, which are compiled quarterly, showed that inflation rose 5.2 percent for the 12 months ended Sept. 30, down from 5.4 percent at the end of the second quarter.
 
Backdrop for Auction
 The figures also provided a positive backdrop for the weekly auction yesterday of three-month and six-month Treasury bills, a sale that had been delayed since Monday by the impasse over the budget.
With a budget agreement apparently in hand, Congress late Wednesday approved another temporary increase in the Federal debt ceiling, which allowed the Treasury to hold the auction.
Abetted by the Federal Reserve, which had some $6 billion from bills that matured yesterday, traders said that demand for the new $17 billion worth of securities was very strong.
At the auction, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.20 percent, up slightly from an average 7.18 percent rate at the last sale on Oct. 15.
Bids on six-month bills produced an average rate of 7.16 percent, down from 7.22 percent at last week's sale. It is the lowest rate on a six-month bill since the auction of Sept. 1, 1988.
"There was a definite appetite for short-term securities," one Treasury bill trader said.
 
Sale of One-Year Bills
 An auction of one-year bills that has been delayed since Oct. 18 will be held today, the Treasury said.
Traders and analysts said they were relieved the struggle over the budget was coming to an end.
But applause for the reported substance of the agreement was muffled.
Though lacking details, analysts said the new budget, which appears to be long on tax increases and short on spending cuts, was likely to be a long-term negative for the fixed-income market.
"The markets are likely to be depressed by the shift toward higher taxes and more spending," said Susan M. Hering, an economist at Salomon Brothers.
"In the 1980's, the problem that caused the deficits was that outlays soared and revenues were static. This budget looks like it will do little to reverse that trend."
Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at CRT Government Securities, said the economic effect of the budget cuts in the current fiscal year, reported to be around $35 billion, would be minimal.
"The effect on the economy in the short run is minor," he said, "because the amount they are talking about is small relative to the total economy."
 
Savings Are Doubted
 Mr. Levy added that would "bet anything" that the $500 billion in budget savings projected over the next five years will never be realized.
Nevertheless, the budget agreement, which still faces a problematic future when it comes to a vote in the House, was enough to spur some buying of Treasury securities yesterday.
In late trading, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 100, up 9/32, to yield 8.75 percent, compared with 8.77 percent late Wednesday.
Among note issues, the 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 29/ 32, up 1/8 point, to yield 8.60 percent. And the 8 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 19/32, up 1/ 32, to yield 7.78 percent.
A number of corporations offered new issues to investors in the investment-grade corporate bond market.
By far the largest issue was a $1.257 billion sale of securities backed by car loans by the Ford Motor Credit Corporation.
The 8 3/4 percent notes, which have an average life of 1.92 years, were priced at $99.28, 1.20 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent two-year notes at the time of pricing.
Goldman, Sachs & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting. The securities are rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In addition, Goldman, Sachs acted as lead manager for an offering of $200 million worth of four-year notes by Associates Corporation of North America.
The 9 percent securities were priced at $99.97 to yield 9.02 percent, 1.08 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent four-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated AA-3 by Moody's and AA-minus by Standard & Poor's.
In other developments, prices of widely held high-yield "junk bonds" moved sharply higher yesterday, traders said, reversing some of the recent sharp declines.
Traders said the gains, which amounted to 2 to 3 points for some issues, were recorded on very thin trading.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, dealers said prices of most issues rose by about 1/4 point, in line with Treasuries.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, prices of widely quoted issues moved up by 3/8 point to 1/2 point, dealers said, pushed higher by clear signs that Federal income taxes are about to be raised.

HEADLINE: Price of Oil Surges by $3.17, Continuing on Erratic Path

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Oil was up sharply yesterday for the second consecutive day, continuing on an erratic path.
Crude for December delivery closed at $34.25 a barrel, up $3.17, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. In trading yesterday and Wednesday, the price of oil was up $4.88, or 16.6 percent, and many traders expect it to go back toward the $40 range. 
 "I don't think there's much point trying to make sense out of the thing," said Ken Miller of the OPEC Listener, an energy newsletter. "It's just more of the same of what's been going on throughout this crisis, just total fluctuation on the latest rumors. You can go through the wire and pick out which one favors your viewpoint."
Yesterday's rumors included one that pushed prices up by about 80 cents in the last few minutes of trading: that American troops had entered Kuwait. Traders also said a story in The International Herald Tribune, quoting an associate of Francois Mitterrand as saying that the French President expects a war, also pushed up prices, despite a denial from French officials later in the day.
Prices were also pushed up by a statement from Dick Cheney, the Defense Secretary, that more troops would be sent to the Persian Gulf and that the United States did not rule out forcibly evicting Iraq.
Clearly the war worries that waned last Friday and Monday were growing again yesterday. At SHB Commodities, Carl A. Cunneff, an oil trader, said, "It's more tension than anything."
Mr. Cunneff said Monday's drop, which came to about 15 percent in oil for November delivery, had overshot the mark. A lot of people who regretted that they had not bought contracts in September and October when the price was lower were lured into the market this week when the price went below $30, he said, and that rush has helped drive prices higher.
Thomas P. Blakeslee of Pegasus Econometric Group said, "The market is hungry for rumors." But he said he doubted that the market would go back to $40 without "some military justification."
"I don't think it has enough steam to reach the high of $41.15 without guns being fired," he said. That price, the peak in trading on the exchange, was reached on Oct. 10.
But Victor S. Yu at Prudential- Bache securities said the market could test its previous high soon.
"The market's undergoing a period when it's trying to figure out what it wants to do," he said.
The factors driving crude pushed product prices even harder; wholesale gasoline for delivery next month was up 8.21 cents a gallon, or about $3.45 a barrel, to 93.60 cents a gallon, and heating oil was up 6.55 cents a gallon, or $2.75 a barrel, to 91.67 cents.
 
Demand for Heating Oil
 Demand for heating oil has been lower than expected lately, perhaps because of unseasonably warm weather in the Northeast and a decision by consumers and dealers who remember last December's cold to stock up early. But inventory figures on gasoline released Tuesday evening showed a substantial drop in inventories, a bullish factor. Some analysts said yesterday that speculators were selling heating oil futures contracts and buying gasoline contracts.
The volatility in prices has caught the attention of consumer advocates. Richard M. Kessel, executive director of the New York State Consumer Protection Board, complained in a letter to the United States Department of Justice that crude prices had fallen $10 from their peak on Oct. 10 but that gasoline and heating oil prices had not; gasoline, in fact, rose 2.4 cents a gallon in New York last week, reaching $1.474, he said, up 32.5 cents since Aug. 3. Home heating oil prices fell a fraction of a penny last week, to to $1.343 a gallon, he said, up 38.8 cents since the beginning of the crisis. Product prices rose immediately when crude prices did in August, he said, and now they should fall immediately.
Oil companies say that the price of gasoline never caught up with crude oil at the peak.

HEADLINE: THE 1990 Campaign;
Races to Watch: An Update

 BODY:

Major races around the nation that polls how to be close or nearly even.
 
CALIFORNIA GOVERNOR
 
No one issue is the central battleground. A debate was canceled last night because the federal budget battle has kept Senator Pet Wilson, the Republican, in Washington. Another debate with Dianne Feinstein, the Democrat, is unlikely, so the main factor in the final days will be a new barrage of television advertising.
 
FLORIDA GOVERNOR
 
Lawton Chiles, a Democratic and former United States Senator, is running an anti-big money, anti-special interest campaign. The incumbent, Bob Martinez, a Republican, is using an expensive television campaign that portrays him as a dynamic governor from humble beginnings who can admit he made mistakes.
 
MASSACHUSETTS GOVERNOR
 
Things are turning nasty. John R. Silber, the Democrat, has accused his Republican opponent, William F. Weld, "back stabbing" for having left the Justice Department to protest the policies and leadership of Edwin Meese 3d. Mr. Weld is calling the Democratic a "Dr. Know-It-All" who is doing nothing bu "spewing venom." The economy remains the key issue. Mr. Weld supports a mandatory cut in taxes; Mr. Silber opposes it.
 
NORTH CAROLINA SENATOR
 
Harvey Gantt, the Democrat, has matched Jesse Helms, the three-term Republican incumbent, in fund raising over the past three months and has managed to do what none of Mr. Helms' other opponents have done - put him on the defensive on issues like education and the environment.
 
TEXAS GOVERNOR
 
The Democrat, Ann Richards, who was behind when she was short on funds, raised enough money to keep her ads on television. Clayton Williams, the Republican, seems to have trouble painting the race as a clear-cut choice between a conservative and a liberal.

HEADLINE: Warts and All, a Budget Victory

 BODY:
It took four months, a Government shutdown and the threat of two more, and the pressure of public disgust to get the job done. But now, finally, Congress is about to approve a credible and fair budget bill that will drive the deficit downward over the next five years.
The bill is full of quirks and half steps. And it makes two glaring errors, on capital gains and public investment. Yet it achieves substantial deficit reduction without hurting the poor or ravaging domestic programs. On balance, it will help the economy and open the way for Congress to get on with other pressing business.
 The quirks and half steps need candid appraisal. The bill promises to cut the deficit by $40 billion next year and $500 billion over five years. It won't. Next year's hit, counting expenditures in the Persian Gulf, will be closer to $30 billion. And the $500 billion estimate is based on improbable projections.
The package would hike the gasoline tax by 5 cents a gallon; a boost of 20 cents or more would conserve energy. The legislation does not eliminate a single weapons system. Entitlements were barely nicked. The ugly tax bubble -- whereby some families are hit with a higher marginal tax rate than other families with higher incomes -- remains.
None of these flaws, however, are fatal. What comes close is the provision concerning capital gains. Wednesday morning, the Bush campaign to lower the tax on the profit from selling stocks, bonds and other investments was declared dead and buried. But by evening a strange, stunted version was back on the docket. For wealthy families, the budget conferees would lower the capital gains tax to 28 percent, even though ordinary income would be taxed at 31 percent.
Why? No serious economist would argue that a cut this small could raise national saving, investment and growth. Its only purpose would be to hand wealthy families windfall profits on past investments. At a time when everyone else will be paying higher taxes, this provision is unconscionable.
The other unforgivable provision is a three-year cap on discretionary domestic programs. A provision that would require Congress to pay for new spending by raising taxes or cutting programs would make sense. But the budget bill veers irresponsibly in another direction. It would forbid Congress from spending more on child nutrition even if it would decide to spend less on missiles. In short, the bill would prevent Congress from doing what it is elected to do: make choices.
Despite these provisions, the budget deal makes subtantial progress. Over the next five years, it will push the deficit down decisively, and this time the budget cuts are real. Gone are the one-shot tricks and accounting scams Congress has routinely used in the past.
Six months ago, the agriculture committees were figuring out how to raise farm subsidies; the budget package will cut them by a whopping 25 percent. Well-to-do families will pay more for Medicare, setting a constructive precedent. And the package denies Mr. Bush his destructive proposal to cut the capital gains tax all the way to 15 percent.
For all the public disgust over dissembling and delay, Congress labored to make the budget package fair. It succeeded. Taxes on the poor will fall. Taxes on the very rich will rise by more than 6 percent. Everyone else will face a modest tax increase of roughly 2 percent.
Perhaps the finest part of the package is a decision to heap tax benefits on a segment of the population that hires no lobbyists: the working poor. Congress is prepared to approve an unprecedented increase in tax credits for poor parents who work as a way of helping them pay for quality child care and insulating them from excise tax increases.
The process wasn't noble. The product isn't exactly pretty. But, with the exception of two glaring flaws, Congress has done its duty.

HEADLINE: Financial World Will Give New York City Time for a Good Plan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
After Mayor David N. Dinkins reached a settlement with the United Federation of Teachers, outlined an omnibus criminal-justice program, imposed an immediate hiring freeze and instructed New York City agencies to propose options to cut spending by up to $800 million for the Nov. 8 modification of our financial plan, you argue ("New York's Fears Won't Wait," editorial, Oct. 10) that Nov. 8 is too long to wait for a plan that protects the city's financial stability.
"What makes City Hall think a worried financial world will wait?" you ask.
Consider the views of members of that financial world. Both Moody's and Standard & Poor's have said it is reasonable for the city to be given until Nov. 8. The private members of the Financial Control Board agree.
You believe we should put all negotiations with municipal unions on hold until fiscal concerns are addressed. But if we achieve satisfactory settlements, doesn't it make sense to conclude those agreements before Nov. 8? That insures that the modification is as full and accurate an accounting of our fiscal position as possible.
This is not a planner's esoteric exercise. The city must enter the credit markets in November to meet its cash flow requirements to pay employees' wages and for services rendered by contractors. Before it does, doesn't it make sense to have as credible a financial plan as possible?
Uncertainty might ultimately reduce our access to the market and, even worse, spark a resumption of the Financial Control Board in running the city's fiscal affairs. Having sacrificed so much to restore New York's fiscal independence, we should avoid any steps that might cause us to lose it.
"The surest way for Mr. Dinkins to restore confidence in his administration and in the city," you argue, "is to present a financial plan quickly." Only, if "quickly" is synonymous with "completely." Which it isn't.
In recent weeks, the Mayor has consulted with private members of the Financial Control Board, with his Council of Economic Advisors, with Standard & Poor's and Moody's, with municipal unions, with the Comptroller, the City Council Speaker and daily with his deputy mayors and budget director. These meetings are proving invaluable as we prepare a complete, credible, achievable and balanced Nov. 8 modification.
You hint such meetings are a waste of time. The Mayor, you argue, should move full steam ahead, not consulting the experts, ignoring those experienced in fiscal crises. That approach runs the great risk that the plan will be seen as a new, unconnected event, triggering a new round of criticism and devastating consequences to the city's well-being.
Were balancing a budget like a horse race, your counsel might make sense. But what wins at the track doesn't necessarily prevail in the financial markets.
 
NORMAN STEISEL
First Deputy Mayor
New York, Oct. 17, 1990

HEADLINE: The Founders Dreamt of a Classless Society;
Grow Up, America

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In writing about the myth of classlessness (Op-Ed, Oct. 10), asserting that much of our governmental structure and purpose is heavily biased in favor of wealth and the well born, Benjamin DeMott exhibits proper liberal outrage but blurred focus. Republican Party adulation for the dollar in the last dozen years has suffered from neither subtlety nor restraint. Questions of fairness and even logic have not been permitted to interfere with conservative orthodoxy. Yes, we have become a very classy society. But where's the myth?
The far larger threat is the direction we have taken, the garden path down which we have increasingly been led, in the manifest and growing immaturity of all of us, leaders and followers, Democrats and Republicans, the United States.
The most interesting example of our immaturity is to be seen in taxation, the necessary lubricant of government. Hundreds of thousands of the new-rich wallow in a largesse created by a genial benefactor, Ronald Reagan, who had more savvy about make-believe and mob psychology than economics. He chopped the top income tax rates of our luckiest or wealthiest from 70 percent to 28 percent. At the same time, he borrowed trillions of dollars from those same
people, as well as from the Japanese and Germans, to pay for the monstrous, quickly ballooning, deficits.
With an ever-growing population in this country, with the almost ceaseless toll of inflation and with ever-developing social needs, taxes must increase. We cannot avoid or repeal that reality. But we must, too, accept that the need for hope in our ghettos and homes for our homeless exceeds the need for greed of the most fortunate among us.
George Bush quibbles about whether top tax rates should be raised from 28 percent to 31 percent or 33 percent, while he expresses no concern for increasing the tax burden of the couple struggling with an income of $30,000 or $40,000 a year. Restoring the top rates to the 90 percent they once were might be a bit too much and too sudden. But a return to a rate approaching the pre-Reagan 70 percent, for income exceeding $200,000 or $500,000, could signal a return to fairness and adult responsibility. With those rates we once were the economic world leader, before Ronald Reagan (with the compliance of the Democrats and a supine Congress) gave away the store.
 
WALTER HEWITT
Vincentown, N.J., Oct. 12, 1990

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Unisys Had Big Deficit In 3d Quarter

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
Citing "the pronounced softness of demand in the worldwide computer industry," the Unisys Corporation yesterday reported a third-quarter deficit of $356.8 million. The troubled computer maker also said it would eliminate 5,000 jobs.
The company, based in Blue Bell, Pa., said a fourth-quarter loss was now very possible, contrary to its recent expectations. 
The deficit for the quarter ended Sept. 30, included a $181 million charge to cover the cost of the reductions.
 "Given this difficult business environment, we are sizing our operations on the assumption that order activity will continue to be weak," said James A. Unruh, the company's president and chief executive who yesterday added the additional title of chairman.
 W. Michael Blumenthal resigned from the non-executive post in order to spend more time at the Paris headquarters of Lazard Freres & Company's international group. Mr. Blumental, who retired as the Unisys chief executive in April, is a limited partner in the investment banking firm and co-chairman of its international coordinating group.
 
$200 Million Savings Seen
 Mr. Unruh said the job cuts and other stringent cost control actions would save the company more than $200 million a year.
 Unisys stock fell 12.5 cents yesterday, to $3.375, down from a 52-week high of $17.125 in March.
 In the third quarter a year ago, the company reported a loss of $648.2 million. The 1989 third quarter included a $231 million restructuring charge to cover the cost of eliminating 8,000 jobs. At the end of 1989 the company had 82,300 employees, according to the company's annual report.
 Revenue for the third quarter was $2.4 billion, compared with $2.35 billion a year ago.
 Mr. Unruh attributed the third-quarter loss to a weakening of general business conditions and a slump in worldwide computer sales. "Order growth in the United States continues to be weak and orders have slowed significantly in Europe in recent weaks," he said.
 Unisys said the weak economy would hamper its efforts to reduce its $2.59 billion in long-term debt. The company had said it planned to reduce its debt by $600 million to $800 million this year, but Mr. Unruh said yesterday that that would be difficult, but not impossible.
 The company has hired Lazard Freres and another investment banker, James D. Wolfensohn Inc., to sell assets to reduce debt.
 It has been a difficult fall for Unisys, which was created in 1986 by the combination of the Burroughs Corporation and the Sperry Corporation. In September, the company's board voted to omit the 25-cent-a-share quarterly dividend in a move intended to save the company $160 million a year. Earlier this month, Moody's Investors Service downgraded its rating of the Unisys debt to below investment grade.

HEADLINE: Anti-Florio Fever Is Giving A Headache to a Democrat

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMDEN, N.J.

 BODY:
By many traditional political measures, Rob Andrews ought to be running away in the race for the First Congressional District seat.
He has been campaigning virtually nonstop for more than a year, while his opponent, Dan Mangini, took time off from work only this month to campaign full time. Mr. Andrews is the Democrat in a heavily Democratic district, and he has raised more than $300,000, to Mr. Mangini's $30,000. 
 The 32-year-old Mr. Andrews spits out answers on issues like a computer; Mr. Mangini, who is 57, called in an issues adviser from Washington a couple of weeks ago, and his position on the emotional issue of abortion seems to be all over the place.
And finally, Mr. Mangini has a "resume problem": he claims to have studied at aninstitution that has no record of him. Yet Rob Andrews is running hard, and he admits, "I'm running scared."
The reason is voters like Mary Natale, who stopped to talk with Mr. Mangini as he shook hands in a shopping center in Woodbury.
 
A Man in Trenton
 "Florio did us in good," said Mrs. Natale, who voted for Jim Florio for Governor last year. "I'm ashamed of myself. He was not going to raise taxes. And he was not even in office before he knew what he was going to do."
Mr. Mangini encouraged her. "You were lied to, you see."
"He made fools of us!" Mrs. Natale said with some heat.
"You send them a message," Mr. Mangini said. "Put me in office. I'm the opposite party."
Mr. Florio represented the First District for 16 years, and he was enormously popular. But that ended when he became governor and, having said in his campaign that no new taxes were necessary, promptly rammed through a $2.8 billion tax increase.
"Jim Florio doesn't have a tax problem; he has a credibility problem," concedes Mr. Andrews, who is perceived as Mr. Florio's hand-picked successor. "Jim Florio in the First District was thought of as somebody different, somebody you could trust. Now, the thought is, we got duped."
Mr. Mangini, a Gloucester County Freeholder who agreed to run for the seat only when assured he would have no Republican primary opposition, seemed unprepared three weeks ago when a poll commissioned by the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee early this month showed him virtually even with Mr. Andrews, the odds-on favorite. The poll showed the main reason to be voter resentment of the Florio tax increase.
Mr. Mangini acknowledged at a news conference called to announce the poll results that an adviser was coming up from Washington to brief him on issues. Now he loses no opportunity to refer to his opponent as "a Florio clone." And the issue, he says, is "taxes, taxes, taxes."
"The guy's not running for Congress," Mr. Andrews said. "He's running on a protest vote."
 
Mangini Has Problems, Too
 "For obvious reasons," Mr. Andrews said in an interview, "we want the race to focus on me and on my opponent, and not on Florio. Even if Florio were exceedingly popular and we brought him in to campaign, the perception would be, 'He's Jim's caddy; he's Jim's understudy.' People want their own man."
Since the poll, Mr. Mangini has run into some political problems of his own.
On his resume, he has for years stated that he attended Drexel University, but the school has no record of his attendance. Mr. Mangini has conceded that he was never enrolled as a student.
In an interview, Mr. Mangini, who works for Glencoe Star, a commercial refrigeration manufacturer in Philadelphia, said, "I worked for General Electric when I got out of high school, and our training was we went to school a couple of hours a week, and we were told what we were taught there was the same as being at Drexel."
"What happened was I quit there, some kind of difficulties with the boss, and I guess they never transferred it over. I never questioned it for 38 years."
 
Approval Withdrawn
 Mr. Andrews, a lawyer who is a summa cum laude graduate of Bucknell and a magna cum laude graduate of Cornell Law School, says, "The first responsibility of a candidate is to tell the truth."
Mr. Mangini has also had some trouble with the abortion issue, first identifying himself as "pro-choice" but later saying that he did not favor allowing abortion after the first trimester under any circumstances.
The Women's Political Caucus of New Jersey, which had intially approved the positions of both candidates on abortion, last week withdrew its endorsement of Mr. Mangini and now supports only Mr. Andrews, who fully supports the Supreme Court's Roe v. Wade decision on abortion, which allows abortions after the first three months with some restrictions.
"Mangini is not pro-choice, he's multiple choice," Mr. Andrews said.
Both candidates say the economy is the major issue and that New Jersey is in a recession. Mr. Andrews pledges not to vote for any tax increase in his first term and to return to voters with his position before the next election. Mr. Mangini says he would oppose any tax increase while in office, except for a major emergency like war.
Mr. Mangini would bring most United States troops home from aboad, while Mr. Andrews would ask host countries to pay for them.
Both candidates say the Florio tax increase is a state issue, but Mr. Mangini says it should be rolled back, while Mr. Andrews opposes the sales tax increase but supports the income tax increase on wealthier taxpayers to provide property tax relief.

HEADLINE: Rally in Oil Is Short-Lived; Crude Closes $1.24 Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Oil prices seesawed on the futures market yesterday, closing more than $1 a barrel lower after a rally based on war fears ran out of steam and traders began to sell.
"They've taken it all over the place," said Thomas P. Blakeslee, an energy analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J. "The market is so hungry for news, and without the rumors and news it's come off slightly." 
 Crude oil fell $1.24 a barrel, to $33.01, for December delivery contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Oil had traded as high as $35.40 a barrel yesterday before the selloff began.
 
 Other Contracts Fall
 Contracts for delivery in later months all closed lower after they also retreated from previous gains.
Oil began the day by moving up about $1 as speculators again bet that war was likely in the Persian Gulf. Crude then began to tumble on hints of possible diplomatic solutions.
Traders were responding partly to a news report that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq sent a conciliatory letter to President Francois Mitterrand of France, although French officials said they had no knowledge of such a letter.
The market was also moved by news of Soviet diplomatic efforts in the Mideast.
Prices also declined as many traders expressed reluctance to hold too many oil contracts over the weekend. Fresh in their minds was the record plunge of $5.41 a barrel on Monday, the last day of trading for the November contract.
After that tumble, oil rebounded strongly with gains of $1.71 on Wednesday and $3.17 on Thursday. But for the week, crude was down 78 cents for next-month delivery.
 
 Refined Products Also Seesaw
 As crude prices shot up and then tumbled yesterday, futures contracts for refined petroleum products moved in a similar pattern.
Wholesale home heating oil closed down 3.42 cents, at 88.25 cents a gallon, for November delivery contracts, with most later contract months moving lower. For the week, heating oil dropped 0.15 cent.
November contracts for wholesale unleaded gasoline fell 2.13 cents a gallon, to 91.47 cents, with most other delivery months trading lower. For the week, gasoline was up 3.56 cents.
Oil's big swings seemed to be coming closer together, analysts said, sending the market further in less time than it had been moving in recent weeks.
"The volatility's been extremely high," said William Byers, an analyst with Bear, Stearns & Company. "There is some sense that time is running out on the situation. Whether that's a correct perception, I don't know."
Many traders have asserted that any military action against Iraq is likely to occur shortly before or shortly after the United States elections, which are less than two weeks away, Mr. Byers said.
Mr. Blakeslee of Pegasus said the wild swings had occurred on light volume, as small traders felt the need to make trades quickly based on news developments and rumors.
"The market will move very quickly on their panicking -- if you want to call it that -- or buying," he said. "Someone with deep pockets will withstand these moves."

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Baker Visiting Saudis Soon To Coordinate Next Steps

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
The White House said tonight that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d would soon go to Saudi Arabia to coordinate with the Saudis on the next steps toward resolving the Persian Gulf crisis.
Speaking to reporters in Los Angeles, where President Bush was on an election campaign swing, the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said the visit would involve "a general discussion of the situation in the gulf." 
 The Baker trip is expected to begin late next week. His visit, coupled with the decision to send as many as 100,000 more American troops to the Persian Gulf and to add hundreds of advanced tanks to the American force there, suggest that the Bush Administration has determined that it needs to make its threat of force against Baghdad more credible.
 
Actions Speaking Louder
 Judging from what Washington is doing, more than from what it is saying, it appears that after several weeks of relying on sanctions and diplomacy alone to move Baghdad, the Administration has concluded that a more threatening posture is needed.
Relying on diplomacy alone has led to a loss of momentum, has invited President Hussein to believe that he might be able to split the coalition by freeing some hostages, like the French, has encouraged some Saudi officials to put out compromise feelers to Baghdad and has undermined Washington's coercive diplomatic approach.
The approach is designed to drive President Hussein to an unconditional withdrawal by convincing him that if he stays in Kuwait he will face a war and lose.
The White House said today that President Bush telephoned President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and King Fahd of Saudi Arabia on Thursday to discuss developments in the region. Late on Thursday, Congress approved the President's request to forgive Egypt's $7.5 billion military debt.
Administration officials said the call to King Fahd was to thank him for his unambiguous statements in the last week, which, in contrast to those of the Saudi Defense Minister, Prince Sultan, made it unambiguously clear that Saudi Arabia still insists on an unconditional Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. Officials said the President emphasized to the Saudi King that it was important that the countries speaking in one voice.
 
No Final Plans
 Earlier in the day, as the State Department refused to confirm the Baker trip publicly, officials said privately that a trip to Saudi Arabia, Egypt and London with other stops was likely, but that the itinerary had not yet been made final for two reasons.
First, the White House has not decided what Mr. Baker's message to the allies should be. Will he simply go out to bolster the coalition, or will he go out to line up their backing for a military operation or other steps against Baghdad? The question, officials say, has not yet been resolved.
The Baker trip "should tell us which way the Administration is heading," one Arab diplomat said.
The other, less important, reason that the itinerary has not yet been made final is because at the moment Israel is not on the tentative schedule, Administration officials are concerned about potential negative domestic political consequences of yet another Baker visit to the Middle East that would not take in Israel.
Mr. Baker traveled to Saudi Arabia, Syria, Egypt and the United Arab Emirates in September, but did not stop in Israel, where he is yet to visit.
Administration officials said Mr. Baker would consider a stop in Israel if the Israeli Government could find a way to resolve the dispute with the United Nations Security Council, which has asked Israel to cooperate with an investigation of the killing of 21 Palestinians at Al Aksa Mosque in Jerusalem on Oct. 8. Israel has refused.
Israeli and American officials say they believe a Baker visit to clear the air between them could be useful now, but only if it comes in the context of a resolution of Israel's differences with the United Nations. Otherwise, officials fear, a visit could make things worse. Washington joined other Security Council members in condemning Israel this week for not accepting the United Nations mission.
In another matter relating to the gulf crisis, Richard A. Boucher, a State Department spokesman, said today that the Bush Administration believed Jordan was complying fully with the sanctions against Iraq and deserved Western assistance for its ailing economy.

HEADLINE: THE STRUGGLE IN CONGRESS;
Major Legislation Moves Ahead in Both Houses of Congress

 BODY:

Clean Air
The House approved a House-Senate-White House agreement to amend the air pollution law for the first time in 13 years. The action is widely considered to be one of the major achievements of the 101st Congress.
It makes important changes in regulations of emissions of chemicals into the air by factories, electric utilities, automobiles and other sources of pollution. Economists estimated the cost to industry and individuals at $25 billion to $35 billion a year.
 
Military Budget
 The Senate passed a House-Senate agreement to set military spending at $268 billion, $17 billion less than last year. Only $3 billion of the $35 billion in research and development goes to the "Star Wars" anti-missile system, the lowest level of spending on it in several years.
The Senate is also set to take up a military authorization bill setting broad policy guidelines and allowing $288 billion in programs, including some money to be spent in later years.
The Stealth bomber program continues, but at sharply reduced levels. The Pentagon is directed to spend more on fast ships and heavy cargo planes for deployments like the one in the Arabian Peninsula. The measures would allow money to be spent that had been contributed by foreign nations for the Arabian operations.
 
Money Laundering
 The House passed by voice vote an anti-money-laundering measure that passed the Senate earlier.
It permits Federal agencies to revoke charters of banks and other financial institutions in which an employee is found guilty of obscuring the source of money.
The Treasury Department will complete guidelines by Feb. 15 on discouraging money laundering by electronic transfer. A study will be performed on whether bar codes on paper money can help track narcotics transactions.
 
Food Labeling
 The House, on a voice vote, adopted the Senate version of the Nutrition Labeling and Education Act, which curtails disease-prevention claims on food packages and requires more nutrition information for virtually all grocery foods.
 
Foreign Aid
 House and Senate negotiators agreed on $15.5 billion in foreign aid, allowing the Administration to forgive Egypt's $6.7 billion military debt, in exchange for Egypt's joining in the buildup in Saudi Arabia.
But military aid to El Salvador would be cut in half, to $42 million, in a blow to Central America policies.
In a break from past practice, a set sum is not earmarked for Pakistan, usually the third-largest recipient of military assistance. The United States has expressed concerns over nuclear weapons in Pakistan.
Cash military and economic aid of $3 billion is given to Israel , and $700 million worth of military equipment would be transferred from American stockpiles. Egypt gets $2.1 billion of cash aid.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
U.N. Council Appears Close to Accord on a Tougher Stance Against Iraq

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 26

 BODY:
The United Nations Security Council appeared close to agreement tonight on a new resolution declaring Iraq responsible for financial losses caused by its invasion of Kuwait and ordering governments to present evidence of war crimes committed by its forces there, diplomats involved in the negotiations said.
This new resolution, designed to increase pressure on President Saddam Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait and focus world attention on the gulf crisis again, threatens Iraq with further punitive mesures if it refuses to obey. But it also asks the Secretary General of the United Nations to make another effort to find a peaceful solution. 
 The emerging agreement, confirmed by American, Cuban and Malaysian diplomats, is expected to reassert the Security Council's unity in the crisis by bridging a potentially serious split that had developed between some of its 15 members.
Led by the United States and Britain, the five permanent Council members with veto powers wanted a tough new resolution calling on all countries to draw up financial claims against Iraq and collect evidence of human rights violations. The three other permanent members with veto powers are the Soviet Union, France and China.
But four of the nonaligned members -- Columbia, Cuba, Malaysia and Yemen -- favored a more moderate approach, a resolution merely asking the Secretary General to use his "good offices" to promote "a peaceful solution" to the gulf crisis. The final compromise is expected to combine both approaches, diplomats said.
 
Negotiating Through the Night
 In addition, the new omnibus resolution demands an end to all hostage-taking, pillaging and looting by Iraqi forces in Kuwait. And it says that Baghdad must resupply the handful of foreign embassies still holding out there with food and water. If Iraq fails to comply, the Council threatens "further enforcement mesures under the Charter."
Western diplomats say this can only mean a resolution invoking Article 42 of the Charter, which allows the Council to enforce its decisions by military might if it believes economic sanctions have failed.
Article 41, under which the Council has already imposed such sanctions on Iraq, also allows it to sever all telecommunication links with an offending country as well as diplomatic relations. But Council members say they do not want to do this.
The emerging agreement follows prolonged negotiations lasting throughout Thursday night and all of today. The Council's other nonaligned members -- Ethiopia, Ivory Coast and Zaire -- have supported the tougher permanent members' draft all along, as have the three other northern rotating members, Canada, Finland and Romania.
The United States is seeking quick approval of its resolution tonight so it can refocus the Council's attthe on the gulf crisis after the two resolutions it approved earlier this month criticizing Israel over the killing of 21 Palestinians in Jerusalem on Oct. 8.
 
Speedy Action Sought
 Another reason for acting speedily, diplomats say, is to keep the debate over the new gulf resolution from running into next week, when it might become intertwined with discussion of a report the Secretary General is to present on ways of safeguarding Palestinians against further Israeli violence in the occupied territories.
The four dissidents include the Council's only two predominantly Muslim members and its two Latin American members. They argued that President Hussein may now be willing to compromise over Kuwait and that the Council should therefore give priority to seeking a negotiated solution.
The five permanent members disagreed, saying that adopting a mild resolution now that does not put additional pressure on Baghdad will only encourage President Hussein to believe the international coalition against him is crumbling.
Although they already have the nine votes needed to pass their resolution, the five are also striving to keep the Security Council as unified as possible in its approach to the gulf crisis.
