HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
KEEP TO HARD LINE, SAUDI KING ORDERS

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Oct. 26

 BODY:
King Fahd of Saudi Arabia has ordered an end to further conciliatory-sounding remarks to Iraq like those made early this week by his brother, the Saudi Defense Minister.
Apparently seeking to stop speculation about a possible shift in the Saudi position, King Fahd signaled a more hawkish stand on the Persian Gulf crisis when he issued an unusually harsh statement Wednesday night in which he said there could be no compromise in the demand for total Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. 
 The remarks by the King, who has made few such substantive comments since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, had the effect of banning any dissenting views from public discussion here. His intervention was apparently prompted in part by concern expressed by Washington about comments from Saudi Arabia suggesting less than complete adherence to the anti-Iraqi coalition's demand for a total Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait.
King Fahd's statement outlined principles for a settlement with Iraq including the pullout from Kuwait, the return of the Kuwaiti Government that was deposed in the invasion, the withdrawal of Iraqi troops from positions near Saudi borders and guarantees that no future aggression by the "ruler of Iraq" would be carried out against any gulf nation.
 
Defense Minister's Remarks
 On Sunday, the Defense Minister, Prince Sultan, answering a question from a journalist, said, "Saudi Arabia has said, and says now, that giving rights, including territorial brotherly concessions -- given willingly -- is a matter of pride for the Arab nation."
He later issued several statements clarifying his remarks and saying they had been misinterpreted. Although he stressed that any negotiations could not begin before an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, he apparently failed to put to rest suspicions of weakening Saudi resolve.
King Fahd, in his statement Wednesday, stressed that Saudi demands for an Iraqi withdrawal "are not subject to bargaining or misinterpretations" and that "any understandings or predictions that fall outside those clear parameters" emanating from any individuals "or are yet to be uttered in the future" are "untrue and should be paid no attention at all."
The King's comments were followed by many comments from various senior officials and a stream of editorials in the semi-official Saudi press that used language so aggressive that they caused Saudis as well as foreign diplomats here to speculate on when, not if, war with Iraq would begin.
Departing from the usually ambiguous phraseology that characterizes most Saudi pronouncements, the King's statement affirmed in clear language Saudi Arabia's determination that "invading Iraqi troops must withdraw unconditionally and immediately from all Kuwaiti territory, where the legitimate authority must be reinstituted" in the person of the Emir of Kuwait and the ruling Sabah family.
Saudi officials and newspaper editors said they took the King's statement to mean that any talk of conciliation with Iraq by any of them must end immediately.
"To the degree that there was a debate about various options to resolve the gulf crisis, the King has put an end to it," a Saudi newspaper editor who asked not to be identified said in an interview tonight. "It was a signal to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq not to mistake various appeals for a peaceful withdrawal as a weakness of our resolve to fight him."
Indeed, the King's remarks, which one official described as "practically a countdown to war," appeared intended not only to reassure foreign allies of Saudi Arabia, including the United States and Egypt, about Saudi positions on Iraq, but also to signal to the Saudi people that if war breaks out, hard times may follow.
 
Sharp Change in Tone
 The change in the tone of Saudi public discourse on the gulf crisis over the last several days contrasted sharply with what had been a far more complacent attitude that was dominant over the last few weeks.
Several prominent Saudis as well as ordinary citizens said they had become convinced that a peaceful settlement with Iraq was the Saudi goal and an imperative alternative to what could be widespraed economic dislocation in case of war. In private conversations, these Saudis had started to call upon Kuwait to sacrifice some of its territory for the sake of a settlement.
On Sunday Prince Sultan, who is second in line for the throne, suggested that Kuwait might grant Iraq an outlet on the Persian Gulf in return for its withdrawal from that country. The episode stood out as highly unusual in a country intent on projecting in its policy declarations an image of steady, calm and controlled decision-making.
 
Questions Asked Privately
 While the King's edict has mobilized the Government and semi-official press, it has not stilled questions asked privately by business and other leading Saudi figures about the wisdom of letting matters slip into a war that could be devastating to Saudi institutions, the economy and social welfare.
But in this country, where obedience to the King is paramount, his statement will insure that other public fiures, like Prince Sultan, will refrain from expressing further views on the matter.
In his remarks, disseminated by the official Saudi News Agency in the form of answers to questions, the King outlined four "fixed and unchanged" principles to correct what he described as the "sinful Iraqi aggression upon our sisterly Kuwaiti nation."
He said the points were the condemnation of the Iraqi aggression "and the rejection of all consequent measures" that have resulted from it; the application of resolutions adopted by the Arab summit meeting, the Arab League and the United Nations Security Council; an unconditional Iraqi pullout from Kuwait; the return of Kuwait's legitimate Government, and the "withrawal of all Iraqi troop concentrations on the Saudi borders, accompanied with guarantees that the aggression of the Iraqi ruler will not be repeated against any other gulf nation."
 
Iraq's Allies Denounced
 The Saudi press followed the King's remarks with articles in Thursday's and today's papers strongly criticizing Arab countries allied with Iraq, including a harsh campaign against Yemen, Jordan and the leadership of the Palestine Liberation Organization.
In a typical comment directed at Jordan, the daily Al Riyadh in a front-page editorial today said that Jordan had never contributed much to the Arab nation, whether it knew which course to take or "continued to flounder as it is now."

HEADLINE: ACCORD REACHED ON RIDDING SKIES OF NOISY PLANES

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
After nearly a week of intense negotiations, Congressional leaders and the Administration agreed today on major legislation that would eliminate most of the airlines' noisier passenger jets from the nation's skies by the turn of the century.
In return for quieter airplanes, the agreement would restrict the ability of most cities and towns to impose noise regulations of their own. And local governments could impose arrival and departure fees on passengers and use the money for expansions and improvements at local airports. 
 The agreement will be attached to the broad budget measure that is being presented to Congress,said Representative James L. Oberstar, Democrat of Minnesota, the House's principal negotiator on the issue.
 
New National Policy
 "The policy issues have been decided," Mr. Oberstar said. Staff members of the House, the Senate and the Department of Transportation were told to write the provision immediately so it could be adopted this weekend, before the Congress adjourns.
Mr. Oberstar and Senator Wendell K. Ford, a Kentucky Democrat, agreed late in the day to establish the national policy on airport noise. The agreement would protect existing local anti-noise regulations, and a few airports that were in the middle of imposing new rules would be allowed to do so. But for most communities, new regulations will have to be negotiated with the airports and airlines, and the Federal Government will arbitrate any disputes.
Unlike previous versions of the legislation, the agreement reached today would not increase the number of daily flights allowed at La Guardia Airport in New York.
The new noise regulations would not require that any particular models of airliners be taken out of service, since most jets can be modified to make them quieter.
There has been an increasing trend in which local airports have established their own noise policies, like banning flights by noisy aircraft, especially at night. The new law would seek a uniform Federal policy, one that would also encourage better planning by local officials of land use around airports.
The Secretary of Transportation, Samuel K. Skinner, who has called for both a national noise policy and a system of local passenger fees, was actively involved in negotiations with the Mr. Ford and Mr. Oberstar by telephone all afternoon.
At the end of the day, Mr. Skinner said that passage of the compromise would accomplish his most important objectives for aviation in the current legislative session.
 
Dealing With 3 Major Issues
 "It is the most comprehensive piece of aviation legislation since deregulation," he said. "It deals with three very prominent issues: capacity and congestion and environmental noise."
Among the interested parties that have lobbied all sides frenetically since last weekend are the airlines, which will have to spend billions of dollars to comply with any new noise regulations; the nation's biggest airports, which will be able to borrow billions of dollars on the strength of expected collections of fees from passengers; and residents of communities surrounding the airports, who wanted the Federal noise limits in the law to be as tough as possible, because local communities would have a hard time imposing tougher ones under the new law.
As important as the noise provisions, and likely to be noticed by passengers before quieter air traffic is noticed in communities near airports, are the new provisions for local airport fees.
 
$1 Billion for Airports
 Mr. Skinner said the availability of those fees "puts over a billion dollars a year into enhancing capacity and airports all over the country."
During the negotiations, Senator Ford accepted the House's formulas for how the passenger fees would be imposed. The fees, of up to $3 at any given airport, could amount to up to $12 on a round-trip ticket if the trip involved connections along the way. The charge would appear on the passenger's ticket, and the money would be controlled by the local airport, not the Federal Government.
Partly because airline passengers already pay a Federal ticket tax of 8 percent, which would be increased to 10 percent under the new budget proposals, local communities in the past have been prohibited from raising money from travelers.
The most difficult part of the negotiations dealt with how to phase in the replacement of noisier planes that are now in service. The agreement says that these planes must be replaced with new, quieter jets on a schedule that will retire at least 85 percent of them by July 1999, and the rest of them a few years later.
Airlines with financial problems will be given the most leeway in how quickly to replace their fleets.
Mr. Oberstar said that of the nation's commercial fleet of 4,800 airliners, some 2,350 are the noisier variety, known as Stage 2 because they replaced even louder planes in the 1970's. About half these will be replaced by quieter Stage 3 aircraft by the end of the 1990's he said.
 
Quieter Craft On Order
 He estimated that the nation's airlines had already ordered $150 billion worth of Stage 3 airplanes, and would order another $50 billion. One purpose of the law is to assure that the airlines do not face new local restrictions on these quieter aircraft after they are bought.
The Transportation Department estimated today that despite the high cost of new airplanes, the economic burden on the industry would be slight, because many planes could be fitted with "hush kits," at an estimated total cost of $870 million. Based on current travel projections, the department said, the cost of those modifications per passenger during the 1990's would amount to less than 25 cents.
The department estimated that three million people now live in areas around airports where noise is a serious problem. It said this number could be reduced to about one million by the year 2000.
Foreign airliners will be required to meet the same noise standards as American aircraft when flying in the United States.
"We have done a pretty decent job," said Mr. Ford, who took the first step in working out the compromise when the Senate Commerce Committee's aviation subcommittee, of which he is chairman, drafted the broad outlines of the bill and persuaded the full Senate to attach it to the budget bill with very little debate a week ago.

HEADLINE: Dime Posts Loss and Halts Payout

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Dime Savings Bank, one of New York City's most active mortgage lenders in the late 1980's, said yesterday that rising losses on residential real estate loans had led to a loss of $153.6 million in the third quarter and prompted the company to suspend its common stock dividend.
"I am fairly pessimistic about a rebound or recovery for the local economy in the near term," said Richard D. Parsons, the chairman of Dime. As real estate prices fall, he said, the bank suffers larger-than-expected losses when it sells houses and cooperative apartments acquired through foreclosure. 
 The loss in the quarter ended Sept. 30 compared with a profit of $2.1 million, or 9 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter of last year.
Dime's stock fell $1.25 yesterday, or 32 percent, to $2.625 a share. It was the third-largest percentage loser on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Real Estate Investors Default
 Most of Dime's foreclosures have been on one-to-four-family houses and cooperative apartments with mortgages made in 1987 and 1988 when real estate prices were peaking, Mr. Parsons said. Foreclosures have been most common, he said, on properties that were not occupied by their owners but were bought by individuals or partnerships who expected to sell them at a profit.
From 1986 to 1989, Dime made $12 billion of residential mortgage loans in New York, many of them "low-documentation" loans, in which the bank, for competitive reasons, asked buyers for less information about their income and financial condition than banks normally required.
"Dime was a very aggressive competitor, and now they are paying for it," said Peter Treadway, a banking analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham. Because Dime's business is heavily concentrated in the New York area, Mr. Treadway said that it is vulnerable to the ill effects of job cuts by banks and securities firms and the increases in city taxes that have squeezed some homeowners.
Some of Dime's efforts to diversify turned out to be badly timed. Its mortgages in Massachusetts, which accounted for a large part of a $110 million loss in the fourth quarter of 1989, are still causing problems.
Because of rising losses on foreclosed properties, and an increase in delinquent or seriously troubled loans to $857.2 million, from $754 million at mid-year, Dime set aside $167.9 million in a reserve in the third quarter to cover possible losses. About $45.2 million of that amount was for commercial and multi-family real estate and $121.4 million was for loans on co-op apartments and one-to-four-family houses.
Mr. Parsons said that he expected Dime to become profitable again in the fourth quarter but that it would not stop preparing for difficult times. "This is not a time when we should be doing anything other than husbanding our capital," he said.
Dime's capital was cut by a $92.3 million loss in 1989 and will be further reduced by the loss that is certain for all of 1990.
To conserve the $497.5 million of shareholders' capital, which serves as a cushion to absorb future losses, Dime suspended its quarterly dividend of 15 cents a share. Although the institution is in compliance with capital standards set by regulators, Mr. Parsons said he was planning other steps to strengthen Dime's financial condition by reducing its size and cutting expenses. One option, he said, is the sale of some of its 50 offices in New York and 8 in New Jersey.
Before the announcement yesterday, Dime had cut its staff to 2,600, from 3,600, closed all sales offices outside the New York area, and it had adopted tougher loan standards for potential home buyers.

HEADLINE: Default Fears Depress Bank Stocks

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Banking companies continue to be mauled in the financial markets as investors worry about rising losses from real estate lending and the growing risk of defaults on other loans.
Five of the 10 most active stocks on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday were banking companies, and all of them declined. Some of the sharpest drops were for California banks, as some analysts warned that losses on real estate loans in that state will soon begin to rise. 
 At Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, investors continued to demand high dividend rates for variable-rate preferred issues. Preferred stock with a 49-day maturity sold yesterday at 12 percent, down slightly from the 12.5 percent of Wednesday. Citicorp's common stock also fared poorly, falling 50 cents a share, to $11.125, a low for the year.
 
 Manufacturers Drops the Most
The sharpest decline among bank stocks was for the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Corporation, whose stock fell $3 a share, or nearly 18 percent, to $17.
At a meeting with analsyts on Thursday, Peter J. Tobin, the company's chief financial officer, refused to rule out the possibility that the company's common stock dividend might be reduced -- an action widely predicted for weeks. Mr. Tobin said Manufacturers' financial condition was not deteriorating, but noted that the economy was fragile enough to raise questions about the bank's future prospects.
Among California banks, the Security Pacific Corporation's shares fell $1.625 each, to $18.625, and Wells Fargo & Company's stock fell $3.625, to $47.875. First Interstate Bancorp's stock dropped $1.375, to $18.125, and BankAmerica Corporation lost $1.125, to $18.75.
At yesterday's re-marketing of Citicorp's variable-rate preferred stock, an official at Merrill Lynch Money Markets said high dividend rates were starting to attract new kinds of buyers. She said that instead of the corporate treasurers who usually buy variable-rate preferred because the dividend is 85 percent tax-exempt, many new buyers who did not benefit from the tax-exemption were attracted by the dividend rates, which are far higher than they could earn on alternative investments like commercial paper or certificates of deposit.
Merrill Lynch set dividend rates of 12 percent for investors who chose to hold the stock 49 days, and 9.25 percent for investors who chose a 7-day investment period. At the end of 7 or 49 days, investors have the option of accepting new rates for another 7 or 49 days, or selling their stock.
The dividend rates were set at levels that Merrill Lynch officials estimated would attract enough buyers for the more than $100 million of stock that was turned in for sale yesterday.
While Citicorp's 12 percent rate for the 49-day preferred was down from Wednesday, it was far higher than the 6.13 percent paid yesterday by General Electric Capital or the 6.24 percent paid by Ford Holdings, a unit of the Ford Motor Company.

HEADLINE: THE STRUGGLE IN CONGRESS;
U.S. Deficit for 1990 Surged to Near-Record $220.4 Billion, but How Bad Is That?

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Closing the books on 1990, the Treasury Department made it official yesterday: the budget deficit, after dwindling to manageable proportions in the late 1980's, surged to a near-record $220.4 billion in the last fiscal year.
But while the prospect of $200-billion-plus deficits is scaring Congress and the White House into working out a record deficit-reduction package, economists say the huge number suggests more damage to the economy and to the well-being of Americans than has actually occurred. 
 They argue, for example, that the deficit is temporarily overstated because of the savings and loan bailout. What's more, they say, the deficit is still manageable; in fact, not much more of a burden than a $3,000 a month mortgage is to a family earning $85,000 a month. The problem is that the deficit, the mortgage, is rising, and the national income isn't.
Or, as David A. Stockman, former President Ronald Reagan's first budget chief, put it, "The deficit does not cause short-run domestic catastrophy, but over a long enough time it is poison."
 
Trend of Rising Deficits
 The announcement yesterday underscored the trend of a rising deficit in a period of stagnant income. While the $220.4 billion in 1990 barely missed the record of $221.2 billion in 1986, that high-water mark almost certainly will not survive another year.
Even if the budget proposals now before Congress are approved, the deficit for 1991, the current fiscal year, will be at least $250 billion, the Congressional Budget Office estimates. And this at a time when the national income, the Gross National Product, is barely growing because of the weak economy. The G.N.P. is running at about $5.4 trillion this year.
That makes the deficit equal to 4 percent of the G.N.P., roughly the annual average for the 1980's, but well below the 2 percent or less that prevailed from 1950 until 1975, when the deficit suddenly shot up to 3.5 percent of G.N.P. and became a national issue.
Many economists applaud the efforts of Congress and the White House to work out a budget accord that would reduce the deficit by $500 billion, with the goal of once again making it a shrinking percentage of G.N.P. But some economists, like Robert Heilbroner, the economics historian, or Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Prudential-Bache, question whether the day of reckoning will ever arrive.
 
A Skeptical Economist
 "We really don't know how to measure the deficit," Mr. Heilbroner said. "The numbers by themselves don't tell the story and in a world economy, to separate the American balance sheet no longer really works."
The numbers released by the Treasury Department yesterday underscore some of the difficulties. After the deficit fell to $152 billion in 1989, several factors reversed the trend, making the deficit rise by a whopping 45 percent in a single year.
At the head of this list of factors that continue to swell the deficit in 1991, are the weak economy and the savings and loan bailout.
The weak economy held down corporate profits and household incomes, reducing total tax receipts to $1.032 trillion. That was $30 billion less than the Bush Administration had expected to collect, according to Sidney Jones, an Assistant Secretary for Economic Policy at the Treasury Department.
Tax revenues, however, always fall and the deficit rises in periods of economic weakness. In the 1981-1982 recession, the deficit nearly doubled, to 4.1 percent of G.N.P. The problem is that after the 1981-82 recession, four years of robust economic growth passed before the deficit finally again subsided to less than 4 percent of G.N.P.
 
Advent of Huge Expenses
 In the 1950's and 1960's, the Government balance sheet shook off the effects of a recession in only months. But that changed with the 1974-1975 recession. The advent of Medicare and huge increases in Social Security and other entitlement programs more than tripled the deficit as a percentage of G.N.P. in 1975 and it did not subside to a more standard level for nearly four years.
The savings and loan bailout is also becoming a major long-term Federal expense, costing the Government in 1990 $58.1 billion, or 4.6 percent of total outlays of $1.252 trillion, to reimburse people whose bank deposits had disappeared in thrift institutions that failed. Economists argue that rather than being a true expense swelling the deficit, the $58.1 billion is a bookkeeping item -- temporarily borrowing or transferring money from the savings accounts of some Americans to replenish the accounts of others.
Mr. Stockman and others argue that there will be a loss from the bailout some day. The deposits the Government had to replenish were used to finance the construction of white elephant hotels and other ventures that today fail to earn an adequate return on the investment, if they earn anything at all.
The real loss in 1990, then, will not be the $58.1 billion announced yesterday, but only the $4 billion to $6 billion a year that might have been generated if the $58.1 billion had been invested in successful ventures. "There are all sorts of estimates," Mr. Stockman said, "but we don't know yet what the true loss will be from the ill-conceived ventures of the thrifts."
For this reason, some economists would reduce the deficit by the amount of the thrift bailout, in calculating the impact on the economy. In 1990, that would leave a net deficit of $162 billion, which represents a less alarming 3 percent of G.N.P., although in the view of Mr. Jones at Treasury, it is still too much.
"That is why some of us, zealots, believe we have to do something about the deficit," he said.

HEADLINE: THE STRUGGLE IN CONGRESS: Not a Big Tilt In Tax Policy;
Plan Doesn't Revive The Era of Loopholes

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
On first glance, the income tax changes cobbled together in Washington seem an ungainly mix of partly concealed rate increases and new fiddles for the wealthy -- a return to the old days when the only real issue in tax policy was who got soaked, and a thousand and one tax shelters made a mockery of the progressive tax system.
Certainly the language of the debate fit the mold, as Democrats took every opportunity to tar President Bush as a defender of the privileged, and everybody gave short shrift to questions of how tax changes would affect productivity and growth. But surprisingly, that is not the way some tax experts see the result. 
of simplicity, efficiency and equity," said Senator Bill Bradley, the New Jersey Democrat who was the principal architect of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 but who apparently was shut out of the latest negotiations because his colleagues consider him too straight to deal. In Senator Bradley's view, the balance struck in the 1986 tax act has survived largely intact.
 
 Of Brackets and 'Bubbles'
 A gap between taxes on capital gains and other sources of income has indeed been reopened, allowing a little oxygen to permeate the comatose tax shelter industry. And upper-middle-income families will indeed be enveloped in yet another tax "bubble," raising their marginal bracket above the level of the truly rich.
But the resulting economic distortions are not likely to be large, experts say. And the scheduled increase in the alternative minimum tax -- what Joseph Minarik, a senior staff member on the Joint Economic Committee, not so affectionately calls the tax code's "spare tire" -- will make it more difficult for the wealthy to exploit tax gimmicks, new or old.
Rudolph G. Penner, an economist at the Urban Institute, said the thrust of tax changes in the 1980's was to "broaden the definition of income as much as possible in order to lower the tax rate as much as possible." The idea was to collect sufficient revenue to pay for the Government, but to collect it in a way that equalized the burden on families with similar incomes while having the least possible impact on incentives to work, save and invest.
 
 A Bare-Bones Approach
 Pure reforms, like the one proposed in 1983 by Robert Hall of Stanford University and Alvin Rabushka of the Hoover Institution, would have cut the maximum bracket below 20 percent by disallowing deductions for everything from home mortgage interest to fringe benefits to state tax payments. The Hall-Rabushka rules were so simple that the tax form would have fit on a postcard.
The bill actually shepherded through Congress in 1986 by Senator Bradley and Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, was far from pure. Many forms of untaxed income, everything from employee fringe benefits to mortgage-financed housing, remained untaxed. And the revised tax system was hardly simple: those who used the remaining tax preferences spent more time than ever documenting expenses and filling out forms.
But the law was widely regarded as a triumph for tax reform because it did broaden the tax base sufficiently to cut the maximum tax on an extra dollar of income from 50 percent to 33 percent. Moreover, by eliminating the lower rate on capital gains, it reduced a notable source of distortion in investment decisions.
 
 Some Confusion Expected
 The deal struck this week will raise the maximum tax bracket for a family of four by just one percentage point. But because of what Emil Sunley of Deloitte & Touche calls President Bush's "penchant for subterfuge," it will do so in a way that many are likely to find both confusing and unfair.
Under pressure to take a whack at wealthy families who got the lion's share of benefits from the big tax cut of 1981, Congress insisted on raising the top tax rate. But the highest nominal rate President Bush would accept was 31 percent. To raise more revenue at the expense of the affluent, negotiators agreed to limit itemized deductions for families earning more than $100,000 and to phase out personal exemptions for families earning between $150,000 and $275,000.
The itemized-deduction limit is roughly equivalent to a one percentage point surcharge, raising the effective maximum income tax rate to 32 percent. The exemption phase-out offered by the negotiators (but apparently still subject to modification) is equivalent to an extra half-percentage point for each family member -- three percentage points for a family of six. Uncle Sam will thus take roughly 35 cents of the last dollar earned by a family of six reporting an income of, say, $175,000, and just 32 cents of the last dollar earned by a family of six with an income of $400,000.
 
 Assessing the Effects
 The incorporation of this new bubble in marginal tax rates has been widely interpreted as a defeat for tax rationality. But Senator Bradley is not so sure.
Bubbles may be awkward artifacts of a complicated tax system, he argues, but their intent and impact are often benign. The working poor who are eligible for the earned income tax credit, he notes, currently pay 25 cents in tax for every extra dollar earned, while those who are slightly better off pay just 15 percent.
This new bubble, by comparison, opens a gap of just three percentage points in marginal rates -- too little, in the view of most tax analysts, to affect economic incentives very much.
Nor, Senator Bradley argues, does the new bubble do much violence to the equity of the tax system. Large wealthy families will end up paying a bit more tax than small wealthy families with the same income. But the bubble will not interfere with the progressivity of the income tax: the higher a family's income, the higher the percentage of income it will pay out. No taxpayer, moreover, will end up paying more than 31 percent of earnings in income tax.
 
 Worries About a Precedent
 Fans of the 1986 tax changes are less sanguine about the new 28 percent maximum tax rate on capital gains. They fear this concession to President Bush is the nose under the camel's tent -- an invitation to come back next year or the next with a bid for a still lower rate. But they worry less about the plan than the precedent.
For the very richest taxpayers -- the ones who in the past made greatest use of the capital gains preference -- the new capital gains rate will be only three percentage points lower than the marginal rate on other income. And that seems a modest rock on which to build new tax shelters. "A differential this small," Mr. Penner concluded, "shouldn't distort incentives very much."
The negotiators added tax breaks for small insurance companies, energy producers and developers of low-income housing -- breaks that amount to backsliding from the 1986 law. But negotiators also raised the alternative minimum tax to 23 percent, from 21 percent, making it more difficult than ever for the wealthy to use personal deductions to lower their tax burdens below that of the middle class.
On balance, experts believe, it will probably be harder for high-income families to avoid taxation: preliminary Government estimates show that Americans earning more than $200,000 will on average pay about 6 percent more tax, while those with incomes of $20,000 to $200,000 will see their taxes rise about 2 percent.
The resulting redistribution of tax burdens, Mr. Minarik notes, only partly offsets the tilt created by the 1981 tax cuts. But the fact that the negotiators were able to make the tax system more progressive -- as the public apparently wanted -- without significantly undermining its efficiency surely must count as a modest triumph for the spirit of tax reform.

HEADLINE: Loss Shown By Cummins In 3d Quarter

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
The Cummins Engine Company, citing a sharp decline in demand for its truck engines, said yesterday that it had a third-quarter loss of $33.7 million, compared with a loss of $39.7 million in the corresponding quarter last year.
Cummins, the largest independent maker of diesel engines in the world, said that it expected no improvement in the North American heavy-truck market anytime soon and that it planned to continue to reduce its work force. Painting a grim picture of the future, the company said that truck sales could decline by up to 10 percent next year. 
 Cummins, which is based in Columbus, Ind., seemed poised for a turnaround this year after two years of consecutive losses. But the company said yesterday that it expected a loss in the fourth quarter also, and analysts said the company was likely to lose more than $50 million this year.
 
 Sales Up by 2.8 Percent
 Sales in the third quarter were up by 2.8 percent, to $829.8 million from $807.3 million.
Faced with slumping demand, the company said it planned to trim expenses, causing some analysts to wonder if Cummins would be forced to cut its quarterly dividend of 55 cents to save money. Eli S. Lustgarten, an analyst with Paine Webber Inc., said that "one has to realize that the current payout ratio is suspect." However, Ann C. Smith, a Cummins spokewoman, said that "the company has no plans to adjust the dividend."
The company's stock fell $1.125 yesterday, to $37.125 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Cummins earnings report for the quarter ended Sept. 30 included a one-time $22.1 million gain resulting from the repurchase of debt. The company also set aside $18.2 million for the cost of repairing products under its extended warranty program.
In response to weak demand for truck engines, its main product, Cummins is cutting costs and capital spending. In recent months, the company has reduced its worldwide work force by 300 employees. The company said yesterday that it was cutting 210 production jobs in the Columbus area and that additional layoffs were expected in coming months. The company has 25,000 employees.
Cummins recently reduced its Columbus engine assembly plant to one shift and analysts said the plant was running at 50 percent of capacity.
 
Improvement in 1991 Seen
 Steven J. Colbert, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities, said, "I think that they are going to have to do more to cut costs." Cummins told analysts in a conference call that it planned to break even or make a profit in 1991, despite its projection of a continued softening of the truck market.
Analysts agree that it will be difficult for Cummins to achieve profitability in the difficult economic climate. Mr. Lustgarten of Paine Webber said, "It is going to be a real challenge for the company to make money next year."
In July, Cummins, which has fought off two takeover attempts in recent years, sold a 27 percent stake to three friendly investors, the Ford Motor Company, Tenneco Inc. and the Kubota Corporation.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Hoards His $5 Million Fund

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN

 BODY:
After spending $1 million on campaign advertising in the last month, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo still has $5 million available for the last two weeks of his re-election campaign -- and any future campaigns, according to campaign financial reports filed yesterday with the State Board of Elections.
But none of the Cuomo money went to the hard-pressed Democratic candidates for the State Senate, who are borrowing money for the final stages of their effort to win control of the upper house of the Legislature, a campaign in which they have been outspent by the State Senate Republican Campaign Committee by at least 4 to 1. 
 Mr. Cuomo has argued that it would be breaking faith with his contributors to divert his campaign money.
In contrast, the Democratic state committee reported spending $213,000 for postage, polls, advertising and literature, mostly for the State Senate candidates.
Any excess Cuomo funds that fall within the $1,000-per-donor Federal limit on contributions could be used in a Presidential campaign.
The Democratic state chairman, John A. Marino, said an earlier $400,000 transfer from the Cuomo committee for "get out the vote" mailings would "indirectly benefit" the party's State Senate candidates, as well as other Democrats.
 
Abrams Borrows
 For other candidates, fund-raising efforts were considerably more difficult. Attorney General Robert Abrams, one of the top fund-raisers in the state, borrowed $250,000 to maintain his $1.1 million television campaign. He has raised about $1.6 million, well short of the $2.5 million goal he had set.
Mr. Cuomo's Republican opponent, Pierre A. Rinfret, was able to raise only $135,255 in the last three weeks, despite his pressure on Republican county organizations to donate and an unusual 900 telephone number to raise money, in which $3 of each $5 call goes to the Rinfret campaign.
Mr. Rinfret reported $239,307 in unpaid bills, which he said earlier this week he believed he was "morally obligated" to pay himself, although candidates often hide behind their committees and disclaim responsibility for campaign bills.
Herbert London, the Conservative candidate, trailed behind Mr. Rinfret, and although his contributions picked up slightly to $66,1365 in the last three weeks for a total of $182,070, and he did not receive the major infusion of conservative Republican money for which he had hoped.
Politicians in both parties attributed the fund-raising difficulties to a depressed economy and the lack of competitive statewide races except one, the campaign for state comptroller.
 
From Shepherd to Poodle
 In that contest, the Democratic challenger, Carol Bellamy, was competitive in fund-raising with the Republican incumbent, Edward V. Regan. But neither has raised $1 million yet, although their original goals were $2.5 million each.
Ms. Bellamy actually had more cash available for the final push to Election Day and was using it in her first television advertising that attacked her opponent directly, in a commercial using four dogs to depict Mr. Regan's watchdog role.
The commercial starts by showing a German shepherd as watchdog and ends by showing a poodle.
The message was to question whether Mr. Regan was an effective watchdog and to highlight criticism of his fund-raising tactics by the State Government Integrity Commission.
Mr. Regan's media adviser, Maureen R. Connelly, said she was not impressed.
"It looked like a dog food commercial," said Ms. Connelly, adding that Ms. Bellamy "is barking up the wrong tree."

HEADLINE: Daily News: The Combatants

 BODY:

Michael J. Alvino
President, Deliverers Union
 Michael J. Alvi no, 54 years old, the president of the 700-member Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, is not happy about the walkout at The Daily News. "I needed a strike this weekend like a hole in the head," he said the other day. Mr. Alvino has a specific reason, a family wedding in Maine. But his irritation expresses the sentiments of most of the employees at The News who are now out of work.
"This is New York City," Mr. Alvino said. "It's a union town -- and The Daily News right now is attacking our union, bringing in these hired guns from out of town to take jobs away from my men."
Mr. Alvino, who has been president of the drivers union for 16 months, has a reputation for outspokenness. Testifying under immunity at the Federal trial of one of his predecessors, Douglas LaChance, Mr. Alvino readily acknowledged being a conduit for payoffs to Mr. LaChance from News wholesalers who wanted to lay off drivers. Mr. LaChance, the union's president during the 1978 newspaper strike, later was imprisoned for corruption.
But it was Mr. Alvino who brought the drivers into the Allied Printing Trades Council, and the drivers are generally acknowledged to be the most powerful of the 10 unions now battling The Daily News.
 
Charles T. Brumback
President, Tribune Company
 Charles T. Brum back, president and chief execu tive of the Trib une Company, which owns The Daily News in New York and The Chicago Tribune, is an ac countant by training who shuns the spotlight and who made his mark in the Tribune organization as a cost cutter, a decisive manager and a tough man on unions.
"Union leaders vilify him. Newspaper analysts lionize him. Shareholders are going to love him," said a profile in Crain's Chicago Business magazine just before Mr. Brumback, 62 years old, added the title of chief executive on Aug. 1, taking over from Stanton R. Cook, who remains chairman of the Chicago-based company.
Mr. Brumback, who graduated from Princeton in 1950, won a Bronze Star as an Army lieutenant in infantry fighting in Korea. Returning to his hometown of Toledo, Ohio, he studied accounting in graduate school at the University of Toledo while working for Arthur Young & Company. In 1957, he took a job as controller for the Star Sentinel Company in Orlando, Fla. The Tribune Company purchased the newspaper in 1965.
Mr. Brumback turned the Orlando paper into a money maker and caught the eye of Chicago headquarters. He was named chief executive of the Florida company in 1976 and in 1981 was brought to Chicago as head of The Chicago Tribune.
Mr. Brumback succeeded in breaking three unions at The Tribune in a 1985 strike of pressmen, printers and mailers. He was named president of the parent company on Jan. 1, 1989.
 
James Hoge
Publisher, Daily News
 James Hoge, 54 years old, be came publisher of The Daily News in 1984 after a mercurial career in Chicago journalism in which he became city editor of The Chicago Sun-Times at 29, managing editor at 31 and publisher at 44.
He came to The News two years after its parent company, the Tribune Company of Chicago, had nearly closed it and has presided over six years of continuing economic difficulty.
Last year he signaled the newspaper's new tough stance toward its unions by retaining the Nashville law firm of King & Ballow to represent it in talks that Mr. Hoge said could determine the survival of the paper. The law firm has frequently been used by companies looking to break unions or vastly renegotiate their contracts with them.
He called for renegotiations with the paper's 10 unions that would dramatically revamp work rules and overhaul salaries, benefits and other compensation so that the company could save what has been estimated as more than $100 million annually.
Mr. Hoge grew up on Park Avenue and was educated at Phillips Exeter Academy and Yale. He is married to Sharon King Hoge, a former television consumer reporter, and has three children from an earlier marriage. His brother Warren is an assistant managing editor of The Times.
He has been quoted as saying, "I want to be the man who has on his epitaph that he saved The Daily News."
 
Barry F. Lipton
President, Newspaper Guild
 Barry F. Lipton, president of the Newspaper Guild of New York since 1985, rose to power during a period of bitter factionalism and financial difficulties within the union. He was renominated on Thursday night for another two-year term.
Previously an advertising salesman for The New York Times, Mr. Lipton became active in the union as a grievance officer. In 1982, he was elected to the full-time post of secretary-treasurer, which led to the presidency. Mr. Lipton, 48 years old, is separated and has one son, and lives in East Hills, L.I.
His local has about 5,500 members working at 33 newspapers and magazines in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. The guild's jurisdiction is broad, covering most white-collar jobs, including those in the news, advertising, circulation and business departments.
Mr. Lipton has encouraged cooperation with leaders of unions in the industry that represent various production and delivery departments. Relations between such unions in the past were sometimes characterized by rivalry, at times including crossing each other's picket lines.

HEADLINE: Turning Profits Hand Over Wrist

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Social scientists have long puzzled over fads, those brief, extraordinarily popular obsessions with peculiar objects and clothing. They have pondered their causes in late 20th-century America and their meaning for Western civilization.
But Tara Murtha is not puzzled. The 10-year-old likes the latest fad because it lets her do a neat trick with her big toe. 
 Her father, Eugene Murtha, is behind the latest craze among the schoolyard set. As president of the Main Street Toy Company, he makes and markets Slap Wraps, a long, thin piece of fabric-covered steel that curves into a bracelet when slapped around the wrist or ankle. It is basically a Venetian blind with an attitude. In the last three months alone, Main Street Toy has sold more than a million Slap Wraps, all of them by word of mouth.
 
 Short-Lived Craze Expected
 Like other crazes in the toy business, slap bracelets are almost certainly doomed to a short life. But Main Street Toy, based in Simsbury, Conn., is led by experienced executives from Coleco Industries, the marketer of Cabbage Patch dolls, which is now bankrupt. They say they learned lessons from Coleco's mistakes about managing windfall profits from selling to 10-year-olds, like keeping corporate overhead lean. Meanwhile, they ride the rocket.
Last November, when her father showed her a prototype Slap Wrap, Tara went crazy over it, endlessly snapping it around her wrist. Her coolest trick was to balance one on her big toe, flip it into the air, and let it fall onto her ankle with a giggle-provoking snap.
Under the perplexed gaze of adults, millions of Taras are slapping the metal slats on their limbs. Main Street says it has orders for five million of the bracelets, which sell for about $1.30 wholesale, or about $2.50 retail in Toys "R" Us, Kay Bees and other toy stores.
And like other companies with a hot toy, Main Street has found itself watching helplessly as competitors cash in on the frenzy. Main Street estimates that other companies have sold another 10 million to 15 million cheap and sometimes shoddy imitations for as little as 70 cents each. Some Federal and state regulators, schools and parents have acted to stem the tide of the bracelets, concentrating on the knockoffs, which have been blamed for causing some minor injuries to children.
Main Street, whose sales may have benefited from negative publicity about the imitators, says it is planning legal action against the competitors for trademark infringement.
Although in business just two years, Main Street Toy knows a lot about the vagaries of the toy field. The 10-person company is led by five refugees from Coleco, once based in nearby West Hartford, Conn. At its peak in 1985, Coleco had sales of $776 million, mostly from Cabbage Patch dolls and an ill-fated personal computer called Adam. Coleco filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in 1988 after children started relegating its products to the toy graveyard next to Hula Hoops and Teddy Ruxpin.
Main Street was founded by Mr. Murtha, 39, a former vice president for marketing at Coleco, where he helped sell the games Scrabble, Parcheesi and Trivial Pursuit -- products that Coleco had obtained through its purchase of Selchow & Righter. He also held senior positions at toy companies like Fisher-Price, the General Mills toy group and Milton Bradley. He recruited to his fledgling concern senior Coleco officials with skills in order processing, accounting and marketing.
"Slap Wraps is interesting because it shows how conservative the toy business has become," said Larry Carlat, editor of Toy and Hobby World magazine, a trade publication. Large toy companies, he explained, had turned down the product, which a small company was able to market successfully.
Mr. Murtha knew the slap bracelets would be the latest rage. "Big numbers was what I was thinking," he said. "It would make a perfect counter-seasonal product with multiple-purchase possibilities," meaning that a lot of people would buy a lot of Slap Wraps at times other than Christmas.
 
 Cheapest Craze Since Pet Rocks
 So far he's been right. Slap Wraps is the biggest cheap-novelty craze since Pet Rocks in the late Paleozoic Era, circa 1975, Mr. Carlat said.
Of course, Slap Wraps at perhaps $15 million in retail sales this year will not come close to Barbie dolls (about $680 million annually) or Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (perhaps $1 billion for all merchandise). But slap bracelets only cost $2.50 -- a cheap chotchke for recession-haunted times.
Orders are pouring in so fast that Main Street has stopped counting them -- it simply weighs them, about 30 pounds a day. The company might post 1990 revenue of $6 million to $8 million compared with $2.5 million last year.
Main Street plans to come out with new lines of Slap Wraps, covered with cartoon characters and Valentine's Day greetings, for example. But for the moment, it wants to put a brake on expanding corporate overhead. "If we need to hire two people, we'll only hire one," Mr. Murtha said.
 
 Invented by Shop Teacher
 Slap Wraps was invented by Stuart Anders, a high-school shop teacher from Sun Prairie, Wis. In 1983, he was fiddling around with steel ribbons in his father's shop when he invented what would eventually become Slap Wraps.
By chance, he showed his invention to Philip Bart, an agent who represented toy inventors. Last November, when Mr. Bart got in touch with Mr. Murtha, the three men formed affiliated companies.
Mr. Murtha had hundreds of prototypes made for the Toy Fair held in February in New York, the industry convention where manufacturers sell wares to distributors and retailers.
Rival companies, seeing Slap Wraps at Toy Fair, saw their potential, too. Mr. Murtha was not worried then because Main Street expected to have its version out on the market as early as April. But the company did not introduce Slap Wraps until July.
 
 Safety in Gauge of Steel
 When Main Street started testing the product to conform with Federal safety regulations, it discovered that the steel could break and slice through the fabric, exposing sharp metal edges. By making Slap Wraps out of thicker gauge steel -- 0.006 inch thick, instead of the prototype's 0.004 inch -- it was less likely to break.
Introduction was postponed while the company developed a safer product and awaited shipments from its Hong Kong factory.
Meanwhile, competitors were able to bring out similar products at the same time as Main Street because they had copied the thin-steel prototype. Millions of knockoffs, made in Taiwan, flooded the Northeast.
 
 Injury to a 4-Year-Old
 In Wallingford, Conn., earlier this month, 4-year-old Nicole Tomaso was playing with a cheap knockoff when she ran screaming into the family living room. An exposed edge had cut her finger and nail.
Outraged, her father, Joseph N. Tomaso, filed a complaint with Connecticut's Department of Consumer Protection, which began an investigation. The agency is now asking Connecticut retailers to recall the imitations and has alerted its state counterparts, as well as the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission, about the knockoffs' dangers. New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Minnesota are contemplating action.
Mr. Anders, the inventor, is fatalistic about his product's future. "I'd like to think Slap Wraps will last 30 years," he said, "but I know it won't. I hope to be somewhere between Pet Rocks and the Hula Hoop."

HEADLINE: Macy Says It Might Sell Sizable Stake to Trim Debt

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
R. H. Macy & Company told its investors yesterday that it might sell a more substantial stake in the debt-laden company than it had previously sold to other investors. Some speculation centered on a Hong Kong company as a possible buyer.
In a quarterly letter to investors in Macy's 1986 leveraged buyout, top management did not identify a potential buyer. The company did not say whether it was already negotiating with one buyer or was still exploring the field. But a Macy spokeswoman said, "This is not a veiled reference to a specific buyer, but it is stronger than merely exploring the possibility." 
 Macy said in its letter: "The buyer would be one who shares our view of Macy's value and future. We believe such a sale would be in the company's best interests as it will allow us to make a major reduction in our interest costs."
In the 1986 buyout, Macy took on $5.6 billion in debt, and the interest on that debt has put a severe strain on the company's finances with the slump in retailing.
Executives in mergers and acquisitions said that in view of the current difficult times in American retailing, it was likely that a buyer would be a foreign company. Among the possible buyers mentioned was Wharf Holdings Ltd., a Hong Kong shipping and real estate concern. Myron E. Ullman 2d, Macy's executive vice president since November 1988, is a former managing director and chief operating officer of Wharf. But the Macy spokeswoman said the company had no comment on the reports that it was negotiating with Wharf.
Efforts to reach Wharf by telephone last night were unsuccessful.
"It's obvious that Macy's will need a large equity infusion to pay interest on its debt principal and for working capital," said Gilbert Harrison, chairman of Financo Inc., a mergers and acquisitions specialist in New York. "I would estimate such an infusion would be at least $200 million to $300 million and perhaps even more."
Earlier asset sales by Macy have been relatively small ones, including the sale of 1 percent equity to buy $50 million of Macy high-yield bonds; a proposed sale of the former Bullock's office building in Los Angeles, with the proceeds going to reduce senior debt, and a sale of Macy's credit card finance subsidiaries, the Macy Credit Corporation and the Macy Receivables Funding Corporation.
Macy said it had reduced expenses in line with anticipated slower business conditions and also cut its inventory levels to $600 million less than they were a year earlier at retail.
While Macy said it expected the Christmas season to reflect the continued sluggish economic conditions, it also said the low level of inventories would prevent a "repetition of the heavy markdown activity of last fall."
Macy distributed its investor letter with the release of its financial statement to the Securities and Exchange Commission for the fiscal year ended July 28. As previously reported, Macy had a much higher net loss in the recent year, totaling $215.3 million, against a net loss of $63 million the year before.
"Our fiscal 1990 performance was certainly not satisfactory," Macy said. But it added that its conservative approach had produced benefits. Earnings before interest, taxes and depreciation for the second half rose to $339 million from from $321 million in 1989. In the fourth quarter, earnings before interest, taxes and depreciation increased to $179 million from $167 million.
Remuneration during the 1990 year for Macy's top executives was listed in the company's financial statement. Edward S. Finkelstein, chairman and chief executive, earned $1,134,149; Mark S. Handler, president and chief operating officer, $864,707, and Mr. Ullman, $519,886.

HEADLINE: 2,600 Jobs To Be Cut By Aetna

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
The Aetna Life and Casualty Company said yesterday that it would eliminate 2,600 jobs as part of a program of broad changes. Coming on the heels of similar reports by other leading American insurers, the announcement is a sign of continuing problems in the industry.
The Hartford-based insurer said the move would save the company $50 million next year and more after that. The job reductions were announced along with the company's third-quarter earnings, which were down sharply. 
 Analysts praised the move as necessary although painful. They said it reflected a retrenchment across the industry after nearly two decades of rapid growth. Insurance companies have been experiencing some of the credit problems of banks and other financial institutions in the face of falling real estate values and a decline in high-yield "junk bond" portfolios.
 
 Decade of 'Retrenchment'
 "Other than the people losing their jobs, I think it's terrific," said A. Michael Frinquelli, an analyst with Salomon Brothers. "The decade of the 1990's will be one of retrenchment. The whole economy is going through that, and insurers, since they reflect the overall economy, are retrenching, too. This isn't just Aetna. It's a foregone conclusion industrywide."
On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Aetna's shares gained 25 cents, to $31.
James T. Lynn, Aetna's chairman, said the move had been made "to best position the company for success in a rapidly changing marketplace. He added, "Our goal is to build on the many areas of excellence Aetna must retain, and to solidify our position as a leader in insurance, related financial services and managed health care."
Most of the job eliminations will come from Aetna's three Hartford-area offices. Essentially, the company is disbanding one layer of corporate management that consisted of three domestic divisions. These divisions will be replaced by a single corporate unit. The changes are effective March 4.
As part of the plan, the company announced a $90 million one-time pretax charge to cover the costs of severance, benefits and other costs of reorganization. This charge pushed down third-quarter earnings by 51.5 percent, to $88.6 million, or 80 cents a share, on revenues of $4.8 billion. In the 1989 third quarter the company earned $182.6 million, or $1.63 a share, on revenues of $4.9 billion. The 1989 performance, however, was aided by $42 million in one-time gains.
Aetna has 45,200 employees nationwide, with 17,400 in the Hartford area. Some of the jobs will be lost through attrition. But the company gave no specifics on the number of employees affected.
 
Others Trimming Also
 Similar changes have been taking place at the Travelers Corporation, also based in Hartford, and the Philadelphia-based Cigna Corporation announced recently that it would take a restructuring charge when it reported its third-quarter earnings. The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States is also pledged to a $100 million cost-cutting effort.
Aetna said yesterday that the retrenchment would provide after-tax savings of $50 million in 1991, $90 million in 1992 and $95 million a year after that.
"This is a good move," said G. Alan Zimmerman, an analyst with Smith Barney Inc. "It's imperative for the whole insurance industry and for corporate America to stay as lean as possible."
The industrywide moves are a reversal of the strategy of the 1970's and 1980's, when insurers grew quickly by writing policies and investing the proceeds in a broad array of new financial products. During that time, the industry grew to have more than $1.8 trillion in assets. But, as the economy has faltered, so has their business. Insurance company failures have been on the rise, and questions have been raised in Congress about the industry's solvency.
"What's going to happen in the 1990's is that the industry will focus on profits and not on size," said Mr. Frinquelli of Salomon Brothers.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Mixed Showing for Dollar; Gold Stumbles in New York

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mixed yesterday in quiet trading on world currency markets amid some nervousness over the United States military buildup in the Persian Gulf.
Gold prices slipped overseas, and the decline accelerated in United States trading. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery fell $4.90, to $370.90 an ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted gold at $371, down $5.25. 
 Currency traders said there was occasional dollar-buying as some investors sought a haven in the United States currency ahead of an uncertain weekend in the Middle East. Adding to their concern was the disclosure on Thursday that the United States plans to send up to 100,000 more troops to the area.
"It appears, with the situation in the Persian Gulf very, very tense, that people wanted to buy back a few dollars," said Robert Hatcher, a corporate dealer with Barclays Bank. The dollar typically is considered the currency of choice in times of global turmoil.
But countering the advance was an underlying bearish sentiment toward the dollar based on the expectation of lower interest rates and a weakening economy. The market is anticipating that the Federal Reserve will act to lower interest rates once the deficit-reduction budget package proposed this week is enacted. Lower interest rates make dollar-denominated securities less attractive to investors.
Michael Malpede, a senior analyst with Refco Group Ltd., characterized yesterday's trading as trendless. There was no commitment, he said, to either buying or selling dollars.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose 1.35 yen, to a close at 128.50 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 128. In New York, the dollar settled at 128.25 yen, unchanged from Thursday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.9555, from $1.9545 late Thursday. In New York, it cost $1.9565 to buy a pound, up from $1.9505 on Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.5130 German marks, down from 1.5185; 1.2810 Swiss francs, down from 1.2845; 5.0670 French francs, down from 5.0820; 1,134.00 Italian lire, down from 1,136.50, and 1.1644 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1657.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $373.75 an ounce, from $376.25 late Thursday. In Zurich, the metal slipped to a closing bid of $373.40, from $374.80. Financial markets in Hong Kong were closed for a holiday.
Silver prices also declined. On the Comex in New York, silver for current delivery settled at $4.050 an ounce, down from $4.204 on Thursday. Earlier in London, silver fell to a late bid of $4.14, from $4.24.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Alaska Air Group To Reduce Staff

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Oct. 26

 BODY:
Alaska Air Group Inc. said it was reducing its management staff by 46 and leaving 39 other positions unfilled because of high jet fuel costs and a weakening economy. The cuts, effective Nov. 9, are expected to save about $3.3 million a year.
"Unfortunately, dramatic increases in jet fuel prices triggered this action,' said an official of Alaska Airlines, the company's main operating unit. He said no further reductions were expected. Alaska Airlines currently employs 6,500 people, including 980 managers. The company's stock fell 62.5 cents today, to $16.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Escalation, 1990 Style

 BODY:
Does it make military or political sense to add 100,000 or more American troops to the 210,000 already deployed in Saudi Arabia? Though the buildup announced by Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney is unexpected, that does not mean it is imprudent. But if Americans are to support this new commitment, the Administration needs to explain its purposes and to allay fears that the collective forces in the Persian Gulf are becoming excessively Americanized.
The buildup may be essential to persuade Saddam Hussein that he has no choice but to withdraw from Kuwait unconditionally. But since Vietnam, Americans have been wary of escalation, and slippery official justifications for it. Pentagon analysts say that even 100,000 additional troops may not be enough, that more backup is required. As the risks and sacrifices swell, so will the pressure to initiate use of force soon, when the desert is cooler and dark nights favor surprise. 
 Administration officials insist there is no change in the declared strategy of multilateral collaboration to evict Iraq from Kuwait. Tough U.N. resolutions have imposed sanctions against Iraq that already seem to be producing results. This collective effort has prevented Saddam Hussein from defining the conflict as a U.S. vendetta inspired by a thirst for cheap oil. Increasing the U.S. component in the multilateral effort risks Americanizing the siege to his advantage.
Creditably, the Bush Administration seems alert to the danger and is finally taking up a Soviet proposal to upgrade the long-moribund U.N. Military Staff Committee. For the first time in memory, senior military officers representing the five permanent members of the Security Council will meet to discuss joint action.
Success, however, will require more than multinational unity. To nurture American understanding and support, the President needs to explain why more American troops must be deployed when there is no commensurate increase by European and Arab allies.
Saudi Arabia has 60,000 troops in the force. France has reportedly agreed to put its 13,000 under U.S. command. Britain has done the same with its 15,000 troops. Syria has pledged 19,000, Egypt 20,000. Other countries are sending detachments or ships. But so far, there's been not even a token military contribution from Germany or Japan.
No one can say for sure that war will be avoided, or that economic sanctions and the multinational force will induce Saddam Hussein to disgorge Kuwait. But the terrible cost in lives, and the risk of enduring Arab hatred of America, are powerful arguments for restraint. Impatience alone is no argument for initiating war. The burden is on President Bush to show that a significant increase in American forces will make less likely their use in battle.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Teachers' Pay Raise Tests Our Commitment

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Divisiveness during a time of increasing fiscal crisis in New York is unfortunate. Nevertheless, the controversy surrounding the 5.5 percent increase in the teachers' contract presents the city and state, the public, and business and civic leaders with the opportunity to make a clear and fundamental choice: What are truly our highest priorities? Where will we put our money? 
 All of us say that education is among the city's highest priorities and is the key to our long-term economic health. Indeed, all of us have cried out for better quality education for New York's young people. We have a dynamic new Chancellor who is beginning the process of change. We have a new Mayor who has clearly and ringingly stated his belief in children as the city's future.
No one doubts that a well-recruited, well-trained, motivated and dedicated teaching force is the key element in the strategy for educational improvement. None of us can be naive enough to think that simply a 5.5 percent increase will accomplish that end overnight. But when areas surrounding the city and districts all over the state that have higher entry salaries to start with are granting 8 percent increases and more, we must respond. If we don't try to be competitive, how can we expect to attract, retain and motivate the best available teachers?
The choice is clear: If we value education as much as we say we do, we must value teachers accordingly. But if education is not truly our top priority, then by all means let's rescind the teachers' contract and live with the consequences. If educational improvement is a top priority on the city's agenda, the contract must stand.
 
FRED SALERNO
REUBEN MARK
New York, Oct. 18, 1990
 
The writers are, respectively, president and chief executive officer of the New York Telephone Company and the Colgate-Palmolive Company.

HEADLINE: And in Bergen, Add Anger at School-Aid Loss

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY

DATELINE: HACKENSAC

 BODY:
THE $2.8 billion tax increase Gov. Jim Florio whipped through the Legislature in June has cast a long shadow over the contest for Bergen County executive.
The candidates, Jeremiah F. O'Connor, a Democrat, and William P. Schuber, a Republican, have scrambled for weeks to capitalize on the deep voter hostility to the taxes and the millions of dollars Bergen's schools will lose under the state's revised school-aid formula. In debates, television and radio ads, and fliers, each has extolled efficiency in government, trumpeted his own budgetcutting plan, and painted the other as having willingly raised taxes in the past. 
 These themes have dominated the campaign to run the $320 million government of the state's most populated county and detracted from talk about major issues facing the county in the 1990's.
On many of them, Mr. O'Connor and Mr. Schuber agree. Both favor open space and regionalization of municipal services like road repair, firefighting and public works. Both oppose construction of the $400 million incinerator for garbage from Bergen's 70 towns and the $1 billion tunnel proposed by the Army Corps of Engineers to divert flood waters from the Pompton and Passaic Rivers in Wayne to the lower Hackensack River and Newark Bay.
In recent interviews, their sharpest disagreement dealt with steps the county executive could take to ease the deep financial losses county schools face under the Governor's new Quality Education Act.
The law, enacted in late spring, shifts hundreds of millions in state education aid from the state's wealthiest districts to middle- class and poor districts. Bergen's schools will lose nearly $89 million in state aid from mid-1993 to mid-1996 and are required to pay another $97 million in teachers' pension and Social Security costs, starting next fall. These changes will mean deep cuts in education programs or sharply higher local property taxes, school superintendents say.
Mr. O'Connor testified against the new school-aid formula last spring before it was enacted. Only the Legislature can change it now, he said.
Mr. Schuber, a five-term State Assemblyman who voted against the formula, said: "The next executive has to work with the legislative delegation. It's incumbent to exercise leadership to get a better share for Bergen in school funding. We'll focus public attention on it."
By that, he said, he meant that as next fall's legislative elections approach, he will publicly challenge Bergen's Democrats in the Legislature to either side with the Governor and the new formula and its deep cuts or fight in Trenton for changes benefiting Bergen schools.
Seven of Bergen's 15 state legislators are Democrats and their votes were crucial to the passage of the higher taxes and the revised school-aid formula in June.
Politically, it would be a simple matter for Mr. Schuber, if elected executive, to campaign next year against those Democratic legislators who helped enact the taxes. To do the same, Mr. O'Connor would be forced to break ranks with fellow Democrats and jeopardize both their re-election to the Legislature and the slim majorities the Democrats now hold in the Assembly and Senate.
Mr. O'Connor and Mr. Schuber are vying to succeed Bergen's first Executive, William McDowell, a Republican, who is not seeking re-election. Mr. McDowell quietly guided the county over the last four years through a historic charter change and transition from a weak form of government overseen by a board of freeholders to a stronger, more centralized form run by an executive.
 
Re-Entry to Politics
 For Mr. O'Connor, long a power in Bergen's Democratic Party, the campaign is a re-entry to elective politics after a decade's absence. Now 57 years old, he served as a State Senator in 1966 and 1967, a freeholder from 1974 to 1980 and freeholder director from 1975 to 1979. Currently, he is vice chairman of the board of Interchange State Bank, a 12-branch chain with headquarters in Saddle Brook.
Mr. Schuber, a 43-year-old lawyer here, was first elected to the Assembly in 1981. He represents Bergen's 38th District, which includes the central Bergen communities of Bogota, his hometown; Hackensack; Paramus; Lodi, Maywood and Oradell. He was re-elected last year in a blitz of ticket-splitting that overcame a Florio landslide in the 38th District. Although Mr. Florio carried the district by about 13,000 votes, Mr. Schuber won his contest by nearly 5,000 votes.
He is trying to depict Mr. O'Connor as a big spender by saying Mr. O'Connor endorsed Mr. Florio's tax increases and oversaw an increase in county spending to $184 million from $84 million while freeholder director in the late 70's.
Mr. O'Connor cries distortion. On the tax issue, he said he endorsed the idea of raising the income tax for individuals earning more than $100,000 as an equitable way to cut the state budget deficit. As for the county spending record of the late 70's, he said much of the increase came from Federal grants. He argues he held county property tax increases below the inflation rate.
 
'Not Business as Usual'
 And, Mr. O'Connor says, Mr. Schuber voted for 21 different tax increases during Thomas H. Kean's two terms as Governor.
Both insist they are now against tax increases.
"Hard decisions will have to be made," Mr. Schuber said in an interview. "This is not business as usual. People have had it with spending and taxes."
Mr. O'Connor said: "The day of raising taxes is over. We have to keep spending under inflation."
 
Plans on Budget Cuts
 Mr. O'Connor said he would cut about $15.5 million from the $320 million county budget -- $9 million through a hiring freeze, reduced overtime and an increase in the work week to 40 hours from 32 hours for mid- and upper-level managers in county departments, $6.2 million through consolidation of departments and cuts in the county's car fleet and $250,000 through cuts in trips and conventions for county officials. In addition, he said, his department heads would be required to cut their budgets for an additional $7 million.
Mr. Schuber has outlined $3.4 million in budget cuts, including about $1.4 million in the county motor pool; $1.2 million in county grants to nonprofit groups; $500,000 in county printing costs, $200,000 in trips by county officials and $150,000 in summer jobs.
Both promised a savingsto property-tax payers from the state's pending takeover of $10 million in county costs for welfare and mental health sites and care.
On the issue of garbage disposal, which affects every county household and property-taxpayer, both opposed construction of the proposed $400 million incinerator in Ridgefield. As an alternative, Mr. Schuber proposed increased recycling and construction of a non-burning, composting operation, similar to one in Dade County, Florida, that pulverizes organic trash into a form of topsoil and metals and other non-organic trash into a gravel-type substance for road beds. Mr. O'Connor proposed more recycling and shipping the remainder to a new incinerator in Newark that is too big for Essex County's volume of garbage.
