SECTION: Section 12; Page 4; Column 4; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1373 words

HEADLINE: Water Chief Meets Friends and Foes

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

DATELINE: KATONAH

 BODY:
THE New York City reservoir system occupies 18,000 acres of county land, pays taxes to 20 different communities and for 156 years has affected the development of large parts of Westchester because of its authority over its watershed. After a long hiatus, the city is on the move again.
Last week, the man who supervises the seven-county reservoir system came here to discuss strict new proposals to protect the quality of the huge water-supply network, the first changes contemplated in 37 years. 
 The proposals were designed to preserve the purity of the drinking water of nine million people -- including most county residents -- into the next century by severely limiting "irresponsible development," city officials said. They would prevent thousands of acres in the watershed from being developed, place strict and costly limitations on existing and proposed sewage-treatment systems and impose new restrictions on the disposal of snow and road runoff into local waterways.
If the proposals are not put into effect, the city says, it will be forced to build a $4 billion filtration system to comply with new state and Federal requlations to insure the safety of the water supply.
 
Creativity Is Called For
 "Nothing substitutes for pristine, natural water," Albert F. Appleton, New York City's Commissioner of Environmental Protection, said last week. "We are going to have to be enormously creative and spend a fair amount of money -- some of it ours and some of it money that will add to the costs of development here -- to protect what is a priceless resource, your resource and our resource."
The city is already building a $600 million filtration plant for the Croton system, which lies in Westchester and Putnam Counties and which municipal officials say has been contaminated by over-development. Commissioner Appleton said the proposed regulations "are our tool for insuring that the Croton contamination won't spread" to the much larger Catskill and Delaware systems, which provide 90 percent of the total water supply.
While environmentalists in the New York region and several northern towns who oppose continued development here have been pleased by the city's proposals, developers in the county have criticized them as a severe limit on the county's growth and a threat to an already shaky economy.
 
A Walk Through the Woods
 In an unusual meeting last week called by State Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, Westchester developers and environmentalists joined county municipal officials and Commissioner Appleton on a tramp through the woods past a section of the Muscoot Reservoir here polluted by the seepage of phosphorous. The group then sat down at the Katonah Library to discuss the draft regulations published last month.
"We are in the fascinating position of having people sitting here chatting comfortably while they are suing the hell out of each other in court," Mr. Brodsky told the group, in a reference to litigation between developers and municipal officials.
One opponent of tighter restrictions warned that county residents would have to pay higher water bills, and increased septic and sewage costs under the proposals. The opponent, Joseph Baratta, president of Par-Bar Associates, a real estate-development company based in Elmsford, confronted Mr. Appleton in the library:
"New York City is imposing regulations that will cause certain hardship for the citizens of Westchester County. What gives New York City the right to do this?"
 
It All Dates Back to 1834
 "This watershed has been here since 1834," the Commissioner replied. "Nine million people depend on this water and have for well over 150 years. Water is a fundamental health need, and that's what gives us the right."
The city also has the law on its side. There were a number of lawyers at the meeting, including Mr. Brodsky and Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who represents the Hudson River Fishermen's Association and is also senior staff lawyer with the Natural Resources Defense Council. In a 1905 state statute, the city won the right to take upstate lands, flood them for reservoirs and create and enforce rules protecting water purity.
Mr. Kennedy said: "I don't look at New York City as any kind of Big Brother telling us what to do. This is our water, which goes to our residents, and I am grateful to New York City for coming and helping us to protect it."
 While the 85-year-old law did create hostility toward the city's water system and its overseers in the past, a mood that lingers in less-developed parts of the watershed, residents in more urban areas have begun to see the city and its water system as providing needed protection against development pressures.
 
Past Mistakes Conceded
 "Thank you for coming to Westchester," said Richard Knabel, president of the Federated Conservationists of Westchester County, a coalition of environmental groups,to Mr. Appleton. "We have been trying for years to get the city's attention."
If the city had exercised its mandate for protecting the watershed more aggressively, Mr. Knabel said, development issues would not be as critical as they appear to be now.
One mistake, Mr. Appleton said, was the city's failure to buffer the reservoirs properly when they were built. "Now, in the late 20th century, we are going to have to play catch-up," he said. "I expect we'll buy some land."
In addition to new regulations, the city has broadened its watershed-protection strategy to include legal action to force compliance with existing regulations, Mr. Appleton said, and renewed pressure on state agencies to require higher standards for sewage-treatment permits.
Developers at last week's meeting said that they agreed with the city's objectives but that the proposals targeted them unfairly.
"We thoroughly recognize the very severe problems existing today in the water supply, problems that will be exacerbated in the future," said Norman Judelson, a principal in the White Plains real estate partnership of Glickenhaus Judelson.
While water quality is deteriorating, fertilizer and road salt are "probably the biggest offenders," he said, and asked, "Why aren't there regulations limiting the use of fertilizers?"
 
Plan Is Called One-Sided
 Mr. Baratta, a member of the board of the Builders Institute, a trade association of several hundred builders in Westchester and Putnam Counties, agreed. "Something has to be done but it shouldn't be so one-sided," Mr. Baratta said. "We don't have any affordable housing; we don't have the means to house the people who work here. These regulations have wide-ranging implications."
Municipal officials from the county who attended the meeting appeared to welcome the city's renewed interest in their localities but many wondered what the cost of the proposals would be and who would pay for them. "Local communities simply can't achieve what the city wants by themselves," said Theodore H. Chase, deputy supervisor of Lewisboro. "We simply do not have the resources."
Guy L. Gagne, Town Engineer of Somers, said he was concerned about the communities with older homes and small septic systems that are draining into the Amawalk Reservoir. Sanitary sewer systems need to be installed in these areas, he said, but "it would be very, very cost- prohibitive to place the entire financial burden on these small communities."
When the town of Bedford recently proposed a $12.6 million referendum to build a sewer system for the downtown hamlet areas of Bedford Hills and Katonah, it was soundly defeated by voters not living in the affected area.
"The city's reservoirs are being polluted slowly but surely by Katonah," the Bedford Town Planning Director, Jeffrey Osterman, told Mr. Appleton. "We really need help."
The informal draft of the proposed regulations will be reviewed by the many communities and constituencies that would be affected, Mr. Appleton said. The results of those discussions will form the basis of a formal draft of the regulations, which is to be published before public hearings planned for early next year. After the hearings, a final proposal will be submitted to the State Department of Health and the New York City Department of Environmental Protection.

HEADLINE: More Urban Enterprise Zones Sought

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
A SEVEN-YEAR-OLD program that provides sales tax exemptions to businesses and customers in the state's most economically depressed cities has proved so successful, officials say, that they are considering asking the Legislature to expand the program to include additional municipalities.
The New Jersey Urban Enterprise Zones Act of 1983 exempts qualifying businesses in parts of 11 cities and towns from paying the state sales tax on purchases and allows shoppers in seven of those municipalities to pay a 3.5 percent tax, or half the normal rate, which is then retained by the municipality. 
 Besides wanting to increase the number of cities and towns participating in the program, officials say they also hope to see some of the present zones expanded, and all the qualifying localities given the right to offer the 50 percent sales tax exemption on consumer purchases.
But while nearly everyone agrees that the program is helping to revitalize deteriorating downtowns by stimulating development, generating employment and increasing reliance on local businesses, some merchants outside the zones say that they are being hurt by the competitive edge stores in the zones hold.
 
Impact on State Budget
 In addition, state officials acknowledge that the success of the program must also be weighed against its impact on the state budget: every sales tax dollar saved by businesses and customers in an urban enterprise zone is a dollar lost to state government.
That impact takes on even greater significance in light of the recent increases in the income tax and the sales tax itself that were adopted to balance the state's $12.4 billion budget.
"The Urban Enterprise Zones Act was passed to improve the economic life of the inner cities," said S. Charles Garofalo, state administrator of the Urban Enterprise Zones program, "and it's doing that job beautifully."
 Mr. Garofalo said that since its inception in 1983, the program has helped create more than 15,000 new jobs in participating cities. In addition, he said, more than $1.5 billion has been privately invested in those cities for commercial construction and rehabilitation. The program, which by law expires after 20 years, is considered a model for similar programs across the country, Mr. Garofalo said. "We get calls from all over the world asking about our program," he said.
 As a result of the program's success, he said, a committee of the state Economic Development Authority recently recommended that the number of participating cities be increased and that the current zones be expanded.
 
Enthusiastically Received
 The Urban Enterprise Zones Act originally allowed for the designation of up to two enterprise zones each year. The first zones were in Camden and Newark -- the two cities deemed by state officials the most in need of assistance.
The program was so enthusiastically received, however, that by 1985 all 10 zones permitted under the act had been designated. There are currently 11 municipalities participating in the program, with Millville and Vineland sharing one zone. Besides Camden and Newark, the other municipalities are Bridgeton, Elizabeth, Jersey City, Kearny, Orange, Plainfield and Trenton.
Each zone covers on average about 30 percent of the city it lies in, with the zone area designated by municipal officials. Municipalities are selected for the program on the basis of need. Businesses in each zone must apply to join the program. To qualify, a business must create at least one permanent full-time job for a resident of the area or, if the business employs 10 or fewer employees, it can qualify by making a capital expenditure of as little as $5,000.
 
'Saved Close to $1,000'
 Once qualified, the business is exempt from paying state sales tax on purchases of equipment and on renovation expenses. And that, business owners say, can mean substantial savings.
"We renovated our store a couple of years ago and saved close to $1,000," said Robert G. Johnston, owner of Johnston Jewelers on West State Street in downtown Trenton. "And I think a lot of other merchants in the area are taking advantage of the program."
Indeed, the savings resulting from participation in the program is limited only by the amount of money a business owner wants to invest. Essentially, a qualified business receives what amounts to a 7 percent discount on almost all purchases.
The savings on new construction, Mr. Garofalo said, can amount to as much as $1.70 a square foot. And that, he said, is at least partly responsible for an increase in the number of new commercial developments and a decrease in the unemployment rate in the cities participating in the program.
 
Luring Suburban Customers
 In Trenton, for instance, the unemployment rate in the city was 8.8 percent in 1984, the year before the program became effective there. By 1988, Mr. Garofalo said, 912 new full-time jobs had been created in the zone, and the unemployment rate in the city dropped to 5.2 percent. Other cities in the program are experiencing similar results.
"In Newark we're doing pretty good," said Rafael Zabala, the coordinator of the city's enterprise zone program.
"As we speak, close to two million square feet of office space is being built within the urban enterprise zone here, and we project an additional 300 jobs will result from that development," Mr. Zabala said.
While one goal of the program is to persuade businesses to remain in the cities, officials say, another is to entice customers to return there from the suburban malls to shop, lured by the 50 percent sales tax reduction on their purchases, on everything except vehicles. The strategy appears to be working.
"It's been an unbelievable boon to us," said Stan Demski, sales manager for the Chopin Piano Company in Trenton. "We have people coming in from all over the place just to save the 3 1/2 percent tax," he said.
 
Street Lights in Trenton
 Besides increasing sales and saving customers money, the program also allows each city to retain the 3.5 percent tax that is collected by participating merchants.
Municipal officials can then use that money to make additional improvements in the zone in conjunction with developers and area businesses.
West State Street between North Broad Street and North Warren Street in Trenton, for example, was formerly a series of privately owned older buildings, said Thomas McGough, coordinator of the city's urban enterprise zone program.
Now, the area contains a pedestrian mall with thriving retail shops on one side and a recently completed $35 million office and retail complex on the other. Part of the money for the street and lighting improvements, Mr. McGough said, was taken from the sales taxes retained by the city.
Trenton's enterprise zone, which encompasses 2.3 square miles, was designed to include as many businesses as possible. Some cities, however, were not able to include all of their commercial areas within the zones.
 
Unfair Edge, Merchants Say
 In those municipalities, some business owners feel that the zones create an environment of unfair competition.
"I think it's totally outrageous," said Joseph DeBrito, an owner of Newark Hardware and Paint Company Inc., a retail business in the Ironbound section of Newark. "One block away from here they're charging 3 1/2 percent tax," he said, referring to the fact that the enterprise zone ends at Pennsylvania Station and does not include the Ferry Street shopping area where his business is situated.
A business in an enterprise zone, he said, has an unfair edge over those businesses not in the zone.
"It's like an invisible barrier," Mr. DeBrito said.
Officials, however, disagree.
"I don't think it gives a business an unfair advantage," said Joseph G. LaMonica, director of communications for the Newark Economic Development Corporation, the city agency that manages the enterprise zone program. "It puts the merchants on a more level playing field."
 
'Justifiable Reward' for Merchants
 Indeed, some experts say, the program was intended to help the businesses that needed help the most.
"It's a device to rebuild the urban centers," said Gerald D. Hall, vice president of the New Jersey State Chamber of Commerce. Merchants who enjoy the program's benefits, he said, may be reaping a "justifiable reward for remaining in the worst part of the city."
 Perhaps the best indicator of the success of the program is the desire of municipalities to participate.
Of the 11 municipalities that now have urban enterprise zones, four -- Kearny, Jersey City, Elizabeth and Orange -- are not permitted to offer the 50 percent sales tax exemption on customer purchases. All, however, want to.
"The four zones without the 50 percent sales tax amenity are at a complete disadvantage as they relate to the other zones," said Thomas V. Henderson, the coordinator of Orange's urban enterprise zone program. "We are hopeful that this discrepancy will be rectified in the very near future."
 
Salem County as Urban Zone
 Indeed, State Senator Raymond J. Lesniak, Democrat of Elizabeth, has introduced legislation that would extend the 50 percent reduction to qualified businesses in all urban enterprise zones.
In addition, several other bills have been introduced to expand existing zones or create new ones. One bill, proposed by Assemblyman Frank A. LoBiondo, Republican of Vineland, would broaden the definition of eligibility for the program. Another, sponsored by State Senator Raymond J. Zane, Democrat of Woodbury, would designate all of Salem County as an urban enterprise zone.
"It may be parochial," Mr. Zane said of his proposal, "but with great justification." Salem County, he said, is just across the river from Wilmington, Del., where no sales tax at all is charged on purchases.
But while legislators, municipal officials and business owners support the idea of increased or expanded enterprise zones, state officials are wary of taking any steps that might decrease state revenues.
 "This is a very sensitive area now," said James N. Albers, chief of staff of the state Department of Commerce and chairman of the state Economic Development Authority. "We're talking about taking revenues out of the state treasury."
 
Report Finds Revenue Increase
 Before the authority could endorse such an idea, Mr. Albers said, the members would have to be satisfied that the benefits outweighed the potential loss of revenue.
Officials are encouraged, however, by a recent study of the state's program conducted by Dr. Marilyn Marks Rubin, associate professor of public administration and economics at John Jay College in New York. The study was paid for by the New Jersey Department of Commerce.
Dr. Rubin's study concluded that the state's urban enterprise zone program "is a cost-effective economic development tool." For every $1 of state sales tax revenue foregone as a result of tax exemptions, almost $2 more is gained from state and local taxes on the economic activity generated by the program, the study said.
 In addition, Dr. Rubin said, her study indicates that the economy of the 11 municipalities in the program showed improvement when compared with the economy of the seven others that applied to participate but were not chosen.
"Urban enterprise zones are not a panacea," Dr. Rubin said. "But if they can keep a city like Newark alive, then they're doing what they're supposed to be doing."

HEADLINE: Budget Fight Hinders Races for Congress

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
THE shortest election campaign period in the modern history of the House of Representatives has frustrated incumbents fearful of an angry electorate, impeded the efforts of challengers facing long odds under the best of circumstances and aggravated the organizers of debates.
Members of Congress, who had planned on at least a month of uninterrupted campaigning in their bids for re-election, have only 10 days to convince voters that the "mess in Washington," as challengers described the bitter and drawn-out negotiations over a Federal budget, was not their doing. 
 In the 20th Congressional District, where the Democrat Nita M. Lowey is seeking a second term, her two opponents, Glenn D. Bellitto, a Republican, and John M. Schafer, a Conservative, have grown accustomed to debating each other in the presence of a substitute for Ms. Lowey.
Mr. Bellitto, who has taken a leave of absence form his job at General Foods to campaign, said he feels there is "a growing anti-incumbency vote" among voters. "I go to train stations and supermarkets, and more and more people ask, 'Are you in or out?' When I say I'm out" -- the challenger -- "they say, 'Great. You have my vote.' "
 
85-Year-Old Opponent
 Benjamin A. Gilman, the nine-term Republican seeking re-election in the 22nd Congressional District that includes only Greenburgh in Westchester County, decided weeks ago not to use substitutes in debates he could not attend, so his 85-year-old Democratic opponent, John G. Dow, has faced an empty chair or a "speaker box" linked by telephone to Washington.
Mr. Dow is a former three-term Congressman whom Mr. Gilman defeated in 1972 to win the seat and again in 1974 to retain it. Mr. Dow said he "did not care whether Gilman comes to debates or not" because "I can say what I want whether he's here or not." Mr. Dow said he was "a reformer by tradition and reputation."
The district, which includes Rockland County and parts of Orange and Sullivan Counties, also has a Right to Life Party candidate, Margaret M. Beirne. Andrew J. Zarutskie, who is press secretary for the 67-year-old Mr. Gilman, offered an example of the campaigning acrobatics forced on incumbents by the budget debate.
He said the Representative had made two round trips from Washington last weekend, on Friday and Saturday nights, to attend events. "He had planned a third trip on Sunday night to attend a Monday-morning editorial debate, when he learned that the House was going to reconvene at 10 A.M. on Monday, so he had to stay."
The newspaper canceled the debate, which was intended to help determine an election endorsement, Mr. Zarutskie said, "but some groups are not quite so understanding." Mr. Gilman, his spokesman said, "would rather be on the hustings; he's down here and doesn't know what the other fellow is doing."
William J. Gouldman, a Bronx Republican who is seeking to replace Eliot L. Engel, a freshman Democrat, in the 19th Congressional District, said he felt people had "become apathetic about what's going on in Washington." Mr. Gouldman, who is in the insurance business and has an office in Tarrytown, said he had counted on debating Mr. Engel to get the political exposure "because I know it's an uphill battle."
 
'Voters Tired of Congress'
 "Two years ago," Mr. Gouldman said, "98 percent of the Congressional Representatives who wanted to be re-elected were re-elected, but only 50 percent of the electorate voted. This gave me a positive outlook that the voters throughout the nation were getting tired of the way Congress was doing its job and would like to see new leadership."
The 19th District was represented by Mario Biaggi until the Democrat's conviction in 1987 for accepting an illegal gratuity, a paid vacation and for obstructing justice. The district reaches into Westchester to include about two thirds of Yonkers , but is predominantly in the northeast Bronx, stretching from City Island and Coop City to Riverdale. The Conservative candidate, Kevin Brawley, also has Right to Life endorsement.
Mr. Engel's spokesman, John Calvelli, said, "We've spoken at seminars and forums with Mr. Gouldman and have had people filling in for the Representative at debates and meetings he could not attend. We thought it was important for the budget crisis to be resolved before the members of Congress could go home."
In the 21st Congressional District, which includes the northern third of Westchester as well as Putnam, Dutchess and part of Orange Counties, Hamilton Fish Jr., the 11-term Republican incumbent who has Conservative Party endorsement, is being challenged by Richard L. Barbuto. Mr. Barbuto, a Democrat, said he had "no hope that Mr. Fish will attend any of the debates we've scheduled."
Mr. Barbuto, who served one term as a Croton-on--Hudson Trustee and has been unsuccessful in other election campaigns at village, town, county and state levels, said he had "taken over from Larry Grunberger, who ran three times against Mr. Fish, and I intend to go again" if the current bid to unseat Mr. Fish fails. The Right to Life Party candidate is Richard S. Curtin.
Mr. Barbuto, a banker, said he favored a tax on imported oil as a means of providing the incentive "for a true energy alternative," and is generally against what he says is "the tyranny of the status quo." He said Mr. Fish had not dealt with "pocketbook issues" of the district.
 
'Not Much Difficulty'
 Mr. Fish's press spokesman, Fred Stokeld, said the Representative had returned to the district "when he could" during the intense negotiations over the budget and in the meantime was using advertisements on radio and in newspapers to keep his constituents informed. "With 22 years in office," Mr. Stokeld said, "he's not in as much difficulty as other Congressmen."
The only Congressional District entirely within Westchester, and thus the one affecting the most voters in the county, is Ms. Lowey's. She won narrowly in 1988, ousting the Republican incumbent, Joseph J. DioGuardi, in part through the disclosure just before the election of irregularities in his campaign financing. Employees of an auto dealership were allegedly reimbursed by their employer for their donations to Mr. DioGuardi's campaign.
Last week, Aldo V. Vitagliano, a Rye lawyer who said he had intended to run against Ms. Lowey this year, charged her with "gross violations of the Federal Election Campaign Act" in 1988 by "failing to properly disclose contributions of $250,000 to her campaign within the 48 hours required by law." He said the money had come from Ms. Lowey within the last 12 days of the campaign.
Robert Bauer, a lawyer with the Federal Election Commission, said the 48-hour rule applied to special-interest groups, "to make available to the public 11th-hour contributions from private interests." He said that since Ms. Lowey "was a candidate, she was not subject to those limitations, because the Supreme Court has ruled that you cannot corrupt your own campaign."
 
Lowey's Defends Herself
 Mr. Vitagliano said: "She bought the seat with the huge sums and is repaying herself this year with money from political action committees. She has raised $540,000, or 60 times more than her opponents combined."
Ms. Lowey said that "the charge will be proved empty, as a similar charge of illegal contributions was proved empty two years ago."
Mr. Schafer, the Conservative candidate opposing her, who also has Right to Life backing, said he did not think Ms. Lowey had spent anything close to the $500,000 she has raised, "although I suppose we'll see some television ads soon." He added that she had not attended scheduled debates in the district.
He said, "It's not like saying the dog ate her homework -- she can't show up if there are votes or other matters keeping her in Washington -- but she's made no great effort" to debate her two opponents.
Ms. Lowey said she had "agreed to every debate, over a dozen," and had attended two of them. Nothing would please her more, she said, than dealing with her opponents face to face.
"The challengers have been out there with no responsibilities, distorting members' records," she said. "They can say whatever they want; they don't have to produce and they don't have to vote." Ms. Lowey said that before the budget debate she had voted to cut back on farm subsidies and to make "serious cuts" in the military budget.
 
'Worst of All Scenarios'
 Mr. Schafer said Ms. Lowey represented "the worst of all possible scenarios, a recession that could turn into a depression with taxes being raised, and a war we could lose with cuts in defense spending."
She said the round-the-clock budget negotiations leading to a final package "were intended to make sure that the taxes President Bush said would have to be raised were distributed fairly and evenly."
Mr. Bellitto said he had focused on "the mess in Washington, which Ms. Lowey's absence from the district highlighted," claiming that "the incumbent is part of the problem." He said that "our NATO allies and Japan should start sharing our common defense costs." Congress, he said, had made some cuts in farm subsidies and in other areas, "but the cuts are too little; costs have to be slashed."
He said he also favored a 12-year limit, or a maximum of six terms, for United States Representatives "to avoid a class of professional politicians -- or bureaucrats turned politician -- like Ms. Lowey." Ms. Lowey left an Albany post as assistant secretary of state to run for Congress in the 20th District, which includes all of southern and central Westchester except the Greenburgh and Yonkers parcels in Mr. Gilman's and Mr. Engel's districts.

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW JERSEY

BYLINE: By Anthony DePalma

 BODY:
ON the corner of Court Street and what once was known as High Street, now Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard, in the Central Ward of Newark, there stands one of the grandest houses ever built in that rawboned community, a symbol of what Newark once was and a rallying point for what it might someday become.
It does not look like much now. The roof, three stories above the sidewalk, is blanketed with black plastic. Windows are boarded up; brownstone lintels are cracked and broken;, steps list so badly that were they not made of stone they would have slipped into the mud a long time ago. 
 Still, beneath the wrinkles, grandeur peeks out. It is not hard to imagine old Gottfried Krueger, the German beer baron who built the place in 1888, gazing contently over the city from the 50-foot-high observatory at the prow of the masonry mansion. Or to imagine the measured voice of Louise Scott, who is said to have been Newark's first black millionaire, greeting guests beneath the stained-glass dome in the central corridor of the house she bought in 1958.
After Mrs. Scott died in 1983, the city took over the mansion, a ransom for unpaid back taxes. In a little while the vandals took over, trashing the place and stealing every mahogany mantel, life-size wooden statue and panel of cherry wainscoting. Packs of wild dogs gnawed their way in, and pigeons roosted in the elevator shaft. Vagrants lighted fires that nearly burned the place down.
As recently as last winter, city officials were saying that Newark could not afford to keep the 25-room Krueger-Scott Mansion standing. But under pressure from people in the neighborhood, and with the help of a $436,000 state grant, Newark came up with $2.8 million and commitments from private interests in the city to save the house and turn it into a cultural center of black history.
This is an important step for a city that sometimes has been at war with its past and unable to come to grips with what it has become. A modest ceremony was recently held to begin rehabilitation of the mansion. Louise Scott, the 30-year-old daughter of the former owner, was there, puffed up with pride and close to tears as she walked through the badly deteriorated remains of the house, in which she had been raised.
"This is not the house I left," she said, inside for the first time since 1983. "It hurts to see it this way."
There is something about old houses that makes them intensely evocative. They are like old people, rocking on a sunny porch, who have seen much, been through much. If only they could talk.
It is that way in the Krueger-Scott Mansion. Poking around its eccentric rooms and strange corners with Ms. Scott, a visitor glimpsed several layers of a city's history unfolding. The entrance foyer was dark, almost black, but in the diagonally cut tiles on the floor were clearly displayed the initials G and K, still as arrogantly indelible as when they were first laid in wet cement 102 years ago.
The initials are those of Gottfried Krueger, who arrived almost penniless in Newark in 1852 and by 1875 was sole owner of Krueger Breweries, a major producer of beer that operated until 1960 and was the first major brewery to sell beer in a can. Like Peter Ballantine and Christian Fiegenspan, other wealthy Newark brewers, Mr.Krueger delighted in showing off his success. On the highest point in the city, along the grandest street, he built a house so splendid that everyone would see that he was successful.
Charles F. Cummings, Newark's historian, said Mr. Krueger represented the very essence of the 19th-century, rags-to-riches success story.
"He went from poor immigrant to rich burger in just a lifetime," Mr. Cummings said.
In 1925, well after Mr.Krueger had died, his house was sold to a Masonic lodge. Then in 1958, at the start of Newark's social and economic dissolution, the house was sold again, this time to Louise Scott. She, like the brewer, had started with almost nothing, having come from South Carolina to New York to work as a domestic during the day, studying to become a beautician at night.
In 1940 she moved to Newark and opened her first beauty parlor. Soon she had five salons, a guesthouse and a hotel. When she purchased the Krueger Mansion and made it the Scott College of Beauty Culture and the center of her civic and business enterprises, she was said to be a millionaire.
Although they were as different as two people could be, Gottfried Krueger and Louise Scott shared the same diligence, vision and drive to pay back in some way the community in which they had once struggled. Thus, since 1888, the mansion on the corner of High and Court Streets has been a focus of community activities. Mr. Krueger was an assemblyman, a judge and a founder of a home for the aged. Mrs. Scott started a nursery and baby clinic and accommodated groups of the elderly, disadvantaged and those searching for hope.
Mrs. Scott also raised a family there, and her daughter remembers what it was like growing up in the house at the center of the city. "This was my room, this was my baby sitter's room and this was my other room later," Ms. Scott said, sweeping quickly through the mansion's second floor.
She remembers her mother throwing the house open on many a day and night. She remembers her mother broadcasting messages of hope from a first-floor drawing room. She remembers weddings held there, and anniversaries and the other important occasions that blow life into a neighborhood.
Now that the house will again become a center of city culture, she sees hope reviving in the debris that remains. "There's so much blood and fighting on the streets now," she said. "If we give our black youth some history, maybe tomorrow will be a better day."
Speaking at the public ceremony, Mayor Sharpe James said the city was committed "not only to renovating a building of mortar and bricks but to bringing people and ideas together."
For many in this city of empty lots and vacant buildings, saving the grand house on High Street counters, in small measure, Newark's past disasters, like the high-rise public housing projects just a block away that were blasted to pieces, a final, deafening confession of government's inability to care for its own.
"This building," Mr. James said, "shows what Newark was like in the past during its greatest history and what Newark can become if we all work together."
Ms. Scott stood quietly on the back of the dais while the officials went on about the importance of preserving her former home. She held in her hands a book of poems by Langston Hughes, a bookmark next to one poem entitled "History." The poem, she said, expressed her feelings on that most important and exciting day. The poem was for Newark.
 
 The past has been a mint
 Of blood and sorrow.
 That must not be
 True of tomorrow.

The 25-room mansion will be restored and become a cultural center of black history; Gottfried Krueger, a German beer baron, built mansion in 1888. (The Newark Library); Louise Scott, Newark's first black millionaire, bought the house in 1958 (Photographs by F.N. Kinney for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Woodcliff Lake Journal;
A Wicked Witch, an Orange Moon and the Snarled Traffic

BYLINE: By ALBERT J. PARISI

 BODY:
WOODCLIFF LAKE
ALONG a half-mile stretch of Chestnut Ridge Road, traffic backs up, the lines are long and a steady wind ripples the tattered dress of a wicked witch against the backdrop of an orange moon on display at one of the farms in the distance.
And yet for all the drumming fingers on steering wheels and anxious glances, once the drivers get to the farms, a glass of fresh apple cider, a dozen doughnuts and pumpkins the size of many small children help to relieve the tension. 
 Like Halloween itself, the traffic that snarls roads here on October weekends is as much a tradition as hayrides and Indian corn tacked onto doors..
For two working farms and the families that operate them, this season mixes the hope of a profitable harvest with the long hours and children's laughter. Yet it was not always so.
Several years ago, before Chestnut Ridge Road was widened in 1988, traffic lights installed and a new exit, 171, opened nearby off the Garden State Parkway, it was not uncommon for families bound for these farming outlets, once roadside fruit and vegetable stands, to sit and wait in their cars for hours until parking spaces appeared. At its worst now, the wait can be from 20 minutes to a half-hour. Tempers often frayed and local police officers, hired by the farms, would find themselves as useful as the limp scarecrows guarding adjacent corn fields.
"There came a time when we needed change and that change helped out a great deal," said Richard F. Tice, 61 years old, a partner in the 10-acre Tice Farm, run by the family since 1910. "As this area has grown, so have we all and growth here means traffic," he said.
The congestion forced local officials to call for county and state aid to widen the road, even though borough residents for years had learned to use back roads to get from one end of town to another.
Both Mr. Tice and Peter Van Riper, a co-owner with his brother, Arthur, of Van Riper's Farm just down the road, say that their agricultural operations were not responsible for the improvements.
Borough officials disagree. They point out farmland sold off by the families over the last 15 years and developed as office parks and hotels increased traffic year-round and forced the widening of the road.
Mr. Tice and Mr. Van Riper, who are cousins, shrug off the suggestion. "It's my understanding that the improvements were made so that emergency vehicles could get in and out without having to battle the traffic," Mr. Van Riper said. "We still get those tie-ups, but it's a matter of minutes now, not an eternity."
While the families' business interests have branched out to real-estate development, they both see themselves as simple farmers who have melded into the 20th century. Farms in the state are declining in record numbers, according to the state Department of Agriculture, partly because of the financial lure of developers offering huge sums for land that was once home only to rich crops and weeping willow trees.
"I guess we could have sold out years ago but some things are hard to get out of your blood," Mr. Tice said. "There's a satisfaction from it that few people today will ever know because hard work comes from working the fields and growing and harvesting and passing on those things to others."
For Mr. Van Riper, 56, the grip of the land is hard to release for much the same reasons. He represents the 10th generation of his family to toil the earth; his forebears came from Holland and settled in the area in 1791. "This is the life that I know, that I have always known," he said. "And it's what I want to pass on." But for both families, modernization has helped the farming tradition compete in hard economic times that have forced others in the state's 21 counties to abandon their land.
In October 1979, an electrical fire destroyed a building that the Tices used to sell their fruit and vegetables just as the weekend crush began. "A day and a half later, we cleaned up the mess, pitched a circus tent and were back in business," Mr. Tice said.
What he chose to rebuildthe next year was a "country mall" complete with space for fruit and vegetables as well as some 30 stores including a dry cleaners, a gourmet cheese shop and an arts and crafts store. While it may have diminished some of the farm's country charm, Mr. Tice says it provided the means to stay in business. Both families say there is no rivalry between the two; a tractor-pulled hayride transports customers to both locations.
Yet the families' need to cultivate the soil is both bitter and sweet. For Mr. Tice, the dream of passing on the business from father to son ended when his oldest child died of cancer several years back. Today his daughter and son-in-law help to manage the operation. Mr. Van Riper's children have sought careers other than farming.
 "I'd like this to remain a family business," he said, "but I don't know what the future holds."
But to the thousands who visit the two farms as Halloween nears, the holiday tradition is a family affair and more. At Van Riper's the greenhouse is transformed into a scene from "The Wizard of Oz" and a mock graveyard complete with a dozing Dracula and amplified ghostly shrieks tantalize both the young and old.
"We're all having a grand time here, just look at the smiles," said Ray Pitt of Leonia looking at his two granddaughters, Emily, 4, and Isabella, 2, at Mr. Van Riper's farm. "It wasn't that long ago that we took our own kids here."
"Look, Mommy! The pumpkin patch!" said a chestnut-haired 3-uear-old boy, pressed into his mother's arms. "Is the great pumpkin here? Mommy, is he here?"
For Debra L. Fox of Mahwah and her two children, Adam, 4, and Michelle, 9 months, Halloween pumpkins cannot be picked in a supermarket.
"When I was little this was where Halloween came alive for me and now as a mom with my own, it's twice as good, twice as special," she said as her children cradled small pumpkins.
One sign of a strained economy, Mr. Tice and Mr. Van Riper noted, are customers who would traditionally decorate one pumpkin and buy another for display but are now buying only one to do both jobs. An average pumpkin costs from $8 to $10.
"The prices are a little high this year, but maybe I'm just feeling it more because I'm on the giving end now instead of the receiving end," said Jackie Manzi of Hasbrouck Heights as her two children, 4 and 17 months, looked at the rows of pumpkins. Her friend, Ruth Botto of Maywood, told her children : "Don't touch! Please put that back on the table! Get off the pumpkins, please, guys!"
For Mike Lotito, 30, of Wyckoff, the choice of a Halloween pumpkin was the excuse to take the day off from work and share an afternoon with his 4-year-old son Thomas. "This is our day together," he said, recalling that when he was a child, "things were a lot different."
Mr. Lotito recalled: "I remember that around Halloween, we'd come here and get stuck in traffic and my dad would get so mad that he'd mutter, 'We're getting out of here,' and my mom and us kids in the back would holler 'Oh no we're not!Those were good memories and this guy here and I are creating our own."
For some farm family members, the rewards of their work are in the wide eyes and cotton candy stains on children's fingers.
"It moves me to see regular customers who were kids back then come back with their own now," said Bonnie Van Riper, Mr. Van Riper's sister-in-law. "The faces change a little, but that glow is always in their eyes."
For Mr. Van Riper, the weekend chaos is never dull.
"A few years ago, before they widened the roads, I asked a guy why in the world he waited three hours in traffic to get here," Mr. Van Ripersaid. "He said, 'It's a hell of a lot better than raking leaves.' "

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Swarthmore;
Seeking Women To Protect Others After Dark

DATELINE: SWARTHMORE, Pa.

 BODY:
As students leave Swarthmore College's library or social center late at night, a woman may offer to walk them home. This semester, five women are acting as escorts in the college's Safewalk service, a security program in which students offer to accompany men and women back to their dormitories.
While Safewalk has hired women in the past, typically only one or two apply and work each semester. The low turnout may have been traceable to a belief that only men could become escorts, said Christina M. Saunders, the program's first female coordinator. 
 Miss Saunders, a senior from Olney, Md., majoring in sociology/anthropology and psychology, said she publicized Safewalk's nondiscriminatory policy when she became coordinator this spring. However, the number of women seeking the jobs did not increase until this fall, when all who applied were hired.
"The philosophy of the program has been prevention rather than protection," Miss Saunders said, explaining that having two students walking together may deter potential attacks. For that reason, she said, women can be as effective as men.
 
 Are Women Patronized by Men?
 Although most of the 31 Safewalk staff members are men, the presence of women should encourage more women to use the service, Miss Saunders said. Currently, the majority of Safewalk's users are women, she noted. Escorts usually work about two and a half hours a week and are paid from $4.30 to $4.55 an hour.
Nicoletta Karam, co-coordinator of Friends of Survivors, a campus group dedicated to promoting awareness about sexual assault, said many women feel patronized when men offer to escort them home.
"You feel as though they question your ability to help yourself," said Ms. Karam, a junior history major from San Francisco.
Ms. Karam said that with the presence of female escorts, she would be more inclined to have someone walk her home, be it a man or a woman. She said Safewalk has become less a perpetuation of the stereotype of the helpless woman.
"The pressures are much lower in accepting a woman escort," said Heather Blair, a first-year student from Seattle who was recently hired as an escort. "You don't feel as if you are being weak or being protected."
Miss Blair said that although she was subjected to occasional laughs when she offered to escort men, most of the feedback from men as well as women has been positive.
Brian J. Zikmund, a fourth-year Safewalker from San Bruno, Calif., majoring in economics, said having female escorts "makes it very clear to all concerned that their Safewalk service is a security-related program and does not have an inherent gender issue."
Nevertheless, some at Swarthmore have raised concerns about the use of women, since the escorts must return alone after dropping off a student at a dorm. Most students agree, however, that the campus is generally safe.
Carolyn Fay, in her second semester as an escort, said she felt "very omfortable walking by myself" in a campus where very few incidents take place.
Ms. Fay, a junior from Gradyville, Pa., majoring in French literature, said she applied as an escort to break traditional gender roles. "I thought it would be neat to do something that a lot of women don't do," she said.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Escaping the Capital Shortage

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
THE Bush Administration and leaders in the House and Senate finally cobbled together a budget agreement last week. And if it sticks, it might even have a real -- although small -- shrinking effect on the nation's budget deficit.
But for the equity investor, the reduction will not be enough, by any stretch, to ease the growing capital supply problem that is coloring the economic outlook for the next year. Nor will the situation be helped even if the Middle East crisis is resolved relatively quickly. 
 That is because the United States, which has become the world's largest debtor, will still need billions of dollars in foreign capital to cover its trade and budget deficits. And Eastern Europe will also be screaming for capital to rebuild itself after more than 40 years of Communist rule.
Yet the world's two main creditors, Japan and Germany, have less to lend, perhaps much less. Japan, the largest exporter of capital, is pulling back as money is brought home to help recapitalize banks and cushion their losses from the Tokyo stock market's decline this year of nearly 50 percent. And Germany has to pay for the rebuilding of the old East Germany.
This capital imbalance, at least for now, is the reason for the bear market outlook of David C. Roche, the co-director of research for Morgan Stanley & Company in London. It accounts for his predisposition to invest in cash or bonds in Europe.
Mr. Roche is worried that bankruptcies of major companies suddenly may start to pop up, shaking the financial markets. And he concludes that the worsening outlook for growth and inflation in Europe will aggravate the capital problem by enlarging deficits there next year.
The consequence of meeting this capital demand, he said in an interview last week, is going to be a rise in overall savings. The attraction of high interest rates diverts consumer spending into savings, which in turn slows economic growth. This rise in savings and resulting slowdown was already under way before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Mr. Roche expects consumers to continue saving because rates will remain relatively high for the next few months.
The question is just how severe the slowdown will be. Mr. Roche expects "recessionary periods," or quarters, next year in which growth will decline in Italy, Scandinavia and possibly in France and Spain. A recession is likely in Britain. Germany is still growing the most but it is not the engine it might have been for the rest of Europe. Because of its central role in the European economy, Germany has exported its high interest rates to its neighbors and that has been enough to offset the growth generated by rising European exports to Germany.
Mr. Roche has cut his forecast for growth in Europe in 1991 to 1.9 percent, from 2.7 percent. And he predicts earnings per share will drop by 2.6 percent, a dramatic shift from his previous forecast of a 4.5 percent increase.
But because Mr. Roche believes the economic slowdown in Europe is being caused by rising savings, he also thinks a turnaround can come quickly with a decline in interest rates. He notes that household income in Europe has been rising this year, so consumers are not losing buying power. They are just deciding to save more because of the high rates they can earn.
This all combines to form an approach to equities that inspires caution but also encourages investors to be ready to pounce.
So while Mr. Roche still likes cash, he has reduced his cash position to 13 percent, from 19 percent, in order to buy bonds in Europe, especially Germany and France, because he feels interest rates are near their peak.
And he has a new interest in Japan, where the recent rise in the yen and a small drop in interest rates have sparked a nice rally. "I just feel that the relative strength of Japan to Europe no longer directs such a strong overweight to Europe," he said.
In Europe, Mr. Roche is staying away from chemicals, automobiles, machine tools, airlines (except for Germany's Lufthansa) and hotels. These will all suffer in the slowdown. He is also staying away from many banks for now, selling Credit Lyonnais in France and Banco Commerciale Italiana, among others. (But he is keeping his banks in Germany.) As for countries, he is avoiding investments in Italy (except for telecommunications), Greece, Turkey, Spain and Sweden; he does not think they will rebound quickly. Italy has deep budget problems, for example, and Sweden is facing an economic overhaul.
Mr. Roche likes companies that will play a role in the remaking of the old East Germany and the rest of Eastern Europe: road builders, telephone companies, office suppliers and utilities, among others.
This theme has piqued his interest in Germany although he expects a 4 percent overall decline in earnings there next year. He thinks most of this decline will be borne by the chemical, auto and other stocks that he is avoiding. On his "buy" list: Siemens, Hochtief, Mannesmann and Bilfinger & Berger. He also likes CGE and Saint Gobain in France.
"I can find stocks," he said, "that are doing things that can get done despite the economic cycle."

HEADLINE: All About/Elevators;
Building Business on a Few Seconds' Edge

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
TODAY'S concrete urban jungles owe their characters not only to architects and engineers, but to the unassuming electric elevator. Its invention in 1889 by Otis Elevator Inc. ushered in the age of the skyscraper. The 20-story Flatiron Building in Manhattan, built in 1902 with five electric lifts -- still operating -- was one of the early structures to use the new technology.
Today, elevator researchers are not after revolutionary advances but incremental jumps -- speedier rides for passengers and shorter waits. For manufacturers, any edge can make a difference in what has become a hotly competitive market. 
 Consolidation has kindled competition. The top three companies, Otis, the Swiss-based Schindler Group and Kone of Finland, now control 50 percent of the worldwide market, up sharply from 1980. Kone and Schindler have expanded to stand taller against the world leader, Otis. And all three have widened their reach in an increasingly global business and participated in the robust growth of the last decade.
Sparked by a building boom that has spread from the United States to Europe and Asia and by the development of third world cities, the worldwide elevator market expanded by about 15 percent a year through the early 1980's, and reached $17 billion in sales last year. About 40 percent of those sales came from maintaining and modernizing elevators; new installations accounted for the rest.
But installations have recently begun to taper off, stoking rivalries. Orders have suffered from the decline in office construction in the United States, the biggest outlet for new elevators. Second-quarter sales of the leading elevator companies fell by an average of 5 percent, and some dropped by as much as 20 percent.
"It is no secret that there is a recession, or something like it, and that the construction sector has been hit harder than any other," said David J. Bauhs, president and chief executive of United States operations of the Schindler, the world's No. 2 elevator maker. The unavailability of financing and high vacancy rates have hurt us, too."
Elevator prices, which range from $25,000 to $500,000 apiece, have started to slip. "We're seeing heavy price pressure and we anticipate that prices will fall 2 to 6 percent in 1991," said James Cocca, vice president of marketing in the United States for Schindler.

 
 
Greener Markets

 
Stability in Europe, A Boom in Asia
 To cope, companies are stressing less mature markets like Asia, Europe and Eastern Europe. While the United States market has expanded by only about 2 percent a year since 1986, to about $4.2 billion last year, annual growth in Europe has remained strong, at 10 percent a year, for total sales of $5.9 million in 1989.
The industrialization in Asia has also kept momentum building. "We have seen 30 percent annual growth in new elevator orders in Japan for each of the last four years," said George A.L. David, chairman and chief executive of Otis, a subsidiary of the United Technologies Corporation. Last year, Otis built an engineering center in Japan and recently introduced a new, space-saving elevator motor there.
Manufacturers are also chasing the market for elevator maintenance, repair and modernization, which has grown by 25 percent since 1985, to about $7 billion last year. While big manufacturers like Schindler have grown by concentrating on installation, they have lately pushed harder in the service business. They calculate that as new construction slows and investment in older buildings shrinks, property owners will have no choice but to modernize elevators.
That will put new pressure on the small elevator companies, which have largely been pushed out of manufacturing by bigger rivals and which have turned servicing into their specialty. The big manufacturers may deem some of them attractive acquisition targets.

 
 
Shifting Strategies

Turf Battles On a Global Scale
Acquisition, in fact, has been the main mode of growth for the three largest elevator makers -- and has dramatically reshaped the industry in the last two decades. In the 70's, dozens of elevator manufacturers were scattered throughout the world, each typically with a dominant market share in its home country. Only one, Otis Elevator, had plants and operations around the globe.
Today, Otis remains the foremost elevator manufacturer, with sales of $3.3 billion in 1989, up from $1.6 billion in 1980. But it faces far stronger competition.
The bulging elevator market in the United States beckoned foreign elevator producers to challenge Otis on its home turf in the early 80's. With sales of $2.3 billion last year, Schindler, for instance, has expanded its share of the global market to about 15 percent, from 7 percent in 1980.
Last year, Schindler acquired the elevator and escalator business of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, giving Schindler a large research center in the United States, in addition to one in Switzerland. Schindler had already purchased elevator companies in Japan, India, Kenya, Chile and Hungary.
Kone, with $1.6 billion-a-year in sales, has followed a similar tack. Five years ago, it bought the Armor Elevator Company of Louisville, Ky., a specialist in service and modernization. It has since purchased two of Italy's largest independent elevator companies: Fiam and Sabiem.
In recent years, Mitsubishi and Hitachi, large producers in Japan, have also become more visible, although they have yet to establish a global presence and their manufacturing plants are based primarily in Japan. Still, Otis and Schindler expect them to acquire elevators companies in the United States and Europe. At the same time, Otis has been expanding as feverishly as its rivals, invading many of their home markets. It has bought four small Italian elevator makers, three in Britain and one in Germany in the last 15 years. In the last year, it has solidified its presence in Eastern Europe, the development of which, Otis claims, could double its sales.
But Otis is unlikely to have the market to itself. Both Schindler and Kone have been setting up joint ventures and buying major interests in elevator companies in East Germany and in Hungary.
Meanwhile, these changes in the market have pushed out many small American companies and have driven others into niche markets, like elevators for small apartment houses or freight elevators. "There is always a niche for smaller companies who might focus on the two- and three-story buildings," said George R. Strakosch, an editor at Elevator World, a trade publication in Mobile, Ala.

 
 
Shaving Off Seconds

The Mighty Microprocessor
The difference between a 20-second wait and a 15-second wait is of little consequence for the average elevator passenger. But for manufacturers, it can mean the difference between winning and losing a contract.
As rivalries have grown, so have the research outlays by companies to develop ways to improve response and delivery times. Otis, for instance, will spend $80 million on research this year, up from $26 million five years ago.
Microprocessors have already allowed elevator control systems to be programmed for dispatching, and their uses are being broadened. Researchers at the major companies are developing computerized systems that dispatch elevators to floors according to traffic patterns detected by a control system during the course of a week. In addition to microprocessor technology, this system depends on perfecting the complex algorithms in an elevator's computer system that decide, for instance, how best to distribute cars in a high-rise building that has more than one elevator.
At Otis and Schindler, researchers are also working on a system that can determine the number of people waiting for an elevator. Now an elevator is unable to detect, once a call button is pushed, whether there is one passenger or 40 waiting on a floor. But engineers at Otis have found that lasers can count the number of people waiting in an area and relay that information to the dispatching system, which would then use it to decide the number of elevators to send to the floor.
In addition, elevator companies are developing systems that would shave seconds off their performance times. Researchers at Otis are close to selling systems that will place sensors near the elevators on each floor of a high-rise building which can determine whether people are moving toward the elevator as it approaches a floor. If no one approaches, the doors will close quickly rather than remain open for several seconds.
 
 
THE REMNANTS OF A GENTLER AGE

 A GENERATION ago, the men and women who operated elevators were almost fixtures in office buildings, apartment houses and department stores. But in the last 30 years, with the evolution of elevator technology, the profession has virtually vanished.
Indeed, in New York City, which has historically had the largest number of elevator operators, the number of unionized elevator operators has dwindled to 1,000, from 20,000 in 1950. "There was a time when you could walk into almost any high-rise building in New York City and see an elevator operator," said John J. Sweeney, president of the Service Employees International Union in Washington. "But this is an area that technology has done away with."
The feature that put many operators out of business were the elevator buttons that allow riders to designate their own destinations. Previously, operators actually drove the elevators, guided by a combination of lights, bells and landmarks to line up the elevator door with the door onto a given floor.
The largest number of elevator operators, Mr. Sweeney said, is in New York and Chicago; there are fewer in the West and Southwest, where skyscrapers were built only after technology had made operators obsolete.
There are a few elevator operators left, but they tend to be in luxury apartment apartment buildings and sometimes, in department stores.
"I keep elevator operators in some of my buildings because it lends a certain air of luxury and elegance," said the owner of several apartment buildings on Manhattan's Upper East Side. The owner, who insisted on remaininganonymous, added that he had also continued to employ elevator operators because he uses older, manual elevators in those buildings.

GRAPHIC: Photos: A research laboratory at Schindler Elevator in Randolph, N.J. Left: Evaluating elevator doors at Schindler (Eddie Hausner/The New York Times); In most buildings, technology has superseded the elevator operator. (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Business Diary/October 21-26

BYLINE: By Sallie Hofmeister

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
 
A Tisket, a Tasket, Taxes in a Basket

 After five months of nettlesome negotiations, Congress and President Bush finally seem to be of one mind about how to reduce the Federal deficit. And not a moment too soon: After dwindling to manageable levels in the late 1980's, the budget deficit surged in this fiscal year, which just ended, to a near-record $220.4 billion. The budget accord reached by Congressional leaders on Wednesday, which has the tacit approval of the President, is similar to the rejected plan announced in September, placing a burden on drivers, liquor drinkers, smokers and the wealthy. But this package would ask the rich to pay more than the first accord did and would give the poor a bigger break. Among the winners are the energy producers, which get a tax break for drilling and for making ethanol. One big loser: life insurers, which face the biggest tax increase of any industry.
 
Cleaner Air, but Count the Cost
 Cleaner air is in sight, but it may cost consumers as much as $50 billion. Settling a decade of differences, Congress was expected to approve this weekend amendments to the Clean Air Act that are intended to clear the sky of smog and harmful fumes by limiting emissions from cars and factories. The chemical, steel, utility and auto industries will bear much of the estimated $30 billion in compliance costs but may have little luck passing them onto customers if a recession causes demand for their products to shrink.
 
All-New Labeling for Food
 Food packaging designers may be in for boom times. In the most sweeping revision of food labeling laws in 20 years, the Senate approved a bill, a version of which has already passed the House, that would require nutritional labeling on all packaged foods and strictly regulate disease-prevention claims on labels. An estimated 40 percent of last year's food product introductions made such promises. Under the bill, which is bound for Presidential approval, manufacturers have two years to relabel products and grocers would be expected within a year to post nutritional information on 20 popular fruits and vegetables.
 
Oil-Price Respite Proves Brief
 Oil prices dropped to their lowest level in weeks on Tuesday, to $28.38 a barrel, on news that Saudi Arabia was mulling concessions to Iraq to end the Persion Gulf stalemate. But crude rose the rest of the week, closing at $33.01 on Friday, driven up by President Bush's plan to deploy 100,000 more troops.
 
Milken Takes the Fifth
 Michael Milken may have decided to quit while he was ahead. Rather than taking the stand in the hearing ordered by Judge Kimba Wood to help decide his sentence for six felonies, Mr. Milken took the Fifth Amendment on Friday, bringing the two-week hearing to a close. The hearing cast doubt on the probity of Mr. Milken's "junk bond" operation at Drexel Burnham Lambert, but whether Mr. Milken ever traded on insider information is murky.
 
 S.&L. Examiners and 'Bandits'
 In further evidence that regulators played a part in the downfall of the savings industry, a former examiner at the Federal Home Loan Bank of Seattle testified in Congressional hearings last week that she was harassed and dismissed for questioning $300,000 in bonuses paid to management by the Far West Federal Bank, the largest savings institution in Portland, Ore., which is now in Government hands. An official of the Office of Thrift Supervision said the evidence backed up her position.
Described as "one of the biggest savings and loan bandits" by Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, Jarrett E. Woods was indicted last Thursday on 37 charges of bank fraud, misuse of funds and conspiracy in connection with one of the largest bank failures in Texas, Western Savings Association. Federal regulators had filed a civil lawsuit against Mr. Woods, its former owner, seeking $560 million in damages, one of the largest sums sought by the Government from a savings executive.
 
INTERNATIONAL


 
 
R.T.C. Finds Japanese Investor
 Despite the skepticism among the Japanese about investing in the United States and the decline in the fortunes of Japan's financial firms as the stock market there has slipped, the American subsidiary of the Nomura Securities Corporation is negotiating to purchase $1 billion in commercial loans from the Resolution Trust Corporation. If the deal is finalized, it would represent the largest sale yet by the agency overseeing the savings and loan bailout and one of its first involving a Japanese investor.

 
 
Philips Keeps Trimming
 N.V. Philips is continuing to slim down in an effort to become a more nimble opponent for the Japanese. The Dutch electronics conglomerate announced a bold plan to eliminate by year-end up to 45,000 jobs, or 16 percent of its work force. The company also said it would pay no dividend this year and its annual loss would be more than its projected $1.18 billion. A cost-cutting program to trim 10,000 jobs from its work force of 286,000 was already under way before the announcement, and follows another move by Philips to pare itself down: earlier this year, it sold far-flung operations in toothbrush and a garage-door opener manufacturing.

 
 
Little Success in Trade Talks
 President Bush has gone to bat for the American farmer. But Washington's negotiators are striking out in talks aimed at getting trading partners to reduce farm subsidies, as part of a four-year round to liberalize world trade. Division in the European Community on the level of reductions caused the group to miss an Oct. 15 deadline for a proposal, raising the specter that the talks would collapse. Washington was pushing for a 90 percent reduction in subsidies, which it says make it difficult for Americans to compete. But France and Germany refused to shave them by even 30 percent, the level favored by their fellow members.
 
COMPANIES


 
 
Fat Gas Profits? Not Yet

 Price-gouging among gasoline marketers? You'd never suspect it from oil companies' third-quarter results. For most, refining and marketing operations were a hinderance, not a help. Analysts say that honoring the President's request for price restraint at the pump allowed oil companies to recover only about half of their higher crude costs through gasoline price hikes. Companies relying most heavily on outside crude supplies for its refining and marketing operations took the worst hit. They include the two largest oil concerns: the Exxon Corporation, which, without a one-time gain, would have seen quarterly earnings drop slightly, and the Mobil Corporation, whose profits did drop, by nearly 29 percent. Both purchase roughly half of their crude from foreign sources. In contrast, Texaco Inc., which produces more than half of its crude needs, enjoyed a 25 percent rise in earnings.

 
 
UAL's New Spunkiness
 Despite a downturn in travel and an upswing in fuel prices, the UAL Corporation is splurging. After the protracted takeover battle for its United Airlines came to a close early this month, the company placed a $22 billion aircraft order, the biggest ever. And it agreed last week to pay Pan American World Airways $400 million in cash for several vaunted routes from the United States to Europe. If approved by regulatory authorities, the purchase would give United a big lead in Europe over its archrivals, American and Delta. United's renewed spunk has perked up its stock, which had dropped to the mid-$80 after the failed buyout bid but closed Friday at $96.75. And UAL was among the best-performing airlines in the third quarter, noticing only a slight fall in earnings while other carriers took losses.

 
 
Continental Sheds Top Brass
 The Pan Am Corporation is hurting for cash. But it is the parent of Continental Airlines that apparently brushed with bankrupty last week. Although it has been beaten down by unexpected losses, rising fuel prices and a payment of $80.5 million to the pension fund of its sister, Eastern Airlines, Continental decided against filing bankruptcy proceedings after preparing the documents. But another overhaul took shape. In an apparent attempt to clear the decks of close allies of Frank Lorenzo, its former chairman, Continental said four top executives would leave the company.

 
 
Citicorp, Paying Dearly
 Concerns over mounting loan losses are exacting a toll on banking companies' cost of capital. Citicorp agreed to pay higher dividend rates on its preferred stock to keep its auctions from failing. Monday, it paid 9.4 percent on a $75 million issue, nearly three percentage points higher than that paid at an auction earlier this month, before Citicorp released disappointing third-quarter earnings. On Thursday, the bank agreed to another three-point jump, to 12.5 percent on a $100 million issue -- about double the yield paid by one of the strongest banks, J.P. Morgan.
Weighty loan losses are forcing some banks to part with their most precious assets. The MNC Financial Corporation of Baltimore, Maryland's biggest banking company, was forced to put its $1 billion credit card business, the nation's fourth largest, up for sale to offset losses. Pining to expand in plastic, industrialist like A.T.&T. and General Electric may try to pick up the prize.

 
 
The Reds' Win is CBS's Loss
 The Cincinnati Reds' four-game sweep over the Oakland Athletics in the World Series may saddle CBS with a loss of $100 million or more in the first year of its high-priced, four-year, $1.06 billion baseball contract. The series ran shorter than the six-game average, depriving CBS of advertising revenues.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
A New Test Of Buffett's Reputation

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
JUST when oil prices started to fall last week, the United States Government began talking tough and hinting of a possible military action to liberate Kuwait, pushing crude quotes higher again. And as the week ended, a deal to raise taxes significantly seemed to be near.
With actions like that, one could conclude that the Government wants a recession. And, from President Bush's perspective, why not? The 1981-82 recession cost the Republicans some Congressional seats but it paved the way for an economic recovery that made Ronald Reagan the most popular President in a generation. 
 With that last recession having ended eight years ago, many on Wall Street now worry that the excesses built up since then -- especially in debts that will not be paid back -- make a new recession potentially a very damaging event. Real estate -- the most popular of assets for much of the last decade -- now is seen as a curse that could bring down the American banking industry.
Wall Street's worries last week came through both in the movement of the Dow Jones industrial average, which declined 84.65 points to 2,436.14, and in the further erosion of confidence in bank securities. The flight from most New York money center banks -- J. P. Morgan is a conspicuous exception -- took on a new impetus just as the banks were having their annual convention in Orlando, Fla., down the road from Disney World. Unfortunately, investors are beginning to realize that Mickey Mouse cartoons have sometimes been closer to reality than were bank estimates of possible loan losses.
Citicorp, the biggest bank holding company in the country, was forced to pay a 12.5 percent dividend to find willing owners of its preferred shares. Considering the tax advantages of preferred stock, that means corporations buying the shares are demanding the equivalent of a taxable 17 percent yield, a "junk" rate if ever there was one.
Into that glum setting came word that Warren Buffett, the boss of Berkshire Hathaway, a student of the legendary Ben Graham and a man renowned for investment judgment, was loading up on shares of Wells Fargo, a California bank that is far from being a basket case but whose stock price has nonetheless fallen sharply amid fears of losses from its aggressive real estate lending. Mr. Buffett's companies now have almost 10 percent of Wells Fargo's stock.
Almost by definition, the best time to buy is also the most difficult time to make the decision. It is when things look bleakest, when almost everyone is bearish, that prices hit bottom. For the entire stock market, that time may not have arrived yet. But in bank securities, it is to be fervently hoped that a bottom is near, if not at hand, and that Mr. Buffett, who built his reputation by buying insurance and newspaper stocks at a time when few wanted them, will be proved right again.
The alternative conclusion is that the banking industry will go the way of the savings and loans, becoming a Government ward. If that is to happen, it is hard to be bullish about anything.
