HEADLINE: FORUM;
A Company Gives Up on New York

BYLINE: By CHARLES L. SCHULTZE; Charles L. Schultze, senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, was chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Carter Administration.

 BODY:
THE budget agreement that is now working its way toward enactment is a good one. It will not achieve all that is claimed for it, but it will make substantial cuts in the deficit that are real. The tax increases and some of the entitlement cuts will be locked into substantive law, and, barring a shooting war in the Persian Gulf, future defense spending is likely to be less than what the budget agreement promises.
We Americans are finally facing up, if only partially, to correcting a decade of public and private profligacy, during which the country borrowed massively at home and abroad to finance a consumption boom. As a nation we now save and invest only 3 percent of our national income. Our economic future depends on raising national saving, mainly through getting rid of the Federal budget deficit and ultimately turning it into a surplus. The budget agreement is a major step in that direction. 
 The magnitude of the sacrifices the American people have now been asked to make is actually quite small. The sum of all the tax increases, about which such a titanic struggle has been waged, will amount to something like seven-tenths of 1 percent of national income. Yet listening to months of rhetoric about "fairness" -- on the part of the Democrats -- and "the need to preserve incentives," on the part of the Republicans, made it seem that the country was engaged in some massive economic restructuring, a perestroika of our own.
The progressivity of the latest tax agreement makes it better than the original proposal. And establishing the principle that progressive income taxes are not off-limits when taxes have to be raised is worthwhile.
But most of the political fights that erupted were not worth bringing the whole agreement to the brink of defeat. Reducing the gasoline tax increase from 12 cents to 5 cents a gallon, for example, will mean a savings of only about $1.40 a week for the average family. Inequality in the United States has indeed increased over the past 15 years, but the tax code was not the principal culprit.
The Republican position in the recent squabble was particularly silly. Does anyone really believe that American productivity and efficiency will be seriously affected by whether upper-income executives and Silicon Valley entrepreneurs pay a top-bracket rate of 28, 31 or 33 percent? Do our German and Japanese competitors appear to be severely handicapped by the fact that one has a top income tax rate of 53 percent and the other of 50 percent? Only in the heat of an ideological passion, could grown people make so much of so little.
The payoff from reducing the budget deficit will not be immediate. It will not rescue us from the recession we are apparently entering. Rather, it will come from larger national savings and investment, whose benefits in the form of higher economic growth will show up only gradually.
It is terribly hard to muster political support to do painful things for such subtle and distant goals. And for eight years the country has had two popular Presidents who have not only failed to use their office to mobilize public opinion toward that goal, but have actively blocked the modest tax increases that were obviously necessary to reach it.
Small wonder that the Congressional troops concentrated on bickering about how the costs were to be divided. The bully pulpit had never been used to educate the troops' constituents on what the benefits would be.
In the end what is truly remarkable is the fact that the system ended up doing the responsible thing. President Bush deserves credit for reversing his stand on taxes. But the real heroes are the Congressional leadership. Ultimately, even the troops in the trenches look as if they will respond with an act of political courage. The majority will vote for a tax increase two weeks before an election. It is not such a bad system after all.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Opportunities in Soviet Disintegration

BYLINE: By VLADIMIR KVINT; Vladimir Kvint, the U.S.S.R. Professor of Political Economy, resides in Manhattan and advises companies about doing business in the Soviet Union.

 BODY:
DESPITE the Soviet Parliament's approval of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plan to create a market economy, the Soviet Union will not live to celebrate its 70-year anniversary in 1992. The Soviet Union's political and economic crises are intensifying and if the forces of disintegration continue -- as I expect they will -- the Union will come apart. By 1992, there will be no country called the Soviet Union.
In place of the old Soviet Union, new states will appear. These states will welcome foreign investment. For Europe and the United States, these resource-rich republics could become the new Klondike. But to take advantage of the opportunities that will arise as the Soviet Union disintegrates, investors will have to think in terms of several diverse markets -- not one country. 
 My own assessment, as a regional economist, is that the safest place to invest will continue to be the Russian Republic. Even without its empire, Russia will remain the largest country in the world. Siberia alone, which is a part of Russia, is bigger than the United States. Russia contains not only 92 percent of the Soviet Union's oil, but also 85 percent of its natural resources. According to my calculations, it would cost one-fifth to one-third as much to transport oil to the United States from Russia as from the Middle East.
But Russia is not homogeneous. That is why the degree of political and economic risk varies depending on the territory.
The region of Russia called Dagestan, on the Caspian Sea, is largely Muslim, but is also home to 36 other ethnic groups. Dagestan is very stable and open to foreign investment, unlike its neighbor, Azerbaijan, where ethnic fighting is rampant.
Moscow and Leningrad are attractive places to invest. In the Soviet Far East, the Sakhalin and Primorski territories near Japan are especially attractive as markets. Political risk there is minimal and a basic infrastructure is already in place. The Pacific region in general is becoming the center of world business activity and the Russian Far East, with its tremendous resources, can play a major role.
So far, the Parliament of Russia is the most full-blooded and reliable in the Soviet Union. Next comes the government of the Ukraine and then, with more reservations, the governments of Estonia and Latvia. Guarantees coming from the other Republics are not worth much now.
The 1990's will see the re-emergence of Russian companies, after nearly 70 years. The 1990's will also see these companies become integrated into the world economy through alliances with foreign companies. What will be created, as these changes unfold, is a new nation, devoid of empire, but with the potential for creating abundant wealth.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
The Global Strategy of Fiona Biggs

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
ON Aug. 3, Fiona Biggs received the news in a routine 1:55 A.M. telephone call from her Japanese stockbroker: Iraq had invaded Kuwait. After she hung up, she stumbled over the freeweight equipment and the Reuters and fax machines that crowd the bedroom of her New York City apartment and sat in the kitchen impatiently until 4:30, when the European markets opened. Then she quickly sold all of her British stocks and bought shares in Royal Dutch Petroleum.
This bet paid off handsomely, like many others she has placed in the past. In 1989, her first full year managing the $25 million Dreyfus Strategic World Investing fund, and in 1990, too, Ms. Biggs far surpassed the other 10 global flexible funds. Global flexible funds invest in stocks, bonds and money-market securities, with at least 25 percent of the portfolio invested outside the United States. 
 So far this year, the 28-year-old Ms. Biggs has posted a 5.4 percent gain while other global flexible funds have lost nearly 7 percent. For the 12 months ended Oct. 11, her fund was up 7.3 percent while her competitors as a group posted a 5.6 percent drop and all stock funds plunged 15.3 percent, according to Lipper Analytical Services.
 "She's had a great deal of success," said John A. Rekenthaler, a senior analyst at Morningstar Inc., Chicago-based mutual fund consultants. "You can't argue with the results for the last two years."
Ms. Biggs's own philosophy is simple: "I don't like to gamble with my money or with my investors'," she says. To that end, she operates her fund as a defensive play, using hedging and trading techniques to minimize her downside risk, techniques that force her to move nimbly across different markets and to maneuver through a world of risk and opportunity. Unlike many of her rivals, who often just stick to stock and bond picking, she sells stock short, leverages her portfolio and invests in interest rate futures contracts or stock index futures.
How did she build this year's spectacular record? "I was cautious on the U.S. and Japan all year," she said. She bought companies with strong balance sheets and sold short the shares of cyclical companies with weak balance sheets. (In a short sale, you sell stock that you do not own, hoping to deliver the promised shares by buying the stock later at a lower price.)
She began 1990 with 50 percent of the fund in cash -- the smallest cash position that she's had all year. The rest was divided among stocks: 5 percent in Japan, 25 percent in Europe and 20 percent in the United States. Sensing a free fall in the Japanese market because of the weakening yen, she sold all the Japanese stock by the beginning of February and then began to buy put warrants on the Nikkei index, a proxy for the Japanese stock market. (A put warrant is an option to sell stocks at a set price for a set period.)
In May, concerned about Japanese liquidity problems and how they could affect the American market and about America's troubled real estate and financial services sectors, she sold some American holdings short, primarily leveraged companies and those in financial services and consumer goods. In August, after the Iraqi invasion, she sold European stocks, bringing that sector to about 7 percent, from 25 percent, and raised cash to nearly 65 percent. "I thought the invasion would have a short-term negative effect on worldwide stock markets," she said.
The fund can buy bonds but she held only small amounts of American debt for short periods in 1990. Why didn't she tap into the fat returns of foreign short-term paper? "I should have, but I didn't," she said. "We had a lot of other bets already." Her biggest oversight, she thinks, was not selling more Japanese stocks short because "that was the most obvious way to make money this year."
Ms. Biggs, who earned an M.B.A. from New York University and joined Dreyfus in 1987, splits her work day between her Dreyfus office and her four-bedroom Manhattan apartment, navigating markets that operate in different time zones. She usually sleeps between 10 P.M. and 5 A.M., with two wake-up calls from stockbrokers -- one at 1:55 from Japan, the other at 4:30 from Europe.
She has a dour view of things to come, believing the "U.S. market will continue to decline, reaching 2200 or lower." She now has 63 percent in cash, 35 percent in American and European stocks, and the rest in short positions and Japanese put warrants. In mid-October, she closed out many of her Japanese short positions "because the strength of the yen is a new positive for that market."
 Her American stock holdings are split among food, drug and energy companies. Her biggest position is Beckton Dickinson, a Franklin Lakes, N.J.-based medical supply company. Another favorite: Philip Morris. Her European portion is split between food and capital goods companies. She likes Nestle, the Swiss food conglomerate; Siemens, a German industrial conglomerate, and C.G.E., a French transportation, communications and energy company.
Many of her hunches have proved right and depending on how much money was at risk, she probably has pulled in profits. So how much is she paid for her acumen? She won't say.

 
 
THE WIDENING YIELD SPREAD ON 'JUNK'

 AFTER peaking in February, the spread in yields between "junk bond" funds and corporate A-rated bond funds drifted downward until August. At that point, the trend reversed as the yield spread neared the February high, and in September, surpassed that high.
What happened? The last time there was a big jump in the yield spread -- late in 1989 -- Drexel Burnham Lambert, the dominant junk bond force, was unraveling and there were growing concerns about whether there would be a market for junk issues. This time, investors are worried about whether companies, unable to meet their huge interest payments during a recession, will default. Indeed, junk bond defaults are already at record levels and show no signs of slowing. Yield spreads are likely to stay wide, then, as investors demand high rewards for assuming high risk.

HEADLINE: The News Strike Shows Shifting Labor Relations

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
With nonunion workers crossing picket lines in large numbers, the strike at The Daily News has underscored the new realities for labor and management in New York City. Labor experts say these realities illustrate why, 10 or 20 or 30 years ago, the strike would not have unfolded the way it has in what was long considered to be one of the nation's last big union towns.
"There are no union towns any more," said Esther Fuchs, a professor of political science at Barnard College, who is completing a book on labor relations in New York and Chicago. She and other labor specialists, as well as some labor leaders, said that changing public attitudes have played the largest part in why that is so. The air-traffic controllers' strike in 1981, crushed by President Reagan, gave credibility to antiunion attitudes that had been growing a long time. 
 "Since the controllers' strike," said Theodore W. Kheel, a lawyer and longtime adviser to unions at The News, "employers have been emboldened to take more and more militant stands."
Management's increasing boldness at once reflected and reinforced the perception that unions no longer seemed focused on safeguarding workers from unfair management, but on fulfilling the economic desires of an increasingly well-paid work force.
"It's more dramatic in New York, as everything is more dramatic in New York," said Professor Fuchs, "and the old coalitions die hard. Unions are still part of the politcal fabric of New York City, but I would easily guess that the public is not going to be particularly distressed that The Daily News is considered to be antiunion in this particular dispute."
Dick Netzer, a professor at the Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service at New York University, said newspapers waited longer than other businesses to try to put unions on the defensive. "It's inconceivable to me that a newspaper employer would have been this tough 10 or 12 years ago," he said.
At The News, where labor had long said it believed that it was on reasonably good terms with management, the more strident approach was also built on economic necessity. Despite New York's boom of the 1980's, The News was a losing operation. In trying to sell the paper in 1982, management acknowledged that the paper was awash in red ink. Circulation declined by more than 700,000 copies a day between 1983 and 1990.
 
Victim of Demographics
 The News's increasingly weak position forced the unions to react in a way that was almost the polar opposite of what was familiar to them."Twenty years ago," said Mr. Kheel, "unions struck at drop of a hat. Here, the union was determined not to."
Newspaper analysts say The News was a victim of changing demographics. "Large numbers of the people who were traditional readers of The Daily News moved up and out and ceased being readers of daily newspapers at all," Professor Netzer said.
The changing work place was more of a factor in the erosion of union support. The city's old manufacturing base, which once provided vast numbers of unionized jobs, gave way to nonunionized information and financial services. "Twenty or 30 years ago, you could find a labor movement with clout, backbone and visibility," said Sumner Rosen, formerly a high-ranking organizer at District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. "That's gone."
Unions now account for less than 20 percent of the working population nationally, labor specialists say.
Now, with the New York economy on shakier ground and the city threatening to lay off more than 30,000 workers, there is, Professor Fuchs said, little public support for striking workers like those at The News.
"The general public tenor is, 'If I'm not protected, so why should you be?' " she said. "There are hundreds if not thousands of people waiting on line to take blue-collar jobs, so the ability of unions to rally people in their favor has declined."

HEADLINE: U.S. Says It Sent No Signals To Expel Lebanese General

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27

 BODY:
The Bush Administration has taken the view that while Syria's ouster of Gen. Michel Aoun from the presidential palace in Beirut was particularly violent, it was the only solution that offered any promise of a more stable Lebanon.
Questions have arisen on what signal the United States may have sent Damascus before the confrontation between Syrian troops and supporters of the renegade general. About 750 Lebanese and Syrian soldiers and civilians were killed in the fighting two weeks ago, and unconfirmed reports say that dozens of the dead were executed after they surrendered, or were victims of revenge killings long after combat ceased. 
 Administration officials, still smarting from accusations that they sent the wrong message to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and may have inadvertently encouraged him to invade Kuwait, say they went out of their way to notify Damascus that the United States did not endorse a Syrian military operation to oust General Aoun.
But officials make clear that they did not flash any red lights at Damascus either, since the Syrian-supported Lebanese Government was inviting the Syrians to remove General Aoun. He had entrenched himself in the Presidential Palace in Baabda and refused to stand aside for the legally elected President, Elias Hrawi, or to recognize the constitutional changes approved by the Lebanese Parliament last year in Taif, Saudi Arabia, that put Lebanon's Muslims and Christians on a more equal political footing.
 
'Not Approving Anything'
 "We had conversations with both the Lebanese and the Syrians," a senior Administration official said. "We made clear that we were not giving anyone a green light. We did not give any red lights either. You couldn't, because the Lebanese Government was inviting the Syrians to take action. We just made clear that we were not approving anything."
But the question Administration officials asked themselves, he said, was "whether the fighting might lead to a process where they begin to put Humpty Dumpty back together again."
"The process was dead in the water before," he said. "Now at least there is a glimmer of hope."
As Lebanon's Ambassador to Washington, Nassib Lahoud, put it: "The Lebanese Government has neither sought nor received any green lights from the United States. We asked for Syrian intervention in accord with the Taif agreement, which allows us to seek their assistance in recovering Lebanon's sovereignty."
 
A Protest in Washington
 That view is not shared by some groups in the United States that view General Aoun as a Lebanese patriot who was fighting to keep the country independent of Syria. The National Alliance of Lebanese-Americans demonstrated across from the White House on Friday, carrying placards reading: "Middle East Double Standard. Iraq Invades Kuwait: Outrage. Syria Invades Lebanon: Silence."
But far from creating any friction between the Administration and President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, the Syrian effort to oust General Aoun seems to have added momentum to the improvement in relations resulting from Syria's commitment of troops to the American-led coalition against Iraq.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, in his testimony before the House Foreign Affairs Committee on Oct. 18, was asked to comment on relations between Washington and Damascus.
"We are appreciative of the role that Syria is playing in support of the international coalition in the gulf," he said. "Its commitment of troops to that effort is particularly welcome. We would like to think that this could lead to a more constructive Syrian role on other issues."
He added: "I spent a fair amount of time in my visit with President Assad in Damascus emphasizing the fact that we have some serious differences with the Syrian Government, pertaining primarily to the issue of terrorism. Better relations between Syria and the United States are really going to depend upon their being willing to take action to curb some of the activities of terrorist groups."
 
Refusing to Expel Terrorists
 The pro-Syrian Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, General Command, is suspected of involvement in the December 1989 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103, in which 189 Americans were killed. The Syrians have refused to expel the group from Damascus.
Representative Edward F. Feighan, Democrat of Ohio, then asked Mr. Baker for his attitude on the loss of life in the Syrian operation in Beirut.
Mr. Baker responded: "We've condemned violence in Lebanon for a long time. Most recently, we argued against that in President Bush's meeting on the 29th of September with the Prime Minister of Lebanon in New York, so suggestions that somehow we've given a green light for this are wrong. That's not the case. I do think we should recognize that Syria was there at the request of the legitimate Government of Lebanon, a Government that we recognize and a Government that we support."
 
Demanding His Trial
 The Hrawi Government has said that General Aoun, who has taken refuge in the French Embassy in Beirut, and his aides should stand trial for crimes against the state, as well as on charges of embezzling as much as $75 million in public funds.
France is refusing to turn General Aoun over for trial, and the United States is quietly advising the Lebanese Government to let him go and focus its energies on reconstruction.
After 15 years of civil war, no one in the Administration is prepared to predict that Lebanon has finally turned the corner, but there is a sense that it now has probably the best opportunity in years to achieve some stability. This is a result of several factors: the relative weakness of the militias, Iraq's preoccupations elsewhere that limit its capacity for trouble-making in Beirut, the new Constitution that divides power more equitably between Moslems and Christians and the fact that the Syrian-backed Government appears to be bringing all of Beirut under its control.
Much depends, though, on whether the Syrians will continue to support the Hrawi Government fully or will, as they have in the past, play off one Lebanese faction against another to keep them all off balance and dependent on Damascus.
Another major factor is whether Lebanon's Shiite Muslims, who are the single largest religious group but whose economic and political shares were always the smallest, will be made to feel that they have a stake in a "new Lebanon."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Children in a Christian district in Beirut playing yesterday near a barricade built to protect the area from sniper fire from a neighboring Muslim district. The shield was erected after barriers that had separated the city's Christian and Muslim districts during Gen. Michel Aoun's insurrection were dismantled after his ouster earlier this month. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Kremlin Signals Hope in Standoff By Sending an Envoy to Baghdad

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 27

 BODY:
The Soviet Union indicated today that it was mounting a new effort to end the standoff in the Persian Gulf and hinted that it hoped for some progress soon.
The Soviet Union abruptly postponed a Security Council vote on a new resolution pressing for an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, saying that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had sent a special emissary to Baghdad for talks with President Saddam Hussein. 
 Mr. Gorbachev, commenting while in Spain on an official visit, said: "There are some signs the top leadership in Iraq has understood that a solution cannot be found through ultimatums. Perhaps I am wrong. In the next days things will become clearer."
The mission by Mr. Gorbachev's personal envoy, Yevgeny M. Primakov, marks his second visit to Iraq this month.
"His mission is not finished," Mr. Gorbachev said at a news conference in Madrid. "The Soviet Union has this possibility of finding a solution."
 
Gorbachev to Visit Paris
 Mr. Gorbachev is to fly to France on Sunday, where he is expected to discuss the gulf situation with President Francois Mitterand at a dinner in the evening. On Friday night, a spokesman for President Mitterrand denied any knowledge of a letter rumored to have been sent by President Hussein to the Mr. Mitterrand.
Unconfirmed reports in London and Paris suggested that Mr. Hussein had sent a letter to Mr. Mitterrand and Mr. Gorbachev saying he was willing to enter discussions on the future of Kuwait.
At the United Nations, the Soviet representative, Yuli M. Vorontsov, said that Mr. Primakov would meet with President Hussein and Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz this weekend.
 
Soviet Hints at Progress
 "We have great hopes for the success of his mission there," he said, adding later, "We all expect he will have very fruitful and important discussions."
He refused to provide further details on the mission.
In a speech at the United Nations last month, the French President sought to tempt President Hussein to give up Kuwait, declaring that withdrawal could lead to a diplomatic settlement of the Palestinian question for which Mr. Hussein could then take political credit.
The hints by the Soviet Union that progress toward resolving the gulf crisis might come soon elicited plenty of skeptical reactions at the United Nations and in Washington.
 
Bush Comments in Hawaii
 The United Nations move by the Soviets clearly caught the United States and other natiions by surprise, and American diplomats at the United Nations left the headquarters building without commenting on it.
In Washington, Bush Administration officials said late today that the Soviets had contacted the State Department to ask for the postponement of the vote.
They said that while the Soviets were not entirely explicit about their motivation, they left the impression that they did not want Mr. Primakov to have to go into a meeting with President Hussein in the wake of yet another Soviet vote imposing sanctions on Baghdad.
The officials noted the Soviets' cooperation with Washington at the United Nations in recent months, but said that pressing for an immediate vote would emphasize their lack of enthusiasm for any kind of Primakov compromise solution.
But at a news conference in Honolulu today, where he was meeting with the leaders of Pacific island nations, President Bush seemed to reflect a trend toward using diplomatic means to get President Hussein out of Kuwait.
 
Bush Sees 'No Softening'
 He knew of the actions in the United Nations, according to his aides, when he said: "In terms of a peaceful solution, I'm told that the economic effects are taking hold. I'm told that he now sees that he's up against a substantial force that clearly could prevail in any battle. So I'm hopeful that there will be a peaceful solution to this question. But there can be no preconditions. There can be no rewarding of aggression."
Asked if he agreed with Mr. Gorbachev's comment in Spain on a new Iraqi attitude, President Bush said: "I have not noticed a softening. But I've heard more kind of little threads of talk of quote, negotiation, unquote. That's all. Maybe that's what President Gorbachev is talking about."
Although optimistic about Mr. Primamakov's forthcoming talks with President Hussein, Ambassador Vorontsov admitted to the Security Council that past efforts to find a settlement have got nowhere, saying, "Reports from the Persian Gulf show Iraq has not given a positive response to efforts by many countries to settle the conflict."
Ambassador Vorontsov also said Moscow fully supports the new council resolution tightening sanctions on Iraq and plans to join a majority of members in voting for it next Monday.
Earlier this week, Ambassador Vorontsov told nonaligned Security Council members that Mr. Primakov had found no evidence that President Hussein is prepared to give up Kuwait when he visited Baghdad earlier this month, as he sought to persuade them to support the council resolution.
The Security Council's current President, Sir David Hannay of Britain, was openly skeptical about reports of a new Soviet peace initiative, describing them as "quite speculative."
He said there was "no indication that anything is cooking at all," pointing out that Iraq has consistently refused to obey the Security Council's call for total and unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait. He also recalled that the Soviet Union fully supports the new resolution against Iraq and intends to vote for it on Monday.
"I dont't think you should read very much into this short postponement," he said.
Kuwait's United Nations representative, Mohammad A. Abdulhassan, was equally skeptical. He stressed that the Soviet Union had little negotiating room because it is bound by Security Council resolution 660, which demands Iraq's immediate and unconditional withdrawal.
"I doubt that this effort will lead anywhere," he said.
The Soviet Union's sudden request for a postponement threw the Security Council into confusion this afternoon, just as it was about the adopt the new resolution. It appeared to catch everyone by surprise including the Soviet delegation, who had been negotiating the new resolution throughout Thursday night, all day Friday and until 2:30 this morning.
An Arab diplomat said he believed President Hussein had been resisting a new visit by Mr. Primakov as late as Friday, but then for no clear reason suddenly changed his mind.
The new resolution the council will vote on next is intended to increase pressure on President Saddam Hussein by calling on all nations to begin collecting evidence of Iraqi human-rights violations in Kuwait and preparing their financial claims against the regime for losses suffered as a result of the invasion.
The resolution also demands an immediate end to Iraqi hostage-taking, looting and pillaging in Kuwait, calls on Baghdad to resupply the few remaining foreign embassies there with food and water, and warns President Hussein that if he fails to obey those orders, the Security Council will "take futher measures under the Charter."
But in deference to a determined campaign by four of its seven non-aligned members, the Security Council is also planning to authorize the United Nations Secretary General to make another attempt to find a peaceful, diplomatic solution to the gulf crisis.
The Bush Administration has toned down the reference to a negotiated settlement, however, and early this morning even rejected language already accepted by the United States representative, Thomas R. Pickering, because it felt the passge in the resolution put too much emphasis on the case for a diplomatic solution.
The expectation is that it will be overwhelmingly approved if there is no dramatic breakthrough in the gulf before next Monday, with diplomats predicting that 14 of the Council's 15 members will support it. Only Cuba is expected to abstain or vote against.
The strong support the resolution now enjoys is widely seen as reaffirming the impressive unity the Security Council has displayed in its handling of the gulf crisis so far, following some signs of strain who much emphasis on the case for a diplomatic solution.
The expectation is that it will be overwhelmingly approved if there is no dramatic breakthrough in the gulf before next Monday, with diplomats predicting that 14 of the Council's 15 members will support it. Only Cuba is expected to abstain or vote against.
The strong support the resolution now enjoys is widely seen as reaffirming the impressive unity the Security Council has displayed in its handling of the gulf crisis so far, following some signs of strain when Yemen, Cuba, Malaysia and Colombia urged the council to adopt a different text that called for a negotiated settlement.
But the threat of a serious split was overcome by combining both points of view into a single document that authorizes another peace initiative by the Secretary General while simultaneously increasing international pressure on Baghdad.

HEADLINE: THE STRUGGLE IN CONGRESS;
Lawmakers Agree to Curb Exploration for Offshore Oil

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27

 BODY:
Congressional negotiators agreed today to keep vast tracts of coastal waters off limits to oil and gas drilling, rejecting arguments that domestic fuel production should be increased because of the crisis in the Middle East.
But Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. said he would recommend that President Bush veto the measure if it cleared the full House and Senate. Because it is attached to the 1991 spending bill for the Interior Department, it is not clear what effect a veto would have on other operations of the department.
In the past, Cabinet members have recommended that Presidents veto bills with similar provisions, but the threat has never been carried out, and appears unlikely to be this time. 
The lawmakers' decision was the first clear sign that oil disruptions caused by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait had not reversed the decadelong aversion to offshore drilling in Congress.
 
Jubilation and Dismay
 It drew expressions of jubilation from environmental groups and dismay from the oil industry.
"I am bouncing off the ceiling," said a happy Lisa Speer, a coastal expert at the Natural Resources Defense Council. But Charles J. DiBona, president of the American Petroleum Institute, an industry group, said in a statement that he was dismayed.
Steven Goldstein, the spokesman for the Interior Department, said the Administration was "extremely disappointed." The decision can only lead to more imports, Mr. Goldstein said, adding, "If the image of troops over in Kuwait that people see in the nightly news and the morning newspapers is not strong enough to change people, then I am not sure what is."
 
House Position Wins Out
 The decision came at a meeting to resolve differences between House and Senate bills appropriating money for the Interior Department, which manages the sale of offshore leases to the oil industry. It was not a compromise but a clear decision to accept House positions over a Senate bill that included no such terms.
Although the moratorium on leasing lasts only one year, it will probably be extended in the future, given the decision today in the face of high oil prices and military crisis.
For 10 years, Congress has stymied development of extensive areas off the nation's coasts by refusing, in annual appropriations bills, to allow the Interior Department to conduct lease sales.
In June, President Bush tried to break that pattern by unilaterally imposing a selective set of protections for the West Coast, the Florida Keys, and New England's Georgia Banks in hopes that the restrictions on other areas would then be dropped. The protection would last 10 years but could be reversed by the White House.
Mr. Bush's move, meant in part to help Republican candidates for the governorships of Florida and California, broke from the policy of the Reagan Administration, which had tried to make the entire 1.4-million-acre outer continental shelf available to industry.
 
135 Million Acres Affected
 Before the invasion of Kuwait, the first sign appeared that the Administration's ambitions would be thwarted, when Congress put restrictions on drilling off the coast of North Carolina.
Today's action is much more extensive, affecting 135 million acres of the continental shelf and significantly expanding the area protected by Mr. Bush's unilateral decision last June.
The oil industry had opposed Mr. Bush's earlier action, and expressed dismay at the latest development.
"Given the situation in the world today, where our supply of fuel is threatened and we are asking foreign producers to increase their output of oil to help the world, it is disturbing that Congress acted to close off huge supplies of oil and gas off our shores that could help our energy security and would be produced in an environmentally sound way," said Mr. DiBona of the petroleum industry group.
But Ms. Speer, the environmental activist, said, "Opening these areas is not going to solve either the immediate problem or the long term problem."
She said that the restrictions would affect areas containing about 2 percent of the nation's economically recoverable oil and gas reserves, and that even if leasing resumed it would take years to develop wells.
The areas that have been put off limits, she acknowledged, contain reserves that could easily be produced, and in amounts that would be profitable to individual oil companies. But she said the bulk of offshore drilling, in the western Gulf of Mexico near Texas and Louisiana, is unrestricted.
Aside from the areas protected by Mr. Bush's action this summer, the Congressional action would restrict leasing or drilling in the Bristol Bay, Alaska, where it would extend the current delay on leasing and exploration and seek a report on the potential impacts of a catastrophic spill there and in Florida's eastern Gulf of Mexico, where it would delay for one year preparatory steps leading up to a sale of leases off Florida's Gulf coast.

HEADLINE: 14 of 15 Jersey Lawmakers Reject Federal Budget Plan

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
With New Jersey's huge tax increases -- and raging taxpayer revolt -- uppermost in their minds, 12 of the state's 13 members of the House of Representatives voted early yesterday against the Federal deficit-reduction plan, as did both its Senators last night.
Representatives said their votes reflected concerns about the economic strains and political repercussions of Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion in increases in state income, sales and excise taxes. 
 "It's clear evidence of the reaction to the Florio tax package," said Representative Marge S. Roukema, Republican of Ridgewood. "There is a tax revolt going on in New Jersey of major proportions, and this plan will only add to it."
Although most House Democrats voted for the budget plan, Representative William J. Hughes, Democrat of Ocean City, said the party's leadership did not try to sway New Jersey Democrats from their opposition to the measure.
"Everyone knew we had a unique situation because of the Florio package," Mr. Hughes said. "It was probably one of the most difficult votes we had to make."
 
Courter Supports Measure
 In fact, the only House member from New Jersey to vote for the plan was the man whom Mr. Florio defeated in last year's race for governor, Representative Jim Courter, Republican of Hackettstown. Mr. Courter is not running for re-election.
Mr. Courter could not be reached for comment, but many of his colleagues in the delegation attributed his vote to his close ties to the Bush Administration.
"The one person to vote in favor of this bill is the one person who is not going to come back to deal with the practical application of this budget," said Representative Frank J. Guarini, Democrat of Jersey City.
The state's two Democratic Senators, Frank R. Lautenberg and Bill Bradley, opposed the measure. Mr. Bradley, who is up for re-election on Nov. 6, said in a statement that the final agreement was an improvement over the earlier versions but still reflected "a mistaken version of our nation's priorities" for the next five years by failing to take advantage of reduced military needs.
The tax increases in the Federal budget plan duplicate many of the increases approved in June for New Jersey, Ms. Roukema and other representatives say.
"People in New Jersey have been hit with an increase in excise taxes, an increase in the sales tax and a doubling of the state income tax," said Representative Matthew J. Rinaldo, Republican of Union. "Imposing additional Federal taxes on this state tax burden on the residents of New Jersey would be unconscionable, in my view."
 
Boat Builders Affected
 In particular, New Jersey Representatives cited the Federal plan's elimination of some itemized deductions and personal exemptions. New Jerseyans with higher incomes could be faced with one of the highest tax rates in the nation, they said.
The plan affects New Jersey residents in both general and specific ways. Like residents of other states where housing costs are high, New Jersey residents will be penalized more by the limits on deductions for state and local property taxes than residents of states where real-estate prices are lower.

HEADLINE: New York Fiscal Woe Doubted as Talks Stall

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
At the core of the stalled New York City municipal labor talks is the union leaders' growing distrust of the claims being made about the city's financial plight.
Union leaders acknowledge that the city has a financial problem, but they are dubious about its extent. In their eyes, the city's credibility is undermined by the discrepancies in revenue estimates and by work-force reduction warnings that have jumped in the last two weeks from 15,000 to 53,000. 
 After a decade of dire financial predictions that never materialized, union officers are skeptical that the problems are as stark as portrayed.
Public officials and fiscal watchdog groups insist they are not crying wolf about plummeting revenues and the specter of mass layoffs. But the unions say they have heard that song before, particularly from Mayor Edward I. Koch in the 1980's.
 
'Wacky' Projections
 "Mayor Koch always cried wolf," said Stanley Hill, executive director of the 140,000-member District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees.
"Past history has shown their projections are way, way out -- wacky," Mr. Hill said. "Now, my God, every day the figures are changing. We know the situation is not good, but we feel very strongly there is still money there to fund the contract without bankrupting the city."
Negotiations with two major unions intensified 12 days ago but have so far failed to yield agreements. Talks continued Friday night at Gracie Mansion.
Throughout the 1980's, budget gap predictions were an annual routine. They ranged from $237 million to $870 million. But those budget years ended with handsome surpluses, ranging from $288 million to $570 million.
Felix G. Rohatyn regularly criticized labor settlements, decrying each raise as excessive. He spoke as chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, a financing agency that helped the city recover from the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's.
The current gloomy predictions remind union leaders most strongly of 1982. As the nation slipped into a recession, falling tax revenues prompted Mr. Rohatyn to call for scaling back existing contracts, and Mayor Koch prepared for thousands of layoffs. Instead the local economy reversed, revenues rebounded, layoffs were averted and another surplus was recorded.
"You can always say that somebody was overly conservative in the past, and in that case I plead guilty," Mr. Rohatyn said last week. "But that doesn't mean I'm wrong today." This time, he and most other experts say, the city's economy is worse.
The crisis of the mid-70's -- when the city was forced into drastic cuts and layoffs -- left a lurking fear of a relapse. But it also left a legacy of many fiscal safeguards, including projections to warn of possible deficits and prompt early action to prevent them.
Mr. Koch defended the process recently as "a very good system," although he said that the forecasts may err. He and others argued that union leaders knew full well that the projections were of potential problems, not actual deficits.
 
'Crying Wolf'
 Norman Steisel, Mayor David N. Dinkins's first deputy mayor, who also served under Mr. Koch, said that the current problems are real, but that "It's no wonder they are suspicious of the enormity of the problem."
Barry Feinstein, president of the 12,000-member Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, who is negotiating with Mr. Hill, said: "Any number of times the former administration would bring us in and say: 'This time, it's really true.' We would say, 'What makes this night different from all others?' On every occasion we were right, and the city was wrong."
Mr. Feinstein called the city budget director, Philip R. Michael, "more full of it than a Christmas turkey." Mr. Michael insists his estimates are sound.
Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, an organization financed by businesses, says the current talks are seriously hampered by past oratory and actions.
"The city pleads poverty and shows big deficits, and everybody says, 'Oh, that's the way the game is played,' " Mr. Horton said. "But there are consequences for not being more honest."

HEADLINE: Voters' Unhappiness Aside, Most Incumbents Seem Safe

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27

 BODY:
The election is still 10 days away, but in much of the country the races are already over, or never even began.
For all the signs of anger among voters, and the near panic among Republican politicians that the budget debacle has brought the wrath of the electorate down on them, most lawmakers are certain of re-election, either because they are unopposed in the balloting on Nov. 6 or because they face an opponent so underfinanced as to be out of contention. 
 About 375 members of the House of Representatives fall into this category, as well as at least 16 senators and 90 percent, or about 5,600, of the state legislators. Four senators, two from each party, and 81 members of the House, 35 Republicans and 46 Democrats, are running with no major party opponent at all. Gary Jacobson, a professor at the University of California at San Diego, said this is the largest group of House members to be unopposed in a general election since the 1950's, when Democrats in the solid South rarely drew a general election opponent.
So, all the discussion in the next 10 days about last-minute campaigning, partisan shifts and voter anger will actually be about battles for a relatively small percentage of the nation's political offices.
"Even if you had some big throw-the-bums-out surge or a huge anti-incumbent trend, you're never going to turn over more than 10 percent of the House seats and 20 percent of the Senate seats that are up," said Charles Black Jr., a senior political adviser to the White House and chief spokesman for the Republican National Committee.
A combination of forces has produced a decline in electoral competition: House and state legislative districts in many places have been drawn in such a way that they are full of supporters of one party or the other, thus making it almost impossible to elect an opposition candidate; the campaign finance system routinely produces incumbents with war chests 10 times as large as their opponents'; political parties are so weak that they cannot effectively recruit candidates, or at least recruit effective candidates, and incumbents are bolstered at home by government-financed staff and mailing privileges.
When the head of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, Representative Beryl Anthony Jr. of Arkansas, was asked this week to list Republican incumbents in the House whom he expected to defeat, he could name only three -- and this in a year when the frustration of voters with government has been described as an "anti-incumbent mood" and Republicans, in particular, seem to be taking the blame for a budget deal that raises taxes and squeezes Medicare.
Mr. Anthony said he preferred to focus his committee's efforts on the seats left vacant by members who retire, die or move on to other ambitions. "We get our wins not by defeating incumbents but by those open seats," he said. But there are only 29 such open seats this year (11 held by Democrats, 18 by Republicans) in a House of 435 members.
 
Political Fatalism
 A kind of political fatalism has developed in which the belief that incumbents are hard to beat begins to fulfill itself. Political strategists concede that in making their plans for this election they did not foresee the volatile mood that voters would be in and the political opportunities this might create.
Many potential challengers in both the House and the Senate, convinced a year ago they could not win, walked away from races they might now do well in. Professor Jacobson, a student of Congressional campaigns, said this year's crop of House challengers is the weakest he has ever seen.
"You have a situation where there might be opportunities to defeat incumbents if there were challengers out there with skills and resources to exploit them," Professor Jacobson said in a telephone interview from California, "But in the absence of challengers with skills and resources to exploit public disaffection with incumbents, here will be few defeated."
 
'Don't Have Real Elections'
 Incumbent politicians argue that the lack of competition generally reflects an electorate which, for all its frustration with government in general, is still basically satisfied with individual representatives.
But critics of the system vehemently disagree. "We're at a point were we don't have a real electoral process," said Fred Wertheimer, president of Common Cause, a lobbying group. "If you don't have real elections, you do not have the basic accountability our political system is based on. This is a major part of the public frustration and backlash. You have a combination of public anger and no real electoral process for it to play out in. That's very dangerous."
Common Cause thinks the solution is stripping the incumbents of their financial advantage through public financing of political campaigns, spending limits and other campaign finance reforms. Others, particularly Republicans, agree there is a lack of political competition but disagree that public financing will change that. Mr. Black argued that in a race between an incumbent and a challenger with roughly equal amounts of money, the incumbent will almost always win because of other advantages, like the way districts are drawn, the incumbent's larger staff and free mail.
 
Change in the South
 The decline in competition is not an across-the-board phenomenon. For one thing, an entire area of the country, the South, is far more competitive than it was 50 years ago, when virtually all elected officials were Democrats.
But even with this change, there are fewer competitive elections now than at the end of World War II. Consider Senate elections won by the incumbent with more than 60 percent of the vote. From 1984 to 1988, 54 percent of incumbents won by that margin; four decades earlier, only 39 percent did.
If the increasing competition in the South is removed, the number of senators from the rest of the country re-elected with more than 60 percent of the vote increased from 22 percent in the 1940's to 55 percent in the 1980's.
This year there are four Senators, an unusually large number, who have no opposition at all from the other major party. They are Sam Nunn of Georgia and David Pryor of Arkansas, both Democrats, and John W. Warner of Virginia and Thad Cochran of Mississippi, both Republicans.
"Nobody wanted to run," said Paul Goldman, chairman of the Democratic Party in Virginia, explaining why Mr. Warner had no Democratic opponent. "I set up a search committee to find someone. They searched for weeks. They couldn't find anyone."
In the 31 other Senate races this year, a dozen senators are what Common Cause describes as "financially unopposed." That is, as of Sept. 30, when financial documents were last filed, they had outraised their opponent by at least 9 to 1.
Money, of course, isn't everything. In Minnesota, Paul Wellstone, a Democrat, has a chance to unseat Senator Rudy Boschwitz, even though he had spent $600,000 and the Senator $6 million as of Sept. 30.
But Senate races in states like Minnesota that do not have highly expensive media markets are considerably more competitive as a group than Senate races in big states or races for the House. For instance, Harry Lonsdale, the Democratic candidate for Senate in Oregon, is having a lot more impact with a $1.5 million campaign than Representative Lynn Martin, the Republican, is having with $6 million in her Senate race in Illinois.
A major factor that has strengthened the hand of House members in recent years is the rising importance of their role as case workers for constituents who want help with Government -- finding a social security check, say, or getting a relative admitted to a veterans hospital. The number of Congressional staff members working in district offices has grown much faster than the number working on Capitol Hill, and the typical member now has about 40 percent of his or her staff working back in the district, as against about 25 percent 15 years ago.
Paul Tully, political director of the Democratic National Committee, said this has strengthened the connection between individual members and their districts and weakened the power of national political trends on Congressional midterm elections.
Races for governor remain more competitive. Governors are more visible than either senators or House members and tend to have their image shaped more by news coverage, which they cannot control, and less by newsletters, which they can. Voters also hold them individually more responsible for taxes, spending and the state of their state's economy. But even here several governors, including Mario M. Cuomo, Democrat of New York, and Carroll A. Campbell Jr., Republican of South Carolina, are coasting to re-election because the opposition party could not mount a serious challenge.
In this year of discontent, many poll takers and politicians are predicting that more incumbents will be ousted from office than has been the case. Charles Cook, who monitors Congressional races, said 16 House incumbents are in danger of losing their seats.

HEADLINE: National Party Wins New Zealand Vote; Improved U.S. Ties Sought

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Oct. 27

 BODY:
Jim Bolger, a conservative who has pledged to patch up relations with the United States, easily captured the Prime Minister's job today as his National Party won by a landslide in national elections.
The party capitalized on a faltering economy to end six years of rule by the Labor Party in this South Pacific nation of 3.5 million people. 
 Final unofficial results projected that the National Party would capture 68 seats in the 97-member Parliament, with Labor taking 28 and the New Labor Party winning 1. A few seats were close enough that they still could be decided by absentee ballots.
In the campaign, both Labor and the National Party had pledged to continue the anti-nuclear policy that badly frayed military relations with the United States after it took effect in 1984; under the policy, nuclear-powered ships and ships with nuclear weapons were barred from making calls at New Zealand ports.
The National Party, however, has said it seeks some sort of reconciliation with Washington, and Mr. Bolger was welcomed there at a time when other top New Zealand officials were rebuffed.
[A State Department spokesman, Adam Shub, said that the United States welcomed Mr. Bolger's election but that it did not know what kind of reconciliation he might have in mind. The spokesman said the United States looked forward to cooperating with the new Government "on issues of mutual interest such as international trade and the environment."]
In today's voting, the National Party won 49 percent, and Labor 35 percent. The Green Party, a relatively new political group that as part of its policy has no official leader, was third with 7 percent; New Labor drew 5 percent.
The defeated Prime Minister, Mike Moore, had held the post for only two months.
Mr. Bolger, the 54-year-old son of Irish immigrants, immediately spoke of reconciliation. "As far as I'm concerned, from tonight, the politics of inclusion begins," he said.
Several Cabinet ministers were among the Labor casualties.
 
Range of Economic Ills
 Labor had a 56 to 40 majority in the old Parliament, with New Labor holding 1 seat.
The National Party, which suffered a stinging defeat in 1987, has dominated opinion polls the last two years. The party's support has grown as disenchantment with Labor set in over high unemployment, slow growth, high interest rates and other economic woes.
Mr. Moore, 41 years old, took over as Prime Minister when Geoffrey Palmer resigned with polls indicating Labor trailing by 21 points and heading for a landslide loss.
 
'Selling Off the State Silver'
 Labor was dragged down by a sagging economy and its unpopular privatization efforts, which National branded as "selling off the state silver to pay the bills."
The top concern of voters was an unemployment rate of 7.9 percent, the highest since World War II.
David Lange, the Labor Prime Minister who instituted New Zealand's antinuclear policy, resigned 15 months ago, citing health reasons.
The United States cut high-level contacts with New Zealand in 1986 in response to the antinuclear policy and dropped the country from the Anzus military alliance, which also includes Australia.

HEADLINE: THE STRUGGLE IN CONGRESS;
Ambitious Air Pollution Bill Sent to White House

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27

 BODY:
The Senate granted final Congressional approval today to the 1990 Clean Air Act, a measure that transforms the 20-year-old original law from a path-breaking but narrow statute into an ambitious plan to cut contamination from every sizable source of air pollution in the nation.
The Senate vote, 89 to 10, means the legislation now goes to the White House, which has indicated that President Bush will sign it. 
 Almost everyone who negotiated the final accord agreed that the new legislation is one of the exceptional achievements in the current session of Congress and the most inclusive environmental statute ever approved by Congress. It is the first to tackle an immense environmental problem with equally broad legislation. The first Clean Air Act in 1970 was written on 41 pages; the 1990 act may take up more than 700 pages.
"I'm convinced that people will look back at the 101st Congress and say, 'God bless them,' " said Representative Gerry Sikorski, a Minnesota Democrat who played a major role in developing provisions to end acid rain and to limit air pollution from toxic substances. "I'm not so sure they'll look back at the tax and budget fights. I know they'll remember the clean air legislation."
 
New Ways of Cutting Pollution
 Lawmakers said the measure offers imaginative and, in some cases, experimental provisions to reduce environmental contamination, like economic incentives to polluters that are aimed at gaining greater cooperation from companies.
The legislation will serve as a model for updating in the 1990's the other 1970's-era statutes that form the foundation of the nation's environmental program, the lawmakers said.
The largest economic incentives are in a provision on acid rain. The provision sets an overall annual level of emissions of sulfur dioxide from power plants, of 8.9 million tons, by the year 2000. That level is less than the half the current emissions. The measure sets a specific emissions limit on 111 utilities in 22 states. Under this plan, if a utility reduces emissions below the required level, it can sell the difference as a credit to new power plants or plants that are planning expansions. Those plants have to buy the credits to win permission from the Government to emit all their pollution.
The lawmakers said they believe they can meet their goal of cutting emissions of sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide by 12 million to 14 million tons annually. The pollution credits will help offset the cost of installing equipment in power plants in the those states.
For instance, a power plant in Ohio, required to release no more than 30,000 tons of sulfur dioxide a year by the year 2000, has the option to install equipment that would reduce its emissions to 20,000 tons. That plant could then sell the 10,000-ton difference as a pollution credit to a new plant in Utah. The Utah plant, which expects to produce 10,000 tons of sulfur dioxide each year, would have to buy the 10,000-ton allowance to operate. The incentive, then, for both buyer and seller is to reduce their emissions as low as possible.
The proposal for credits was developed by the Environmental Defense Fund, an environmental group based in New York and was included in the Clean Air legislation that President Bush submitted to Congress last year.
It is a departure from the traditional environmental requirements, which commanded the environmental agency to develop new limits on pollutants and then required the agency to manage a program to enforce the new controls. Lawmakers hope the new approach will lead to more cooperation from utilities and decrease the burdens on the environmental agency, which has been criticized by Congress for failing to manage or enforce the nation's environmental law aggressively.
"This approach cut the cost of achieving substantial reduction in acid rain pollution in half and made it possible for the President, Congress and environmental groups to negotiate a strong Clean Air bill after 13 years of gridlock," said William J. Roberts, legislative director in Washington for the Environmental Defense Fund.
 
Specifics in Legislation
 The legislation is also more precise in specifying the limits on pollution for industries and businesses and in setting timetables for meeting those limits. No other environmental statute is as precise. The agreement requires oil companies to develop new types of gasoline that burn more cleanly by 1995 and names nine cities, including New York, where the only gasoline available for sale will be the new fuel. Cities are required to reduce concentrations of ozone, a principal component of smog, to a level considered safe, and the act includes penalties if cities miss the deadlines.
By writing the specific requirements into the legislation, lawmakers reduced the role the environmental agency would play in developing standards. The original Clean Air Act gave the agency such broad discretion to develop new rules and to enforce them that the effectiveness of the old law was severely limited, particularly in controlling toxic pollution from factories.
The original law called on the environmental agency to identify chemicals that were toxic and to set limits on the amounts of these chemicals factories could release into the air. In 20 years, the agency completed work on just seven compounds.
"We have to be more direct and more clear in environmental legislation than we were in the past," said Representative Henry A. Waxman, the California Democrat who was one of the most influential negotiators on the measure. "We wanted to minimize the number of things we could leave to the E.P.A.'s discretion because we've seen that the E.P.A. became more interested in protecting polluters than the environment."
Mr. Waxman and other lawmakers were cautious about predicting the success of the new approach. The Environmental Protection Agency is still charged with writing hundreds of new rules and with enforcing many provisions. Environmental leaders noted that hidden within the bill were waivers and exemptions that would reduce its effectiveness.
And industrial executives said they were concerned whether they could meet the new guidelines and about the cost of putting the plan into effect. Various estimates have put the annual bill at $20 billion to $50 billion. Under the best of circumstances, Mr. Waxman said, the nation will not begin to breathe significantly cleaner air until after the turn of the century.
 
Bridging Differences
 The agreement was possible, lawmakers said, because a formula was discovered to bridge the political divisions caused by an environmental threat that has multiple causes, crosses state boundaries and thus puts powerful groups and entire regions at odds.
The most important factor in the new formula, they said, was the overwhelming public concern about the deterioration of the environment and broad popular support for measures to stem that decline, even if those measures resulted in higher costs for cars, electricity and consumer goods.
"The equalizing factor that is unique to the environmental movement is that the American public has said overwhelmingly that they want the environment cleaned up, be it water or air, hazardous wastes or nuclear contamination," said Representative Mike Synar, a Democrat of Oklahoma. Earlier this year, Mr. Synar helped to establish the coalition between environmentalists and industrial leaders that led to agreements on reducing urban smog and toxic air pollution.
A final factor in reaching political compromises, said environmental leaders and industrial executives, is that much more is known about the causes and effects of pollution. And lawmakers, especially House members elected in the mid-1970's and early 1980's are now experts in understanding environmental problems and in developing solutions. Many have also achieved enough prominence and seniority to defend their proposals.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
GAS PRICE PROTEST CRIPPLES HUNGARY

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUDAPEST, Oct. 27

 BODY:
Angry taxi drivers and truck drivers blockaded the streets and bridges of Hungary's capital today to protest the government's decision to raise gasoline prices by 65 percent.
Protesters also snarled traffic in dozens of other cities and towns, closed border crossings and brought much of the nation's economy to a standstill.
The protests began on Friday morning when the new gasoline prices took effect, but the Government has vowed not to bow to the protesters' demands to roll back the increases. 
 "The Government has reached a decision, and it is irrevocable," said Interior Minister Balazs Horvath.
It remained unclear today when the barricades would be removed because Government officials said they would not forcibly end the roadblocks. The blockades usually took the form of taxis and trucks parked to shut bridge and highway entrances, railroad crossings and key intersections in dozens of towns and cities.
 
Army Ordered Not to Interfere
 In his capacity as commander in chief, President Arpad Goncz ordered that the army and its vehicles not be used to settle the dispute. According to MTI, the Hungarian press agency, Budapest's police chief, Sandor Barna, said he would resign if he were ordered to use force against the taxi drivers and truckers.
Political commentators said that after decades of repression under Communism, the Government was loathe to be seen as heavy-handed and stifling democratic expression. To try to end the crisis, the center-right Government was negotiating with representatives of Budapest's 40,000 private taxi drivers.
The public seemed displeased with both sides in the dispute. Many Hungarians criticized the Government for raising gas prices to about $3.80 a gallon, from $2.30 a gallon. That is equal to Western European prices and far higher than American prices, even though the average Hungarian earns less than $50 a week at current exchange rates.
At the same time, many Hungarians condemned the taxi drivers and truckers for causing chaos. Many people could not get to work, many food deliveries could not be made, and there was a rush of panic buying for essentials like break and milk.
 
Hundreds Slept in Cars
 Hundreds of people had to sleep in their cars because the blockades prevented them from reaching home. Army trucks helped bring them food and drink this morning.
For much of Friday and today, five and sometimes all six of Budapest's bridges across the Danube were blocked. The highway to Budapest's main airport was also blockaded much of Friday but was reopened sporadically today. Hundreds of passengers missed their flights, and a charter helicopter service was begun between downtown hotels and the airport.
Government officials said they were forced to raise gasoline prices because the Government has had to start buying large supplies of oil at world prices after the Soviet Union cut its heavily subsidized oil shipments to Hungary by 30 percent this summer. Officials also said Hungary was down to just four days of gasoline reserves, and prices had to be increased to reduce consumption.
But the taxi drivers contended that the 65 percent increase was more than they could afford and more than was justified by the higher price the government pays for crude oil. Some economists said much of the price increase was designed to balance the nation's budget and reduce consumption to help keep the nation's oil bill from ballooning and its trade balance from worsening.
 
Protests Reflect Impatience
 Many Hungarians said the protests reflected a growing impatience with the Government of Prime Minister Jozsef Antall for failing to make tangible improvements in economic conditions. There was also frustration that the price increase could add one or two percentage points to inflation, which has hovered near 30 percent for the past year.
The main opposition party, the Free Democrats, lashed out at the price rise. "We condemn the way the price increase has been implemented as well as its size," said Miklos Haraszti, a leader of the Free Democrats. "We fully understand the reaction. This price increase does not fit into any kind of economic strategy and will increase inflation."
In parliamentary debates, Gabor Fodor, a member of the Young Democrats, said the government would have a hard time wriggling out of the trap it had stepped into.
Poland, Czechoslovakia and Romania have also raised gasoline prices, partly as a result of the cutbacks in Soviet oil shipments. But none of those countries had huge protests like those in Hungary.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Taxi and truck drivers blocked roads and bridges in Budapest yesterday to protest a 65 percent increase in gasoline prices ordered by the Government. A driver served donated food to colleagues at a roadblock. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Women's Group Seeks Environmental Role

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
Alarmed by the deteriorating health of the planet, women from around the world have come together to demand a bigger role in all levels of decision-making on the environment and development.
In a four-day session that ended Monday, 50 women met at the United Nations Church Center to establish a worldwide network for bringing their agenda into the environmental debate. Their immediate goal is equal representation at the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development in Brazil in 1992. 
 The international committee includes leading environmentalists like Vandana Shiva of India; Wangari Maathai of Kenya, a grass-roots organizer; Dr. Rosalie Bertell of Canada, an environmental health specialist, and radical environmentalists like Claire Greensfelder of the Earth Island Institute in California.
Women have been "invisible in policy-making on environmental and development issues," said Bella Abzug, a founder of the Women's Foreign Policy Council, the meeting's sponsor. The participants put together a plan to mobilize their local constituencies and lay the groundwork for their own congress in Miami in November 1991, the Brazil conference in 1992 and other efforts over the next decade.
 
'A Real Learning Process'
 Although they came from diverse cultures in Latin America, Africa, Asia, Europe and North America, the women had little difficulty in reaching a general consensus on their basic goals, principles and plan of action. They differed mainly in style, with some of the more radical campaigners fiercely attacking governments viewed as anti-environmentalist.
Libby Bassett, an American environmental consultant, said the congress did not become a regional debate or a struggle between the first world and the third. She described it as "a real learning process in which we worked out an alternative way of planning the planet."
The plan of action sets these main goals:
*Full participation by women in environment policy at all levels.
*Freedom of choice in family planning.
*Redefinition of development on the principle that investment must not destroy the environment.
*Increased education and information on the environment and development.
*Protection of natural systems.
*Development of a code of earth ethics.
The conference took health as its central theme, inspired by the work of Dr. Bertell, who heads the International Institute of Concern for Public Health, based in Toronto. For the last 12 years, Dr. Bertell has helped organize communities and individuals whose health is threatened by industrial and military pollution.
"Everybody agrees that the environment is sick -- the Earth and air, water, forests -- and that what we want is a healthy, balanced environment," said Chodchoy Sophonpanich, president of the Thai Environmental and Community Development Association.
 
Keeping 'Systems in Balance'
 Maria Eugenia de Cotter, director of the Arias Foundation of Costa Rica, said that healthy development means "keeping the natural systems in balance, whether it be the human system or the ecological system."
Tamar Eshel, a former member of the Israeli Parliament, said that up to now, women have been out of the environment policy process. She felt that this would change now, adding that her own government had asked her to report on the results of the meeting.
Brief reports from the industrialized and developing world on the health of the environment were equally grim.
"What we have today is maldevelopment, wealth and poverty," said Dr. Rosina Wiltshire of the Caribbean Conservation Association in Barbados. "This distorted concept of development will ultimately lead to the de struction of the planet."
In Thailand, people either don't know or don't care about environment, Ms. Sophonpanich said. She stressed that many laws have not stopped deforestation, either at the hands of businessmen or villagers.
 
'The War of Resources'
 In India, economic development has not improved the quality of life, said Vanaja Ramprasad, a consultant on ecology. "New technologies have increased food production but the majority cannot afford to buy."
"In Africa we have no choice; we know we're doing the wrong thing but what else can we do?" said Gertrude Mongella, a member of the Central Committee of Tanzania's governing party. She said impoverished women were among those who routinely exploit the environment, cutting down trees for firewood, growing tobacco, allowing overgrazing and using pesticides.
"Even if there's a woman at the top, they can still destroy environment very thoroughly," said Bernadette Vallely of the Women's Environment Network in Britain. She pointed to a crisis in the country's health service, as well as acid rain, poverty and high levels of pollution.
Concern over "the war of resources" was voiced by Perdita Huston, an American writer on women in development. Noting that most natural resources are found in the third world, particularly in the south, she warned that "the world is heading for a real south-north confrontation."
But Ms. Maathai, founder of Kenya's Green Belt tree-planting movement, cautioned, "It's easy to accuse the north, but they have brothers in the south who make it possible to exploit our resources." She said that members of local power elites must be made aware of "threats to all forms of life, even the butterflies."
