HEADLINE: Peru's Leader Proposes A Market to Fight Coca

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 27

 BODY:
Peru's new President has proposed a novel approach to fighting coca-leaf production: the creation of a free-market environment where peasants would find alternative crops to be economically attractive.
In a speech in Lima on Friday, the leader, President Alberto Fujimori, rejected military and police repression, which until recently was the dominant anti-coca strategy in Peru, the world's largest source of the raw material for cocaine. 
 Instead, Mr. Fujimori, an agronomist by training, proposed granting land titles to coca growers and radically slashing state controls and private monopolies that currently make cultivation of legal export crops unprofitable for small farmers.
"There is now no possibility of moving to other crops because of the restrictive regulatory environment," Hernando de Soto, a free-market theorist and contributor to the plan, said today in a telephone interview. Mr. de Soto, a key adviser to the new Government, is to travel to the United States on Monday to promote Peru's new approach.
 
Fear of Civil War
 Last month, Mr. Fujimori angered United States officials by rejecting a $35.9 million military aid package. The aid included training and equipping six Peruvian Army batallions for operations in Peru's Upper Huallaga Valley, an area responsible for most of Peru's annual $1 billion coca-leaf harvest.
During the presidency of Alan Garcia, who stepped down July 28, the United States financed an aggressive program in the Upper Huallaga of blowing up jungle laboratories and of eradicating fields of coca.
But fear of setting off a full-fledged civil war with the one million Peruvians involved in coca-leaf cultivation was a recurring theme in Mr. Fujimori's speech on Friday.
"Efficient repression, which leaves peasants without alternatives, could easily unchain a civil war of unsuspected dimensions," the President warned of the Upper Huallaga. The region is already heavily influenced by guerrillas of the radical Shining Path movement.
 
Plan to Revive U.S. Talks
 "Let us not repeat the errors of President Ngo Dinh Diem of Vietnam," the President continued in the speech, which was delivered to foreign diplomats, including Ambassador Anthony Quainton of the United States. "Here in Peru, we are not going to run the risk of being defeated because we put the peasants, their innumerable relatives, friends and countrymen on the side of the drug traffickers and terrorists."
Also on Friday, Mr. Fujimori sent President Bush a letter proposing renewed talks on military and economic aid. The military aid money rejected by Mr. Fujimori last month will now be reassigned to Bolivia and Colombia, two countries regarded by Washington as more cooperative in the war on cocaine.
In a sharp break with conventional discourse in the Andes over coca production, the Fujimori policy speech did not discuss specifics of military aid, economic aid or even potential alternative crops.
After the speech, Mr. Quainton told reporters that United States official would closely study the new anti-drug strategy before commenting.
 
Issuing of Land Titles
 In August, American officials were angered when Mr. Fujimori moved into retirement Juan Zarate, the police general most closely identified with American anti-drug efforts.
In early August, at the time of a visit to Lima by Vice President Dan Quayle, the United States Office of National Drug Control Policy called Peru's drug fighting effort "the most problematic" of the three Andean producers.
A report by the agency said the Bush Administration was evaluating the efforts of Peru's new Government to see if they "justify the provision" of more aid next year. The Administration has proposed sending $700 million in military and economic aid to Peru over the next five years.
Mr. de Soto estimated this week that land titles could be issued within a year to coca growers in the Upper Huallaga, the source of about one half of the world's clandestine coca harvest. But violence from guerrillas will undoubtedly be a major obstacle.
 
Army Commander Wounded
 In the last month, heavy fighting in the area has claimed the lives of over 160 people -- Army soldiers, peasants, and Shining Path guerrillas. On Oct. 19, guerrillas ambushed and severely wounded the regional army commander, Gen. Mario Britto Romero. The general's jeep driver and two bystanders were killed.
Even with peace, a free-market environment and access to rural credit, peasants may not be interested in dropping cultivation of coca leaves, which are the most profitable crop in Peru.

HEADLINE: FINAL PAYMENTS;
The Budget Battle Reflects The Strain in the System

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE 101st Congress began its two-year tenure in January of 1989 with a simple but lofty goal: to govern.
But as the weary and frustrated lawmakers struggled toward a close this weekend, days before the midterm elections, governing seemed almost beside the point. For some, the question was whether a bitterly divided legislative branch and a frantic White House could even function. 
"What we are seeing is a very good illustration that divided government doesn't work anymore," said Senator Warren Rudman, a New Hampshire Republican. "Our system of checks and balances that worked in a simpler time is now an obstruction to governing. The American people don't know who to blame because nobody is accountable."
The criticism was heartfelt, but perhaps unduly harsh. The 101st Congress will leave behind some bipartisan accomplishments: an overhaul of the 1970 Clean Air Act, a redesign of farm programs, new anti-discrimination protections for the disabled, a new child care program and, most important, a five-year regimen of spending cuts and tax increases aimed at cutting the Federal deficit by nearly $500 billion.
But it is a record tarnished by legislative disorder more severe than any in recent memory and all but obscured by five chaotic months of indecision and partisan warfare over the budget.
That assessment is especially galling to the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley of Washington.
"We ought to have some credit for the fact that this is not an agreeable or easy job to do," he said, his voice rising in anger. "It's courageous. It's heroic in some ways that the members of Congress can, in a representative government system, stand up immediately before an election and do unpopular things. People ought to take some hope from that process instead of dumping all over it, instead of saying that it isn't quite as tidy as some think it ought to be."
In many ways the battle of the budget was emblematic of everything else Congress did or was unable to do over the last two years. The lesson of divided government and splintered political parties is that it is impossible to simultaneously maintain partisan identities, make coherent policy and cut a deficit in the hundreds of billions. At each step in the legislative process, one or more of these objectives had to give way.
 
Better Than Expected
 "You have to judge the disorder and the chaos of the process by the magnitude of the economic and the political problem they were trying to cope with," said Tom Mann, director of governmental studies at the Brookings Institution. "On balance, the 101st Congress may have acheived more than anyone had a right to expect."
Given the mismatch between Government resources and the pent-up demand for Government services, the most striking characteristic of this Congress's legislation is that it directs others to do what the Federal Government is unwilling or unable to pay for. The Clean Air Act, the Americans with Disablities Act and the increase in the minimum wage are ways of requiring the private sector to achieve social objectives. Congress can claim credit for expanding the Medicaid program, but state governments will have to bear a heavy share of the cost.
Early on, this Congress was persuaded that the voters were not in a mood to pay for their programs. Landmark legislation providing catastrophic health insurance was adopted by the 100th Congress in 1988, but a year later the 101st repealed the law when angry senior citizens refused to pick up the tab. Budget negotiators' efforts to even consider linking Social Security or Medicare to recipients' incomes were squelched before they left the bargaining table.
Intent on addressing domestic needs long neglected, Democrats and Republicans alike struggled to produce the first overhaul of housing programs in more than a decade. But the measure was primarily symbolic, since the appropriation is expected to be small.
 
An Old-Fashioned Bill
 Of all the new initiatives, the child care program bears the closest resemblance to legislation molded the old-fashioned way. Financed partially by grants to the states and expansion of an existing tax credit, it was the centerpiece of both Democratic and Republican agendas this year despite a price tag of more than $20 billion over the next five years. The great majority of the benefits would go to low-income families through the tax credit.
But as the Senate Majority Leader, George Mitchell of Maine, noted, it can take decades to build the political support for such a huge undertaking. "The first child care bill was brought up 22 years ago," he said.
If the child care initiative was a success of divided government, there were also casualties. Despite their majorities, the Democrats failed to override a single one of Mr. Bush's 15 vetoes, including those on civil rights legislation and requirements for employers to provide unpaid leave for working parents.
Lawmakers had hoped for major surgery on the military budget. But events abroad dictated otherwise. Although military spending is supposed to decline by $170 billion billion over the next five years, the much anticipated "peace dividend" may be long in coming if American troops remain in the Persian Gulf.
Institutional reforms will also have to wait. Despite months of talks on overhauling the campaign finance system, Democrats and Repubicans remain stalemated over the central issue of spending limits for candidates. In the House, where an ethics scandal toppled Speaker Jim Wright of Texas in June 1989, Mr. Foley moved quickly to contain the damage. By the end of that year, House members had approved a previously defeated Congressional pay raise and a ban on outside speaking fees. The Senate would not ban the outside fees and settled for a small pay increase pegged to inflation.
For all their travails in negotiating a budget deal with the White House and their worries about Congress's image, both Mr. Mitchell and Mr. Foley are reveling in the recent polls that show Democrats on the winning side of the tax issue for the first time in a decade. Nine months ago, the Democratic leaders vowed firmly and frequently that they would not allow their party to be trapped into calling for tax increases.
But the President's acquiescence to new taxes last summer and the resulting fracture in the Republican Party has allowed them to shift the terms of the debate from whether to tax to whom to tax. Mr. Mitchell said he was not worried about a backlash even though Democrats had to provide the majority of votes forthe deficit reduction package.
"The President said there had to be new taxes, and he didn't just say it, he wrote it down," the Senator said with a grin.
But as the House Republican leader, Bob Michel of Illinois, said on the House floor in Saturday's predawn debate, the larger issue of governing was at stake. "We're attempting to turn our backs on instant political gratification, the curse of this institution," he said, pleading for Republican votes. "If you want to play you've got to pay."

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
In Some Places Gentrification Is A Weekend Guest

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

 BODY:
JUST over a decade ago, Frenchtown was simply another boarded-up town on the Delaware River, a greasy spoon and a pizza parlor its only businesses. Today, it bustles on weekends with tourists who come from the New York and Philadelphia metropolitan areas for a day or two to enjoy its small-town charms and patronize its antique shops, boutiques and cafes.
Frenchtown represents a growing national trend in which once-depressed towns have transformed themselves, sometimes with professional advice, into magnets for lovers of expensive, creative merchandise and historic architecture. The disposable income of the 1980's, the numbing sameness of shopping malls and a reaction against bruising big cities have all helped feed the gentrification, redefining municipal identities almost overnight and sometimes stoking class frictions. 
 Changes have also come to Hudson River towns like Cold Spring, N.Y., in Putnam County and Piermont in Rockland County. In New Jersey, there are Frenchtown and Lambertville, both on the Delaware in Hunterdon County. Nor is the phenomenon limited to isolated towns: in Connecticut's sixth-largest city, the waterfront area known as South Norwalk -- and in recent years by the more trendy SoNo -- has become a popular weekend destination.
Most of these towns shared certain characteristics that made them ripe for revitalization. They had historic buildings dating from before the Revolutionary era through the Victorian. They were built on the waterfront and within an hour's drive of New York. Hurting economically, they were all open to new ideas.
Take Piermont, a town with a population of 2,500. Its main street, Piermont Avenue, consists of two- and three-story brick buildings, with elaborate lintels and cornices, and clapboard houses with wide porches. They provide the setting for the dozen antiques and crafts stores. But it wasn't always this way.
"It was a wild town where people would go to the bars on Saturday night and fight," said Anna Duzzi Stafford, the owner of Mistral, a shop selling European country furniture.
"In the past five years, there's been a renaissance as buildings changed ownership," said Vivian Harnett, a retailing pioneer who opened Goose Cove Antiques in 1981, shortly before the town's paper factory closed. "It's a step back in time."
Some native Piermonters, whose fortunes were most recently linked to those of the local paper mill, which closed in 1983, had a hard time adjusting to the upscale evolution. Piermont's gentrification hadn't brought displacement per se; many of the hardware shops and supermarkets had already closed from chain-store competition in a nearby town.
"There was a strain between your mill-town blue-collar workers and your so-called professional people," said Don Cocker, Piermont's deputy mayor, fire chief and highway commissioner, "but that's mended itself over time."
 
A Reaction to Malls
 Piermont's property taxes remain unchanged primarily because property values haven't been reassessed since 1967. But old-timers mind the crush of people on weekends, swarming around stores many residents can ill afford. "We're glad to see the buildings restored, but no one's ecstatic about how crowded the streets are," said one Piermont native. "And I can only window-shop."
The erosion of manufacturing has not been the only catalyst in the makeover of some towns. Historic preservationists and urban planners say the advent of the shopping mall also helped pave the way for small-town revivals nationwide by not only supplanting the middle-range retail market in many towns, but also by dulling shoppers' senses.
"For the past 20 years, towns have been trying to figure out where to go from here," said Kennedy Smith, the acting director for the National Main Street Center, a program of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, a non-profit organization in Washington. "And a piece of that has been discovering that people like to visit quaint small towns.
"Tourism is something that a lot of communities have latched onto -- capitalizing on their historic buildings and ambience -- to provide some general economic support," she added. "People are becoming a little tired of the artificial mall environment where you can almost pick out the Orange Julius blindfolded. They are looking for something that is real and authentic."
The 10-year-old center has worked with more than 650 towns and cities in 31 states in an effort to breathe new life into their communities while saving historic structures. Many have followed the path to tourism. Other towns that have attracted weekend explorers, Ms. Smith said, include Benicia, Alameda and Petaluma outside San Francisco; Tarpon Springs near Tampa, Fla., and Media and West Chester in Pennsylvania. Paradoxically, one of the great preservers of historic buildings is economic decline itself, since there is little pressure to raze them to make way for new structures.
The robust economy of the 1980's also contributed to the rebirth of certain towns. "People don't appreciate how rich this country got in the last 10 years, particularly in the three states of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut," said Lawrence O. Houstoun Jr., president of the Atlantic Group in Cranbury, N.J., which advises cities and towns. "There was an incredible amount of disposable income, and people indulged themselves."
 
'Stress Victims'
 In keeping with the trend in travel toward people choosing to take a series of mini-vacations, some of them are heading to these towns for a night or two, using them as a base to view the fall foliage or visit historic sites. According to the United States Travel Data Center, the averge length of vacations has dropped from 5.7 nights in 1985 to 4.7 nights in 1989.
"We get a lot of stress victims from New York," said Gloria Cappiello, the owner of the Frenchtown's Old Hunterdon House, which offers four-poster beds and candle-lit breakfast for up to $115 a night.
Like Piermont, Frenchtown's transformation happened suddenly. Both the Old Hunterdon House and the Frenchtown Inn, considered one of the best restaurants in the state, opened in the last five years, as did most of the antique and gift shops.
"When we moved here in 1976, the town was basically boarded up," said Palmer Ward, the owner of Blackburn & Ward, a fine arts and antiques shop that opened in 1979. "The town was cheap, and arty people could afford to live here."
Some worry, however, that if the popularity streak continues for towns like Piermont and Cold Spring, they could become so big and slick they lose their small, old-fashioned feel. "Right now it's riding that fine line," said Leslie Farrell, a 28-year-old writer who grew up near Cold Spring. "But if Main Street gets any more developed, forget it."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
U.N. Sponsorship of a War in the Gulf Is No Simple Matter

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
IN the nearly three months since Iraq invaded Kuwait, President Bush has assembled a most impressive international coalition in favor of punishing Baghdad. But now the United States and the other four permanent Security Council members are beginning to wonder if the United Nations could ever agree on terms that would give sponsorship to the use of military force.
The United States, Britain and France, which have the largest military deployments in the gulf, used to claim that they already had all the authority they needed to fight President Saddam Hussein -- Article 51 of the United Nations Charter, which says one member can ask others for help against aggression. 
 But recent developments are pushing Washington to seek the Security Council's explicit blessing if it decides on military action.
Most other United Nations members, including the Soviet Union, have made clear that only if the Security Council authorizes force could they support it, send troops themselves or help defray the cost.
Some experts also dispute the claim that the use of force is condoned under Article 51, which Kuwait and Saudi Arabia invoked when they asked Washington and other capitals to send military units to the gulf.
Thomas M. Franck of New York University Law School and Abram Chayes of Harvard Law School said in Washington recently that the United States has lost that right because Article 51 only establishes the right of "collective self defense" until the Security Council takes measures "to maintain international peace and security." In their view, the sanctions and the authority to enforce them are such measures.
Pressure is also building among some members of Congress for the Administration to obtain Security Council approval for a war. Some Congress members, anxious to clip the President's foreign policy wings, believe the United States cannot fight without a formal Congressional declaration of war. As it prepared to recess, Congress appointed 18 members to watch developments and summon it back if fighting looks imminent.
But some experts say that even without Congress, an American President can fight once the Security Council orders a decision enforced by military might under Article 42. That provision allows the council to order "action by air, sea or land forces" to enforce an embargo.
Indeed, the legal route the Security Council has embarked on in the gulf crisis leads directly to the authorization of the use of force. The trade sanctions against Iraq were imposed under Article 41, which says the council can enforce its orders by economic pressure. If these prove inadequate, there is Article 42.
 
Complications Arise
 But there are difficulties. China or the Soviet Union could veto an American attempt to invoke Article 42. And the Pentagon worries that if the matter of going to war is discussed in the Security Council, the element of surprise will be lost.
In addition, another charter article threatens foreign interference in the command structure. Article 46 says "plans for the application of armed force shall be made by the Security Council with the assistance of the Military Staff Committee." That is a panel, long moribund, comprising the chiefs of staff or their designees of all five permanent members, which Moscow wants to revive, and which will meet this week. But to American military planners, who insist that their forces are independent and must remain so, it conjures up the specter of an international committee of generals running a war out of New York.
The United States side-stepped this difficulty in Korea by using the Soviet Union's absence from the council to have itself appointed commander of the international war effort. But that would be harder in this post-cold-war world. In addition, the United States and its allies insist on keeping control of their own forces in the gulf.
So if force is to be used in the Persian Gulf, the challenge is for the Security Council to find a way to authorize it under Article 42 in terms that are acceptable to Congress, maintain the international coalition against Saddam Hussein, preserve an element of surprise and satisfy Moscow's desire to activate the Military Staff Committee -- but leave the United States, Britain and France in command of their own forces.
Since the charter never says who shall command a United Nations force, this is technically possible. But whether the political will exists is another matter.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
The Governors Talk About Taxing and Spending

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
GOVERNORS in states from Alaska to Louisiana say that while they are fundamentally opposed to many of the ways Congress is raising and spending money in its new budget, their overriding concern is whether the effort in Washington can stabilize the slumping national economy.
Their views, given in interviews last week with 17 Governors, indicate how much state economies have become tied into national and international patterns. Their views also reflect the fact that 33 states are facing budget deficits this year. 
 Most of the Governors, Republicans and Democrats alike, said Washington had not gone nearly far enough in reining in the Federal debt, which now stands at more than $3 trillion and is projected to grow to $4.7 trillion by 1995 despite the new deficit-reduction measures. Although economists differ widely on the effects of the growing debt, the Governors said it is soaking up savings, causing interest rates to rise, depressing local economies and raising fears of a deep recession.
"It is not enough to simply reduce the rate at which the Federal debt is growing," said Gov. Steven Cowper of Alaska, a Democrat who is not running for re-election. "We need to balance the Federal budget this year and every year from now on. You won't find me whining and complaining about Federal cuts in programs and funds."
A handful of Governors gave Washington credit for starting to cope with the deficit. "The good news is that this is the first indication that they are facing reality," said Gov. Madeleine M. Kunin of Vermont, a Democrat whose term ends in January.
"It's a step, but not a giant step, in the right direction," said Gov. Tommy Thompson of Wisconsin, a Republican who is running for re-election. "But Congress has been on a spending binge for 30-some years."
At the same time, all of the Governors interviewed, as well as the budget directors of seven other states, expressed concern about the way the Federal Government has shifted more and more expensive responsibilities, particularly in health care, to the states.
 
More for Medicaid
 "Over the last three years," said Daniel M. Sprague, executive director of the Council of State Governments, "Congress has passed $2.5 billion worth of Medicaid mandates on to the states, and this latest budget is going to add another $2.5 billion in the foreseeable future." The added costs largely come from the mandated extension of Medicaid benefits and increased costs for states that pay Medicare premiums for some people to keep them out of the Medicaid program.
"When they talk about belt-tightening in Washington, they are talking about tightening our belts," said Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey, who is in political trouble for raising taxes. He said that the state's $12 billion budget this year includes $1.2 billion for Medicaid and that he expects Medicaid costs to rise sharply next year.
Gov. Richard F. Celeste of Ohio, a Democrat who is not running for re-election, gave as an example a requirement in the new budget that would cost Ohio $30 million a year by forcing the state to stop contracting out to the lowest bidder all of its prescription drug purchases, and start purchasing from manufacturers that give discounts on individual drugs. "At the Federal level this policy may look like a cost saving, but it's obviously not for us," Governor Celeste said.
The new budget also advances what the states view as Federal encroachment on their sources of revenue: excise taxes on gasoline, cigarettes and alcohol. In addition, the new Federal taxes are expected to reduce consumption and cause the state tax revenues to decline.
"It appears as though Washington expects the people to drive, to smoke and to drink their way out of this deficit situation," said Gov. George Deukmejian of Calfornia, a Republican who is not running for re-election.
In Indiana, Gov. Evan Bayh, a Democrat whose term ends in 1993, said: "They are just shifting the budget crisis from Washington out to the states. Congress can't rein in their political appetite for spending and, since they don't have any money, they have to look for the states to pay their bills."
The new budget also raises the hackles of state and local officials by subjecting more people to double taxation. In 1986, the Government started down this path by eliminating the deduction of state and local sales taxes on Federal forms; the new budget now eliminates a small portion of all deductible expenses for high-income taxpayers. Before long, state officials gloomily predict, Congress will disallow all deductions for state and local taxes -- a prospect especially painful in such high-tax states as New York, New Jersey and California.
"For Congress and a President that can't agree on raising taxes, the beauty of raising money by limiting deductions is that it is very difficult for us to explain to taxpayers what is happening," said Susan J. White, a spokeswoman for the National Association of Counties. "It's also being portrayed as a New York problem. Everybody likes to be anti-New York, but it clearly affects everybody because all states have property taxes and over 40 states have income taxes."

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
A Traditionally Insular Community Begins to Reach Out

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH

 BODY:
YU KIM LY was buried last week in his faded blue jeans. At his wake, near his coffin, the photograph of the winsome-looking 16-year-old and the small crowd of black-clad teen-age mourners offered few hints of the violent death he met the previous week on a street in lower Manhattan.
The boy was shot three times in the head along with two other teen-age friends, all members of the Vietnamese gang Born to Kill, a violent group that has increasingly encroached on the territory of established Chinese gangs, terrifying the Chinese, Vietnamese and Korean communities throughout New York. 
 Although law-enforcement officials said the three deaths were not officially gang related, the murders galvanized more than 20 Asian community groups, traditionally wary of outsiders, to meet recently with the police and protest increased gang violence and insufficient police protection.
Their protest differed from similar protests in past decades. Not only did it demonstrate a new pan-Asian solidarity, but it also appears to have been ignited by the changing random pattern of gang violence and the rise of the drug trade. The meeting also pointed up the chasm between Asian-Americans and the police department -- as well as conflicts within their own communities.
"Now is the time to fight back," Paul Mack, the executive director of the Brooklyn Chinese-American Community Association, said. "But without any assistance from higher up, we just can't do it. But also look at it this way, without cooperation from the community, there isn't much police can do."
The dramatic rise in the number of Asian immigrants over the last 20 years has been reflected by an increase in gangs. "The stakes are higher now," said Ko-lin Chin, a senior research analyst at the New York City Criminal Justice Agency, a private nonprofit organization, who wrote "Chinese Subculture and Criminality" (Greenwood Press, 1990). "More immigrants mean more business, more money, more power. There's more heroin trafficking. And when the gangs in the 90's now send a message, they kill people."
An estimated 300,000 Chinese live in New York, 150,000 in Chinatown. In the 1980's, as new groups from Taiwan and Hong Kong flowed in they settled in Flushing in Queens and along Eighth Avenue in Brooklyn, each area with Chinese populations of over 60,000. More recently, Chinatown has felt the influx of a wave of 30,000 undocumented immigrants, mostly from China's Fukien Province, according to Virgo Lee, the director of Mayor David N. Dinkins's office of Asian Affairs. The Vietnamese population has jumped from 5,000 to 40,000 since 1980.
A possible indication of increased gang activity is reflected in police statistics for Chinatown. The data for the first six months of 1990 show robberies up by 30 percent over 1989. In the Fifth Precinct, which patrols Chinatown, 13 people have been murdered so far, compared with 12 homicides for all of 1989. This month alone, five gang members were murdered in three separate incidents in lower Manhattan.
At the heart of the violence is Born to Kill and its rivalry with more traditional Chinese gangs. The gang, made up of young Vietnamese immigrants, is extremely unpredictable and violent and primarily involved in robbery, extortion and burglary of Chinese retail stores and restaurants.
"One merchant in Brooklyn was hit six different times in one day by gang kids who wanted money," Mr. Mack said, referring to different gangs.
The Chinese, Korean and Vietnamese gangs are linked to their community's social and economic life. The Chinese gangs especially rely on their relationship to certain large, established social and political associations. These groups use the youths to protect illegal activities like gambling, Mr. Chin said.
The leaders of the groups that have an association with the gangs "have an ambivalent and very subtle relationship with their gangs," said Mr. Chin. "They cannot dismiss them because they are the nuclear power of the adult organization. If they let them go, another will recruit them, and they will be left without street soldiers."
 
A Little Progress
 The communication gap between the police and the community only assists the gangs. The police claim that Asians are easier victims because they are scared or unwilling to report crimes; the community groups say the only solution in the short term is more police on the streets and in the long term school programs to discourage children from gangs.
The language barrier and the innate distrust of authority add to the unwillingness of the Asian community to work with the police or even appear in court. The police say they cannot make arrests and prosecute unless the attitudes change.
"The community has to make a difference," said Sergeant Michael Collins of the Fifth Precinct's Asian Gang Intelligence Unit. "They have to report the crimes. They have to stop participating in extortion. They have to be willing to follow through the system."
Community leaders, like Paul Yee, president of the Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Association, a group of more than 60 community organizations, argue that the legal system quickly frees criminals, who take revenge on their victims, who lack police protection.
"We feel the system is just too ridiculous," Mr. Yee said. "The police blame the community people. They don't blame the crime."
Both law-enforcement officials and community leaders claim some progress. The police say they are increasing the number of uniformed patrol officers in the precinct and upgrading the gang surveillance unit.
Still, many present at the meeting were skeptical. To some, it recalled the old Chinese saying, "When alive don't go to authority. When dead don't go to hell."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
For Vietnam, The Price Of Progress Is Cambodia

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand

 BODY:
THERE are two Southeast Asias, Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan of Thailand is fond of saying: one thriving and capitalist, the other socialist and stagnant.
So it should be no surprise that even the famously stubborn Vietnamese leadership, despite its divisions over the pace of change, has realized that it must join the development race now or be forever left behind, floundering in a politically unstable swamp of unemployment and inflation. 
 That is the prime reason Vietnam finally decided to cut a deal on Cambodia and withdraw the bulk of its troops after an occupation of 11 years -- to end its international isolation and attract Western investment. And it is the prime reason that Vietnam's Foreign Minister, Nguyen Co Thach, went to Washington recently, the highest-ranking Hanoi official to do so since the north became independent in 1954.
That year, when the French left Vietnam, Hanoi was the most modern city in Southeast Asia. In 1975, when the Americans left, the region's most advanced city was Saigon. Both cities today have a sort of aspic charm, with moldy French provincial buildings in Hanoi and American DeSoto buses still grinding through the streets of Ho Chi Minh City.
The isolation and stagnation have been the price of both war and ideology. But now Hanoi, like the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, needs the West, and seems more willing to pay the price.
Vietnam eased central controls on the economy beginning as early as 1987. But a Cambodia-related embargo on aid, investment and trade with Vietnam, led by Washington, has successfully blocked vital loans from multilateral agencies like the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank.
While more countries now trade with Vietnam, the American veto on the lending agencies has forestalled significant Western investment and stifled domestic development, particularly as Soviet aid declines.
A settlement in Cambodia, much more than the emotional and easily manipulated issue of the American M.I.A.'s, has always been the key to economic and diplomatic normalization between Washington and Hanoi. And only normalization will open Vietnam in a serious fashion to the West.
So it is Washington's main card with Vietnam, and even the American Chamber of Commerce, eager to do business with Vietnam, should not be surprised that the Bush Administration will continue to play it, at least until a Cambodia settlement is ratified.
Cambodia is also the main obstacle to normal relations between Hanoi and Beijing, whose support for Vietnam's revolution soured quickly over its Cambodian adventure. Hanoi's expulsion in 1979 of China's allies, the Khmer Rouge, no matter their crimes, was an insult for which the Chinese, especially Deng Xiaoping, were eager to extract the severest pain.
But China's own isolation over the killings near Tiananmen Square, coupled with the collapse of Eastern Europe and Moscow's sudden retrenchment everywhere, have also pushed Vietnam and China closer together.
Both leaderships are intensely aware of being socialist holdouts, but hope that Asian socialism will be a more lasting brand. They cite the communitarian nature of Asian societies and the fact that Communist rule rose from revolution and nation-building, and was not merely imposed, as in Eastern Europe, by a conquering army.
Still, there is an element of whistling in the dark. Vietnam's aging leaders, like China's, hope to embrace Western aid, investment and private enterprise while preserving the one-party nature of the Leninist state. But increasingly, younger intellectuals and those with more experience in southern Vietnam are expressing doubts that economic and political development can be separated -- or that the country can walk with one leg shorter than the other, as one Politburo member, Tran Xuan Bach, put it before being purged in March.
All this is taking place in the context of a leadership struggle. The party General Secretary, Nguyen Van Linh, has begun the reforms but lacks the time and strength to see them through. He has said he will retire at the next party congress, probably in May, and the battle between conservatives and reformers has gathered bite.
The conservatives, who had been grouped around Le Duc Tho, who died two weeks ago, and his brother, Interior Minister Mai Chi Tho, have used the collapse of Eastern Europe to try to brake any move toward even a Soviet-style multiparty system.
In the last five months, the Vietnamese have had a security crackdown, arresting as many as several hundred people, some for just a few days, especially in the south. They include retired soldiers of the old National Liberation Front, religious figures, businessmen and others with what the Government calls "too much" contact with Westerners.
While the internal crackdown has now eased somewhat, there continues to be a public campaign about the reported efforts of "reactionary forces overseas" to sabotage the state and socialism. Two weeks ago, a court in Hanoi convicted 38 people of trying to overthrow the Government with the help of Thailand and of Vietnamese exiles based in the United States.
While these people represent no real threat to the regime, the trial is apparently being used to justify the crackdown and serve as a warning to others, including the Western-leaning reformers in the leadership, among them the urbane Mr. Thach.
But while some might see his international prominence as a stepping stone of sorts, he will almost assuredly not be Vietnam's next General Secretary. Even in a collective leadership, there are other, less congenial forces at play.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 717 words

HEADLINE: The Governor, the Folk Hero

 BODY:
"The Decade of the Child." "The Family of New York." Government with "a heart and a head." Mario Cuomo's language encapsulates the political man. He moves audiences with his oratory; he articulates the most humane goals. It's small wonder, as he runs against token opposition for a third term as Governor of New York, that Democrats consider him Presidential timber.
Closer to home, however, where the problems are great and the Cuomo magic familiar, New Yorkers see a sometimes maddening political figure who is, yes, better than most -- but who could also be so much more. If he would close the gap between oratory and accomplishment, he might become the folk hero his Democratic champions around the country think he is.
 The 58-year-old Mr. Cuomo is more comfortable with himself and his job than he used to be, less inclined to pick petty fights or to throw his intellectual weight around. With the economy weakening and tensions high, he is a soothing presence who never divides or appeals to base instincts.
He can be breathtakingly candid. At the recent dinner of an Italian-American organization, he could easily have given a dutiful speech but instead challenged his audience: "Wouldn't it be a sin if we, having heard those cruel epithets -- guinea, dago, wop -- were to sit back now and talk about 'the spics' and 'the niggers'?" That was Mr. Cuomo at his best, a moral leader.
Yet he is not, even after eight years on the job, a masterful political leader. He chooses competent but rarely outstanding staff. He portrays himself as a reformer but bows to the dictates of patronage. His policies brim with compassion but his programs often fall short.
Three years into his vaunted Decade of the Child, budget constraints have drained his ambitious plans to help needy children. It is no small achievement that next year, needy college students will be able to apply for Liberty Scholarships. But the Decade, so far, does not meet expectations.
The same is true of drug treatment: after announcing he wanted to create drug treatment "campuses" for 2,000 addicts, he backed off in the face of legislative and local opposition. The 2,000 new treatment beds will become 300 -- if Federal funding materializes.
The Governor's flaws will not prevent him or his sound running mate, Stan Lundine, from winning, nor should they. The Republican candidate, businessman Pierre Rinfret, has made a mockery of the campaign, failing to show any respect for the elective process. The Conservative, Herb London, appeals to a narrow electorate.
The public loses because there is no real campaign, no challenging scrutiny of the Cuomo record, so important now that the state is in bad economic trouble. The Governor has a point when he blames Washington and the Republican State Senate. But while he has produced some budget reforms, he has chronically underestimated the problem. He was a year late in seeking an essential delay of an income tax cut, and his failure to produce a convincing budget plan contributed to a reduction in the state's credit rating.
Neither has he helped New York City with its fiscal morass. He has the stature to mobilize business and labor leaders and politicians, but Mr. Cuomo has done little more than pronounce. To do otherwise risks making enemies, not his favorite strategy. Long Island would be saving 20,000 barrels of oil a day if Mr. Cuomo hadn't played to the unreasonable fears that closed Shoreham, the nuclear power plant.
On issues of profound principles, the Governor has admirably withstood withering opposition. He has repeatedly vetoed the Legislature's efforts to reinstate the death penalty and maintains a pro-choice stand on abortion.
On many other matters, though, Mr. Cuomo is loath to spend his political capital. He's likely to have many more opportunities. The economy will demand painful choices about how best to use shrinking resources. With crime worsening, he will have to go beyond his successful effort to double the state's prison capacity: the problem also demands effective drug treatment and more judges.
In a third term, he can work to meet the perceptions of those who know him only from his words. We endorse Governor Cuomo with the hope that, whatever the future brings him, he will resolve to match word with deed.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Republicans From Afar Glare at Washington

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
REPUBLICANS always knew that history was working against them this year, that a President's party was almost bound to lose Congressional seats in a midterm election. But before Labor Day, with a popular President buoyed by Americans rallying around the troops in the Persian Gulf, many Republicans hoped to beat the odds.
Since then, in large part because of a worsening economy and the tumultuous budget negotiations, the political terrain has become far more perilous for Republicans. A week before Election Day, many are dismayed over the losses they expect, disgusted with the lack of political acumen displayed by the White House in the budget talks and deeply divided over their party's philosophical direction. 
 Democrats are downright gleeful. "We're more upbeat, no question about it," said Paul Tully, political director of the Democratic National Committee.
White House officials were scrambling to repair the political damage, sending President Bush out on the stump last week to claim that the Democrats made him do it -- made him raise the taxes that he promised not to touch. But there was considerable doubt within his own party as to whether that could overcome weeks of Democratic agitprop depicting the Republicans as the guardians of the rich and the plunderers of Medicare.
There was no clearer sign of Republican distress than the public feuding of recent days, extraordinary for a party that had prospered in togetherness for a decade while "Democrat" became synonomous with disarray. During the 1980's Republicans of all ideological hues shared a stage with Ronald Reagan.
But last week, Mr. Bush found himself on the campaign trail for Republicans who kept him at arm's length. It was a taste of what his Democratic counterparts have known for years: the loneliness at the top of a divided party. "Never get between a Congressman and re-election, even if you're the President of the United States," said one Republican strategist.
An embarrassing memo to Republican candidates from Edward Rollins, co-chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, was published in The Washington Post. "Do not hesitate to oppose either the President or proposals being advanced in Congress" on taxes, it said. The White House was reduced to public complaining about a party official.
These little humiliations were just part of payback time for Mr. Bush. Throughout the budget negotiations, some Republicans felt that the White House was taking a very cavalier attitude toward the fate of the Congressional wing of the party in the 1990 elections.
 
A Strategy Gap
 Since Lee Atwater, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, fell ill with a brain tumor last March, Republicans have worried about the political instincts of this White House. Without Mr. Atwater, and with James Baker consumed by his duties at the State Department, Mr. Bush has lost the two men who guided him to the Presidency in 1988. John H. Sununu, the chief of staff, has tried to step into the void, but recent weeks have hardly been a testimony to his political skills.
Still, there are deeper passions at work. The glue that bound the Republican Party over the last 10 years was the charismatic leadership of Ronald Reagan, a fierce anti-Communism and an abhorrence of new taxes. This budget agreement is no mere issue dispute, but painful heresy to many conservatives.
"Republicans at every level are being asked to abandon what they thought was the heart and soul of the Republican message for at least the last 12 years," said Representative Vin Weber of Minnesota. "We've been asked to follow a path down which we cannot go."
The Republicans' angst has an added edge because their political fortunes seemed to shift so quickly. Many have watched in horror as the budget negotiations raised such unpopular ideas as higher gasoline taxes and Medicare cuts while the economy continued to sour. The public debate often became a kind of morality play, adroitly scripted by the Democrats: millionaires versus Medicare recipients, Republicans versus Democrats.
The polls began to show a worrisome erosion in support for the party and some of its candidates, as well as a sharp decline in Mr. Bush's popularity.
One of the more disturbing trends for Republicans in recent weeks has been a shift toward the Democrats among the elderly, who tend to vote in high numbers in midterm elections."Older voters pay more attention," said Mr. Tully of the Democratic National Committee, "especially when you get a budget package where their program is on the line."
Election Day predictions are now being adjusted. Democratic voters "are going home," said Harrison Hickman, a Democratic poll-taker. But Mr. Hickman, like some of his Republican counterparts, says the movement is not on the scale of 1982, when Republicans lost 26 House seats at the height of a recession, or 1986, when the party lost control of the Senate. "In '82 and '86 it was a tidal wave," Mr. Hickman said. "This year, it's a big breaker."
This is a time when both parties try to lowball expectations, but Republican campaign officials say they will be happy to keep their losses in the House to single digits. Even small losses in the House would hurt. In 1982, the party began with a base of 192; this year, because George Bush carried no Republican House members into office with him in 1988, the party starts with just 175.
In the Senate, some analysts say the Republicans will be hard-pressed to meet their goal of picking up two or three seats and thus being well positioned to regain control in 1992. Equally worrisome for them is the tightening of several critical Governors' races where Republicans had strong leads, including Texas and Ohio.

HEADLINE: Karen B. Levy Weds James K. Finkel

 BODY:
Karen Beth Levy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Levy of Pittsburgh, was married there last evening to James Klee Finkel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David K. Finkel 2d of Pittsburgh. Rabbi Walter Jacob officiated at the Rodef Shalom Temple.
Mrs. Finkel, 32 years old, is a vice president and a portfolio manager in New York at Paine Webber. She graduated cum laude from the University of Pennsylvania and received an M.B.A. degree from Columbia University. Her father retired as the mathematics department chairman at Peabody High School in Pittsburgh, where her mother, Joan W. Levy, is a teacher at Madison Elementary School.
The bridegroom, 29, is an associate with the law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft in New York. A graduate of Colorado College with a master of science degree from the London School of Economics, he received a master of laws degree in taxation from New York University and a J.D. degree from the University of Miami, where he was an associate editor of The Law Review. His mother, Elaine S. Finkel, is a former speech pathologist with Columbia University. His father is a retired jeweler.

PUB-DATE: October 28, 1990

SECTION: Section 2; Page 15; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1631 words

HEADLINE: FILM VIEW;
Horror '90: They're Taking Your Home

BYLINE: By Caryn James

 BODY:
"LADY," SNARLS A HIGH-INTEREST moneylender as he refuses to help Melanie Griffith pay the mortgage. "You're sitting on a $750,000 piece of property. Sell it and keep the change."
Sounds like good advice, but being practical about home ownership is a villainous trait in "Pacific Heights," the sloppily plotted but commercially successful new film about the romance of real estate. Ms. Griffith and Matthew Modine play an unmarried couple who buy a Victorian house they can scarcely afford. Michael Keaton is the tenant from hell, who farms cockroaches on the premises in one of many improbable schemes to steal their property out from under them. 
 The moneylender, in his single scene, evokes decades of movie bankers who threaten to foreclose on the farm. And Ms. Griffith's whiny plea, "It's our home!" is the film's most heroic line, for she is the virtuous homesteader. But something more than a cinematic convention is at work in this mediocre thriller.
"Pacific Heights" may be the harbinger of the recession-era movie, preying on the legitimate and timely 90's fear of losing one's home. In a larger-than-life way, it touches the same nerve as some chilling economic news reports. In the last year, there has been a record number of foreclosures in the northeastern United States; the middle classes from New York to Tokyo are finding it next to impossible to buy homes; many economists talk about recession as inevitable, and some say it's already here.
So in several current films, the sacred house is invaded; and that action evokes the worst economic fears of the middle class. Superficial plots suggest the lost dream of home ownership and give films a topical edge.
In both "Pacific Heights" and "Ghost," an unmarried couple find romance in renovating their home (for white-collar workers, they're awfully handy with nail guns), only to have that home invaded by sociopaths and killers. The idyllic country house in "Arachnophobia" is overrun by lethal spiders. The unlucky house behind a "For Sale" sign in "Desperate Hours" is invaded by Mickey Rourke as an escaped killer. And unlike the spirited westerns of old, these contemporary stories of beleaguered homeowners are often as pessimistic as today's economic forcasts.
The movie home has always been a sanctuary and a symbol of the American dream, of course. "The Grapes of Wrath" (1940) is the quintessential Depression-era movie, with its homeless Joad family carrying the weight of a decade of economic desperation. "It's a Wonderful Life" (1946) shows that if George Bailey (James Stewart) had not been born, the townspeople would have been left at the mercy of the heartless banker played by Lionel Barrymore.
More recently, foreclosure movies have flourished in times of economic crisis. In 1984 alone, when American farmers were struggling fiercely for survival, three major films dealt with losing the farm. Sissy Spacek and Mel Gibson in "The River" and Jessica Lange and Sam Shepard in "Country" were contemporary farmers who fought the elements and the banks to keep their homes. Sally Field played a Depression-era single mother struggling to maintain her cotton crops in "Places in the Heart," but its story clearly echoed the contemporary farmer's situation.
"Country" was the strongest and most realistic in portraying the wearying psychological battle and isolation of the embattled farm couple. "The River" offered a more cliched view of neighbors pitching in to help save the farm. There, when a flood threatens the crops, the community turns up to salvage them. And Danny Glover as a drifter and John Malkovich -- a blind boarder, he is the tenant from heaven -- pick enough cotton to keep the family going in "Places in the Heart," whose title suggests the sentimental yet willful spirit that informs all three films.
Like "The Grapes of Wrath" and "It's a Wonderful Life," they were defiant movies about the triumph of the human spirit over the forces of big business and an uncaring government. The 1984 films were such strong activist statements that Ms. Spacek, Ms. Lange and Ms. Field testified before the House Agriculture Committee the next year to support increased Government aid to farmers. These movies tapped into a feisty sense of social activism, the spirit that led to the pop-rock benefit concert Farm Aid.
But it's hard to imagine Melanie Griffith and Matthew Modine being asked to comment on the savings and loan bailout. The 90's real-estate films are not only escapist, they also reflect a cynical social mood. With characters pitted against economic and social forces far beyond their control, these films are informed by a sense of helplessness and doom. As the characters fight for their very lives, it seems both inevitable and secondary that they may lose the house along the way.
Like most tragedies, "Pacific Heights" and "Ghost" start by establishing the idyllic world soon to be lost. For both couples, love means renovating together. "Ghost" begins with Patrick Swayze and Demi Moore breaking through a wall in their new home, the first they have shared. Great care is given to the decoration of this artsy loftlike apartment, which holds a huge statue of an angel and a
potter's wheel. But while Mr. Swayze's character may be great at moving furniture, he never manages to get out the L-word and say, "I love you."
The couple in "Pacific Heights" lavishes more care and attention on their house than on their decision to have a child. When Ms. Griffith's character announces she's pregnant, presumably not by plan, Mr. Modine says, "Congratulations," and that's that. The next time the matter is discussed, over dinner at a restaurant and in the presence of a friend, Ms. Griffith says casually, "I don't have to be pregnant." Mr. Modine replies of course she does; he won't sacrifice their child for the mortgage, and that's that again.
Given the muddled script of "Pacific Heights," it's hard to say whether these scenes were meant to be the entire "Let's have the baby" conversation. But whatever the intention, as in "Ghost," the home seems a repository of emotions and perhaps a substitute for more difficult personal issues.
These too-perfect lives, of course, are soon shattered. In "Ghost," Mr. Swayze is murdered, only to reappear as a specter. One of the more effective scenes in this thriller-comedy-romance takes place when the murderer invades their apartment and the newly-dead Mr. Swayze isunable to warn Ms. Moore of her danger. He is helpless and invisible in his own home.
And the couple in "Pacific Heights" is at times equally helpless, at the mercy not only of the demonic invader but also of more ordinary evils; once more, the government works against the struggling homeowner. The couple is morally right but legally wrong in trying to force the tenant out, so the police and the courts offer them no protection. Finally, the all-American dream of home ownership becomes a lethal nightmare as the tenant battles the landlords to the death.
Throughout "Pacific Heights," you might expect a lack of sympathy for these overextended yuppies; they are, after all, sitting on a $750,000 piece of property. Instead there is a sense that they don't deserve their troubles, for Ms. Griffith's "It's our home" echoes a similar helpless cry by thousands of middle-class men and women sitting on less valuable property. Whether they are symbolic movie characters or real-life homeowners, they are pitted against a gigantic, failing economy, worrying about how to pay the mortgage.
Even a lighthearted film such as "Arachnophobia" evokes a similar sense of not being in control in one's own home. When Jeff Daniels moves his wife and two small children from the city to a small town, he gets a house and a barn full of poisonous spiders. He saves his family almost single-handedly, though he is enough of an urban sophisticate to think twice before smashing a spider with an expensive bottle of wine. But here Dad saves the homestead only to leave it, with great relief. At the film's end, the family heads back to San Francisco, where even the threat of earthquakes seems less ominous than the unknown dangers of the country.
"Desperate Hours," Michael Cimino's commercially disastrous remake of the 1955 Humphrey Bogart film, also plays to the fears of invasion, though without much effect. If Mickey Rourke takes over a house and holds a family hostage, it should make for an intense experience. Instead, this film is laughable and overwrought. But in conception, at least, it suggests that the 90's home is not the secure haven it was in the 50's. The happy husband and wife of the original have become a divorcing couple, and the old homestead is now on the market.
Mimi Rogers, who plays the mother held hostage, is quoted in the film's publicity material as saying, "What is truly frightening is the thought of someone invading your home, violating that space. Even in a dangerous world, it's the one place where you're supposed to be safe from whatever craziness or violence is happening outside." If "Desperate Hours" had been more successful in conveying that sense of violation, perhaps it would be doing far better commercially. And the film's happy ending -- the family reunited once more in their own home -- is one of its least convincing, least timely touches.
For the message of the more popular films is fearful and nervous, as in "Pacific Heights" and "Arachnophobia," or at best bittersweet, as in "Ghost." In all of them, some emotional understanding or moral truth is gained, some justice restored; Patrick Swayze heads toward a better afterlife and all those spiders go to the great beyond, too. But something is definitely lost. Usually it's real estate.

PUB-DATE: October 28, 1990

SECTION: Section 5; Page 14; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 2136 words

HEADLINE: A Directory of Cruises Worldwide;
Casting Off in the Spice Islands

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER; STEVEN ERLANGER is head of the Bangkok bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
There is apparently something about a tropical cruise that encourages a California Republican to put orchids in the tops of his knee-length black socks, a Canadian accountant to don a tribal sarong cum dagger and a New York epidemiologist to sit down to dinner in drag.
Unavoidable collegiality on a small ship, aided by alcohol, will do that to the stiffest of people. But the extraordinary landscapes of Indonesia's most primitive islands, hugging the Equator in eerie, barren magnificence, must bring out and distort the tribal instincts, no matter how attenuated, in all of us. 
 This offering of P & O Spice Island Cruises, which moves among the 10 or so main islands of Indonesia's Lesser Sundas, stretching from lush Bali to parched Timor, is not merely for those tired of the usual journeys.
These are some of the most varied and unspoiled waters in the world, free of Thailand's sewage and Penang's murky waters, with psychedelic fish and startling reefs of coral as yet unsmashed by human hands. These cruises, which began five years ago, thus bring to a much wider group the possibility of travel to a part of the world long limited to backpackers with visions of Joseph Conrad, young graduates eager to find material bizarre enough to carry a first book, or what is usually and eumphemistically referred to as "the hardy traveler" -- the kind who enjoys a good steamer, the trampier the better, and a night out in the village goat shelter.
For a week in early October, with the hope of amusement in my heart and 27 other passengers, I sailed with the company's latest purchase, a 121-foot Australian-built passenger catamaran called the Spice Islander. It can hold 42 passengers (62 if people triple up) in 4 suites and 17 attractive, well-designed cabins. The ship, which on three levels includes a dining room, two lounges with bars and a sundeck with a weak Jacuzzi bath, rides on twin hulls; these hulls lend stability and let it roam in shallower waters.
The company's other catamaran, the Island Explorer, is similar: 134 feet long, with 12 cabins, 5 suites and a stunning dining room, with large windows, at the bow. The ships are represented in the United States by Abercrombie & Kent.
I chose to sail west from Kupang, on West Timor, back to Bali along a southern route, hitting Suwa, Sumba, Komodo, Satonda, Moyo and Lombok islands, although one can also chose the eastern and northerly route, from Bali to Sumbawa, Komodo, Flores, Lembata and West Timor, or spend 16 days and make the entire circle.
The cruises try, sometimes awkwardly, to mix culture, commerce, wildlife and a lot of water sports, with at least one shore excursion every day. While the anthropology is hardly serious, with mock ceremonies performed by islanders and good-natured but amateurish slide lectures on board in the evenings, this is still rather far from the beaten track of boutiques and Balinese "dinner and dance" performances. The cruise offers a relatively leisurely look at remote and intricate societies on Sawu, Sumba, Sumbawa and Flores that not too many others have seen, and at some weird wildlife too, like the Komodo dragon, one of the world's oldest surviving species and its largest, smartest and most bloodthirsty reptile.
Meanwhile, between astounding sunrises and sunsets, you can sleep comfortably as the ship sails each night, eat safely if unexcitingly, buy as much of the local ikat fabric as you can carry and absorb as much sun and saltwater as you're likely to be able to stand. And you are spared the usual social director and bingo games common on larger cruises.
You can swim or snorkel from pristine beaches on uninhabited islands, fish for red snapper and tuna, scuba dive, if trained, with a crewman divemaster, windsurf or water ski or simply cruise around looking at the fish and coral from a glass-bottomed boat. This is stored on board, along with two smaller Zodiacs, to take passengers to shore.
 The 21 crew members, all Indonesian,are generally so solicitous and sweet-tempered that they'll allow you to do almost anything within reason, and there are no extra charges except for drinks and laundry. The crew's only real fault, discounting some disorganization on this early shakedown cruise for this ship, is that its members may forget what they promised you if someone else asks them for something else a few minutes later.
 The extremely good-natured and varied group of fellow passengers included six nationalities; the bulk were American. There was also a pleasant range of ages, and only one passenger who seemed regularly unhappy, having expected a more leisurely and traditional sort of cruise.
The cruise operates in a fascinating part of Indonesia, which stretches over 3,000 miles from east to west and encompasses over 13,700 islands, of which some 6,000 are named and 1,000 inhabited all year. This is also a far cry from swarming Jakarta or the intensely settled and detailed societies of central Java, parts of Indonesia that should also be seen. These islands, which are known locally as Nusa Tenggara, stretch some 700 miles and are the peaks of two submerged mountain ranges. The southern one, running from Sumba to Timor, is nonvolcanic, while the northerly one, stretching from Bali to the Alor Islands and dominating Sumbawa and Flores, is intensely volcanic, with the steaming plumes of Mother Earth's digestive system often visible from the ship. With deep waters and fast currents between them, the islands are vastly different from one another. The landscapes are similar, but get drier and more parched moving eastward, with steep hills, narrow coastal plains, savanna and grassland, and scattered lontar palms that provide food, drink and shelter.
But the inhabitants live very distinct lives, often speaking different dialects and sometimes ignorant of the national language, Bahasa Indonesia. Depending on their varying histories -- some islands were discovered by Arab traders, others claimed by the Dutch or the Portuguese -- their religions vary, too, from Hinduism in Bali, Islam next door in Lombok and Sumbawa, Roman Catholicism in Flores and Timor and Protestantism in Sawu, Sumba and many of the rest.
Yet not very far beneath this layer of "foreign" beliefs is a healthy dose of animism, with firm faith in magic, spirits and animal sacrifices tied in to a sophisticated tribal society of ceremony, ritual and negotiations.
These mixed beliefs, with their varying symbols and totems -- from local animals and plants to the lion's heads and tulips taken from old Dutch coins and porcelains -- give interest and value to the highly distinctive warp ikats of these islands, Sawu, Roti and Sumba in particular. Ikat means to tie, and the threads of the warp are patterned by being repeatedly dyed, after different sections have been protected by being tied with dye-resistant fibers.
The results can be magnificent, and even if the villagers you see are primed for your arrival, with their wares on display for purchase after they do some traditional dances of welcome or ceremony, many of the ikats are worth their modest, post-bargaining price.
It is, perhaps, an unavoidable compromise, given your intrusion and their performance, and it helps them survive in a harsh but slowly modernizing landscape, where the cash economy becomes more important. P & O's cruise ships are the only ones to come to these villages, and then only once a week, so some sense of proportion is maintained.
Still, judging from fellow passengers, a lot of people like to buy as much as travel, a sentiment caught by the ship's chief steward, Yusdi Diaz, who announced after a village dance performance on Sawu, "Now it's buying frenzy time."

 The Wallace line cuts through these islands, which the great 19th-century naturalist Sir Alfred Russel Wallace saw as the break between the fauna of Asia and Australasia. West of Lombok, he suggested, are the tropical vegetations, monkeys, elephants, tigers and straight human hair of Asia, while east began the arid plants, cockatoos, lizards, parrots, marsupials and curly human hair of the Australasians and Melanesians. The islands of Nusa Tenggara are considered transitional, with examples of both types, and some unique species.
The fierce and peculiar Komodo Dragon is one. Often 10 feet long, with a forked tongue and hinged jaw like a snake, a thwacking, heavy tail, sharp, sawlike teeth capable of quickly hacking a goat or deer into three or four digestible chunks, it is worth the short trek to its austere habitat.
Huge monitor lizards believed to date from the Jurassic Age and to be extinct everywhere else, the dragons survived because of Komodo Island's inaccessibility. They have no competition as predators and live protected in a huge national park that covers Komodo Island and bits of Flores. Visitors are guided by rangers whose only protection is a cleft stick.
There are always stories of tourists who disappear except for their cameras and gnawed footwear; the week before we arrived, one ranger got bitten because he hung on to a goat a moment too long for the dragons' liking.
The rangers also like to tell disgusting dragon tales for the delectation of visitors, as lizards hiss below in a pit. One grinning ranger, after stirring up the dragons by imitating the bleats of a goat, said: "One time the mother, she eat her baby still in the shell, and she eat shell, too -- she eat everything."
You won't be tempted to do the same on the ship, which serves an awkward mixture of bad Western and indifferent Indonesian food. Some of the best meals were made from fish or lobsters caught by the passengers or crew, although given the expanse of the ocean around us, there wasn't enough fish on offer. The Australian beef is of excellent quality, though usually overcooked. But the desserts are fine and so is the wine list, which offers sensible French and Australian wines for nearly duty-free prices.
Breakfasts and lunches are buffet and offer reasonable choices. But the breakfast buffet is heavy on bacon, sausage and eggs, with heated frozen croissants and danishes and white bread near a toaster, while the cereals were all stale, a hazard of the sea. There was fruit and cheese, however, and very good Balinese coffee available almost around the clock.
But the notion of a relatively stiff, four-course dinner every night in this part of the world is silly, and most passengers said they would be happy with lighter, less pretentious fare, with fewer canned vegetables and canned sauces. There is a choice of two main courses, but except for the last, festive evening, which produced the Republican in orchids, the cooking is Western, and there are some nights on which no fish is offered. One can sit where one likes and needn't dress for dinner, so the atmosphere is pleasant enough. After days filled with so much exoticism, there probably is something reassuring about a simple hunk of beef and some frozen french fries.
 
GETTING SHIPSHAPE FOR A VOYAGE
 
 What You Get
The Spice Islander's cabins are attractive and comfortable, with simple wooden appointments.
There are built-in drawers, cupboards and a closet to cut down clutter. Well-designed bathrooms allow you to take a shower without getting everything drenched.
The ship makes its own fresh water for washing, and there is also laundry service.
So-called suites are only marginally larger and are not worth the extra money. But if you want a queen-sized bed instead of twin beds, insist on it when you reserve. The cabins also have a pulldown twin bed for families.
 
What to Take
The islands covered by the cruise are close to the Equator and the sun is very strong. It's important to take a good sunblock (hard to find in Indonesia), a hat, and T-shirts to swim, snorkel or dive in. You can buy aloe vera on the boat, which has a small stock of drugstore items (though best take your own). A male nurse doubles as a cabin steward.
Also take cotton clothes that are easily washable, at least two swimsuits and clothing suitable for visiting temples and for village ceremonies; for shore visits, culottes for women are fine, but not short shorts or tank tops.
Thin nylon diving boots provide good protection from sea urchins and sharp coral, and take at least one pair of comfortable walking shoes.
The ship provides fins, masks and snorkels, plus a few sets of diving gear. But if you like to dive, say so when you book, and take your own equipment (minus the tanks, of course).
 
Tipping
 There are no extra charges for diving or anything else save drinks and laundry, and those can be settled at the end by credit card.
The company suggests anonymous tipping at $4 per passenger per day. -- S. E.
