LENGTH: 1719 words

HEADLINE: TV VIEW;
Soothing Bromides? Not on TV

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR

 BODY:
TELEVISION ENTERTAINMENT has a knack for sticking close to current headlines, not only with those inevitable docudramas rolling hastily off the more sensational stories (Leona Helmsley's in "The Queen of Mean" or Charles Stuart's in "Good Night, Sweet Wife: A Murder in Boston") but also in the seemingly pedestrian plotting of weekly series.
If the news is dominated by reports of economic decline, rampant crime, drugs, homelessness and official corruption, many prime-time shows -- especially the law-and-order ones -- waste little time catching up, reflecting what has already happened and, in some instances, anticipating what could happen. This season, from NBC's "Law and Order" and Fox's "Against the Law" to CBS's "Trials of Rosie O'Neill" and ABC's "Cop Rock," passing images of the nation's social order can be remarkably scathing and unsettling. 
 Not too long ago, television was thought to be the Great Unifier. Back then, before the cable boom of the 1980's, the three commercial networks alone could command the loyalty of more than 90 percent of prime-time viewers. It was not unusual for most of the country to be found snuggling up together for an episode of "I Love Lucy." For the most part, depictions of society's basic institutions were comforting. Formats were simple, with the good guys clearly identified. The police and other law enforcers, certainly, could nearly always be counted on to be brave and incorruptible. The influence of "Dragnet" stretched over decades.
Today? A police officer can turn out to be a sadistic executioner ("Cop Rock") or a reactionary lug ("The Trials of Rosie O'Neill"). No institution, it would appear, is exempt from an unblinking and sometimes brutal diagnosis. Far from being a noble Marcus Welby, doctors can turn out to be alcoholic blunderers ("Law and Order") or scheming crooks ("Against the Law"). Even representatives of the clergy, long sacrosanct in the gallery of pop images, can become targets, with some priests being exposed as sex offenders (HBO's "Judgment"). The former Great Unifier is, evidently, no longer a reliable source of soothing bromides.
Several reasons can be cited. Like the industry itself, television programming has become more fragmented, appealing to narrower audience targets and, at the same time, more subject to the pressures of innumerable ethnic, racial and special-interest groups, all eager to get their viewpoints represented and promulgated. On a broader level, now that the profligate 1980's have given way unmistakably to the sobering 1990's, a certain sourness is becoming pervasive in the national psyche, as politicians have recently been discovering.
National deficits, budget battles, savings-and-loan scandals, ominous economic developments, the lot, are adding up to a nasty hangover that encourages a hostile "us vs. them" mentality. Even George Bush is not immune. Campaigning for Republicans these days, the President attempts to portray himself as a Washington outsider doing valiant battle against insider Democrats.
In TV entertainment, meanwhile, there is an escalating cynicism about figures of authority. Mayoral candidates, for instance, are openly corrupt on at least two series, "Cop Rock" and ABC's "Gabriel's Fire." In the Showtime movie "Rainbow Drive," an honest police officer does battle with villains ranging from his fellow policemen to manipulating politicians to the town's most powerful newspaper publisher, all of them involved in multimillion-dollar drug deals.
When finally exposed, the publisher is unfazed, arrogantly echoing Mrs. Helmsley ("Only the little people pay taxes") with a remark that "nobody who counts ever pays." For good measure, the wealthy titan adds: "Do you really think that billions of dollars in trade can pass through this country without involving people at the highest levels?"
Perhaps the most startling development in weekly-series scripts over the last year or so has been the emergence, on several levels, of a pronounced class consciousness. Americans generally are not supposed to be overly concerned with class distinctions. In fact, in his new book, "The Imperial Middle: Why Americans Can't Think Straight About Class," the social and literary critic Benjamin DeMott argues that a persistent denial of fairly rigid class lines prevents many of us from considering issues honestly. Yet that denial is now being vigorously challenged in, of all places, prime time.
The trend began evolving last season with NBC's "Shannon's Deal" -- now scheduled as a midseason replacement -- and the decision of its John Sayles hero to leave the lucrative world of corporate law and become a private detective, struggling to put his values and shattered life back into reasonable order. This season we have, among others, the title character of "The Trials of Rosie O'Neill," a socially connected lawyer who, dumped by her wealthy husband, becomes a public defender after realizing that at the age of 43 she has nothing to show for her life except credit cards and a Mercedes.
At the other end of the social scale there's Simon McHeath, the lawyer hero of "Against the Law." Raised in a Bronx tenement and now being divorced by his wealthy wife, Simon can't resist defending assorted social rejects. His father-in-law, head of a very Establishment law firm and unable to recruit the brilliant maverick, is snootily contemptuous: "You went to the wrong school, lived on the wrong side of town and divorced the wrong wife." Simon grins mischievously.
A growing awareness of class may well be an unavoidable byproduct of the Reagan era when, as the statistics keep telling us, the rich got richer and the poor poorer. The process and possible consequences have been described forthrightly by the conservative analyst Kevin Phillips in his book "The Politics of Rich and Poor." Here again, surely, is an underlying cause for the proliferation of us-vs.-them attitudes, whether they concern haves and have-nots or, as Mr. Bush would have it, official Washington and "real people," presumably meaning himself and his supporters.
On television series, the phenomenon can take odd turns. On a recent episode, Rosie O'Neill (Sharon Gless) was advised not to put her defendant, a mechanic from El Salvador, on the stand because "the jury will see just another wetback." Winning an acquittal for her client on the robbery charge, the triumphant Rosie is stunned when the mechanic shows up at her home and, in a vaguely threatening manner, begins talking resentfully about the rich women who bring him their BMW's and Jaguars for repair ("I'm nothing to them stuck-up bitches").
Then he begins directing his anger at Rosie -- "I'm not good enough to sit in your living room. You are not better than me. You are as bad as all the rest of them." Rosie is horrifed at the thought that maybe the man was indeed guilty, yet disturbed by the possibility that his accusations are on target. The man disappears, but Rosie ends up feeling like a hypocrite.
Another theme running through many of the newer series is the conviction that the system, not just criminal justice but all institutions, simply do not work. On "Law and Order," for instance, an investigation of a hospital and its staff finds that "when they don't catch their sometimes fatal mistakes, they just bury them." Medicine, someone observes, is "part science, part lottery." In "Against the Law," hospitals are described as "mills -- push 'em in, shove 'em out." The justice system, its prisons bursting at the seams, appears mired in ineffectual but expedient compromises. After a subway vigilante case in "Law and Order," a Jesuitical district attorney grimly observes: "This is not a question of win or lose. It's just a deal -- suspended sentence and probation. The right thing? Seems to be all we did was make two wrongs seem like a right."
Police have been a traditional source of rich programming material, and there seems to be no change imminent on that score. On current schedules, police can be found as first-rate crime-fighters (the detective team on "Law and Order"), as buffoons (the would-be-cowboy police chief on "Cop Rock" and weepy Andy on "Twin Peaks") and as dangerous killers (seething LaRusso in "Cop Rock" and the prison guards in "Gabriel's Fire"). And when it comes to class stratifications, police happen to be, rather uncomfortably, near the very middle.
Those police officers who work in urban ghettos are often mired in apathy, cynicism and low morale. Several weeks ago, a Brooklyn patrolman, 25 years old, offered this comment to a newspaper reporter: "In the five years I've been here, I've been spit at, kicked, sent to the hospital once and shot at on two different occasions. If you are going to be in a high-crime area, you're not going to have a great opinion of the people who live there." This kind of real-life situation was perhaps captured most vividly on television this season in several scenes on "Cop Rock" in which busted drug dealers sang out their fury in rap: "He calls you son, he ain't your dad, he's just a cop, and you make him mad." Back at the station house, bitter cops booking suspects had their own song: "Garbage In, Garbage Out."
At the same time, the police can find themselves suddenly thrust into the upper reaches of society. Again on "Cop Rock," officers investigating a burglary at a luxurious home are treated like low-paid help ("Have you ever been to Machu Picchu?" the elegant wife asks), which prompts a musical fantasy on their access to the "good life" ("Take a look, but don't touch").
Television entertainment still has its old-fashioned formats and formulas. CBS's "Top Cops," for instance, uses a new "reality" veneer to portray the police in familiar and almost exclusively heroic terms and, despite soaring crime statistics across the nation, doles out warm weekly assurances about the effectiveness of our crime-fighters. But then the nightly news comes on with stories of subway killings and innocent children being caught in the cross fire of drug shoot-outs. Uncertainty, at the very least, is inevitable, stretching from urban streets to the corridors of established institutions. Television's standard bromides are bound to be no more comforting these days than society's.

HEADLINE: POP MUSIC;
A New Respect for Folk - But Black Tie Optional

BYLINE: By JON PARELES

 BODY:
This Saturday at Weill Recital Hall, a sold-out house is to hear the syncopated clatter of a buckdancer, the plunk and twang of a string band and the fingerpicking guitar and train-whistle harmonica of a blues duo. The concert is produced by Carnegie Hall itself, the first of a dozen Folk Masters concerts featuring music of the Americas. It isn't the only traditional music in town; both the World Music Institute and the Ethnic Folk Arts Center will be busy this weekend presenting music from four continents. But when Carnegie Hall puts its clout behind down-home sounds, it signals a sea change among what Nick Spitzer, the folklorist who assembled the Folk Masters series, calls the "blue-chip institutions."
For those institutions, classical music in the European tradition is still their staple. But a declining classical audience, changes in urban demographics, new goals set by government and private financing sources and broader ideas of musical quality have made the world's folk music a new resource for concert-hall programmers. "This year," says Robert Browning, who runs the World Music Institute, "every institution in New York -- Lincoln Center, Carnegie Hall, Town Hall -- bought our mailing list." 
 "There is some pressure from foundations for presenting institutions to respond to the community that lives around them," says Ethel Raim, co-director of the Ethnic Folk Arts Center. "There is pressure to widen their programming, as well there should be."
While many academics debate the wisdom of Eurocentrism and define the late 20th century as a postcolonial era, musicians and listeners have been exploring remote styles. Recent generations were likely to hear folk songs from collectors and interpreters like Pete Seeger and John Jacob Niles, but current fans turn directly to the source. Some seek the thrill of exotica; others are looking for cultures with unmistakable roots. Record stores now have "world beat" bins, while clubs have been skimming off the styles with the closest kinship to rock, like Louisiana zydeco and West African pop.
But plenty of traditional music will never be right for the pop market. It is the music of, say, Mohawk long-house singers, who pass on tribal lore with drums, rattles and chants, or of Turkish Sufi musicians, who perform the ancient songs that help whirling dervishes achieve their ecstatic trance. One of the glories of folk music is that it is anything but a museum piece. Los Pleneros de la 21, a Puerto Rican bomba and plena group, uses age-old rhythms and poetic forms to carry up-to-date lyrics.
More often than not, traditional music is being presented on something close to its own terms -- not as a quaint sociological artifact, not adulterated for the pop market, not too gussied up for outsiders, but as vital music with rigorous standards. Fewer people are asking "But is it art?" Bluegrass fiddlers and Indian raga masters have shown there's more than one way to be a violin virtuoso. "We're trying to get rid of the idea that Western classical music is serious and everything else is entertainment," says Mr. Browning of the World Music Institute. "Many cultures don't draw a line between serious music and popular music, and when an African drummer is drumming, that is definitely serious, although it's also entertaining. But it's entertaining for me to listen to Beethoven."
Traditional music has come to 57th Street before, notably in a short-lived 1984-85 series at Carnegie Recital Hall, co-produced by Mr. Browning. But with a $225,000 budget for Folk Masters, and an additional $100,000 to record the series for broadcast next spring on American Public Radio, Carnegie Hall becomes one of New York's main presenters of traditional music, at least this year. The series includes North Carolina fishermen's sea chanteys, New Orleans Mardi Gras Indian chants, Mexican harp music and what may be the last underdiscovered accordion music of this hemisphere, Colombian vallenato. "Carnegie Hall has to reconcile multiculturalism with excellence," Mr. Spitzer says, "and folk is a great way to do it."
The Folk Masters program follows through on research and audience-building begun nationally by the Smithsonian Institution's Folklife program and the National Council for the Traditional Arts, and in New York by the Ethnic Folk Arts Center (founded as the Balkan Arts Center in 1966), the World Music Institute (which had its beginnings at the Alternative Museum in the 1970's) and smaller organizations like CityLore and the Caribbean Cultural Center. Now, major institutions are endorsing what folklorists, ethnomusicologists, musicians and fans have been saying for years: traditional styles should be prized and preserved.
Alan Lomax, the ethnographer whose "American Patchwork" documentaries enlivened the Public Broadcasting Service this season, has long advocated what he calls "cultural equity." He argues that local cultural forms should not be allowed to die out under a barrage of electronic media, because they represent survival strategies for humanity; each form that disappears is as irreplaceable as a biological species. Mr. Lomax has urged that all cultures, not just economically powerful ones, be given access to media, providing a cultural interchange instead of a one-way flow of information.
That hasn't happened yet. While pop pays for itself and jazz straggles along with occasional subsidy, the music and dance styles of the social elite -- primarily European-based classical music, ballet and modern dance -- still receive the bulk of government support. The National Endowment for the Arts current annual budget for orchestras alone is $9 million, while the entire folk-arts program, which includes crafts as well as music, receives $7 million. "In Carnegie's program book, the folk series is on page 18," says Nick Spitzer, "and it's the only page where the musicians aren't wearing evening gowns, tuxedos or black turtlenecks."
On a broader scale, home-grown styles are beleaguered by all the pressures of assimilation. Generations of immigrants and rural migrants to cities have received signals that old tunes and dances are too foreign, too lower class, too "country." Who wants to listen to grandpa's fiddle when Madonna is on TV? And who will admit to loving Serbian brass bands when the boss attends the Mostly Mozart Festival?
Luckily, traditions die hard. Because folk music is tied to the folks themselves -- to people for whom certain melodies and rhythms and dance steps measure out daily life (births, weddings, funerals) -- immigrant enclaves hold on to traditions, at least for a generation or two.
The Ethnic Folk Arts Center got started because Martin Koenig, a dancer, and Ethel Raim, a singer, loved the music of the Balkans; the music led them to the communities, where they found that preserving it meant showing immigrants that their music was prized by "Americans." From Balkan enclaves, they fanned out to Italian, Central Asian, Irish, Haitian and other communities, seeking out musicians, largely by word of mouth, and introducing them to the wider public.
The idea, Mr. Koenig says, is to bolster carriers of traditions by showing that "you can still get access to what's available in America and you don't have to give up what you come from. In fact, if you do give up what you come from, you're scarred."
The nonprofit Ethnic Folk Arts Center, whose current budget is approximately $600,000, presents about 30 concerts a year, including an annual multiethnic jamboree every September at a Queens beer garden. But its research programs, with recordings to document traditional styles, are equally important. "The hard work will still be to support musicians in the community," Ms. Raim says. "Maybe more people will have their eyes opened to the relationship between these musical forms and the community and their quality of life, but it hasn't happened yet."
The World Music Institute grew out of the Alternative Museum, a Lower East Side art gallery that later moved to TriBeCa. To use the gallery space at night, Mr. Browning brought in jazz and traditional music; by the mid-1980's, audiences grew too big for the room. Mr. Browning started the nonprofit World Music Institute in 1985, with a budget of $65,000; its annual budget is now $700,000. It presents about 70 concerts a year -- mostly ethnic music, but with some avant-garde jazz and cross-cultural experiments -- in places like Washington Square Church, Merkin Hall and Symphony Space.
Like other presenters of traditional music, Mr. Browning sees the need for a new kind of concert hall. The proscenium stages of blue-chip institutions put a distance between audience and performer and presume the seated, silent audience that goes with European styles of music.
"I'd like to see a place for 500 to 600 people maximum, with people in a semicircle, close to the musicians," Mr. Browning says. "It would have a sound system built in that would sound as natural as possible. And the performing space would also have a cafe with a dance floor. Most traditional music is people's music, and it has always been performed in the context of family, ritual, rites of passage, where food and drink are usually part of the celebration."
 Mr. Spitzer, who was the state folklorist in Louisiana and is currently a folk-life consultant to the Smithsonian, created his Folk Masters program to take the music's new context -- Weill Hall -- into account. It emphasizes solo performers and small groups rather than amplified dance bands. "Any new context you put traditional artists in strengthens them," he says. "They can say, 'I've been to Carnegie Hall,' and the echo back into communities means a lot.
"I always say cultural conservation is really cultural conversation. The only way it's going to happen is if there are ways of talking to each other between different spheres and classes. For folk traditions to survive they invariably change. The question is, who controls the change? Is the change dominated by people from outside the tradition who want to put up hothouse flowers, to say, 'Gee, we took care of that pluralistic impulse'? Or is it dominated by people from within the communities looking for ways to mediate between modern, international, multicultural, professional society and the deep sense of needing to belong to a community?
"When I look around Carnegie, at all the busts and portraits of famous composers," Mr. Spitzer adds, "they seem to me like home altars, holding all the received wisdom of the elders of the elite. But hearing this music humanizes classical music. It reminds you that everybody came from somewhere, that classical music has long drawn on the folk tradition, and folk performers have always been influenced by establishment sources. But if you only see it from the top down, then you're missing the other direction of flow."
Bringing folk music into established concert institutions represents a challenge, especially if the music is to be something more than tokenism. (It will be interesting to see whether Carnegie Hall renews the Folk Masters series next year.) Separate the music from an audience that knows how to respond -- dancing, laughing at in-jokes, recognizing a hot solo, speaking in tongues, all of which in turn cues the performers -- and the music may falter, just as a string quartet would have problems at a Cajun fais-do-do party.
But with an audience of insiders who know the music and outsiders eager to understand, folk music offers glimpses not just of different musical structures and techniques, but of different ways for musicians and listeners to share their art -- ways so old they may seem new.
Linda Brewer
 
 
 
ANGLO TO ZYDECO
 In celebration of its centennial, Carnegie Hall launches a 12-concert folk series this week, while New York's progenitors of folk music, the Ethnic Folk Arts Center and World Music Institute, offer a kaleidoscope of programs.
"The Americas: Traditional Music in a New World," at Carnegie's Weill Recital Hall (247-7800), showcases the musical legacies of Indian, European and African cultures in the Americas. The series opens Saturday with an evening of string-band music, barrel-house piano, tap dance and Piedmont blues with John Cephas and Phil Wiggins. Other concerts feature Cajun music, French fiddlers and a Quebecois chanteuse (Nov. 6); Colombian vallenato and Puerto Rican bomba and plena (Nov. 10); gospel (Nov. 13); cowboy poets, mountain ballads and bluegrass (Nov. 17); Hispanic string music and storytelling songs from Puerto Rico, the Dominican Republic and Louisiana (Nov. 20); African-roots music (Nov. 27); Creole music and Mexican jarcoho (Dec. 1); North American Indian song and dance (Dec. 4); zydeco and New Orleans jazz (Dec. 8); folk violin (Dec. 11), and guitar masters (Dec. 15).
The Ethnic Folk Arts Center (691-9510) introduces a "First Fridays" series this week at its Performance Space, 179 Varick Street, with a lineup that includes the Zlatne Uste Brass Band (folk dance), Wretched Refuse String Band (bluegrass) and Los Conquistadores del Sur (conjunto). The series, presented in a coffeehouse spirit, runs the first Friday of each month.
This week, the World Music Institute (545-7536) brings the sounds of India (Friday) and Turkish Sufi (Saturday) to Washington Square Church, 135 W. Fourth Street. Future concerts focus on gospel (Nov. 10 and 11) and the folk music of Russia (Nov. 16), the Mideast (Nov. 17), East Asia (Nov. 18), South India (Nov. 18), the Celts (Dec. 1), West Africa (Dec. 8), Brittany (Dec. 15) and the Andes (Dec. 22).

HEADLINE: A Directory of Cruises Worldwide;
Ships Decked Out With Amenities

BYLINE: By VERNON KIDD; VERNON KIDD frequently writes about ship travel.

 BODY:
Destination: Crown Princess. Side trips to: San Juan, St. Thomas and Nassau. More than ever, cruise ships themselves are the main attraction as sleek new vessels are launched or old ones renovated, each offering constant on-board activities, menus supervised by noted chefs and an increasing number of such amenities as soaring atriums, health clubs and sidewalk cafes.
New or refurbished ships this year will add nearly 11,000 berths, according to Cruise Lines International Association, an increase of 16 percent over 1989. As a result of this increased capacity, a cruise may be the best vacation value around, with the fall season offering the real bargains. 
 In this highly competitive environment, cruise lines are working hard to please. All the big ships launched this year were developed with amenities in mind. Princess Cruises christened its newest ship, the 70,000-ton Crown Princess, at a Brooklyn pier Sept. 25, with a thousand guests applauding as Sophia Loren shattered a bottle of champagne against the white bow. The ship has a combination observation lounge, dance floor and casino in the forward dome, her most recognizable feature, which offers a view usually reserved for the bridge. A disco is deep inside the ship on the first passenger deck next to the health club, where the sound is isolated from most of the cabins.
Between these extremes is an enclosed sun deck with two pools, indoor and outdoor Jacuzzis and a pizza parlor. In the center of the ship is a three-story atrium with waterfall surrounded by shops, as well as lounges, a nightclub, two theaters, a library, a casino that includes baccarat and roulette, a pastry shop, a piano bar and eight other bars, including one that serves caviar and wine. The ship carries 1,596 passengers, considerably fewer than most ships her size, which allows more room for the full gamut of amenities.
In March Carnival Cruise Lines introduced the 70,367-ton Fantasy, which carries 2,600 passengers; her sister ship, Ecstasy, is due next March. In addition to having a six-deck atrium with glass elevators and constantly changing lighting effects, the Fantasy offers individually controlled air-conditioning and wall safes in her cabins. Though identical in physical layout, the two ships differ in decor and theme.
On Costa Cruise Lines' new CostaMarina, the Tropicana Theater is paneled in mother-of-pearl, the Galaxy nightclub is capped by a glass dome, and huge window walls enclose three decks at the stern.
The new superships will find stiff competition from the Norway, the former France. After a major renovation supervised by the marine architect Tage Wandborg, she emerged this month with two new glass-enclosed decks, a proscenium theater now featuring the Broadway production of "Meet Me in St. Louis," 135 luxury suites and two owner's suites of 760 square feet each, said to be the largest afloat (available at $5,085 to $5,495 a person for a seven-night cruise). At 75,000 tons, the Norway remains the world's largest cruise liner. According to Douglas Falk, executive vice president of marketing for Kloster Cruises, Norwegian Cruise Line's parent company, duplicating the Norway today would cost more than $500 million.

MORE emphasis, too, is being placed on entertainment, with large theaters capable of presenting Broadway musicals and revues, movie theaters with first-run films, late-night discos with light shows, and nightclubs with well-known entertainers. This year, for the first time, there will be a Newport Jazz Festival at Sea, part of Crystal Harmony's inaugural trans-Atlantic sailing on April 1. Crown Cruise Line inaugurates its newest ship, the 15,000-ton, 556-passenger Crown Monarch, next month, and "Sophisticated Ladies" will open its cabaret.
Atriums are perhaps the most striking of the new amenities. Reception areas on the larger ships have been designed as dramatic, sometimes glitzy, central meeting points that recall splashy hotel lobbies. The Nordic Empress, introduced in May by Royal Caribbean Cruises, unveiled an atrium 40 feet across and nine decks high, filled with tropical plants. A split staircase on either side is covered by a skylight, and two glass-enclosed elevators connect with each level.
Ships are offering more options for dining, with live combos and dancing, and indoor-outdoor buffets, usually on the sun deck, as an alternative to the regular dining room. A la carte restaurants, attended by master chefs, provide still more choices, some at an additional charge.
The first ship to start the trend was the Seaward in 1988, with its 82-seat Palm Tree Restaurant high up on the sun deck. On the Crystal Harmony there are two alternative restaurants: the Kyoto, specializing in a variety of Asian cuisines, and the Prego, offering Italian cuisine. Many ships also offer 24-hour room service. A name chef as consultant is almost de rigueur. Paul Bocuse supervises the menu for the Royal Viking Sun's Royal Grill, and Michel Roux is consultant chef for the multilevel dining room on Chandris Celebrity Cruises' new Horizon.
Dining rooms, instead of being placed in the middle of the ship, are now designed to offer views from floor to ceiling windows, and some are set in the front of the ship. Design innovations include split levels or balconies.
Cabins are generally somewhat roomier on the new ships, with windows instead of port holes, particularly in suites and deluxe accommodations. Private balconies, marble bathrooms with tub and shower, color television, video cassette recorders, stocked minibars, generous drawer and closet space and butler and concierge service are among the amenities offered. And although many lines have been reluctant to make the necessary changes, more new ships are at least partially accessible to the handicapped, with low sills, ramps and at least a few wheelchair-accessible cabins and bathrooms.
For the sports enthusiast and health-conscious, the seagoing spa is increasingly available, with health menus and personal exercise programs for an extra cost. There is a range of choices from gyms, saunas, fitness centers, swimming pools, whirlpools, aerobics classes, diving lessons, jogging tracks, skeet shooting, shuffleboard, tennis, golf practice areas and a popular new development, the Golf-Simulator, which by means of electronics allows passengers to "play" famous courses.
On the Norway, the health-club amenities give new dimension to Norwegian Cruise Line's slogan, "Athlete's Fleet": there are a 4,000-square-foot health and fitness center with floor-to-ceiling windows, a new 6,000-square-foot Roman spa with computer-controlled hydrotherapy baths and a jogging and walking track that encircles the 1,035-foot ship.
Not to be left out, smaller luxury-oriented ships are entering the amenities wars. For example, Seabourn Cruise Line's ships have some of the most attractive suites. They also have an observatory for stargazing, a glass-bottom port for underwater viewing and a sports platform with a steel-net-protected saltwater swimming pool for use in small coves and inlets. Even the somewhat spartan Nile River boats have been upgraded, with Swan Hellenic's new Nile Monarch offering all outside, air-conditioned accommodations with television, refrigerator, minibar, shower or bath, and a bar and pool on the partly covered sun deck. The new Renaissance Cruises' ships, numbered I to V (with more on the way), are notable for their use of hardwood paneling and brass trim in the cabins, all of which have sitting room, bedroom and marble bath with teakwood vanity. The ships carry only 100 to 114 passengers, but each has a pool, a library and a piano bar.
Reflecting the influence of the environmental movement, Salen Lindblad's Frontier Spirit, which next month will become the first expedition cruise ship to enter service in 16 years, is one of a new breed designed to leave areas unpolluted.
Despite a general flattening of American tourism, cruise operators are optimistic for 1991. The feeling is that people have become accustomed to taking an annual vacation no matter how bad the economic outlook, and those who have sailed previously are likely to continue doing so, even if it means taking a shorter cruise. The three- and four-night market is one of the fastest growing segments of the cruise industry. The larger ships, those carrying 2,000 or more passengers, are entering that market, and at least one, the Fantasy, is sailing at more than 100 percent capacity, which means that some cabins are carrying three or more passengers. While the overall growth rate may start to turn flat next year, the industry expects that when the figures are in for this year 3.7 million people will have taken a cruise. That will be an increase of 400,000 over 1989 and 525,000 over 1988, according to the Cruise Lines International Association.
The Persian Gulf crisis came at a time when the Mediterranean cruise season was drawing to a close, and there were not large numbers of cancellations. Ships operating in the area are maintaining their published schedules and taking a wait-and-see attitude, but the increase in oil prices raises the specter of possible fuel surcharges.
This, coupled with the need to fill the ships will make an interesting if naervous beginning for 1991.

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Still Strangers: My New Neighbors Have Exotic Customs

BYLINE: By MARCIA BYALICK

 BODY:
WHEN my husband and I left Brooklyn and moved to the suburbs 17 years ago to buy a house, to own a backyard and to raise a family, I remember worrying about whether my children would suffer from growing up in such a homogeneous environment. There was no one around who looked or spoke or dressed any differently than we did.
Even though the children I grew up with in my East Flatbush neighborhood had remarkably similar backgrounds, I was always aware that a bus ride away there existed the colors and accents and economic realities of a larger world. We traveled the subways and were often exposed to the melting pot that was New York City. But I feared my children would miss the excitement, the wonder, the spiciness that comes with diversity. 
 I need not have worried. Slowly, over the years, my neighborhood has absorbed the largest Asian population on Long Island, including a sizable percentage of families of Korean, Chinese, Indian and Persian backgrounds. And while the lessons learned are quite different from the fairy-tale sharing of customs and traditions I might have wished for, they are nevertheless valuable additions to life experience.
Asian families now live in 2 of the 10 houses that surrounded mine . I grew up defining a neighbor as someone you borrowed ketchup from, shared leftover birthday cake with, and held an extra key for in case they lost theirs. I am embarrassed to admit I have never even introduced myself to these new families. I guiltily wonder if the situation were reversed and I moved to where they came from whether they would be more hospitable.
But the language barrier, the fact that we never run into one another and a hectic working-mother style of life that allows me a 10-minute phone call to my sister on a good day, puts being a warm welcoming neighbor on my permanent list of things I should try harder to accomplish.
As the names in each grade began to change, so did the roster of the school newspaper, the orchestra, the math and science honor programs and the top 5 percent of the graduating class. In addition to these achievements, I admired the great haircuts and cutting edge of fashion sense I noticed on the Asian children when I drove my kids to school.
And I wondered why my daughters never invited Myung, Indu, Manish or Haejin home. "You don't understand," they say. "We're friendly in school. But out of school, it's just different. They stay to themselves, work with their parents and go to Korean or Japanese or Chinese school on the weekends. We like each other fine. We're just different."
My new neighbors are always out of sight. Just as their children seem to disappear when they are not in school, except for those at the library, their parents seem to do no more than eat and sleep at home. I never meet them in the supermarket, at a restaurant in the cleaners.
 They are still tied to their "old neighborhood," and like all new minorities resist assimilation by clustering together in self-enforced ghettos. Many of the homes house three generations, with grandma fulfilling the role of the family's "wife." She walks the young children to school, does the laundry and makes dinner. Rarely does she speak any English. Although her life may be comfortable in the beautiful home that the 100-hour workweek her children put in affords, I wonder how she handles the alienation and the loneliness. And I wonder how she feels seeing her grandchildren wearing Bart Simpson T-shirts and listening to heavy-metal music.
Of course, not every Asian child plays the violin and wins Westinghouse Scholarships. I have noticed the price paid by some who are less accomplished, who need more supervision. Years ago my daughter told me of the existence of the O.D.S., the Oriental Domination Society, a gangthat cut classes, smoked in the courtyard and encouraged the spread of scary myths about themselves.
This last year the neighborhood was shocked by the brutal murder of a Korean boy and the vicious stabbing of his sister by a 17-year-old who gave as his motive that he was spoken to disrespectfully. It was the knowledge we gleaned from the press of this tragedy that gave those of us who live down the block and around the corner our first opportunity to reach out and behave like neighbors.
 It's going to take a while before any "melting" goes on in the pot that makes up my community. I admire my new neighbors for their courage. I can't imagine what it must be like for them negotiating the frantic frustrating Long Island Expressway, confronting a new alphabet and trying to keep tradition intact while at the same time assimilating into a wildly different culture. I hope that one day life slows down just a bit for all of us, so that the similarities between us become as obvious -- and praiseworthy -- as our differences.

HEADLINE: Abandonment

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 The real estate industry seems to have the same answer -- higher rents -- for New York's housing problems no matter what the question is. Now that the 1980's real estate boom is over, landlord groups are threatening building abandonment because of rising operating costs. ("Will Landlords Desert Their Buildings Again?", The New York Times Week in Review, Sept. 30.)
While it is true that some costs have risen recently, New York City's tenants have been much harder hit by the slowdown in the local economy. Yet we don't see any articles about tenants refusing to meet their already inflated rent bills.
Operating cost increases in the 1980's were extremely limited, interest rates fell and the local economy boomed. During all this time, the city's Rent Guidelines Board granted rent increases far in excess of the amount that would have been necessary to compensate landlords for increased operating costs, and widespread major capital improvements allowed enormous jumps in rent. These factors resulted in massive increases in real estate values, which were quickly siphoned off through sales, refinanceing and co-op conversion.
New York's lower- and middle-income tenants have been subsidizing landlords for years enabling some of them to reach the Forbes 400 list of wealthiest Americans. It's about time that landlords put some of this wealth back into the buildings which have made them rich and famous.
 
MORT COHEN
Manhattan
 
The writer is president of the 345 Riverside Drive Tenants Association.

HEADLINE: Apartments Designed For Pragmatic Goals Economics Holds Key to Esthetics

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
On East 72d Street a new apartment tower of red brick, bristling with balconies, is nearing completion. It is ringed by decorative courses, with an amply arched entrance at the base, and the four great lanterns at its top are soon to be illuminated, vaguely recalling the residential skyscrapers of the early 20th century.
Thirty-three blocks to the south, work is about to begin on a new apartment tower of green glass, with no balconies at all. Sleekly devoid of ornamentation, it will have a sheer curtain wall and a flat top that repudiate the architectural trend of post-modern historicizing. 
 These buildings' differences and similarities illuminate the way in which the marketplace, the government and the developer shape an apartment building. And what makes the contrast between them instructive is that both were designed by the 87-year-old family firm of Emery Roth & Sons.
Beginning in 1903 with the Hotel Belleclaire, at Broadway and 77th Street, the Roth firm produced chunky red-brick flats, encrusted in decoration; then limestone and buff-brick buildings in Renaissance Revival and Art Deco styles during the 20's and 30's (epitomized by the San Remo on Central Park West, between 74th and 75th Streets); bulky, boxy, white-brick piles in the 50's (exemplified by 215 East 68th Street, at Second Avenue) and the freestanding apartment skyscrapers that began to rise in the 60's.
Now Roth has designed the red-brick Oxford at 422 East 72d Street, near York Avenue, a 46-story tower with 204 condominium units. It is being built by Burton P. Resnick of Jack Resnick & Sons. And Roth also is designing the green-glass tower, St. James's Plaza, at 240 East 39th Street, near Second Avenue, with 250 condominium units. It is being developed by Peter deSavary and Michael Sarch.
If there has been a uniting principle behind these works, it is economic -- not esthetic.
The Roth family has always been candid on this point, to judge from an Emery Roth axiom quoted in "Mansions in the Clouds," Steven Ruttenbaum's 1986 book on the architect:
"The primary purpose of building apartment houses is to create the best possible return on the investment. A building that does not pay is poor architecture, no matter how interesting the design, costly the construction or clever the layout."
Today, Emery's grandson, Richard Roth Jr., says: "There is no way a developer will not want to build what he's entitled to. What he's paying for the land is based on the maximum F.A.R. he can build."
A floor-area ratio for an apartment building might range as high as 12-to-1 in some areas of Manhattan. That means, for example, that a 20,000-square-foot lot can contain a building with 240,000 square feet of space. The mass of the building, however, can be arranged very differently. If the structure covers 80 percent of the lot (16,000 square feet), it could have 15 floors. If it covers 40 percent of the lot (8,000 square feet), it could have 30 floors.
Richard Roth designed New York's "first sheer tower residence," as the 35-story Tower East apartment building advertised itself in 1962. The site takes up a full blockfront on Third Avenue, between 71st and 72d Streets, but above a one-story commercial base, the tower occupies only 25 percent of the lot area.
The tendency in zoning today is to discourage that tower-in-a-plaza approach and encourage lower, bulkier structures that are meant to reinforce the existing physical context of a neighborhood. Nonetheless, Mr. Roth said, tall towers have adherents.
"View seems to be an important sales point," he said. "Towers are popular and seem to sell to a particular group of people."
The Oxford reflects the older tower-in-a-plaza approach, particularly in the asymmetrical front it presents to 72d Street. The eastern part of the tower comes almost to the lot line but the western part is set back behind a deep plaza. That open space generated part of the building bonus that allowed the Oxford to rise as high as it does.
The plaza bonus is available in an R-10 zoning district, which applies to the north half of the lot on which the Oxford was built. The southern half of the lot is within a lower-density R-8 district and that portion of the building facing 71st Street is about half as high as the 72d Street side.
Had the Oxford's overall bulk been evenly distributed across the two zoning districts, the building would have had only 20 to 22 stories. But such a structure would have "overburdened" the R-8 zone and "underburdened" the R-10, Mr. Roth said. "Zoning really guided the tall tower," he said.
As city planners have shaped exteriors, the City Council has shaped interiors -- particularly with Local Law 58 of 1987, which requires that new residential construction be accessible to physically handicapped persons. "Kitchens are bigger today because of handicapped requirements," Mr. Roth said.
KITCHENS are also assuming a bigger role in people's lives. "Windowed kitchens are a big selling point," Mr. Roth said. "People are eating in more, doing more entertaining at home. I think entertainment space in an apartment is very important. There are large living rooms and smaller bedrooms."
Closets, however, have not been the same since the 50's. "The minute the bi-fold door was invented, closets got smaller," Mr. Roth said. "The walk-in closet disappeared."
Finishes in apartments, he said, are generally getting "cheaper and cheaper," in part because of the expectation that they will not be retained by purchasers. "Twenty to 30 percent in most buildings will come in and change things radically," Mr. Roth said. "You may offer them marble floors for the foyer or bathrooms, but most people will generally bring in their own marble, gut them and start over."
Within the last decade, Mr. Roth said, a practice has emerged in which layouts are designed to be different, with larger apartments on the upper floors, rather than being duplicated throughout a structure.
"At the top of buildings," he said, "apartments get to be more expensive. Therefore, the areas should be bigger. To pay more, you should get more, besides the views." The strategy seems to be attracting buyers. "The first apartments to go are at the top of the scale and at the bottom," Mr. Roth said.
One of the most obvious features -- the balcony -- is regarded as an asset by some builders, a liability by others. Take the case of Roth's two latest towers.
"Burt Resnick presses our architects for the maximum amount of outdoor space possible," said Dennis P. Brady, vice president of the Resnick concern, builders of the Oxford. "It's something people like. We feel it's a valuable asset and, if it were up to us, every apartment would have one."
But the lawyer for the developers of St. James's Plaza, Peter Siviglia, said: "We think they detract from the elegance of the structure, especially here, where you have a tall, slender, graceful building. It's a combination of the air quality in Manhattan and the fact that balconies -- of necessity -- aren't that large, so they aren't that functional."
Balconies are not the only things separating St. James's Plaza and the Oxford, which have utterly different facades.
"A tall, elegant curtain-wall building in this location is extremely attractive," Mr. Siviglia said. "We're going to be 56 stories high. A curtain wall will add a sense of grace and lightness to something that tall, as opposed to a brick building."
But bricks were called for at the Oxford. "This is a classic New York brick building," Mr. Roth said. "It is more traditional because Resnick is a more traditional builder." At the urging of the Roth office, Resnick also added bands of cast-stone decorative courses under the window sills. "You do want to give a building some distinguishing features," Mr. Brady said.
St. James's Plaza, which has a series of setbacks, is flat-topped. But the Oxford culminates in a bulkhead topped by four large lanterns at each corner that are soon to be illuminated. "We have been very interested in doing something with the top of the building," Mr. Brady said. "Maybe it's back to 'Mansions in the Clouds.' It's something that should be somewhat distinctive. I would hope for people to say: 'Oh, the Oxford. That's the one with the beautiful lights on top.' "
Prices at the Oxford begin at $250,000 for the least expensive studio apartment, with one-bedroom units beginning at $287,000 and two-bedroom units at $395,000. The developers of St. James's Plaza are not yet ready to make their price list public, Mr. Siviglia said.
No one would mistake the Oxford for the beacon-topped San Remo, but it does have more flourishes than most of Roth's postwar buildings, a number of which were built for the family development concern once led by Samuel Rudin and now headed by his sons, Jack and Lewis.
AMONG nearly two dozen structures designed by the Roth office for the Rudins were such archetypal, white-brick apartments houses as 215 East 68th Street, which looks as antiseptic as a hospital pavilion.
Although white brick is long out of fashion, Jack Rudin still rises to its defense, in explaining why it was preferred at the time.
"White brick was a glazed brick, the most expensive brick around," he said. "Red brick was cheaper. White brick was brighter, more reflective, more attractive. Red brick looked like a housing project." And Mr. Roth said, "It's not white brick that's the devil, it's the lack of articulation or decoration."
Besides that, Mr. Rudin added, a discussion of facades misses the point of Roth's workings. "They believe in designing buildings from the inside out," the developer said. "Usability comes first. Layout is everything. That is what's going to get leases renewed in the future. That is the product."
As for esthetics, Mr. Rudin said, the idea has always been "keeping it simple," to help hold down both construction and maintenance costs. "We are manufacturers of apartment buildings," he said. "We have to price apartments so they will rent. What good is having an architectural monument that doesn't rent?"

SECTION: Section 10; Page 7; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: Perspective: Zoning;
Controlling Scale Near Historic Districts

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
THERE is an uncomfortable relationship between New York City's zoning law and its historic districts. The shape and scale of the building that zoning permits is frequently considered inappropriate to the already-built environment that the district seeks to preserve and enhance.
The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission can insist on a satisfactory design within the district -- often in lengthy and contentious negotiations -- but it is powerless to encourage "sympathetic" buildings outside the districts. Jarringly contrasting specimens of new construction have emerged just outside some historic districts. 
 Last week the Municipal Art Society, whose president, Kent Barwick, is a former chairman of the landmarks agency, came forth with a far-ranging zoning proposal designed to correct these presumed deficiencies. The proposals appear in a study called "Zoning and Historic Districts," prepared for the Planning Center of the Municipal Art Society by the planning firm of Abeles Phillips Preiss & Shapiro.
The cover of the report carries a photograph of the immense tower that Citicorp has built in the downtown commercial center of Long Island City, juxtaposed in the background with the old stone-stooped town houses of the Hunters Point Historic District in the foreground.
The body of the report mentions the straight-tower Madison Green condominium on Broadway just south of Madison Square, near the Ladies Mile Historic District, and One Pierrepont Plaza, the office building that Morgan Stanley & Company, the Wall Street investment house, built on land acquired from the city on the border of the Brooklyn Heights historic district, as examples of what it considers inappropriate structures near historic districts.
Mr. Barwick described the report as a discussion paper rather than a policy statement by the society. It is an outgrowth of the Historic City Committee's 1989 report, "New York: the Historic City," and it breaks new ground in its ideas on the substance and process of rezoning to strengthen historic-district preservation by forcing new development to conform to shapes and sizes of the past.
The zoning proposals are predicated on furthering the fairly one-dimensional goal of design conformity to past forms. The report advocates, for example, the mapping of "contextual" zones within and around historic districts, in what are described as transition areas. The contextual zones, already mapped in many of the city's residential locations, would be extended to manufacturing districts and other areas where office buildings and commercial facilities can be built.
The report suggests the elimination of plazas, arcades and urban open-space bonuses in historic districts. It proposes the adaptation of zoning within districts to the already-built style. It would introduce absolute height controls into historic districts, a direct approach that New York City zoning so far has avoided. The concept would probably render unbuildable various projects long in planning, among them the Milstein Properties office building on the border of the South Street Seaport Historic District.
The study also calls for institutionalizing the working relationship between the landmarks agency and the Department of City Planning. Staff officials should meet regularly to discuss the zoning requirements of the districts, the report says.
IN an interview, John R. Fawcett, the project manager of the study, and Brian Kintish, the project manager for Abeles Phillips, elaborated on the recommendations. The original director of the study, Carol Clark, has left the Municipal Art Society to become assistant executive director for intergovernmental relations in the Department of City Planning.
"The zoning in historic districts is not suited to what realistically can be built there," said Mr. Kintish. "What the zoning allows is usually nothing that the Landmarks Commission would or should approve."
Around a historic district such as Ladies Mile west of Madison Square Park in Manhattan, for example, they advocate a contextual zone that would encourage buildings to rise about eight stories from the streetline and then step back sharply through the use of both a front and rear sky-exposure plane. The sky-exposure plane determines the sunlight and shadow that a building allows to reach the street. It is used as a control on the shape and size of buildings.
Critics say current formulas sometimes lead to excessive open-space requirements, and consequently excessive building height to achieve permissible floor area. Others point out that severe height limitations would indirectly impose severe use limitations as well, and thus restrict redevelopment of the land.
A specific example of a building near a historic district that was shaped by an excessive open-space requirement, the planners say, is the Memphis, a 20-story 80-unit apartment house built in the 80's at 140 Charles Street, west of the Greenwich Village Historic District.
Its architect, Bernard Rothzeid, agreed that he would have preferred a more compatible 12-story building, but he said the above-ground open-space requirements of the zoning law at the time forbade it. "Many people gnashed their teeth at what we built," he said, "but surprisingly it's not that bad."
In the city's Planning Department it is pointed out that under housing quality zoning adopted since the Memphis was built the open-space requirements could be waived.
Whether Citicorp Center in Long Island City or the Morgan Stanley building in Brooklyn Heights would have gone forward at all under contextual zoning requirements proposed in the study is questionable. Both were projects widely hailed as keeping thousands of office jobs in New York City.
But the Planning Center's study is not concerned with economic or locational planning goals. It implies a willingness to mandate flat, bulky building shapes in central commercial districts in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens for the first time, possibly reducing redevelopment opportunities by narrowing flexibility by developers.
An example of this effort occurred last year, when the City Planning Department itself proposed a contextual C6-1A zones adjacent to the Brooklyn Heights Historic District. Mr. Kintish was project director for the study in the Brooklyn office of the Planning Department.
The land is along Court Street from Atlantic Avenue to Livingston Street, potentially a future office-development location. Currently it is a general-purpose commercial district zoned C6-1, allowing a maximum floor-area ratio, or F.A.R., of six.
The Planning Commission adopted the recommendation. But Community Board 2, the Brooklyn Heights Association and Borough President Howard Golden opposed it in the Board of Estimate and it was withdrawn.
The Borough President's office said that Mr. Golden felt that the zone would be detrimental to new office or commercial development. With an extreme height limitation, multiplex movie theaters might be buildable, and this might emerge on Court Street in any event. In areas where it is planning policy to encourage headquarters-oriented office growth and the job growth that goes with it, developers will look for height in new buildings to justify land costs. The contextual low-rise office building in a high-land-cost location in Manhattan is not a probable new-building form. Accordingly, transitional zones around such actual or potential historic districts as Ladies Mile, SoHo or NoHo would in effect restrict redevelopment opportunities.
There are currently no contextual zones in locations that have been developed with office buildings, city planners said. Nor are they prepared to criticize a building such as One Pierrepont Plaza, which many consider remarkably contextual for a high-density building and a successful design compromise between the residential and commercial character of the location.
In any event, the Municipal Art Society study is one of many serious zoning proposals that can be expected in the months to come. Others most likely will be community-sponsored, with help from the newly expanded planning offices of the Borough Presidents. Each has a specific agenda rather than a balanced and comprehensive planning objective.
And while there is an argument for compatibility of building types, there is also an argument for preserving flexibility is design so that New York City can remain competitive for both commercial and residential occupancy. Balancing these objectives is the task of the City Planning Commission.

HEADLINE: Focus: Corporate Transfers;
The Struggle to Sell Employees' Houses

BYLINE: By MAUREEN MILFORD

DATELINE: WILMINGTON , DEL.

 BODY:
IT'S tough enough to have one house to sell these days. But America's largest companies are ending up with hundreds, as the stagnant real-estate market swells their inventories of houses they buy from employees they are relocating.
E. I. du Pont de Nemours and Company, , which moves 4,000 employees a year, has watched its inventories double in Delaware and Pennsylvania in the last year, to 160 houses. To sell those houses without driving prices down further, Du Pont has adopted a program of incentives to lure home buyers, including low-interest mortgages and a chance to win prizes just by looking at a house. 
 Buyer incentives and other ways of coping with the soft real estate market were a major topic at the fall meeting of the Employee Relocation Council held last week in Los Angeles.
"Dealing with high inventories certainly is a concern," said Anita Brienza, communications director with the thousand-member relocation council.
Du Pont is not alone. Eastman Kodak Company has also seen its stockpile in of houses in the Rochester area double, and its national inventory increase by 10 to 20 percent. And at ICI Americas, the United States arm of the international chemical giant, the company, which is based here, is now carrying 58 houses, compared with half that number a year ago.
Still, the sluggish real estate market has not cut down on the number of corporate transfers, according to Ms. Brienza, who said that some companies move more than a thousand employees each year.
Transfers this year are at about last year's level, she said, although 1989's activity was down somewhat from a peak the year before.
"Companies view it as a cost of doing business," Ms. Brienza said. "It's worth it to them to get their first choice on the job. They're making an investment in employees."
The cost of relocation can be large, averaging $50,000 for each employee moved. Steven E. Rogers, supervisor of corporation relocation for Du Pont, which has its headquarters here, said that cost is "certainly" a concern." But Du Pont is in the business to make sure the right people are in the right jobs," he said.
The chemical company's program of buying houses from employees it was relocating began in the recession of 1974, when the market was also sluggish. Kodak began its program in the mid-60's. According to the Relocation Council, 84 percent of the council's members now either buy an employee's house during a transfer or assign it to a relocation company like Prudential Relocation Management of White Plains, N.Y., up from from 48 percent in 1974.
"We want to take that worry off the employees, because worry takes away from productivity," said Mr. Rogers. "You can't put a value on it, but we believe it makes a difference for the company and the employees."
Under most programs the company offers to buy a house for the average of two or three appraisals. Many programs allow the employee a certain period, generally 60 days, to sell the house independently or with a broker. Some companies discourage employees from trying to market the house themselves.
"WE don't want them improperly marketing the property," said Thomas B. McLaughlin, assistant manager for finance and real estate for ICI Americas.
Corporate real estate managers say that in the current unstable market they are having difficulty getting employees to accept appraisals of their house as accurate. Similarly, the relocation council says that assessments are a key concern of employees today as well.
"They think the appraisals are low ball," said Warren Dungee, property manager for Du Pont.
For that reason, some companies tell employees that if they find a buyer at a better price themselves or through a broker, the company will step in and handle complications of the closing once a contract is signed.
COMPANIES also offer loss protection plans that reimburse employees for capital improvements they have made to their properties. Under some programs, the company will pay 100 percent of the cost of major additions, and 50 percent of luxury improvements, like swimming pools.
Once a house becomes the property of a company, the carrying costs can be substantial -- 1 or 2 percent of its price a month, by the industry's rule of thumb. This includes interest charges, taxes, maintenance and repairs. Nearly all the companies make whatever repairs are needed to put the house in move-in condition.
While houses Du Pont owns in Louisiana, Oklahoma and other oil-patch states are beginning to move after a few rough years, the properties it and other companies are holding in the Northeast are becoming harder to sell.
"We're taking a major loss in Rochester," said Mee Wing, director of corporate relocation for Kodak. "The Northeast is bad."
For this reason, companies are starting to offer incentives to buyers. The Du Pont company recently announced a special program to sell its stockpile of homes in Delaware and Pennsylvania. The purpose of the incentive program, the company says, is to sell homes without bringing prices down throughout the community.
Buyers of a Du Pont home in Pennsylvania and Delaware will be eligible for below-market financing through a mortgage company with which Du Pont has made a special arrangement.
Anyone who even tours a Du Pont home is eligible for a drawing for a free trip to Cancun, Mexico, and real estate agents who show a corporate listing will have their names in a drawing for a $10,000 prize.
While some homeowners have complained that this use of the financial muscle of a Fortune 500 company leaves them at a disadvantage, real estate agents praise such programs as the only way to keep a community's price structure from tumbling.
In any case, the incentives are working: Du Pont has sold a house a day since the program was announced earlier this month.
"It's put people in the looking mode," said Daniel B. Henderson, director of corporate relocation with Gilpin, Van Trump & Montgomery Inc., a real estate agency in Wilmington.
Du Pont first tried the incentives program in Hobbs, N.M., where Conoco, the company's oil subsidiary, has an operation. Since it was begun in the early summer, 45 of the company's 65 homes in Hobbs have been sold, most within two months, said Anneta Cheney, associate broker with Newman & Company in Hobbs.
The Hobbs real estate market, which fluctuates with the oil-based local economy, has been depressed since 1982. Prices were "devastated" when many of the oil companies pulled out back then, Mrs. Cheney said.
Many of the companies simply told their employees to "slash prices," she said, with the result that values throughout the area went down.
Incentives are a much more community-minded approach, she said.
"Activity breeds activity," Mrs. Cheney said, adding that home shoppers "might start out by looking at a corporate listing and end up buying a house with no special financing."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: 875 Third Avenue;
No Longer That 'Building Behind the Liquor Store'

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
TO say that it has taken a very long time to complete 875 Third Avenue may be understating the matter a bit.
As Madison Equities began assembling the development site, between 52d and 53d Streets, Lyndon B. Johnson was in the White House, a five-room apartment in the Imperial House on East 69th Street rented for $675, Rogers Peet and De Pinna were selling on Fifth Avenue and a new musical called "Hair" was playing on Broadway. Subway riders were paying 20 cents and looking forward to a new Second Avenue line. 
 Today, in a different world, steps are finally being taken to finish 875 Third Avenue. Within the past few weeks bulldozers have cleared away the last of four small tenements at the southeast corner of 53d Street. On that site is to be built an open-air, granite-paved plaza, flanked by a one-story extension of an existing cafe, including outdoor seating, and by a planting area, pergola and new entrance to the IND subway station.
Robert Gladstone, a partner in the family-run Madison Equities concern, said he expects the plaza to be open in 1991, meaning that 875 Third Avenue will have taken 24 years from beginning to end.
The heart of the project, a 29-story office tower with 667,000 square feet, was built eight years ago. Major tenants include Grey Entertainment and Media, and the law firms of Debevoise & Plimpton, Fish & Neave and Sidley & Austin.
"We have never had a vacancy in the building except for 10,000 square feet for two months," Mr. Gladstone said. "Tenants in the building have grown, renewed their leases and are very happy."
But the overall development of the site has long been held up by Ryan's liquor store at 873 Third Avenue, whose proprietor made it plain that he would settle for nothing less than a small fortune -- more than $20 million, as Mr. Gladstone recalled it -- to vacate the building before the lease ran out in 1992.
Rather than pay the price, Madison Equities decided in 1980 to proceed with a tower that would wrap around No. 873 and its three companions. The Chicago office of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill designed one of the more unusual office buildings in New York: a 14-sided structure whose long axis is turned at a 45-degree angle to the avenue.
That angle created a 6,400-square-foot notch to accommodate the little cluster of tenements. As originally planned, they were eventually to be replaced by a two-story, 11,000-square-foot, glass-enclosed shopping pavilion, joined to the concourse at the base of the new tower. "We thought Third Avenue would develop as a great retail thoroughfare," Mr. Gladstone said.
After the tower was finished, the shabby and diminutive tenements looked more conspicuous than ever. Although Ryan's was not quite in the league of celebrated holdouts like P. J. Clarke's saloon at Third Avenue and 55th Street, Mr. Gladstone said his family "heard a lot of jokes about how we owned the building behind the liquor store."
"We finally gave them cash in 1988," he said. At that time, the cost of the buyout had shrunk to $3 million.
By then, it was also clear that Third Avenue's retail potential was limited, so Madison Equities chose instead to build a plaza, designed by David Kenneth Specter of Manhattan. The developers are not losing rentable area by sacrificing the pavilion. Instead, space on the sixth floor that was to have been used for the pavilion's cooling equipment will be given over to commercial tenancy.
Was it worth the wait? "You've got to think in the long term," Mr. Gladstone said. "And a great entrance has long-term value."
Almost everything about 875 Third Avenue requires a long-term perspective. It was in late 1967 that Mr. Gladstone's parents, Lucille and Kenneth, and their partner, Edwin J. Glickman, began assembling parcels on the block between Third and Second Avenues, 52d and 53d Streets. They had just built the 45-story Excelsior, at 57th Street and Second Avenue, which was then the tallest apartment building in New York.
WHAT they had in mind for their next venture were cooperative apartment towers on both avenues, one of them 50 stories tall. Between them were to be four-story, one-family town houses, priced up to $500,000. The project would have increased the residential density on the block sixfold.
By 1971 they controlled about half the block. But resistance was growing. The opposition was led by the East 50's Association, which The New York Times described as a "group of newly militant residents hitherto dedicated mainly to tree-planting."
"Who is Mr. Glickman to decide what makes a better community?" demanded Marion Reider, president of the association. Residents complained of harassment, misrepresentation and secrecy on the part of site assemblers hired by Madison Equities. They also assailed the developers for placing drug addicts in vacant apartments. Mr. Gladstone said the drug abusers were pregnant, unwed women under the supervision of a social worker. Their placement on the block, he said, was part of his family's ongoing charitable work for Odyssey House.
Neighbors also worried that the Third Avenue site would be used for commercial development, threatening the area's residential quality. In response, Mr. Glickman said in 1971, "Anybody who proposed another office high-rise on Third Avenue now should have his head examined."
As efforts to assemble and empty the block bogged down in the mid-70's, so did the economy. And in 1976, with the city in the middle of a fiscal crisis, Mr. Glickman announced that "we've put the block development plan on the shelf, so to speak."
"By the end of the 1970's, the market changed precipitously to office buildings, which is what my preference is," Mr. Gladstone said. Ground was broken in 1980.
A year later, Madison Equities reached an agreement with the city: the developers would build a retail arcade on the mezzanine level of the 53d Street subway station, together with new entrances to the station. In exchange, they would be allowed a bonus of 90,000 square feet in the office building.
The developers were required to keep certain space vacant in the tower until they had either completed the subway project or demonstrated that they had tried to buy out the lease holders in the tenements, which stood above and impeded the subway improvement project.
City officials contended that the 28th and 29th floors constituted the space that was to be withheld. But the Gladstones believed they had more leeway to choose, and kept the third, fourth and fifth floors off the market. When it came to light in 1983 that the top two floors had been rented, a legal battle began.
"THIS is a classic case of a developer, once he gets approval for his plans, looking to get out of his agreements," said Philip Hess, then counsel to the Planning Commission chairman. "If the city can't prevail in a situation like this, you have to believe it's open season. If that's the way developers are treating promises made to the city, I don't think we have a workable system."
"I think I'm being horsed around with," Mr. Gladstone said at the time. "We always thought we were doing everything in cooperation with the city. We are providing more amenities than anyone else I know about. And we have already completed everything except the subway, which we're working on. That's what makes this ridiculous."
The matter was settled in December 1983, when the developers agreed to pay the city $750,000 in damages and formally apologize.
Mr. Gladstone prefers now to emphasize cooperation instead of contention, saying that city planners had been "very helpful" in the final redesign of the project.
Mrs. Reider, who stays active in community affairs, said she still wishes the Gladstones had built an apartment building rather than an office tower. But she also said: "I think they've been good neighbors at 875 to the community. I think we find it an asset having the stores there. It's a nice building and I think they try very hard to maintain it."
