HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Entrepreneurs Offer an Answer

BYLINE: By RONALD S. COOPER; Ronald S. Cooper is managing partner of the Long Island office of Ernst & Young, the Big Six accounting firm.

 BODY:
IN the late 80's, when many people on Long Island were enjoying the luxurious life, we were lulled into a false sense of security. The seeds of our current problems were all there.
The Shoreham debacle was occurring, with our politicians' jumping on the bandwagon of hysteria, and our business leaders did not take enough initiatives to stem the rising ride. In my opinion, the closing of Shoreham will one day be marked as the single worst event that affected the Island's economy. 
 Our real-estate values climbed at a dizzy pace, closing out many of our sons and daughters from returning to Long Island and making it extremely difficult to attract employees. Manufacturers found it increasingly difficult to maintain their labor force, and many operations moved out of state or offshore.
Affordable housing became a buzzword, and indeed a number of initiatives were started. But it became apparent that such initiatives, while important, could not readily solve the issue. We had difficult transportation issues, and taxes were increasing.
Through it all, I remained relatively optimistic. After all was said, we were still one of the most affluent areas in the country. Although I believed our economy had peaked, it did not appear to me that we were in an all-out recession.
Indeed, I saw a number of opportunities for Long Island, with our high-tech base and the entrepreneurial spirit that seems pervasive.
We now have focused on the issues and, whether we like it or not, they must be addressed. And we are beginning. In the private sector, organizations like the Long Island Association and the Long Island Forum for Technology have taken leadership roles, not only in attacking issues but also in suggesting solutions. Our politicians have awakened to the facts of the day and are striving to provide initiatives. I applaud them all, but there is a tremendous amount of work ahead.
The negativism that we have become used to will continue in the short term. Long Islanders are beginning to hurt. Newspapers have reported that foreclosures on Island homes have doubled since last year, and there are a number of developers in serious trouble. Banks are pulling back because of large loan losses, principally in real estate.
Retailers are feeling the pinch because consumers are afraid to spend. Companies continue to explore leaving Long Island. The New York City economy, to which we are tied in many ways, is on the decline, with little prospect for immediate improvement.
All of this erodes our tax base, making it more difficult for our governments to provide services and, on top of that, to continue to offer economic incentives for companies to stay or be attracted to the Island. Law firms are beginning to set up or to enlarge their insolvency practices. The talk has turned from, "I wish I didn't have to read about all our problems," to, "We are in deep trouble and we are not going to get out of it for a number of years."
The awareness of our problems is only the beginning. We must use initiatives in a unified way. And it is the business community that must lead. We must realize that we are a region in change, and we have to quicken the pace of the change.
I believe that our future lies in turning Long Island into a high-tech think tank. We have the talent, we have a good base of high-tech companies and we have the research sites.
Initiatives have already begun. As an example, biotechnology has become a buzzword. The Association for Commerce and Industry has begun an initiative with the new Biotech Association.
Considering all the resources on the Island, I believe that biotechnology companies will help boost our economy. But it is not the key, nor is it the single most important ingredient to return to past successes.
I believe that the key will be to nurture the entrepreneurial spirit that has brought us our past successes. We must formulate a program that attracts and retains entrepreneurs with the vision to turn small companies into large companies.
My accounting firm recently conducted its Entrepreneur of the Year program. We visited more than 75 companies, and I can report that the entrepreneurial spirit is alive and well on Long Island. They were basically not manufacturing companies, but their entrepreneurs have either created new ideas, breathed life into old companies or found a market niche that could be exploited. They are not leaving Long Island.
While they understand the issues, they uniformly are anxious to stay. And their ranks number in the hundreds, if not the thousands. They are the future of Long Island.
Whether they are biotechnology companies, computer-software companies, financial-service companies, retailers or plain nuts-and-bolts companies, they are here will be the backbone of the economy for many years.
I have a theory that everything is cyclical. I look at Long Island like a forest fire. In a fire, old trees burn and new seedlings are given life. Over the years, the forest is rejuvenated.
That is what will happen to Long Island. New companies will be born, companies like Computer Associates, which started not that many years ago and is now a giant of its industry.
People with the entrepreneurial spirit working at declining large companies will leave them to start their own. Other forces will foster their development.
Real-estate values will decline to the point where they become affordable to the people we are trying to attract. Our politicians will streamline government because they will have to reduce taxes or else find re-election difficult. We will support initiatives like the Calverton airport, and perhaps one day we will travel on an eight-lane Long Island Expressway.
Certainly focusing attention on these budding companies helps to provide an optimistic feeling. While I think we have enough business groups, we must allow initiatives of organizations to foster growth in industries like biotechnology. Local governments must strengthen the initiatives already started to attact young companies and to foster entrepreneurs who are already here.
Entrepreneurs are capital hungry. It would be wonderful if Long Island, through a partnership of the corporate, banking and public sectors, could set up an Entrepreneur Superfund. This fund could recycle capital to entrepreneurs and serve as an important hook to attract entrepreneurs. I know this concept has many pitfalls, but we must think in terms of new thoughts and innovations.
I continue to remain optimistic about Long Island, but not in the very near term. We have been traveling along the economic highway at 100 miles an hour; we are now doing 70. That is not so bad, but the reduction in speed is apparent and troubling. I believe that, if we all pull together, the cycle will return us to being the state's economic engine.

HEADLINE: Proposal on Ballot Backed for L.I.

 BODY:
There are few who would argue that one of the most important issues to be faced for our future is the protection and preservation of our natural environment. This is especially pertinent on Long Island, where our economic and individual survival is dependent upon the protection of our underground aquifer, the only source of drinking water for 2.6 million residents in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, and on the preservation of our environmentally sensitive lands.
In my four years in the State Legislature, I have seen and continue to see an ever-increasing awareness of, and commitment to, protecting the health of our environment by the citizens of New York State. 
 Recognition of the importance of Long Island's environmentally sensitive watershed areas, like the pine barrens in Suffolk and the Oyster Bay and North Hills Special Groundwater Protection Areas in Nassau, has been particularly strong. Accordingly, all levels of government have responded by implementing a variety of measures that attempt to safeguard these most important and necessary natural areas.
In fact, the preservation of our precious natural resources -- our environment -- is no longer a luxury to be taken for granted, but is now recognized as an individual obligation and a governmental responsibility. Toward this end, programs that bring such lands into public ownership are of great significance.
In a year in which there could be no agreement on a number of notable issues, the State Legislature overwhelmingly passed, and the Governor signed into law, the 21st Century Environmental Quality Bond Act. Itwill appear as Proposal One on the statewide ballot Election Day.
If we are to preserve our irreplaceable natural and historic heritage, create and improve our municipal parks, provide assistance to local municipalities for closing unsafe landfills, safely handle medical waste and domestic sewage and establish regional recycling facilities, each of us must take affirmative action when we enter the voting booth this year.
For a cost of less than 2 cents a person a day, we will have come one step closer to leaving a living legacy for future generations of New Yorkers.
Vote 'Yes' on Proposal One.
 
THOMAS P. DiNAPOLI
 
Assemblyman DiNapoli is co-chairman of the State Legislative Commission on Water Resource Needs of Long Island.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 19; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 425 words

HEADLINE: Northeast Notebook: Burlington, Mass.;
Small Town, Huge Project

 BODY:
A COMPUTER software company has leased 70,000 square feet of space space in Burlington Center, a large mixed-use project with five office buildings that is rising in this town of 23,000 people 15 miles north of Boston.
The company, Easel Corporation of Woburn, Mass., will move into the first of the buildings, a $21 million four-story, 125,000-square-foot concrete, granite and glass structure now nearing completion. The building was designed by the Urban Design Group of Chicago.
Trammell Crow Company of Dallas, the developer of the $95 million project, is planning 635,000 square feet of office space, 35,000 square feet of retail space and 75 to 100 town- house units. Construction of the town houses is to begin next year, said Richard A. Galvin, vice president of Trammell Crow's Boston office, but no date has been set for the remaining buildings.
Planning for Burlington Center began in 1984 when the developer proposed an office park of about 1 million square feet. The town denied the permit, objecting that the project was too large.
The developer went to court but decided instead to become the first to use a local planning tool introduced in 1987, the Planned Development District, which allows a variety of uses on land zoned for a single use on a case-by-case basis.
Trammell Crow, town officials and abutting residents came up with the final design, which includes housing on land zoned for industrial use. The plan added the retail and residential space and, at the town's request, extensive traffic, sewer and drainage improvements. The plan was approved in January 1988.
There was little commercial or industrial development here until the 1970's. Since then, businesses and institutions have been attracted by the abundance of commercially and industrially zoned land and the town's convenient location on Route 128, the high-tech beltway around Boston. In the last two years, about 1.5 million square feet of commercial projects have gone up, according to the Planning Director, Terry S. Szold. But since 1987 the town has imposed stricter controls to limit the density of some projects and has introduced greater local scrutiny in planning.
Financing for land acquisition and infrastructure work was provided through Kennedy Associates Real Estate Advisers of Seattle.
The Bank of New England provided the $21 million construction loan for the first building and permanent financing will come from the Multi-Employer Property Trust, a pool of union pension funds advised by Kennedy Associates, Mr. Galvin said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: First of five office buildings at Burlington Center, development under construction in Burlington, Mass. (Rick Friedman for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 8; Page 11; Column 3; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 1360 words

HEADLINE: NBA;
N.B.A. Has Money to Burn in Lean Time

BYLINE: By SAM GOLDAPER

 BODY:
IN 1968, Dick Bloch paid $2 million to put a National Basketball Association franchise in Phoenix. In 1987, Bloch sold the Suns to a group headed by Jerry Colangelo, the team's general manager, for $44.5 million. Three weeks later, Colangelo said recently, he was offered $60 million for the team.
"Last December," Colangelo said, "one of the Big Eight accounting firms appraised the team's worth at $98.9 million." 
Such is the state of the economy in the N.B.A. While governments at all levels and corporations of all sizes struggle with deepening deficits, the N.B.A. has offer sheets to burn. Owners, players and even Commissioner David Stern (in the form of a multimillion-dollar contract) are reaping the benefits.
The Suns are not alone in benefiting from the skyrocketing values of N.B.A. franchises. In 1988, Paul Allen, a leader in the personal-computer industry, purchased the Portland Trail Blazers for $70 million. Last year, the Denver Nuggets were sold for $60 million.
By comparision, the Boston Celtics were sold for $19 million in 1983, before the N.B.A. began enjoying its current popularity and financial health. Three years later, the owners went public by offering 40 percent of the team in a limited partnership, and that move brought in $45 million.
Last February, an appreciated group of owners rewarded Stern, who took over in 1984, with a five-year contract that includes an annual salary of $3.5 million plus a bonus package worth $10 million.
Here are some of the assets of what has become one of the world's hottest sports business:
*With the league's network and cable television contracts totaling $875 million in the next four years, its revenues are projected to grow from $500 million to $650 million this year.
*N.B.A. Properties generated $750 million in retail licensing sales last year.
*N.B.A. Entertainment has produced two of the three best-selling sports video tapes: Michael Jordan's "Come Fly With Me," and "Dazzling Dunks and Basketball Bloopers."
*Other than the Olympics, N.B.A. International has become the world's most widely distributed sports property, selling and distributing league television rights to more than 75 countries.
*With some three dozen players earning $2 million or more this season, the average player's salary has skyrocketed from $750,000 last season to more than $900,000.
Indeed, nowhere has the league's wealth become so evident than in the huge salaries being given -- even thrown at -- players of all abilities. John Williams, likely to be the Cleveland Cavaliers' backup power forward, will earn $5 million as part of a $26.5 million package. Patrick Ewing, the Knicks' center, will be paid $3,750,000, the league's biggest salary this season. Not only are big stars earning huge salaries, but marginal players like Atlanta's Jon Koncak have become millionaires as well.
Despite the lack of a player capable of turning around a franchise, last June's first-round draft choices have contracts 38 percent richer than those of the 1989 first-round picks.
Pervis Ellison, the first pick over all in 1989, signed a five-year contract worth $11.5 million with the Sacramento Kings. Derrick Coleman, the first player chosen in 1990, asked the Nets for a 5-year, $16 million contract, then settled for $15 million.
"The league has never been healthier," said Colangelo, whose first N.B.A. job was doubling as chief scout and director of marketing for the 1966 expansion Chicago Bulls. He recalled that back then that team's total payroll was $180,000, and ticket prices were scaled at $2, $3, $4 and $5.
In the 1989-90 season, led by the Minnesota Timberwolves, an expansion franchise that drew 1,072,572 fans, the league enjoyed its seventh consecutive season of growth in attendance, drawing more than 17 million fans to its 1,107 games. The average attendance was 15,690 people.
To appreciate the success the N.B.A. now enjoys, one must understand the trying moments the league had to overcome.
Spurred by the Knicks winning N.B.A. titles in 1970 and 1973, Madison Avenue hypes tagged pro basketball as the Sport of the Seventies.
"They were a decade too early,"' said Paul Silas, a Knicks assistant coach who was president of the National Basketball Association Players Association from 1974 to 1980.
Before a 1976 merger with the American Basketball Association, the salary battles for top players sent salaries zooming to outlandish heights and many teams drowning in red ink.
By 1982, when the All-Star Game was played at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, the N.B.A. owners were greatly concerned. Neither the Denver Nuggets nor the Utah Jazz appeared capable of supporting themselves. The Indiana Pacers were up for sale but there were no takers. As many as five franchises, including the Clippers, then based in San Diego, and the Kings, in Kansas City, Mo., were in trouble.
A committee of owners was appointed to study cutting the league from 23 to 19 teams by merging the problem franchises.
While the owners wrestled with finances and the Players Association were equally concerned over the possible loss of 48 jobs, a more sinister problem emerged: drugs.
Stern, then the league's executive vice president, remembers those troubled times well.
"Those were the dark days," Stern said in a recent interview at his office high above Fifth Avenue. "There were underlying reasons why the N.B.A. got to where it was. When you're fighting off the possibility of a strike, drugs, high salaries and bad ownerships, they pushed their way onto newspaper pages. Once we solved those problems, we pushed the game back to the forefront where it belonged."
Charles Grantham, then the executive vice president of the Players Association and now its executive director, also remembers the bleak time.
"A story in The Los Angeles Times charging that 80 percent of our players were using drugs gave the public the perception that the N.B.A. was too black, drug-crazed and its players overpaid," Grantham said. "The image hurt. Game attendance dropped; television ratings and revenues fell. Things got so bad in the early 1980's that the championship playoffs were aired on tape delay, after the 11 o'clock news."
With Larry Bird, Magic Johnson and Michael Jordan doing their bit on the court, coupled with the amicable collective-bargaining relationships that developed between Stern and Larry Fleisher, the general counsel of the Players Association, two landmark agreements were forged six months apart in 1983. Those pacts, more than anything else, set the stage for the N.B.A.'s dramatic turnaround.
On March 31, 1983, the N.B.A. and its players' union reached an agreement that guaranteed the players 53 percent of the gross revenues in exchange for a salary cap.
"The salary cap has provided the league with stability," Stern said. "Nobody who has been successful in business wants to buy a team that can't make money and can't win. With the cap, old and prospective new owners had a chance to project their costs."
Six months later, the two sides forged a wide-ranging drug program that called for lifetime suspension, with review after two years for players caught using drugs. It was the strongest stance taken against drug use by any professional sports league.
With the fans concentrating on the game again, Stern turned his attention to selling it. Corporate sponsors are eager to link their names with the world's fastest-growing sport.
Although Stern is concerned about the impact of the current economic climate in this country, he thinks the N.B.A. is in a strong position, even should a recession happen.
"I think our industry would be somewhat impaired, but probably much less than others," he said. "There would be a softening of advertising and sponsorship markets, but attendance would not be adversely affected in the short run. Regardless, we expect our growth to continue."
That growth could come from conquering new fields abroad. Phoenix and the Utah Jazz will play their first two regular season games Friday and Saturday in Japan and Stern won't be happy until everyone in Tokyo is wearing something with an N.B.A. logo.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 26; Column 3; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 725 words

HEADLINE: BOOKS & BUSINESS;
Economics 101

BYLINE: By Peter Passell; Peter Passell writes about economics for The New York Times.

 BODY:

THE AGE OF DIMINISHED EXPECTATIONS
U.S. Economic Policy
in the 1990s.
By Paul Krugman.
204 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
The MIT Press.
$17.95. 
IN the introduction to this slim volume, Paul Krugman, a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, divides economics prose into three categories: "Greek letter, up-and-down, and airport." The first, "formal, theoretical, mathematical," is for dedicated members of the cult only. The second, up-and-down economics (as in pork bellies are up, sterling is down), "has a reputation for being stupefyingly boring, a reputation that is almost entirely justified." The third, the gloom-or-boom prose endemic to the sort of economics books found next to the latest Tom Clancy on airport newsstands, "is usually fun, rarely well-informed and never serious."
As one might guess, Mr. Krugman's writing in "The Age of Diminished Expectations" fits none of the above. He is the rare professional economist who knows how to explain the essence of policy issues to a nonprofessional audience, and he manages it without a hint of condescension. "The Age of Diminished Expectations" is a remarkable achievement; a painless quick read that tells you much of what there is to know about the great economic issues of the day.
Mr. Krugman's central thesis is as simple as it is depressing: The American economy isn't doing very well, and no one is likely to fix what ails it any time soon. This country's biggest economic problem, and, arguably, the economy's only fundamental problem, is slow growth in productivity. Unless output per person grows, personal income can't grow very much. And without rising incomes, there will be no way for individuals to make better lives for themselves and no room in their hearts to make life better for others.
But productivity is not an issue that Washington cozies up to, Mr. Krugman notes, and for good reason. No one has a sure-fire way to get out of the productivity slump because no one knows how we got into it. The few things that just might make a big difference, such as a larger investment in intellectual and physical capital, would require sacrifice. And no politician worthy of his media consultant is ready to ask Americans to suffer in the name of an abstraction.
Mr. Krugman may be too pessimistic. It is certainly true that no President has lost points in recent decades by underestimating Americans' willingness to delay gratification. But it is also true that the one President who tried to sell sacrifice, Jimmy Carter, made it sound like an end in itself. The real problem may be that American politics no longer attracts serious characters with serious ideas. If and when we do get a leader with the vision thing, the public might well get the picture.
But you don't have to buy into Mr. Krugman's pessimism to recognize the value of his book. Each chapter is a bite-sized brief on a big issue, artfully compressing a remarkable amount of sophisticated economics. And in some cases, his analysis may even surprise those people who stay on top of the economic news.
Mr. Krugman argues, for example, that the real cost to American banks of writing off third world debts would be a tiny fraction of the $400 billion the deadbeats actually owe. Forgiving, say, half of the debt might actually prove costless because partial relief would sharply increase the value of the debt that remained.
He also offers an unusual take on the debate over whether the wave of corporate restructuring of the 1980's made American enterprise more efficient or simply transferred income from workers to investment bankers bearing spread sheets. Mr. Krugman thinks both forces were at work. Restructuring was immensely costly to the heavily unionized blue-collar elite, but it also allowed Rust Belt industries to adjust rapidly and efficiently to increased international competition.
The only time Mr. Krugman seems to stumble is when he takes on the question of what Japan's looming economic presence means for Americans. He serves up all the right arguments, but can't quite bring himself to the logical conclusion: Japan's failure to play by the rules has had little impact on America's economic prospects.
But this is a minor blemish. It is hard to think of another work of popular economics that asks so little of readers, yet delivers so much.

947 of 1055 DOCUMENTS

Copyright 1990 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 28, 1990

SECTION: Section 7; Page 19; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 2400 words

HEADLINE: BOOKS & BUSINESS;
Dipping Into the Deficit: Should We Make a Federal Case of It?

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle; Louis Uchitelle reports on economics for The New York Times.

 BODY:
THE year was 1938. The Great Depression had taken a turn for the worse, and President Franklin D. Roosevelt, who, through the previous five years, had tried repeatedly to balance the Federal budget, finally gave up the effort. Among other steps, he reversed a cost-cutting order to disband the Public Works Administration. Instead, he pumped $1 billion into the agency -- all borrowed funds -- to pay the salaries of thousands of newly hired workers.
 The story is recounted in "Balanced Budgets and American Politics" by James D. Savage, a political scientist and the author of one of half a dozen books published in the last several years that analyze the present national aversion to deficits. Rarely in American history has the outcry against deficits been as strong as it is today, especially during this fall's messy battle in Washington over deficit reduction. In response, most of the authors of this sampling of books try to calm the citizenry. 
 They succeed, chiefly by offering their readers insights and history that don't often show up in daily news coverage. Roosevelt's experience is part of Mr. Savage's argument. Although the 32d President could never bring himself to acknowledge that deficit spending in peacetime was good policy, he accepted the practice in 1938 "as a positive and necessary activity if the economy were to recover," Mr. Savage writes. The strategy worked; the economy expanded in 1939 and kept right on growing. And for the next 40 years deficit spending became a proven and legitimate tool for regulating the economy. Not until the final year of Jimmy Carter's Presidency did the White House abandon, as standard policy, the sort of stimulation of the economy through Government programs proposed by the British economist John Maynard Keynes and first adopted in this country by F. D. R.
What would move Mr. Carter to abandon one of the New Deal's hallmark economic policies? Inflation frightened him into budget cutting. As big deficits developed, Mr. Carter and others came to blame them for inflation and other problems -- arguing cause and effect relationships that do not hold up well when deficits are examined more closely, as they have been in a number of recent books. That is certainly the case when deficits are placed in a historical context, as Mr. Savage does particularly well, and also Herbert Stein, in his "Governing the $5 Trillion Economy." While Mr. Savage traces various Government budgets back to 1690, Mr. Stein, a leader among the nation's conservative economists and one of his profession's most lucid and succinct writers, covers the pertinent history in a few pages.
The principal insight to be gathered from these accounts, and many others, is that a deficit should not be a nation's greatest concern; economic growth should be. Mr. Savage gives a five-page table of Government finances going back to 1789. It shows that deficits have been standard operating practice for two generations and the Federal Government has reported surpluses in only seven years since 1930.
Deficits simply were not considered a problem as long as the economy generated more than enough new wealth to pay for the shortfalls. The deficit might rise by, say, $10 billion from one year to the next. But if national income went up by $15 billion, then Americans could finance the shortfall -- through tax payments or the purchase of Treasury securities -- and still have $5 billion in new wealth left over for other purposes.
Until early in this century, the White House and Congress did not even think in terms of not having enough funds to pay for Government outlays. Only in 1911 did formal budgeting, as a means of allocating scarce resources, get under way, Mr. Stein notes. "The situation prior to that is something of a mystery," he writes. "The usual description is that, except in wartime, the Federal Government did not live with scarcity." In fact, from the end of the Civil War until the beginning of the 20th century budget surpluses were normal. As the nation spread rapidly westward in that period, the rising output of expanding agriculture, industry and railroads furnished more than enough wealth to pay for whatever services the Federal Government chose to offer.
Except during the two world wars and the Great Depression, Government spending did not outstrip the capacity of the nation's economic expansion to provide revenues until the early 1970's. The rebirth of other industrial nations and stiff competition from foreign corporations then cut into the American market and into the American share of the global market. And in the 70's and 80's Social Security, Medicare, military outlays, farm subsidies, highway and airport construction, welfare, education and many other Federal outlays that had blossomed after World War II became a burden.
What the recent books on the deficit reflect is that at that point the deficit became a political issue. Given an economy that no longer expands at its old, rapid rate, today's budget deficits represent a bigger percentage of the national wealth than they have at any time in the 20th century, except for the war and Depression years. That scared Americans into accepting the imposition a few years ago of the Gramm-Rudman deficit reduction law, which imposes a general sequestering of a percentage of the budget if Congress and the President cannot agree on certain levels of cuts in the deficit. And the fear of deficits explains why the recent struggle between President Bush and Congress, and among members of Congress, was so painful and disorderly as the two branches of Government tried to cut back services that are deeply entrenched in American society.
As the political scientists Joseph White and Aaron Wildavsky, authors of "The Deficit and the Public Interest," put it: "The budget has been to our era what civil rights, communism, the depression, industrialization and slavery were at other times. Nor does the day of the budget show signs of ending." Mr. White and Mr. Wildavsky devote most of their 575-page text to an account of the annual budget negotiations since 1974 -- a history that helps to explain why the push for cutbacks has finally become such a crisis issue. Making the choice to reduce the deficit is more difficult than anyone seems to admit, the authors declare.
BUT while budget deficits might be mostly a political issue, the daily debate highlights economics. Here the new budget literature is particularly useful in sorting fact from fiction. Nearly all the nation's economic ills are blamed these days on the deficit. It is linked to inflation, high interest rates, wasteful spending, lackluster investment, low productivity, the trade deficit and what is often presented as a fatal overdependence on foreign lenders.
F. D. R. had also associated deficits with inflation, although deflation was the big problem in the 30's. Fear of inflation, in fact, had made him reluctant before 1938 to use deficits to regulate the economy. As the reader will find out from these books, the essence of the view that deficits cause inflation and other dire economic consequences is this: to finance the big deficits the Government has to borrow so much money through the sale of Treasury securities that not enough is left over to invest in expansion of the private sector. Inflation inevitably erupts because without strong new investment the economy can't grow fast enough to supply all that people demand, particularly the demands of a big-spending Government. And with investment funds scarce, interest rates rise to ration loans. The high rates, in turn, discourage many companies from investing in factories, offices and machinery, further inhibiting the creation of new wealth. Foreign lenders, attracted by the high interest rates, then step in, becoming big lenders to the Government. Paying the interest in the future on the debt held by foreigners means a further drain on the national wealth.
In "Day of Reckoning," Benjamin M. Friedman, a Harvard University economist, lays out emphatically these doomsday economics of deficit spending. The other economists represented in this group of books mostly seem to disagree. They note, for example, that inflation and interest rates have been both high and low during years of big deficits, and so has investment. The deficit-doomsday links are hard to find in the record, they maintain.
Robert Ortner, in "Voodoo Deficits," is particularly sarcastic about the alleged dire economic consequences of deficits. Mr. Ortner was the chief economist at the Commerce Department during the Reagan Administration, which made deficit cutting a major goal -- even though it took no substantive action to reduce the deficit. Among other arguments, Mr. Ortner notes that the annual deficit would be much lower if it weren't for the nearly $200 billion a year the Government spends on interest payments to service the $3 trillion accumulated national debt. Such big interest payments mean that less is available for Social Security, the military and other programs. But, Mr. Ortner argues, nearly 85 percent of the national debt is held by Americans, so the interest payments go mostly to them rather than to foreigners. They stay within the national family, so to speak, ameliorating the shortage of funds in the private sector.
The accumulation of such arguments in most of the new deficit literature helps to explain why the deficits, big as they are, haven't yet produced much noticeable economic damage. Even Mr. Friedman, committed as he is to cutting the deficit, suggests that the American economy can still find ways to finance it, although it is approaching $300 billion in the current fiscal year, roughly 5 percent of the total economy, as measured by the gross national product. Only in the late 1940's, in the aftermath of World War II, and during the recession of the early '80's, has the percentage been that high.
THE issue, then, is how to reverse the trend and make the deficit shrink as a percentage of the total economy, or least to prevent its rise. Most of these authors devote a chapter to their favorite proposals, and the last chapter of Mr. Friedman's book is eloquent. Among other ideas, he would as a last resort reverse Ronald Reagan's 1981 tax cuts, which reduced Federal revenue by hundreds of billions of dollars in the 1980's. If other measures prove politically unacceptable, he writes, "Then the best way to right our fiscal policy -- the way most likely to promote public understanding and thereby command public support -- is to admit that with Kemp-Roth [the name of the Reagan tax bill] we cut taxes too much, and fix our mistake."
But raising taxes to reduce the deficit just as the American economy is sinking toward recession runs counter to the old Keynesian thesis that in hard times Government should be encouraging people to spend and invest, not restricting spending through higher taxes or cutbacks in outlays. Keynesian stimulus might be gone from the Administration's box of policy tools, but the principle involved remains very much in people's minds. Most politicians and economists are reluctant to cut Government spending in a weakening economy.
Robert Eisner's "How Real Is the Federal Deficit?," first published in 1986 and now the granddaddy of the deficit books, stands today as a sort of classic reference work for those who want to restore the Keynesian approach to politics. Mr. Eisner, an economist at Northwestern University, argues that to a large extent, the deficits represent productive investments that increase the national wealth. For him, spending for highways, education, research, airports, even health care, increases the nation's productive capacity, just as the output from a new factory increases a corporation's revenues and profits. A well-educated worker, for instance, can produce more goods of better quality than a poorly educated one, and a wide new highway gets goods to market faster and less expensively than an older, rutted one.
And just as the corporation uses the earnings from its new factory to repay the bonds floated to build it, the Government draws on the new wealth that flows from the nation's productive investments to finance the deficit. Separate the Government's "capital expenditures" from its outlays for consumption (including most military spending), and the startling deficits of the 80's shrink toward insignificance, Mr. Eisner argues.
Mr. Eisner makes his case in somewhat technical language, while the economists Robert L. Heilbroner and Peter Bernstein, in "The Debt and the Deficit," covering the same ground, assume that their reader comes new to the deficit issue and they make it easier to grasp. The liberal Mr. Heilbroner and the conservative Mr. Stein, however much they differ in ideology, seem to agree that deficits are not the greatest dangers to society. The two men are probably the profession's easiest-to-read and most entertaining writers and their deficit books, each less than 140 pages, cover the ground well enough for most readers. What does the Heilbroner-Bernstein book conclude? "In normal times we favor a 'deficit', by which we mean growth-promoting expenditures . . . of 2 to 3 percent of G.N.P. -- perhaps $100 billion to $150 billion at today's values," they write. "And that is all. The lesson is over."

HEADLINE: BOOKS & BUSINESS;
Organized Looting

BYLINE: By Ronald Brownstein; Ronald Brownstein, a national political correspondent for The Los Angeles Times, is the author of the forthcoming book "The Power and the Glitter: The Hollywood-Washington Connection."

 BODY:

THE GREATEST-EVER BANK ROBBERY
The Collapse of the Savings and Loan Industry.
By Martin Mayer.
354 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $22.50. 
 FOR the past several weeks, Representative Bill Schuette, the Republican Senate candidate in Michigan, has been accusing Democratic Senator Carl Levin of accepting campaign contributions from a law firm that worked for Charles H. Keating Jr., the former savings and loan executive who has become a symbol of the nation's worst financial scandal. When the two candidates debated in early September, Senator Levin fired back, saying that Mr. Schuette had accepted funds from a major accounting firm that had been implicated in another savings and loan failure. The next day Mr. Schuette escalated again, accusing Senator Levin of accepting funds from six accounting firms that are "being sued by the Federal Government in connection with the S.& L. scandal."
Such is the extent to which the bottomless savings and loan disaster has diminished the reputations of many of our leading professions. To the veteran financial journalist Martin Mayer, that story, the failure of accountants, lawyers, Wall Street brokers, politicians and most regulators to rein in fast-dealing S.& L. executives, is the real scandal in the industry's spectacular collapse. "What makes the S& L outrage so important a piece of American history is not the hundreds of billions of dollars [lost] but the demonstration of how low our standards for professional performance have fallen in law, accounting, appraising, banking, and politics -- all of them," he writes in his awkwardly titled book, "The Greatest-Ever Bank Robbery."
That tone of sustained moral outrage at the professions that acquiesced in, and often encouraged, the looting is Mr. Mayer's real contribution to the swelling shelf of books on the savings and loan disaster. Over all, this is only a workmanlike effort that adds little to the existing literature. He revisits the familiar story of the savings and loans' descent into financial hell. Squeezed by inflation in the late 1970's, the industry -- which had traditionally anchored itself in the unglamorous business of accepting savings from small depositors and writing home mortgages -- won from Congress and the Reagan Administration the authority to bid aggressively for larger deposits and to invest the money in speculative ventures. With that new freedom, an astounding variety of schemers and dreamers pilfered, lost and gambled away immense sums, leaving the Federal Government with a tab that may exceed $500 billion by the year 2020.
Other books -- including "The Big Fix" by James Ring Adams and the best-selling "Inside Job" by three financial journalists -- Stephen Pizzo, Mary Fricker and Paul Muolo -- have already recounted the sheer picaresque lunacy of this conflagration with far more enthusiasm than Mr. Mayer. Mr. Mayer does his usual thorough reporting job, but he has little flair for storytelling or characters; his politicians are all cardboard figures, his regulators and industry executives distant and vague.
His preferred milieu is the intricacies of Federal law and banking regulation. Mr. Mayer knows his way around this arcane territory, but his focus on it leaves the book with the dry feel of a legal brief -- and a somewhat disorganized one at that. The book has an unfortunate tendency to begin stories and then drift away to other subjects. If there is an organizational scheme here, it is as complicated as any of the bizarre loan arrangements savings and loan executives used to evade their regulators.
For all its defects, the book has important virtues. Mr. Mayer's asides are often eye-opening: he chides newspapers for unquestioningly running advertisements soliciting deposits for S.& L.'s that were clearly on the verge of collapse. And Mr. Mayer performs a service by shining the spotlight of outrage not only on the crass and colorful hucksters who crashed previously sleepy thrifts, but the pin-striped pillars of prominent law offices and accounting firms who profitably cloaked the hucksters' schemes in respectability.
What Mr. Mayer illustrates is complete institutional myopia on all sides, the dispiriting inability of almost anyone who interacted with the thrift industry -- even those in public service -- to think for a moment about the implications of their actions for the public interest. The exceptions -- a few courageous savings and loan regulators in Texas, California and Washington who tried to slow down the rush to disaster -- found themselves harassed by some of the most powerful members of Congress, from Senator Alan Cranston, the majority whip, to former Speaker of the House Jim Wright, who relied on the industry for substantial campaign contributions.
Mr. Mayer has waded through this financial swamp searching for the correct moral. "We are farther along than anyone thought on our road to a Hobbesian society: These days you can't trust anybody," he writes. "Americans really don't want to live this way. But they have forgotten that there are other ways." That is a sobering lesson from a dizzying calamity.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 30; Column 2; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1840 words

HEADLINE: A Quantum Leap Backward

BYLINE: By Kathleen M. Sullivan; Kathleen M. Sullivan is a professor of law at Harvard University. She is at work on a book on the First Amendment and public funding for the arts.

 BODY:
THE NEW RIGHT AND THE CONSTITUTION
Turning Back the Legal Clock.
By Bernard Schwartz.
310 pp. Boston:
Northeastern University Press. $32.50. 
 WHEN Judge Robert H. Bork was nominated for a seat on the Supreme Court three years ago, Senator Edward M. Kennedy warned that he would "turn back the clock" on civil rights and civil liberties if confirmed. Few phrases could have served as a more potent call to opposition. Liberal constitutionalists have viewed the Supreme Court in recent decades as the agent of ineluctable, enlightened progress, intervening to protect the outnumbered and the powerless from abuses of majority power. A vote for Judge Bork would be a vote to go back to the bad old days. Who wanted to "turn back the clock"? Not the Senate, which ultimately defeated the Bork nomination by a vote of 58-42.
Bernard Schwartz, a New York University law professor, is a strong subscriber to the liberal faith in constitutional progress. The subtitle of his new book, "The New Right and the Constitution: Turning Back the Legal Clock," echoes the refrain of the Bork defeat. His earlier books, "The Unpublished Opinions of the Warren Court" and "The Unpublished Opinions of the Burger Court," gained him unusual access to the Court's normally secret internal correspondence and memorandums. His new book surveys the work of a handful of "new right" judges and law professors who, in Mr. Schwartz's view, have wrought a dangerous influence on the law by seeking nothing less than "a repeal of the twentieth century."
What is the great constitutional accomplishment of the 20th century that Mr. Schwartz would preserve against this onslaught? The transformation of the Supreme Court from reinforcer of existing hierarchies to agent of social change. At the beginning of the century, as Mr. Schwartz tells it, the Supreme Court upheld Jim Crow and capitalism and struck down progressive labor legislation in the name of economic liberty, while leaving oppressed groups and personal liberty at the mercy of the state.
Three great constitutional moments, however, brought deliverance. At the height of the New Deal in the mid-1930's, the Supreme Court retreated from the field of economic regulation, leaving to elected officials the whole business of distributing wealth. As the civil rights movement gained momentum in the mid-1950's, the Supreme Court renounced the doctrine of separate but equal and declared an end to racial segregation in the schools. And as the 1960's brought on the sexual revolution, the Supreme Court acknowledged a right of privacy that would bar the state from regulating what goes on behind the bedroom door.
Along the way, constitutional priorities were reversed to value personal liberty over the protection of property. Government now may freely regulate economic transactions, but it may not act so readily when it comes to sex or speech. Liberty of contraception has replaced liberty of contract in the pantheon of fundamental rights.
Mr. Schwartz treats such developments as a kind of evolutionary necessity. The Court's abandonment of doctrines of "self-devouring individualism" permitted government to "control the excesses and relieve the oppressions of the rising industrial economy." With Brown v. Board of Education, the Court launched a process of desegregation that, as a practical matter, "could not realistically be left to elected representatives." By permitting the post-New Deal growth of independent agencies into a fourth branch not originally contemplated by the Framers, the Court made it possible for "modern government . . . to exercise the functions that public opinion has required it to assume."
In the face of such progress, Mr. Schwartz argues, the "new right" constitutionalists are radical reactionaries who would have us take a constitutional "quantum leap backward." To confine the Constitution to the Framers' original intent, for example, "could mean a return to an era characterized by Jim Crow, the rack and the pillory, and no paper money." To read the Fifth Amendment Takings Clause as narrowly limiting Government's power of eminent domain "would have all but rendered effective urban planning impossible in this country." To insist on a rigid separation of powers in the Federal Government would "strike at the very heart of the administrative state." Taken together, these arguments are "conservative only in a Pickwickian sense," as the "new right" in fact aims "to uproot established doctrine and replace it with principles long repudiated."
"The New Right and the Constitution" usefully gathers and explicates in a single volume a variety of "new right" constitutional arguments. Some have been well ventilated beneath the glare of lights in the Senate Judiciary Committee hearing room. But while the nation watched closely as Ronald Reagan and George Bush filled four Supreme Court seats, it paid little attention as they also appointed over half the sitting Federal judges in the lower Federal courts. Mr. Schwartz performs a useful service by reporting on what some of those lesser-known judges are up to.
HIS book, however, is less successful as a critique. Mr. Schwartz contemplates the implications of "new right" constitutional jurisprudence with an air of disbelief and mild shock, like the hero of a work of science fiction rubbing his eyes incredulously as he witnesses the unexpected resurrection of a hardy band of aliens he thought had been eliminated. His response is to reassure himself and his fellow earthlings that it can't happen here. Why not? Because there is too much settled law under the bridge. Having cast the "new right" as radicals, Mr. Schwartz slips too easily into the conservative role of defending the status quo.
But surely it is not enough to defend a practice simply because it exists, for that it exists does not mean that it is good. After all, one man's progress is another man's decline and fall. The challenge for those of us who defend the liberal constitutional order is to articulate why the right of privacy deserves stronger protection than the right of contract, why sex and speech should not be regulated like commerce, and why desegregation orders are not legislation from the bench. Mr. Schwartz's book leaves off where those tasks for liberal constitutional scholarship begin.
At the same time, Mr. Schwartz credits "new right" constitutional theorists with more influence than they have actually had: however extraterrestrial their origins, he seems to say, they have landed, spread and "altered the American jurisprudential landscape." This is an overstatement.
FOR one thing, "new right" legal scholars are not an army or even a political party. Reagan era Republicans may have been united on a party platform of decreasing economic regulation while increasing social control, but "new right" legal thinkers are hardly so monolithic. Some are libertarian on both the economic and the social fronts. The University of Chicago law professor Richard A. Epstein, for example, would revitalize property rights in part to protect privacy -- to exclude the moral judgments of others in the absence of material harm. Judge Frank H. Easterbrook of the Chicago-based Federal Court of Appeals, for another example, can hardly have endeared himself to the Reagan Administration by striking down an Indianapolis antipornography ordinance on classic First Amendment grounds. And Judge Easterbrook and his colleague Judge Richard A. Posner both recently voted to invalidate a work-place "fetal protection" policy as sex discrimination because it treated women as potential pregnancies rather than as individuals who know their own minds.
Moreover, Mr. Schwartz barely mentions that some of the targets of his book have proved flatly unappointable to the courts. He sounds chapter-long alarms against such academics as Bernard H. Siegan (for advocating a revival of economic rights) and Lino A. Graglia (for attacking school desegregation orders), letting on only in the fine print of the endnotes that the extremism of both men had kept them off the Federal bench. Likewise relegated to an afterthought is the Senate's defeat of the Bork nomination. Mr. Schwartz treats Judge Bork, like Mr. Siegan and Mr. Graglia, as one more player in a cast of influential right-wing jurists -- despite the monumental fact of his rejection by the Senate. Only late in the book does Mr. Schwartz concede, "It is true that President Reagan was not able to win confirmation for some of his most controversial judicial nominees."
The Bork defeat, however, was no minor rebuff. In rejecting Judge Bork in 1987, the Democratically controlled Senate drew a line in the sand. No one publicly committed to "turning back the clock" might cross. When the Senate recently confirmed President Bush's nominee, David H. Souter, for appointment to the Supreme Court, it furnished a cautionary epilogue to Mr. Schwartz's book. Justice Souter survived the Senate gantlet only by affirming at least some broad commitment to an evolving Constitution in which judges must expound unenumerated rights and fill "vacuums" in the enforcement of civil rights. Had he not done so, the outcome might well have been different. Justice Souter's confirmation suggests that moderates, not reactionaries, still hold the key cards.
Does "The New Right and the Constitution" thus cry wolf? The answer is no. While the book overstates the influence of conservative constitutional jurisprudence on actual legal outcomes, it correctly notes that the "new right" has shifted the dialogue. The key players in Mr. Schwartz's book may be alone out near the right-field fence, but when they position themselves so far over, they pull the rest of the players on the field to the right along with them.
WHAT are some examples of this directional shift? The right of privacy is here to stay, and even the controversial Roe v. Wade decision is unlikely to be flatly overturned. But the more the right challenges the legitimacy of that decision, the more likely the center is to tolerate some increased state regulation of abortion. The same holds for the exclusionary rule, which requires that illegally obtained evidence be excluded from criminal trials: Mapp v. Ohio, which announced the rule, won't be flatly overruled, but the more the right employs cost-benefit analysis to attack its reasoning, the more exceptions to the rule the center may agree to carve out. And while the repeal of the entire welfare state as a "taking" of private property is hardly imminent, courts have dealt property owners some more limited victories against government power.
If Mr. Schwartz thus began his book with sirens blaring, he ends on a quieter note. In the final pages, he appears to concede that his hardy band of aliens has had more effect in unsettling the mind than in changing the law -- a bit like a listener to Orson Welles's radio version of "War of the Worlds" might have felt when he found out it was not a real news bulletin after all.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 1; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1314 words

HEADLINE: For Good . . . And Country

BYLINE: By Theodore C. Sorensen; Theodore C. Sorensen, former special counsel to President John F. Kennedy and the author of six books, practices law in New York City.

 BODY:

GRATITUDE
Reflections on What We Owe
to Our Country.
By William F. Buckley Jr.
169 pp. New York:
Random House. $16.95. 
 WHAT a year! Mikhail Gorbachev embraces the free market and wins the Nobel Peace Prize. F. W. de Klerk attacks apartheid. Pat Buchanan criticizes the deployment of United States forces to the Persian Gulf. Jesse Jackson supports that deployment. And now William F. Buckley Jr., the distinguished dean of the intellectual right, in a long essay that he acknowledges will disturb his fellow conservatives, favors national service legislation summoning young Americans to 12 months of low-paid, low-grade public employment.
Growing support for national service, spearheaded by Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, has heretofore been confined largely to Democrats. The national Democratic Party platform of 1988 urged a program providing "opportunities for voluntary national public service, above and beyond current services, that can enrich our communities." In "Gratitude" Mr. Buckley asserts that he is opposed to the Nunn version, but his stated objections do not dispute its basic thrust. A Republican counterpart he dismisses out of hand as "a halfhearted substitute bill, not worth exploring."
To retain his conservative credentials with Milton Friedman, Martin Anderson and other true believers who have attacked the concept of national service as subversive of our freedom, Mr. Buckley sprinkles his commentary with his usual swipes at liberals, egalitarianism, bleeding-heart politics, the bureaucratic class, organized welfare, the war on poverty, the minimum wage, the abolition of literacy tests for voting, The New Republic, Harry Truman and former Interior Secretary Stewart Udall (whom Mr. Buckley confuses with Stew's brother, Representative Morris Udall). It is good conservative doctrine, he insists, to recognize the citizen's ties to the community beyond those that relate to the state or the marketplace.
But Messrs. Friedman, Anderson, et al. are unlikely to be reassured. They know the telltale signs of conservative backsliding when they see them -- defensive statements like "the market shouldn't be asked to perform functions for which it is incompetent" and small heresies such as his view that the country no longer has "the need for a very large military" (both of which sound more like the former Democratic Congressman Charlie Buckley than Bill).
John F. Kennedy summoning young Americans to the New Frontier was rarely more eloquent than Mr. Buckley articulating every citizen's obligation to ask what he can do for his country as requital for liberties inherited and protected. In part, Mr. Buckley supports national service, as President Kennedy did the Peace Corps, out of a conviction that the increased awareness of those who subscribe will be of even greater value to our country than the services they provide.
Essentially, Mr. Buckley favors -- with ample allowance for variations and experimentation -- a national service program enrolling most of the nation's young men and women after high school graduation to perform roughly 12 months of social, civic and philanthropic labor. To prove that he is still the sworn enemy of Federal bureaucracy and coercion, he wants the 50 states to approve the program, pay the volunteers and decide on their activities. He envisions a new Federal agency, financed with Federal funds, setting standards, coordinating efforts and enforcing sanctions.
Sanctions? For a program of youthful volunteers eager to show their devotion to country?
HIS principal emphasis is on gratitude -- thus the title of the book -- on one's debt and duty to country and community, on uniting the privilege of citizenship in a republic with responsibility: "Materialistic democracy beckons every man to make himself a king; republican citizenship incites every man to be a knight." Service to one's society summons forth "the better angels within our nature." Beautiful, especially coming from one who has done his bit over the years to disparage those public servants or would-be public servants with whom he disagrees.
Gratitude, not intimidation. Subscription, not conscription. The state should not be entitled to exact work from unwilling citizens, writes Mr. Buckley. But just to make sure pride of patrimony is awakened in a sufficiently large number of young hearts, to encourage this particular form of expressing gratitude, to penalize any civic sluggard who is unwilling to show his devotion in this fashion, Mr. Buckley favors the extensive use of what he gently terms "inducements" to see to it that national service is "heavily subscribed."
Voluntary? Of course, it's voluntary, young sir or madam. Feel free, upon graduating from high school and turning 18, to renounce any notion of national service -- provided you are also willing to forgo your high school diploma, driver's license, student loan, right to equal treatment under the law and status as a first-class citizen. When Bill Buckley wants you to express gratitude, he doesn't fool around.
Perhaps I misread Mr. Buckley, not being a lexicographer. If I understand him -- and frequently I do not -- national service, morphologically speaking, is apodictically not a mere millenarian velleity or synecdoche exiguously reified as antinomian meliorism by exogenous Ortega y Gasset epigones with their conflated burins. At least, I certainly hope not! But be prepared for these and similar terms when you tackle Mr. Buckley's text.
As always, it is a learned text, citing seven Presidents, six philosophers, five scholars, four economists, three novelists, two popes and one poet -- and there may be a partridge in a pear tree in there as well. One source from whom he quotes at length is none other than William F. Buckley Jr. himself. In sentences running up to 70 words in length, erudite arguments are mixed, not always successfully, with fictitious examples, autobiographical experiences and a dubious analogy to the Swiss national service program.
I HAVE occasional difficulty with Mr. Buckley's sesquipedalian style of writing. I have some mild disagreements with his approach to national service legislation. I doubt that he will succeed in convincing his fellow conservatives that his approach shuns any hint of Federal regimentation. But I have no difficulty understanding and embracing Mr. Buckley's underlying message. He is clearly devoted to this country, deeply grateful for the liberties and privileges it has afforded us and genuinely committed to recognizing and repaying that debt. After an American decade marred by greed and self-indulgence, this book, in reminding us all of our obligations, is a national service.
 
 
 
A CALL TO WORK
 The objective should be to enroll, by the turn of the century, more than 80 percent of Americans born in 1973 or later. . . . Yes, there needs to be a National Service Franchise Administration. Its primary function should be to gather information for use by the states and indeed by individuals seeking (for instance) a locality that sustains an NSFA program most congenial to their inclination. . . . But the NSFA, observing its mandate, should also recommend appropriate legislation to Congress, legislation having primarily to do with federal sanctions. No federal money would be used to finance national service; federal money would be made available only to absorb administrative costs run up by the [NSFA]. . . . A vital function of the Administration would be to establish how long a participant would need to work in order to qualify for his certificate of service. The states decide what are the accrediting activities and which should be given precedence. But only a single agency can reasonably decide what the total contribution, measured in time served, ought to be. The idea of one year's service appeals. -- From "Gratitude."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 18; Column 3; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 1168 words

HEADLINE: On Language;
Moving the Goalposts

BYLINE: BY WILLIAM SAFIRE

 BODY:
"These conditions are clear-cut and are not open to reinterpretation," said President Bush, explaining his criteria for opening trade with South Africa, "and I do not believe in moving the goalposts."
There's a term that has been popping up of late. "The Japanese . . . can no longer rely on localization as a means of satisfying Europe's requirements," complained a Japanese lobbyist in London. "This is a classic case of moving the goalposts." 
 A few years ago, following the Reykjavik summit meeting, a British diplomat at the United Nations objected to the way "the Russians have withdrawn from that understanding. . . . They have moved the goal posts."
The first use I can find is in 1978, when Albert V. Casey of American Airlines used the phrase while keeping a stiff upper lip about deregulation. The Washington Post, in quoting him, used a revealing verb: " 'They keep moving the goal posts,' he lamented."
You lament, complain, gripe and whine about moving the goalposts (which I write as one word, contrary to Times style, to settle the issue). That is because the phrase refers to an example of unfairness, a useful shortening of "changing the rules in the middle of the game."
"This term is British," says Peter Stothard, United States editor of The Times of London, "and means 'changing the terms of a debate or a conflict after it's been started.' I expect it's more from children's playing, where the sticks marking the goal can be moved, than from organized football. It's a very common term now, both in politics and in social conversation. A child, for instance, who's been told to keep his room clean for an extra 50 pence a week, and then doesn't get the extra money, may say, 'Hey, you've moved the goalposts.' "
The term is always accusatory; nobody boasts of moving the goalposts. But a right-wing commentator who was surprised by the scope of change in the Soviet Union, and then set new criteria for the success of perestroika, pre-emp tively struck at told-you-so criticism by asserting that he (O.K., I) had indeed moved the goalposts "to reflect the basic changes in the game."
 
Readout
 "IS A WRITTEN READOUT a handout?" asked my colleague David E. Rosenbaum of The New York Times.
At about that time, Richard E. Cohen of National Journal was being told by a staff member of the House Appropriations Committee that his question would be answered as soon as a readout could be prepared. Troubled by this locution, the reporter found a citation in writing and sent it to me: a transcript of a White House press briefing that began, "Welcome to the prebrief -- or readout, excuse me -- on the visit of President Ben Ali of Tunisia."
A quick phone call to the horse's mouth (which is an expression of authenticity, not a derogation of President Bush or his spokesman) for an explanation of current usage:
"Readout is a colloquial conjunction of two separate expressions," says Marlin Fitzwater, the Presidential press secretary, obviously consulting notes in his hand. "The first is 'to read your notes,' which is what we do in reporting to the press about a meeting we attended. The second part, the out part, may be from 'to speak out,' as in telling the press about what happened."
Date of coinage? "I've heard it since I got here in 1983," recalls Mr. Fitzwater, which pushes its time of origin back to the early Reagan or late Carter Administration. The meaning? "A readout is a report on what happened at a meeting."
The derivation is computerese. The first sense in the Oxford English Dictionary, which prefers the hyphenated form, is "the extraction or transfer of data from a storage medium or device."
For a more hands-on definition, let us turn to Pete Cottrell of the University of Maryland's computer science department: "Readout refers to instrument panels or video displays. It's human interface with the machine conveying information, as opposed to printout, which is the output of the machine that you can carry away in your hand."
Thus, an answer to Mr. Rosenbaum: in journalese, a readout is not a handout; it is a public recitation of information from which notes may be taken or, if permission is given, pictures may be transmitted.
 
Supa Japanese
 THE LANGUAGES OF EAST Asia seem disoriented these days. Bouncing about what is no longer called the Far East, where I found China Airlines (two words) more reliable than Japan Air Lines (three words), the traveler is jarred by the adoption of American terms: teribi is Japanese for "terrible," and supa, for "super," is superseding the ancient Japanese borrowing, "O.K."; the pronunciation of supa mimics the American "soop-a." This signifies a rough balance of trade in words: we have adopted honcho, their word for "squad leader," as a verb meaning "to be straw boss over."
All around the world, however, language follows life. As work habits change and living styles shift, we form new words to describe people in new roles.
In the United States, a word was needed for a man who does the housework and looks after the kids while his wife pursues a career outside the home; the coinage was househusband, based on housewife, which was formed in parallel over the past eight centuries with the German Hausfrau.
Many housewives now prefer the sexless homemaker; few househusbands adopt that term, preferring -- cheerfully or defiantly -- the specifically male identification. In time, as the need to assert sexual identification declines, that term may be replaced by domestic economist despite objections from learned practitioners of the dismal science.
Househusband is an analogue, coined by analogy; the Japanese usually prefer to coin a new life-style word by applying a new sense to a word already familiar in another area.
Example: what do you call a man who retires and pokes around the house, getting in the way? In the United States, he's called a retiree, and in Britain, a pensioner -- both neutral terms, with the adjective aimless or prepositional phrase at loose ends tacked on fore or aft to modify them pejoratively. (If anyone has a good term for "active, involved retiree, creatively contemplative, and a real pleasure to have around the house," as most of my retired readers surely are, send it in.)
In Japan, the word for a bored retiree, as viewed by his soured spouse, is nureha.
"Nureha are wet, fallen leaves," writes C. Alton Robertson in The Japan Times. "And anyone who has tried to sweep wet, fallen leaves off their steps or street (as any Japanese housewife has) knows how impossible it is. They are well and truly stuck.
 "Nureha is now used to mean a retired man who sticks to his wife like a wet, fallen leaf. . . . He watches her cook; he watches her do the laundry; he goes shopping with her. Nureha."
A cruel term, but life is unfair, and language follows life. They keep moving the goalposts.

HEADLINE: Corporations Struggle to Sell Transferees' Houses

BYLINE: By MAUREEN MILFORD

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, DEL.

 BODY:
It's tough enough to have one house to sell these days. But America's largest companies are ending up with hundreds, as the stagnant real-estate market swells their inventories of houses they buy from employees they are relocating.
E. I. du Pont de Nemours and Company, , which moves 4,000 employees a year, has watched its inventories double in Delaware and Pennsylvania in the last year, to 160 houses. To sell those houses without driving prices down further, Du Pont has adopted a program of incentives to lure home buyers, including low-interest mortgages and a chance to win prizes just by looking at a house. 
 Buyer incentives and other ways of coping with the soft real estate market were a major topic at the fall meeting of the Employee Relocation Council held last week in Los Angeles.
"Dealing with high inventories certainly is a concern," said Anita Brienza, communications director with the thousand-member relocation council.
Du Pont is not alone. Eastman Kodak Company has also seen its stockpile in of houses in the Rochester area double, and its national inventory increase by 10 to 20 percent. And at ICI Americas, the United States arm of the international chemical giant, the company, which is based here, is now carrying 58 houses, compared with half that number a year ago.
Still, the sluggish real estate market has not cut down on the number of corporate transfers, according to Ms. Brienza, who said that some companies move more than a thousand employees each year.
Transfers this year are at about last year's level, she said, although 1989's activity was down somewhat from a peak the year before.
"Companies view it as a cost of doing business," Ms. Brienza said. "It's worth it to them to get their first choice on the job. They're making an investment in employees."
The cost of relocation can be large, averaging $50,000 for each employee moved. Steven E. Rogers, supervisor of corporation relocation for Du Pont, which has its headquarters here, said that cost is "certainly" a concern.
"But Du Pont is in the business to make sure the right people are in the right jobs," he said.
The chemical company's program of buying houses from employees it was relocating began in the recession of 1974, when the market was also sluggish. Kodak began its program in the mid-60's. According to the Relocation Council, 84 percent of the council's members now either buy an employee's house during a transfer or assign it to a relocation company like Prudential Relocation Management of White Plains, N.Y., up from from 48 percent in 1974.
"We want to take that worry off the employees, because worry takes away from productivity," said Mr. Rogers. "You can't put a value on it, but we believe it makes a difference for the company and the employees."
Under most programs the company offers to buy a house for the average of two or three appraisals. Many programs allow the employee a certain period, generally 60 days, to sell the house independently or with a broker. Some companies discourage employees from trying to market the house themselves.
"We don't want them improperly marketing the property," said Thomas B. McLaughlin, assistant manager for finance and real estate for ICI Americas.
Corporate real estate managers say that in the current unstable market they are having difficulty getting employees to accept appraisals of their house as accurate. Similarly, the relocation council says that assessments are a key concern of employees today as well.
"They think the appraisals are low ball," said Warren Dungee, property manager for Du Pont.
For that reason, some companies tell employees that if they find a buyer at a better price themselves or through a broker, the company will step in and handle complications of the closing once a contract is signed.
Companies also offer loss protection plans that reimburse employees for capital improvements they have made to their properties. Under some programs, the company will pay 100 percent of the cost of major additions, and 50 percent of luxury improvements, like swimming pools.
Once a house becomes the property of a company, the carrying costs can be substantial -- 1 or 2 percent of its price a month, by the industry's rule of thumb. This includes interest charges, taxes, maintenance and repairs. Nearly all the companies make whatever repairs are needed to put the house in move-in condition.
While houses Du Pont owns in Louisiana, Oklahoma and other oil-patch states are beginning to move after a few rough years, the properties it and other companies are holding in the Northeast are becoming harder to sell.
"We're taking a major loss in Rochester," said Mee Wing, director of corporate relocation for Kodak. "The Northeast is bad."
For this reason, companies are starting to offer incentives to buyers. The Du Pont company recently announced a special program to sell its stockpile of homes in Delaware and Pennsylvania. The purpose of the incentive program, the company says, is to sell homes without bringing prices down throughout the community.
Buyers of a Du Pont home in Pennsylvania and Delaware will be eligible for below-market financing through a mortgage company with which Du Pont has made a special arrangement.
Anyone who even tours a Du Pont home is eligible for a drawing for a free trip to Cancun, Mexico, and real estate agents who show a corporate listing will have their names in a drawing for a $10,000 prize.
While some homeowners have complained that this use of the financial muscle of a Fortune 500 company leaves them at a disadvantage, real estate agents praise such programs as the only way to keep a community's price structure from tumbling.
In any case, the incentives are working: Du Pont has sold a house a day since the program was announced earlier this month.
"It's put people in the looking mode," said Daniel B. Henderson, director of corporate relocation with Gilpin, Van Trump & Montgomery Inc., a real estate agency in Wilmington.
Du Pont first tried the incentives program in Hobbs, N.M., where Conoco, the company's oil subsidiary, has an operation. Since it was begun in the early summer, 45 of the company's 65 homes in Hobbs have been sold, most within two months, said Anneta Cheney, associate broker with Newman & Company in Hobbs.
The Hobbs real estate market, which fluctuates with the oil-based local economy, has been depressed since 1982. Prices were "devastated" when many of the oil companies pulled out back then, Mrs. Cheney said.
Many of the companies simply told their employees to "slash prices," she said, with the result that values throughout the area went down.
Incentives are a much more community-minded approach, she said. "Activity breeds activity," said Mrs. Cheney. Home shoppers, Mrs. Cheney added, "might start out by looking at a corporate listing and end up buying a house with no special financing."
