HEADLINE: On the Stump, Lundine Looks to '94

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

 BODY:
Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine has been running hard. For the last four months, he has been scurrying about the state delivering six-a-day speeches in which he urges voters to return the Cuomo-Lundine team to Albany, to approve the environmental bond act, and to elect a Democratic majority to the State Senate.
But the true focus of Mr. Lundine's rigorous campaign is less the election this Nov. 6 than the one on Nov. 8, 1994. The Lieutenant Governor, who toils largely in anonymity, views this year's race as his last, best opportunity to become better known before the expected race to succeed Mr. Cuomo begins. 
 If Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Lundine are re-elected this year, and if Mr. Cuomo does not run for a fourth term, Mr. Lundine said that "it would be highly likely that I would run" for governor four years from now.
The 51-year-old Mr. Lundine has started that campaign early.
He has traveled the state more extensively than Mr. Cuomo and has concentrated much of his time in New York City, where most of the state's voters live and where the former Jamestown mayor is least known.
 
Raising Visibility
 "The first four years of being a competent insider were fine, but now I think I need to increase my visibility," said Mr. Lundine, whom Mr. Cuomo first selected as a running mate in 1986. "That's a difficult thing to do in a number-two job."
It also can be a difficult thing to do when you have Mr. Lundine's laid-back political persona and labored speaking style.
As politicians go, Mr. Lundine seems refreshingly earnest, self-effacing and devoid of conceit. He is also amiable and funny, especially when deriding his own profession. His imitation of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan is a particular crowd-pleaser.
But he has never been, and may never become, a stirring public speaker or the kind of leader who can control a room with his presence.
Last Thursday, for example, while trying to battle both a breakneck schedule in New York City and a lingering chest cold, Mr. Lundine was oratorically upstaged at a rally for the environmental bond act on the Brooklyn Heights promenade by 14-year-old Paula Rodriguez. Miss Rodriguez spoke poignantly of the obligation of one generation to preserve the environment for the next. Mr. Lundine read from his typed index cards: "I think we all like to drink clean water and we wouldn't want that threatened."
 
Speech Lessons
 Still, there have been signs of progress for the candidate, who takes occasional lessons from a speech coach. At a Nassau County Democratic dinner, Mr. Lundine scored with several ad libs and rhetorical uppercuts aimed at the Republican gubernatorial candidate, Pierre A. Rinfret.
"They nominated him for one reason," he said of Mr. Rinfret. "Because they thought he was rich and would pay for his campaign. The people of the state of New York got shortchanged."
Bradford W. O'Hearn, the director of communications for Suffolk County, said, "He still steps on his best lines, but it's a huge improvement.
"Nobody has ever said that Lundine didn't have qualifications or intelligence, or that he doesn't work hard. All they've said is that he's dull. You can cure dullness. You can't cure dumbness."
 
Political Advantages
 Mr. Lundine is smart enough to play to his political strengths: his 20 years of governmental experience, six of them as mayor of Jamestown followed by 10 as a congressman representing a heavily Republican district in the Southern Tier. And he plays up his relationship with Mr. Cuomo, who himself was lieutenant governor before becoming governor.
Mr. Cuomo originally selected Mr. Lundine to give his ticket geographic balance, but now includes him in an inner circle that is notoriously small.
The Governor has assigned Mr. Lundine to rejuvenate the state's housing efforts, develop its anti-drug strategy, and coordinate its ultimately unsuccessful bid for a federally financed supercollider, a huge and expensive instrument for experimental physics. Some observers of the executive branch believe Mr. Cuomo has given Mr. Lundine such perilous portfolios to distance himself from the consequences in case of failure.
 
The Cuomo Factor
 Mr. Lundine realizes that his closeness to Mr. Cuomo may prove to be both an asset and a liability if he runs for governor himself, especially if public discontent with Mr. Cuomo boils over during a third term.
"It helps me in the sense that there is tremendous respect for Mario Cuomo," he said. "Some of that will be transferable in that I've been a working, contributing right hand.
"But the difficulty is that you would be running with all the liabilities of incumbency without the name recognition."
The Lieutenant Governor said that while campaigning, he has sensed the anxiety and anger of the electorate about the economy and the perception that government has not been responsive. But he has enjoyed the political freedom allowed by the unfocused campaign waged by Mr. Rinfret and his running mate, George F. T. (Geff) Yancey Jr., whom Mr. Lundine has never met.
The lack of a competitive race has afforded Mr. Lundine the luxury of dedicating some of this campaign to his long-term political ambitions. He said his performance on the stump and in the Capitol have convinced him that he is prepared to serve as governor, whether in 1994 or in 1992 should Mr. Cuomo run for and win the Presidency.
On that delicate issue, Mr. Lundine spoke with characteristic candor. "I suppose emotionally I would like to see him do it," he said. "I think it would be good for the country. And it'd be good for me."

HEADLINE: A Soviet Agent? Harry Hopkins?

BYLINE: By Verne W. Newton; Verne W. Newton wrote and co-produced the documentary film "Harry Hopkins: At F.D.R.'s Side."

DATELINE: BETHESDA , Md.

 BODY:
The former K.G.B. agent Oleg Gordievsky seems intent on making the same muddle of history that Kremlin planners have made of the economy. He has captured headlines by claiming that Harry L. Hopkins, Franklin D. Roosevelt's trusted friend and adviser, was an "agent of major significance" of the Soviet Union.
What is infuriating is how the West ern press is aiding Mr. Gordievsky's efforts to craft a best-seller. In the excerpts of his book, "KGB: The Inside Story," I have seen, he never calls Mr. Hopkins a spy. Yet headline writers do. The book says, "Hopkins was an American patriot with no admiration for either the principle or the practice of the Communist state." Absurdly, the author also says, "Hopkins had been an unconscious rather than a conscious agent."
What deeds did Mr. Hopkins commit that may, in the popular mind, attach the monicker "spy" to him? According to Mr. Gordievsky, who was in knickers when Mr. Hopkins died in 1946, the former social worker advocated positions favored by Moscow. Under this definition, King George VI and Ronald Reagan could be considered Soviet agents.
More specifically, Mr. Hopkins is accused of influencing the U.S. to accept Soviet control over Poland, the Baltic states and Romania. I hope Mr. Gordievsky provided more accurate information than this to British intelligence during the two decades he was allegedly a double agent.
As Mr. Gordievsky hits the book promotion trail, perhaps he can explain why he did not identify Winston Churchill as a Soviet agent. After all, Mr. Churchill entered into the highly secret, ill-advised "percentages" agreement with Stalin in October 1944, conceding major portions of Central and Eastern Europe to Soviet domination. Such cynical "spheres of influence" were anathema to Mr. Roosevelt and Mr. Hopkins.
Mr. Hopkins refused to allow the White House to dispatch a cable to Mr. Churchill -- drafted by the Joint Chiefs and approved by the President -- out of fear that it might be construed as American approval for Churchill to enter into such arrangements with Stalin. In May 1945, Mr. Hopkins warned Stalin to his face that "the entire structure of world cooperation and relations with the Soviet Union would be destroyed" if he would not allow a free Poland to emerge from the ashes of war, as he had promised to do at Yalta.
Mr. Gordievsky indicts Mr. Hopkins for a post-Yalta euphoria. But as Sir John Martin, Mr. Churchill's principal private secretary, who was there told me, everyone, British and American alike, believed in the immediate aftermath of Yalta that they had just fashioned an enduring blueprint for peace and freedom. After five years of war, maybe they were entitled to a moment of euphoria.
Mr. Gordievsky is continuing the crusade started by Senator Joseph McCarthy of Wisconsin: half truths, innuendo, distortions, third-hand information -- all fused into a grand name-smearing indictment.
Like Senator McCarthy, if Mr. Gordievsky is to prosper he must make news. But the other revelations in his long-awaited book are rather thin gruel. He "solves" the insipid hunt for the so-called fifth man in the Kim Philby, Donald Maclean, Guy Burgess and Anthony Blunt spy circle by offering up an individual who confessed to being a Soviet agent nearly 25 years ago. And his salutation to Julius and Ethel Rosenberg as "dedicated and courageous Soviet agents" merely echoes the more authoritative voice of Nikita S. Khruschev.
Gen. George C. Marshall predicted that Mr. Hopkins's enormous contributions to his country would never be appreciated. But then, as that renowned savant Senator McCarthy warned us, General Marshall was always in Stalin's hip pocket.

HEADLINE: Even If Sanctions Are Lifted, Few Will Rush to South Africa

BYLINE: By JAMES S. HENRY; James S. Henry is a journalist, economist and lawyer who has written widely about the problems of developing countries.

 BODY:
FORCES now seem to have been set in motion for lifting economic sanctions against South Africa -- a prospect acceptable to a growing number of blacks and whites. The effect this will have on a badly weakened South African economy or on the future of American business there is far less clear.
Events in recent days, if the forces behind them are not reversed, are pointing the way toward lifting the sanctions as early as March, according to a senior United States State Department official. 
 Emergency rule in South Africa, under which some 30,000 political arrests were made during the last four years, was lifted Oct. 18 in the last province where it was still imposed. The ending of such rule was a key condition set by the United States Congress for removal of the American sanctions imposed in 1986 as an anti-apartheid tactic.
Another condition was the freeing of all political prisoners. South African President F. W. de Klerk has moved toward meeting that condition, as well. On Oct. 8, he and Nelson Mandela, leader of the African National Congress, agreed on a schedule to repatriate 20,000 exiles and free all remaining political prisoners by April.
A series of interviews suggest that it will be much later than next March before American businesses, which were slower than some Europeans to begin pulling out of South Africa, renew their South African ties. Several European countries have already begun to resume South African operations.
The first sanctions were imposed in the late 1970's, when the United Nations banned military sales to South Africa, and Sweden and Britain adopted limits on trade, investment and cultural and sporting contacts.
Although the United States moved more gradually, 26 states and 100 municipalities, in addition to the Federal Government, now have bans or limits on investment in or commerce with South Africa. With the 1986 Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act, Congress banned most new direct investment, air transport and imports of coal, steel, uranium, textiles and farm products from South Africa. A 1987 statute abolished tax credits for United States affiliates in South Africa, and a 1983 law instructs the United States to vote against lending by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
Combined with an economic slowdown and increased political unrest, these measures have effectively halted the growth of United States direct investment in South Africa, which had increased from $490 million in 1966 to $2.6 billion in 1981. Since then, 214 of 324 United States companies have withdrawn, and investment has dropped now to $711 million, even lower than South Africa's direct investment in the United States.
White leaders have generally said the sanctions hurt blacks and whites alike by slowing the economy. Many black leaders say the sanctions worked well. "The single most important factor in changing the Government has been the sanctions,"said Dr. Allan Boesak, a leader of the South African Council of Churches, referring to Pretoria's gradual relaxing of apartheid laws. But he said too that, if these changes are not reversed, the sanctions should be removed because the nation needs the economic boost.
UNITED STATES business spokesmen are generally cautious about being a part of that boost. Roger Crawford, an executive at Johnson & Johnson's South African affiliate, said most companies that left will be very slow to go back. "It's very difficult to re-enter a society like that one when you have built up trust over the years and then just pull the plug," he said.
Johnson & Johnson is now the third-largest American employer in South Africa, with a $60 million investment and 1,500 employees. "Lifting sanctions won't affect our investment until the economy recovers and there's growth in the hospital sector," Mr. Crawford said.
Ford Motor Company was once one of South Africa's largest American employers, with its 42 percent ownership of SAMCOR. SAMCOR had a $150 million assembly plant in Port Elizabeth that employed 6,500 workers, 70 percent black or Asian. In 1987, Ford gave 24 percent of SAMCOR's stock to a worker-owned trust and sold the rest to Anglo-American, South Africa's largest corporation. William P. Kelley of Ford said the company had no arrangement to buy back its position and has no plans to re-enter South Africa: "The market was not very profitable then, and you'd need much higher growth to make it attractive."
For Coca-Cola, returning to South Africa would create problems with its new partner, neighboring Swaziland. In the mid-'80's, Coca-Cola was the second-largest American employer in South Africa. Its $60 million concentrate and bottling company employed 4,765 workers, 85 percent of them black or Asian. It sold out in 1986 and now supplies South African bottlers from a new concentrate plant in Swaziland. Brandt Davis of Coke said, "Reinvesting in South Africa would require shutting down this plant, increasing black unemployment in Swaziland." He indicated a strong reluctance to leave Swaziland.
JOHN LORD, a spokesman for Mobil Oil, said: "We're gone; we're out." Mobil, once the fourth-largest American employer, with $400 million invested in 1,200 service stations and 2793 employees, sold out to Gencor Ltd., an Afrikaner-owned conglomerate, in June 1989. Under the sale terms, Mobil may not return for six years.
 Caltex Petroleum, a joint venture of Texaco and Chevron, is South Africa's largest remaining American employer, with a $400 million oil refinery and about 2,000 workers in Durban, half of whom are black or Asian. Bill Dunning, a Caltex vice president, chairs the group of 61 United States companies that observe the Sullivan Principles, a code of conduct that bars racial discrimination at the facilities of the signers. Dunning said that Caltex has been adversely affected by the American sanctions, especially the Rangel amendment that eliminates tax credits. But he also said that the company is not likely to increase its investment if the sanctions are lifted, because "we're sized correctly for the market."
Most executives of American companies see barriers to early reinvestment that have little to do with the sanctions. Like Mobil, some are contractually precluded. There is also what Steve Davis of the Investor Responsibility Research Council called the "hassle factor." Many companies are still smarting from lashings taken during angry board meetings. "They're not eager to go back before the dust clears," he said.
Probably even more significant is the fact that for many companies South Africa is not as attractive to investors as it once was. The economic picture, with or without American investment, is bleak for the short term.
Prof. Merton Dagut, chairman of the economics department at Johannesburg's University of the Witwatersrand, said that by the early 1980's South Africa's mining industries -- gold, platinum and diamonds, principally -- were already reaching their natural limits. Real growth declined from more than 5 percent a year in the '60's to less than 2 percent in the '80's. South Africa failed largely to develop export industries, for example, with the exception of arms. And apartheid created enormous social problems -- six million squatters, the world's most unequal wealth distribution, and high rates of disease, illiteracy and violence -- none of which helped business. "Given all these problems," Professor Dagut, said, "merely lifting sanctions wouldn't relieve the fears that many investors have about the future."
Growth has already been negative for more than a year. By American economic definitions, that constitutes a recession. And the Iraqi oil shock has badly depressed the price of gold, which South African economist Dr. Ronnie Bethlehem said "still drives the rest of the economy. "If it's below $400 an ounce you won't get much foreign investment even if sanctions are lifted. And if gold were $600, as in 1981, we'd be flooded with investment, even with sanctions."
According to Prof. Dagut, South Africa will contract even further: "The recession is likely to last deep into 1991. This is a social disaster: With the labor force growing at 3 percent, we need to grow at 5 percent just to stay even. Already a quarter of the work force is underemployed."
LONGER term, however, observers remain more optimistic. Caltex's Bill Dunning said, "South Africa has an exceptionally bright future; the only question is when." Joseph LaBonte, the former chief executive of Reebok, has been recruiting Fortune 100 C.E.O.'s whose companies have never invested in South Africa to explore opportunities with the African National Congress leadership. According to Mr. LaBonte, "More than half the Fortune 100 have never invested in South Africa. The country needs whole new industries to serve people -- housing, training, medical care, education. So tomorrow's foreign investors may be different, but that's not a bad thing."
Indeed, South Africa could eventually lure investors again. With 6 percent of sub-Saharan Africa's population, South Africa produces half its industrial output. In addition to minerals, it has many industries with growth potential, including tourism, medicine, wine, fruit, fishing and financial services. Its athletes, musicians, actors and writers are among the best in the third world. And at least in part because of the sanctions, it has a modest foreign debt, no dependence on foreign aid and a small budget deficit.
So, given political stability, the economic promise is there. As one economist joked, "Maybe we should have imposed sanctions on the rest of the third world."
 
 
SOME SAY SANCTIONS ARE STILL NEEDED
ALTHOUGH more and more black South Africans are coming to the view that economic sanctions imposed against their country should soon be lifted, the belief is far from unanimous.
Some anti-apartheid activists in the United States and some members of Congress remain concerned that removing the sanctions could reverse the progress made in recent months toward dismantling or weakening South Africa's apartheid laws.
Anne Griffin of Transafrica, an anti-apartheid lobbying group in the United States, said in an interview that South African President F. W. de Klerk "should be happy sanctions haven't been increased." Representative Howard Wolpe, a Michigan Democrat, said, "There still are no real negotiations going on yet. De Klerk needs sanctions to keep people serious."
So far, the official position of the African National Congress with regard to the sanctions remains unchanged. Tito Mboweni, of its Department of Economic Policy, said, "We're still supporting them. The political process is very uncertain."
But other apartheid opponents have grown impatient.
Halton Cheadle, a lawyer for COSATU, the country's largest union federation, said only a bare majority of its members favor sanctions and that SACTU, the third-largest union, is definitely opposed. The economy is in terrible shape, and the political change seems clearly irreversible, he said. Mr. Cheadle is in favor of easing the sanctions. Prof. Pieter LeRoux, a Capetown University economist who helped draft the A.N.C.'s latest economic-policy statement, agreed. "Sanctions did their job, but the case against lifting them now is very weak. If de Klerk waivered, you could always reimpose sanctions."
Last May, Anglican Bishop Desmond Tutu also supported permitting selective investments in housing and education, and in September he said that the time for lifting sanctions is approaching.
 Dr. Allan Boesak, a leader of the South African Council of Churches, said that "the whole question is under discussion right now. My own view is that it may be time to lift cultural sanctions, but economic sanctions should stay on until there are elections for a constituent assembly."
Denis Beckett, a leading South African journalist, said, however, that waiting for such elections "could take years. Most people feel its just plain stupid" to keep the sanctions in place. "But the people are out in front of the A.N.C. on this issue. The problem is, the A.N.C. doesn't have many other bargaining chips."

HEADLINE: Consumers Found Gloomier

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Confidence among consumers sank this month to its weakest level since the nation struggled through a recession eight years ago, a research group said Friday.
In addition, more and more Americans expect the economy to get worse, the Conference Board said. 
 The Consumer Confidence Index plunged 24 points in October, the biggest one-month drop since the index began more than 20 years ago. The October reading was 61.3, a level not seen since the 16-month recession of 1981-82, the board said.
Consumer spending accounts for about two-thirds of the gross national product, so a drop in confidence ripples through the economy.
The index, based on a 1985 base of 100, was at 101.7 in July, before Iraq invaded Kuwait and upset world financial markets.
Buying plans have been curtailed, people expressed difficulty finding jobs and 30 percent of those surveyed believe business conditions will worsen in the next six months, the board said. Last month only 20 percent said they expected conditions to worsen.
In October there was a sharp drop in the number of consumers who consider current business conditions good and a big increase in those who say they are bad, the board said.
The survey found 15 percent of people thought jobs were plentiful, compared with 30 percent who said they were hard to get. More than 35 percent of respondents fear there will be fewer jobs in the immediate future.
The board said only 6.2 percent of consumers plan to buy a car in the next six months, down from the 7.8 percent who said in September that they were planning an auto purchase.
The survey was conducted among 5,000 households nationwide and has a margin of error of three percentage points.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING

BYLINE: By KIM FOLTZ

 BODY:
A COMMERCIAL version of the hit television show "America's Funniest Home Videos" has been created by J. Walter Thompson for its new client Toys "R" Us.
The $15 million campaign, which begins tonight, features dozens of candid shots of children -- and adults -- playing with toys. The results are often amusing and a fascinating interpretation of the company's long-time theme, "I don't want to grow up; I'm a Toys "R" Us kid." 
 One spot focuses primarily on adults, with people trying, and failing, to use the simplest toys. A man throws a small wooden glider and it immediately crashes at his feet, whereupon a disdainful child chases after him and kicks him in the shins. Badminton players get entangled in their net. And a woman riding a tiny tricycle pedals into a swimming pool. There also are, of course, the obligatory shots of hopelessly inept adults struggling with Hula-Hoops.
What makes these commercials powerful is watching people make fools of themselves.
In these commercials, the scenes were not staged. The agency cast about 200 non-actors, whom it found by advertising in local newspapers in the Long Island resort town of East Hampton. Children and adults picked their toys and set out to have a little fun. The goings-on were filmed by cameramen using telephoto lenses.
"We had to make sure that people weren't aware they were being photographed," said Linda Kaplan, a group creative director at the agency. "Otherwise they would have been too self-conscious to have fun."
The agency also did not tell people what to do or interfere once the action began. While the strategy paid off with some wonderful candid footage, it also made for a long, tedious production. "We filmed people for hours when essentially nothing interesting was happening," Ms. Kaplan said.
After the two weeks of shooting for the commercial, many of the toys used were donated to children's hospitals and orphanages.
This is Thompson's second go-around with Toys "R" Us. The agency lost the account six years ago and won it back in March.
The television campaign is not intended to sell particular toys, said Ernie Speranza, the vice president of marketing and advertising at Toys "R" Us Inc., based in Paramus, N.J. "We leave that to the individual manufacturers." he added. "We want to create a brand-name image for the store as a fun place to go shopping for toys."
With annual sales of about $5 billion, Toys "R" Us has a commanding lead in the $15 billion toy market, Mr. Speranza said.
The company intends to use the commercials in other parts of the world. Toys "R" Us has been aggressively expanding in Europe and East Asia and plans to have 100 stores overseas by the end of this year.
Toys "R" Us has also begun its largest print campaign, in which some popular items like Nintendo video games and Teen-age Mutant Ninja Turtle toys are spotlighted. The company figures that when times get tough economically, it is the best time to take business from competitors.

HEADLINE: Speaking About Spending Less, Cuomo Has Spent More

SERIES: LAST OF A SERIES OF ARTICLES ON MARIO M. CUOMO'S RECORD AS NEW YORK'S GOVERNOR.

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct 28

 BODY:
Early in his first term, when the state was faced with a debilitating budget deficit, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo adopted the slogan, "We must learn to do more with less." He recited it to anyone who would listen: to commissioners hoping to expand their agencies, to lawmakers looking to extend the state's largess, even to hospital workers seeking higher pay.
"We must not in this state fall victim to the doctrine that the only way to make progress is to spend massively," Mr. Cuomo said at the opening the 1984 legislative session. "We must find new opportunities to domore with less." 
 As Mr. Cuomo seeks a third term, he is once again faced with an unnervingly large budget shortfall that is likely to grow worse. The Governor no longer speaks stirringly about doing more with less. Instead, he finds himself defending the growth in state spending during the last eight years, when the state's credit rating dropped to the lowest ever and state spending almost doubled.
"It doesn't seem that he could ever see if he could do more with less because he never had less," said Steven D. Gold, director ofthe State University of New York's Center for the Study of the States.
In the mid-1980's, when the New York economy was expanding at an almost giddy rate, it was easy for state government to be generous and for Mr. Cuomo to maintain the stance of a fiscal conservative. So fast did the state's wealth grow in the mid-1980's that in 1987 the Legislature enacted a four-year income-tax cut, which Mr. Cuomo opposed at the time but claimed credit for later. Still the state appeared to be flush.
 
Good Times Gone to Bad
 But when the economy began to contract, the state's spending quickly became unaffordable. Increasingly, the Cuomo adminstration resorted to borrowing and accounting tricks to pay its bills, and many critics asserted that the Governor refused to make the cuts needed to bring spending in line.
"You can really be very critical of the state in terms of its refusal to bite the bullet on balancing its budget," said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group financed by businesses.
Since Mr. Cuomo took office eight years ago, state spending has increased 92.6 percent, or an average of 8.5 percent a year, to $50 billion. Adjusted for inflation, the increase is 22 percent, meaning that state spending in constant dollars has grown by about a fifth.
Cuomo administration officials justify the growth as a reasonable response to the state's ever-expanding social needs. "Important efforts were made to increase services in areas where they were vitally needed," said the Governor's budget director, Dall W. Forsythe, "like AIDS, Medicaid, criminal justice." Cuomo administration officials also note that Federal aid has declined over the last eight years.
In response to assertions that his has been a big-spending administration, Mr. Cuomo often notes that the rate of spending growth has actually been lower than in many other states.
Figures from the National Association of State Budget Officers show that in the last eight years, general fund spending, which does not include Federal grants or capital projects, increased an average of 7 percent a year in New York. The average increase for all Northeastern states was 7.5 percent a year, and for large industrial states, 8 percent a year.
But critics contend that the comparisons are misleading. New York State spending was already so high when Mr. Cuomo took office, they say, that even though other states have increased their budgets more quickly, New York still far outspends them.
 
Deteriorating Fiscal Condition
 "The New England states and New Jersey had big increases during this period, but they started much, much lower," Mr. Gold said. Last year, according to the Census Bureau, per capita state spending in New York -- $2,554 -- was 35 percent higher than the national average.
In good times, the spending growth was relatively easy to sustain, and despite the increases, spending as a percentage of the state's wealth has remained fairly constant during Cuomo's tenure. It amounted to roughly 9 percent of personal income in the state in 1983, according to figures compiled by the Citizens Budget Commission, and it amounts to roughly 9 percent today.
Over the last two years, however, as the economy has slowed, New York's fiscal condition has deteriorated by almost every measure. The state's long-term or accumulated deficit has grown to more than $5 billion, a record. Budget shortfalls have seemed chronic, and the state has increasingly come to depend on reserves and refinancing to pay its bills.
Last year, in a reflection of the state's weakening finances, its credit rating declined to the lowest in its history and the third lowest in the nation.
 
Tough Problems and Solutions
 Critics lay much of the blame at the Governor's door. The Governor, they contend, should have responded to the state's dramatic revenue shortfalls with equally dramatic spending cuts. But instead, they assert, he drained the state's reserves and relied on nonrecurring revenues.
"We didn't see a state that was trying to dig itself out of a hole," said Cynthia Green, a senior analyst at the Citizens Budget Commission. "We saw a state that basically didn't stop digging."
Even the Governor has acknowledged recently that the state, having used up most of its reserves, is heading for grim times. "The truth is we're going to have a difficult time with finances," he said in a recent interview.
But even as the state's fiscal condition continues to decline, Mr. Cuomo defends his record of the last few years. He takes credit, for example, for the historic agreement last spring under which the state is finally supposed to pay off its $5 billion deficit over the next 30 years. And he asserts that his administration has done far better than those of other states.
 
Cutting the Top Income-Tax Rate
 Despite hard times, Mr. Cuomo often notes, New York has not raised its income or sales taxes. And whenever possible, the Governor mentions that New York's top income-tax rate, which has dropped from 14 percent to almost 7.9 percent in the last eight years, is the lowest in three decades.
"We are getting more competitive by not raising our income and sales taxes," the Governor said recently.
But New York has raised just about every other tax imaginable in Mr. Cuomo's tenure, including those on alcohol, petroleum products, soda, hotel rooms and corporations. Both this year and last, the Governor signed record tax increases that totaled almost $3 billion. And in the spring, he successfully pressed for a deferral of the last year of the state's income-tax cut, which would have reduced the state's top income-tax rate to 7 percent.
Administration officials insist that during the Governor's tenure, cuts in state income taxes have equaled increases in other state taxes. But figures compiled by Mr. Gold of the State University show that state taxes as a proportion of personal income has risen slightly in the Cuomo years, from $7.30 for each $100 of personal income earned in the state in 1983 to $7.55 in 1989.
 
Progress of Good Times Ignored?
 Per capita, New Yorkers pay some of the highest state taxes in the country today, just as they did when Mr. Cuomo took office. The state's per capita tax burden -- $1,480 -- was the sixth highest in the country last year, according to the Census Bureau.
While acknowledging the state's fiscal problems, Cuomo administration officials complain that many of the administration's achievements have been ignored in the economic downturn.
They note, for example, that the Governor inherited a large budget deficit in 1983, but managed to balance the budget within a few years. For a time, he even succeeded in raising the state's credit rating. And the state finally adopted generally accepted accounting principles, which forced it to keep track of how much it was spending.
"I think that what we lose in these discussions is the sense of the progress that was made in good times," the Governor's budget director, Mr. Forsythe, said.

HEADLINE: CONGRESS ADJOURNS: ADVANTAGE: DEMOCRATS;
Bush Loses a Game, But Stays in Match

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28

 BODY:
As the 101st Congress adjourned early this morning, Democrats were thanking no one more than George Bush himself for a sudden improvement of their political fortunes.
 The deficit-reduction package that the President initiated clearly inflicted more political damage on Republicans than Democrats in the short run, which almost certainly includes the eight days between now and the Nov. 6 elections. 
 But left open is whether Democrats would gain as much politically in the long run and, perhaps more importantly, whether this budget deal was Washington's first step into a new and more realistic era of budget policy.
 
Political Damage Is Real
 President Bush's decision to abandon his "no new taxes" stance and accept the higher taxes included in the budget package had twin political effects. It divided his own party in a battle over whether taxes should rise and it unified the normally fractious Democrats, who found themselves on the much more appealing political ground of whom to tax rather than whether to tax.
Senior Democrats said they could barely believe that the Administration had allowed the final debate to revolve around whether the wealthy or everyone else should pay the bill. Faced with what the Democrats hope will be a newly effective message of economic fairness, Republicans denounce it as demagoguery. Perhaps so. But the political damage to Republicans is real enough.
Mr. Bush has taken a precipitous tumble in public opinion polls. Only 48 percent of Americans approve of his handling of his job according to Newsweek's latest survey, of 753 adults. That is the low point of his Presidency.
Two months ago, buoyed by Mr. Bush's showdown with Saddam Hussein of Iraq, Republicans actually thought they might defy the normal law of politics and pick up seats at the middle of the Presidential term, or at least lose very few. Now they are talking about minimizing their losses.
 
A General Public Restlessness
 While much of this decline is clearly a restlessness in the public caused by a deteriorating economy, Mr. Bush's missteps and reversals in the budget debate have exacerbated his problems, and his party's.
Paul Tully, political director of the Democratic National Committee, said this was the only time he could find in modern political history when the electoral tide has completely reversed so close to the voting.
It is also the first time in more than a decade that Democrats have had the clear upper hand in an argument over taxes and the economy. But that raises additional questions.
Have the Democrats acquired an advantage that will carry into the next Congress and the 1992 Presidential race? Or will Mr. Bush be able, as he attempted this weekend, to reassert the Republican posture as the more dependable party for keeping down taxes? Moreover, if Republicans under fire are retreating to this tried and true position, does that damage the hopes for further deficit reduction?
While the promise of low taxes is appealing to the Republican Party's traditional constituency, it has also been crucial in holding white ethnic voters in the Republican coalition, a bloc that has already been held together longer at the Presidential level than history would suggest was possible. So it was no small matter when Mr. Bush said in a campaign appearance in Hawaii on Saturday that the deficit package was a one-shot deal. From here on, he said, he was "absolutely going to hold the line on taxes."
 
The Fairness Predicament
 Even more politically explosive is the question, skirted in this deficit-reduction agreement, of whether the country can afford the steadily rising costs of benefits for health and retirement of millions of realtively well-to-do people.
Where does the theme of fairness take Democrats in any serious discussion of fiscal policy? So far the only thing they have promised is to revive in the next Congress their proposal for a surtax on the rich, a levy that produces good headlines but little money. Will Democrats embrace higher taxes or limits on benefits for affluent Social Security recipients?
The fairness issue seems to hold great promise for them while Republicans are mishandling it, but exactly the same thing was true of the abortion issue a year ago. That matter, which appeared to be a turning-point question in many elections, has now lost at least some of its punch as candidates have learned to deal with it effectively.
Democratic leaders concede, too, that their unity was in good measure a fortunate byproduct of events. Sustaining it will not be easy. After all, it was only parliamentary maneuvering by the Democratic leadership in the Senate that prevented an alliance of Democrats and Republicans from cutting capital gains taxes, the very sort of reduction that, when sought by President Bush, forms Exhibit A in the Democratic case that Mr. Bush favors the wealthy.
Even in the final budget votes, some Democrats, particulary those from New Jersey and Massachusetts, defected because of the volatile environment in their states over tax increases.
When Newsweek asked its cross-section of Americans last week whether they thought President Bush was losing political influence, two-thirds replied yes.
That is a deep political hole to climb out of, but no deeper than the one overcome by Ronald Reagan, who at this point in his Presidency was even lower in the surveys as the country struggled through the recession of 1982.
The White House was understandably frustrated that Mr. Bush had taken such a political pummeling for his willingess to assemble the first serious package to restrain the deficit.
But it may not be beyond salvaging. It is still possible that with some repair work by the White House and a soon-to-be-organized re-election campaign, Mr. Bush will gain credit for doing "the right thing" on the deficit, as one of his lieutenants put it.
"I must say I think it's a measure of a person when they take the heat he's taken over this budget," said Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader. "He could have cashed in last week and said, 'We'll pull the plug and blame the Congress.' We talked about it. He said no."

HEADLINE: New York City's Budget Gap Is Even Worse Than It Looks

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
New York City has a budget of more than $28 billion and a projected gap in it for the coming fiscal year of perhaps $2 billion -- in other words, it is short one dollar for every 14. But the problem is really more severe, because the budget over which the city has full control is closer to $12 billion, and that means it is short one dollar for every six.
That little-understood reality, compounded by a stagnant economy and uncertainties about the cost of wage settlements, is why the city's current troubles have evoked dire threats of thousands of layoffs and the worst cuts in city services since the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's. 
 The roughly $12 billion is what remains after the city pays its share of welfare and Medicaid costs, after it pays for pensions of workers long retired and for debt service on bonds long issued, and after it discounts state and Federal aid over which it has little control.
 
Balance Required by Law
 Adding to the administration's problems are wage settlements. A spokesman for one of two large municipal unions said yesterday that the unions, which represent more than 150,000 workers, planned to break off stalled talks with the city. [Page B1.]
Mayor David N. Dinkins, besieged by violent crimes this summer, has vowed to spare the criminal-justice system from deep cuts. But protecting the $2 billion in annual costs for the police, jails and the court system would give the Mayor even less room to maneuver, leaving a real budget of maybe $10 billion in which to find cuts or new revenues, fiscal experts say.
Keeping that budget in balance -- as required by law -- will require managerial and political choices about the goals the city values most and how to achieve them.
"The bad news is you're left with awful service reductions that seem repetitive and almost not even that shocking anymore -- firehouses being closed, potholes reappearing," said Anthony Shorris, a former City Finance Commissioner.
"But the good news is that the components of the budget are so clear, and the law is so clear, that the Mayor is forced to balance the budget, and he will. The interesting question is not whether the budget is balanced, because, of course, it will be. The real question is how it will be done."
Trimming anything like $2 billion from the remaining programs would heavily damage the core of municipal services -- from garbage collection to road repair, fire protection, parks maintenance, libraries and schools. The Dinkins administration has warned that 25,000 to 35,000 layoffs may be necessary if the worst comes to pass.
Even assuming a large tax increase next spring -- on top of the largest annual tax rises in state and city history to balance the current budget -- the cuts would be severe. Since the city would not want to lay off those workers whose salaries are borne partly by state and Federal aid, like social service caseworkers, or those who produce money, like tax auditors, the cuts would fall heaviest on basic services like sanitation.
That is why virtually no one wants the worst to happen. And the administration says it need not if labor unions with whom it is bargaining do not seek more than the 1.5 percent wage increase already accounted for in the city's budget.
New York City has the fourth largest government budget in the nation, after the Federal Government, California and New York State. But because of the laws and oversight rules that are a legacy of its brush with bankruptcy 15 years ago, it must keep its books balanced as strictly as those of a business.
 
Unlike a Business
 On the other hand, the enterprise that is New York is nothing like a business. It does not seek to earn a profit. Political realities, bureaucratic intertia and sheer size make it unable or unwilling to make the choices and to exact the efficiencies that a business can.
Making such choices seemed especially unpalatable, even uneccesary, in the decade-long boom in the city's economy that is now ending. In the administration of Edward I. Koch, about 80,000 workers were added to the labor force, which now numbers more than 300,000. The additions were presented as a sign of the city's recovery and a promise of better services.
But many of the new workers were hired to perform services that the city had little choice but to provide. For example, more than 5,000 of the net increase of nearly 8,000 workers planned for this year were for jobs required by law or regulation, over half of them in the Board of Education and social-service agencies. Those plans themselves were scaled back after a partial hiring freeze imposed as part of the latest retrenchment.
More than 1,500 of the new workers were for garbage recycling programs, to help save room in the city's dwindling dump, and for jails, to control an inmate population that has tripled to more than 20,000 in the last decade. About 2,000 others were to work in revenue-raising or cost-saving jobs.
 
Greater Productivity Needed
 Besides the possibility of layoffs, Mr. Dinkins's Budget Director, Philip R. Michael, has warned that the city may have to cut 15,000 to 18,000 jobs through attrition. The city loses about that many workers each year to resignations and retirement, but because about half of those workers perform mandated services, the city cannot simply let all the positions fall vacant.
But even senior city officials now acknowledge that more scrutiny must be given to whether so many workers are needed, even if the functions they perform are required. That means getting more output from each worker, and that is perhaps the biggest challenge for an organization as sprawling as the city.
"There is less latitude in the budget than the public would imagine," said Henry J. Stern, the former Parks and Recreation Commissioner who is now president of the Citizens Union, a private watchdog group. "But there are a lot of ways they can cut. People are underused. But the problem is doing things sensibly.
"If the Chase Manhattan Bank had to cut 5,000 workers, they'd reduce middle managers and everyone," Mr. Stern said. "If the city had to do it, they'd fire all the tellers and close the bank at 1 o'clock in the afternoon," partly because of legal requirements that the least senior workers in each category be laid off first.
 
Cuts in Staff Resisted
 In the Koch years the city made a breakthrough in productivity by reducing the number of workers on a garbage truck from three to two. But it failed to achieve other gains of similar scope, and even now proposals for one-worker garbage trucks or one-officer police patrol cars meet with stiff political and union resistance.
At the same time, current and former city officials say, many newly appointed commissioners in the Dinkins administration, some from out of town, do not yet know the nooks and crannies of their agencies well enough to find likely spots for trims.
Others, including Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez and Fire Commissioner Carlos A. Rivera, have publicly resisted Mr. Dinkins's calls to meet specific percentage targets for trims to close a budget gap of at least $300 million in the fiscal year that ends June 30 and $1.5 billion in the next year.
The dynamics are difficult and little-understood. Mr. Fernandez maintained that asking for $94 million in cuts from the Board of Education was asking his agency for more than its share. But the board accounts for one-fourth of the entire city budget and has often been spared cuts in recent years when other agencies have made them. Even now, it has been asked to make cuts of 2 percent, half those asked of most other agencies.
 
Most of Budget Essential
 City budget officials like to say that about 70 cents of every dollar in city revenues is effectively spoken for by the time it arrives, just to carry out functions either required or considered vital.
Given that and expected shortfalls in tax revenues, the challenge is to do as much with less. Unlike a business, the city cannot easily close divisions or shed functions, especially since the probable buyer of last resort -- the state, which assumed the cost of the City University system, the courts and drug treatement in the crisis of the 70's -- is now in the midst of its own severe fiscal troubles.
But there are options, big and small. Mr. Stern said it used to cost the city $1 million a year to operate golf courses and driving ranges. Now it has let them to concessionaires, who give the city $1 million to $2 million a year in revenue.
Mr. Stern's successor as Parks Commissioner, Betsy Gotbaum, said she was seeking similar opportunities.
"Whatever the merits of socialism," Mr. Stern said, "it is no way to run a golf course."

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 29, 1990

SECTION: Section B; Page 7; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 2888 words

HEADLINE: Talk of Government Being Out to Get Blacks Falls on More Attentive Ears

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE

 BODY:
Until his brother became yet another black man to die of AIDS, Keith Brown never imagined that a disease so devastating would hit so close to home. Searching for an explanation, he found himself drawn to one his brother had long embraced but that Mr. Brown used to reject: that AIDS was invented by racist conspirators to kill blacks.
"Because of who's being devastated the most, and growing up in the U.S. and knowing the history of slavery and racism in this country," Mr. Brown said, "you can't be black and not feel that AIDS is some kind of experiment, some kind of plot to hit undesirable minority populations." Mr. Brown, 30 years old, virtually apologized for his belief, saying, "I hope I don't sound too radical, because I'm not." 
 "I don't want to believe that AIDS is some kind of Government plot," he said. Then, pausing, he added: "But I guess I do. I do believe it."
Mr. Brown is one of a large and perhaps growing number of blacks turning to racial conspiracy theories to explain black America's ills. The theories vary widely, as do their believability, the backgrounds of the blacks who support them and the degree of support each receives.
 
Suspicion From Distrust
 The startling theory that AIDS is a weapon of racial warfare is the one with the fewest adherents. A more popular theory is that white government leaders play a pivotal role in the drug crisis by deliberately making drugs easily available in black neighborhoods. And the theory with the most support is that white prosecutors conspire to bring groundless charges against black elected officials.
To some black officials, psychologists and scholars, such theories reflect the anger and suspicion bred by persisting racial inequality. In addition, some say, the theories have practical consequences in the barriers they pose to fighting AIDS and drugs.
Some who embrace the theories are political militants. Others, like Mr. Brown, are soft-spoken moderates. While some blacks espouse the theories as firm convictions, others talk of them in tones of mild suspicion, as possibilities they are willing neither to embrace nor dismiss.
While black Americans have often suspected whites of conspiring against them -- and while those suspicions have at times been justified -- the theories about AIDS are new. And many say they believe the level of suspicion has never been higher. In more than 50 interviews, black public officials, professors, doctors, students, public-health workers and average citizens said that serious discussion of racial plots is now common, springing from an American soil rich in racial distrust.
 
Statistics Paint Divided Portrait
 In a separate sounding, a New York Times/WCBS-TV News poll in New York City found that 10 percent of blacks said the AIDS virus was "deliberately created in a laboratory in order to infect black people." Another 19 percent said that theory might possibly be true, and 63 percent said it was almost certainly not true. Of the whites polled, only 1 percent said it was true, 4 percent said it was possibly true and 91 percent said it was almost certainly not true. The rest had no opinion.
A quarter of the blacks polled said that the government "deliberately makes sure that drugs are easily available in poor black neighborhoods in order to harm black people." A third said that might possibly be true, and a third said it was almost certainly not true. Of the whites polled, 4 percent said it was true, 12 percent said it was possibly true, and 75 percent said it was almost certainly not true.
Thirty-two percent of the blacks polled said "the government deliberately singles out and investigates black elected officials in order to discredit them in a way it doesn't do with white officials." Forty-five percent said this might possibly be true, and 16 percent said it almost certainly was not true. Of the whites, only 6 percent said it was true, and 28 percent said it was possibly true. Fifty-seven percent of whites said that theory was almost certainly not true.
The telephone poll of 1,047 adults throughout the city, including 408 blacks and 484 whites, was conducted from June 17 through 20. The margin of sampling error for blacks was plus or minus five percentage points; for whites, it was plus or minus four percentage points.
 
Reflecting Frustration, Neglect
 "The theory that AIDS and drugs are part of a white conspiracy to commit genocide or to damage the black community -- that's popping up in questions more and more," said Dr. Alvin Poussaint, the Harvard psychiatrist, who said he did not believe in the theories but saw them as a measure of frustration and neglect.
"I've heard it discussed among middle-class blacks who wouldn't in any sense be considered militant," he said. "It's spinning around out there."
Presented with the poll results, Dr. Poussaint said that the number of blacks who entertained the theory of AIDS as biological warfare was dismaying. "What do they think?" he said, "that there's a Nazi regime?"
Many observers agree that the figures point toward sores on the body politic. "It is a danger to America to have a large group of its citizens believe that its government is in a conspiracy to eliminate them," said Andrew Cooper, publisher of The City Sun, a black newspaper based in Brooklyn.
 
Feeling Powerless
 But besides their symbolic significance, the theories also have practical consequences. Public-health workers say that the discussion of AIDS as a plot against blacks has eroded the credibility of AIDS prevention campaigns and has made some blacks suspicious of AIDS tests and treatments.
"If I had as many people out there pushing the combat against AIDS as I have pushing the notion that it's a white man's plot, we would be winning the battle," said Dr. Beny J. Primm, a black official in the United States Department of Health and Human Services, who was a member of President Reagan's Commission on AIDS.
In addition, some blacks worry that talk of white plots may undermine struggles outside the realm of AIDS, including those for jobs and education. In assigning so much power to white society, they say, the theories have the potential to make blacks think of themselves as powerless victims.
"If you actually believe that the society in which you live is feeding AIDS and drugs to you, to eliminate you, you're not going to see your own possibilities in that society," said Shelby Steele, a professor of English at San Jose State University. "You're not going to make the effort to move into the American mainstream. It's a profoundly destructive belief."
That view is not universal. Some black officials, while agreeing that a significant number of blacks are considering the conspiracy theories, say the suspicion about AIDS and drugs could have positive effects. "If you think of yourself as a victim, it doesn't necessarily mean you're going to be passive about it," said Dr. Billy E. Jones, the New York City Mental Health Commissioner. Dr. Jones said blacks who believe whites are trying to kill them with AIDS or drugs might become more likely to use condoms or to resist pushers.
 
The Forms
 
From Statistics To Intuitions
By their nature, conspiracy theories and the evidence to support them take many shapes. Some people cite what they call damning dates and documents, while others say proof is elusive. Some say government agencies are behind the plots; others call them the acts of racists outside the government. Sometimes the unnamed conspirators are simply known as "they."
Some blacks say the conspiracy theories are given credence by an American past of real plots against blacks, ranging from slavery to the Federal Bureau of Investigation's infiltration of civil rights groups. Many blacks recall the Tuskegee, Ala., syphilis study in which the Government withheld treatment from 399 black men from 1932 to 1972 to observe the progress of the disease.
Mr. Brown said his parents recently told him that a distant relative was among the Tuskegee blacks who went untreated. "When I heard that, it blew my mind," he said.
In addition, many say the conspiracy theories are lent credence by current bleaknesses: statistics that show more black men in prison than in college, studies that show the mortality rate higher in Harlem than in Bangladesh, figures that indicate AIDS is spreading most rapidly among minorities. While blacks are 12 percent of the population at large, for instance, they account for 30 percent of the nation's 152,000 AIDS cases to date, according to the Federal Centers for Disease Control.
 
Known Simply as 'The Plan'
 Talk of white conspiracy against blacks can take almost limitless forms. For example, William Raspberry, a black columnist for The Washington Post, whose work is widely syndicated, wrote last December: "Let me make a speech before a black audience and sometime during the Q & A someone is certain to ask if I believe there is a conspiracy against black Americans. It doesn't matter whether the subject is drugs or joblessness, school failure or teen pregnancy, politics or immigration. I can count on hearing some version of the conspiracy question." In Chicago, an aide to former Mayor Eugene Sawyer was fired last year after arguing that Jewish doctors were injecting black babies with AIDS. In Washington, talk of concerted white action to discredit and destroy blacks is so common it has long been known simply as "The Plan."
The talk of white conspiracy reached a crescendo in Washington during the drug and perjury trial of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., who was lured into a hotel room and given crack as part of an F.B.I. sting. Mr. Barry was convicted on one misdemeanor charge of cocaine possession, and sentenced to six months in prison.
 
The Settings
 
From Talk Shows To Q & A's
The charge that the AIDS and drug epidemics are white plots against blacks emerges in a variety of settings. Ronald Johnson, director of the Minority Task Force on AIDS, a private AIDS education group in New York City, said he is asked whether AIDS is a form of germ warfare in nearly every presentation he gives to a black audience.
"Invariably, someone will say that the virus was planted by the Government or the C.I.A. or by white people," he said. "This is not just low-income people, but middle class, working class, professionals -- everybody."
Mark Riley, a talk show host on WLIB radio in New York, whose audience is predominantly black, said callers often ask about conspiracies regarding AIDS and crack. "There are people who believe there's a conspiracy of neglect," he said. "But there are also a lot of people who believe the twin epidemics of AIDS and crack are the product of an active white conspiracy."
Mr. Riley described himself as "neutral" about the theories. "As an African-American who knows something about our history, I can't rule out conspiracy as regards AIDS or crack," he said. "A government plan, a scientific plan, a scientific plan that was condoned by government: any number of permutations are possible."
 
'A Means to Supress Blacks'
 Sometimes the charge takes the form of matter-of-fact reporting. "Blacks Intentionally Infected," announced a banner headline last year in The Los Angeles Sentinel, a black-owned newspaper. The paper's series reported, "the virus was made in an American military lab as a means to suppress blacks."
On other occasions, the talk of AIDS conspiracies has taken the form of idle talk show chitchat. Appearing on "The Arsenio Hall Show," Kool Moe Dee, a rap musician, said that AIDS was part of a "clean-up America campaign" intended to hit "target markets" of homosexuals and racial minorities.
"I think they definitely have the cure already and I think it was definitely created by some sick person," he said.
Mr. Hall treated the conversation as just another celebrity interview. "That's interesting," he said.
 
AIDS as Population Control?
 Last year, two members of the black studies department at the City College of New York spoke of AIDS as a white conspiracy in an appearance on the "Geraldo" show. "AIDS coming out of a laboratory and finding itself localized in certain populations certainly has to be looked at as part of a conspiratorial process," said Prof. Leonard Jeffries, the department chairman.
A visit to one of Professor Jeffries's classes indicates that many of his students share his views. After one class, a reporter talked to 10 black students, all of whom argued that AIDS and crack were part of a white conspiracy. They gave a variety of explanations for their views.
Dominique Bachemin, 20, offered impossible numbers in arguing that AIDS was created as a method of population control. "During the Carter Administration, there was a document put out that said by the year 2,000, one hundred billion Africans had to be destroyed," she said.
By contrast, another student, Mark Russell, 24, argued that the motive for an AIDS plot was simply economic, rooted in America's switch to a postindustrial economy. "I think it's a conspiracy because it's very strange that all the sudden this disease popped up out of nowhere and it hits populations that the government considers undesirable," he said.
 
'One Way of Getting Rid of Us'
 "There's no more need for black labor," he said. "So, you know, this is one way of getting rid of us."
In the case of AIDS, the talk of conspiracy has been fueled by the nature of the disease itself: its mysterious origins and the eerie way it has seemed capable of singling out populations. For that reason, AIDS conspiracy theories once circulated among white homosexuals, too, though gay groups rarely speak of them now.
While the discussion of AIDS as a white conspiracy against blacks is new, the charge that crack was invented to hurt blacks echoes debates from the 1960's over earlier drug epidemics. Essentially, the argument went like this: the authorities had little concern about combatting illegal drug use as long as it existed in predominantly black inner-city neighborhoods. They were more concerned once drugs reached the suburbs, where the majority of residents were white.
Now as then, many blacks say the government's failure to stop the crack plague is damning evidence of its complicity.
"If I know who the crack dealer is in the neighborhood, how come the police don't know?" Mr. Russell asked. "If the Government has planes that could pick up a safety pin from the ground from 30,000 feet in the air, how come they can't stop the planes from Colombia?"
 
The Ramifications
 
Hurting the War On AIDS and Crack
While there is no precise way to measure the impact of the conspiracy theories, many public-health workers fear the discussion is inhibiting the fight against AIDS and drugs.
"Unfortunately, the whole issue of AIDS and HIV as a conspiracy becomes a critical issue in discussing AIDS and HIV," said Dr. Jacob A. Gayle, special assistant for minority AIDS coordination at the Centers for Disease Control. "I think it's a significant public-health issue because it enables people to dismiss their own personal risk and responsibility if they say it's something other people are doing to them."
Some public-health workers say the conspiracies erode their credibility. Marilyn Ng-A-Qui, executive director of the Sister-to-Sister program, an AIDS counseling effort in Brooklyn, said that when she speaks to black groups, "There is almost always someone in the audience that has the answer: AIDS is part of a plot, a white man's plan to eradicate black people."
"It makes my job harder because I have to devote time and energy to addressing those concerns," she said. "If I dismiss it out of hand, then those people who believe in it have turned me off."
 
Wary of Testing and Condoms
 Some public-health workers say the theories can also undermine their specific recommendations for fighting AIDS. They say they can make people wary of using condoms to avoid the disease, of early testing to detect it and of using drugs to treat it.
Dr. Primm, associate director of the Alcohol, Drug Abuse and Mental Health Administration at the Department of Health and Human Services, said that black audiences sometimes regard the recommendation to use condoms as part of the same plot that produced the AIDS virus. "People say if the government is telling us to use condoms, it's because they're participating in genocide -- they don't want us to multiply," he said.
He said the same mind-set sometimes makes black patients resistant to taking AZT, the main drug for treating AIDS. "They say the government is experimenting on us," he said.
Dr. Primm said the talk of plots could undermine efforts to treat drug addiction as well. It has, for instance, intensified attacks on programs that use methadone to treat heroin addicts. Critics often say "it's a tool to enslave, to control, all the buzzwords," he said. "And it's ridiculous. Ridiculous."
Others fear that the talk of white plots may harm not only the physical health of black America but the spiritual health as well.
"When you put out theories like genocide you make victims think they have no power, that they can't help themselves," said Dr. Poussaint, the Harvard psychiatrist. "It gives one more excuse for not taking responsibility."

HEADLINE: Prosperous Town Braces for Leaner 90's

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RAMSEY, N.J., Oct. 26

 BODY:
From the storefronts of Main Street to the shops along Franklin Turnpike, merchants here can see the end of the 80's across their counters, in sagging sales of everything from lumber to liquor, from bicycles to auto-repair equipment.
With few exceptions, business people in this upper-middle-class Bergen County suburb say their customers have cut spending. The merchants in turn have reduced their inventories and their orders for goods, creating more drag on the slowing regional economy. 
 The merchants say they see many economic gremlins worrying buyers: layoffs on Wall Street, tighter credit, a glut of unsold homes, higher gasoline prices, the Persian Gulf crisis, the state tax increases initiated by Gov. Jim Florio and the prospect of higher Federal taxes.
Economists say there are sound reasons for the town's consumers to be cautious.
 
Fewer 'Double-Digit Wines'
 "I think Ramsey's a microcosm of what's happening in the Northeast," said Joseph J. Seneca, a professor of economics at Rutgers University. "We have accelerating inflation and slowing growth in employment and personal income. That's a very lethal one-two punch.
"Consumer psychology is switching to worrying about a job and what's going to happen in the next six months."
Everyday cost-consciousness is seen here in stores like Ramsey Liquors on West Main Street. "My Chivas Regal customers and my Dewar's customers who once bought two or three bottles a month buy one now," said the owner, A. Allan Capalbo.
Wine and beer sales are up, but there, too, consumers have changed behavior. "We aren't selling double-digit wines -- the $20 and $30 bottles -- as much," Mr. Capalbo said. "They're now looking at $6 and $10 bottles."
 
Signs of Overbuilding
 The slump is not deep enough to inspire talk of going broke or shutting down, especially after the robust 1980's. Those were banner years for shops in town and out along Route 17, one of the busiest shopping strips in New Jersey.
Retail spending in the borough rose to nearly $317 million in 1987, from about $160 million in 1982, pushing Ramsey, with 13,500 residents, from 57th to 33d in retail sales volume in the state, according to a Census Bureau survey.
Along with the brisk spending camenew office parks and condominiums, adding a sense of sprawl to Ramsey's image of a compact community of well-kept single-family houses.
But then came the signs of overbuilding and downturn. Many office buildings have vacant space. Timber Valley, a 220-unit condominium project, had 70 unitsunsold for three years until all were unloaded for bargain prices at a recent Sunday auction.
In the single-family house market, 150 houses are for sale, the most in years, said Tom Austin, a local real-estate broker and appraiser. In the last year, prices have dropped about 6 percent, and unsold houses now cost $235,000 to $260,000, he said.
"There are tons of buyers out there, but we're having a hell of a job getting the sellers to cooperate and lower the price," Mr. Austin said.
Local merchants talk of a shopping malaise and trouble collecting money from customers. And wholesalers here who sell their goods in the region and nation say a downturn is hitting them, too. Even when business is up, bad times are sometimes seen behind it.
Andre Hartmann sold 16 bicycles at his shop on East Main in August, down from the August average of 26 from 1986 to 1989. "I think people are scared about money," he said. "They see their neighbor can't sell his house and they get scared."
Out at the Ramsey Lumber Company, Todd Zecher, the owner, says his sales are off 40 percent from a $6 million peak in 1988. Fire ravaged his big yard in March 1989. But he says the biggest factor in his slump has been the sharp drop in new-home construction.
 
Truckloads, Not Boxcars
 Mr. Zecher did not hire any summer helpers this year, and he has cut his inventory of framing beams and other lumber. "I'm buying by truckloads instead of box cars."
Mike Rublino tells a similar story of retrenchment at the Ramsey Nursery and Garden Center on Franklin Turnpike. Saplings and evergreens left over from the spring forced him to cancel his usual fall order for that stock and buy more pumpkins and mums. "They're not high-ticket items," Mr. Rubino said. "You're talking $4, $5 and $10."
Mr. Rublino makes most of his money grooming shopping malls and office campuses and designing and planting the landscapes of new office parks and condominium projects. The upkeep work is stable, he said. But new landscaping, which costs at least $50,000 a job, has dropped because of the slump in the building industry, he said.
The Ramsey Outdoor Store, which specializes in gear for hunting, fishing, and other outdoor recreation, has cut its warehouse stock in half, said Ben Raucher, the manager.
"In the mid-to-late 80's, we carried 10 styles of down vests," he said. "Now we have three or four."
Not all is negative. Businesses involved in printing and graphics say their sales continue to grow. Al Purviance, owner of Minuteman Press, said the slump in housing sales had bolstered orders for real-estate sales brochures and unemployment had increased orders for resumes.
"Guys in their 50's come in and say all they need is five," Mr. Purviance said. "And then they come back in two weeks and say they need 1,000."
Thomas A. Schneider, owner of QPL, a photo company specializing in corporate advertisements, says he is benefiting because slow economic times prompt customers to bypass advertising agencies and public relations companies and deal directly with his office. Nonetheless, Mr. Schneider is wary. "There's no major acquisitions of equipment and we're triple-checking what we're investing in."
 
'No One Wants to Commit'
 Wholesalers here say the slowdown is not singular to Ramsey. Two involved in the auto industry -- Metropolitan Car-O-Liner, which sells hydraulic lifts and wheel alignment systems to garages from Maine to Virginia, and Wurth U.S.A., which sells nuts, bolts, tools and paint to repair shops and dealers nationwide -- both say their sales are down.
"Some of our equipment costs $30,000 and $35,000, and no one wants to commit to that kind of debt until they see which way the economy is going," said William Bologna, controller at Car-O-Liner.
At Daybreak Floral Distributors, which sells flowers to 500 retail shops in the New York region, Craig Hackenberg, the owner, says his sales growth has gone from a 50 percent increase in 1987 to stagnant now. He is trying to recoup by seeking more retail customers and cutting prices on weekend specials by 10 to 15 percent.
"Flower shops aren't buying as much because customers aren't spending as much," he said. "It's that simple."

HEADLINE: CONGRESS ADJOURNS;
$500,000 Federal Grant Buys a Lot of Grief for Lawrence Welk's Birthplace

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STRASBURG, N.D., Oct. 27

 BODY:
Isolated, windswept and scratching to survive, this dusty farming community, founded a century ago by Volga German immigrants from the Russian steppe, has never had a high profile.
But now, a rash of angry, often snide, remarks are being called in from around the country by people complaining that Strasburg, population 600, has become a vivid symbol of Government waste and special interest politics. 
 This is the childhood home of Lawrence Welk. And last week, the town won Congressional approval for a $500,000 grant to build a German-Russian museum, with a section devoted to the famous band leader, at the farm where he was born.
 
Economic Hopes
 The town, hurt badly by drought and falling farm prices, has pinned its hopes on tourism. It will try to attract some of the tourists that pass by Strasburg on their way to the Black Hills, more than 200 miles southwest of here.
But at a time when the nation is increasing taxes to try to balance its books, the Welk project raised hackles in Congress and quickened the salivary glands of radio talk show hosts. Now people from thousands of miles away are calling to upbraid the town.
"What will they do for an encore?" said Representative Silvio O. Conte, the Massachusetts Republican who launched the first salvo. "Earmark funds to renovate Guy Lombardo's speedboat? Or restore Artie Shaw's wedding tuxedo?"
Since then, the Welk Heritage committee, which operates in a small storefront on Main Street here, has been fielding calls that are sarcastic enough to bring cringes to the faces of the lovely Lennon sisters.
"I never know what's coming when the phone rings," said Sharon Eiseman, executive director of Welk Heritage Inc. "You get to start feeling very defensive."
 
Making Fun of Welk
 Many of the callers have made fun of the homespun style and old-fashioned gimmickry that served as a trademark for Mr. Welk, 87 years old, who lives in retirement in Los Angeles. (Mr. Welk used to return here every May to visit friends and family until the trip became too strenuous.)
The people in Strasburg say they don't make fun of other people's music, but concede that Mr. Welk's brand of entertainment is an easy target for sophisticates. To the people here, as in so many little towns and ethnic city neighborhoods, it was the kind of joyful music that once stirred the crowds at barnyard dances, neighborhood taverns and big weddings.
The people of Strasburg regard Mr. Welk as a hero, although many believe that John Schwab, a local farmer, was probably a better accordian player. And they are a bit wounded by the jokes and insults directed at their greatest source of civic pride.
"You people in New York have a lot of famous people, but we've just got Lawrence," Rasmus Dirk, a retired carpenter, said plaintively. "He's one of our boys."
The callers have a different view. "You're just a bunch of dumb. . . ," one man screeched, spicing his comments with a few profanities before hanging up.
 
Missing the Point
 Supporters of the project say critics miss the point. The museum, to be called the German-Russian Interpretive History Center, will not merely celebrate a successful band leader, but will also commemorate the experience and ambitions of a distinctive culture, illustrated by Mr. Welk's roots.
Townspeople have refurbished Mr. Welk's childhood home, a sod brick hut, later covered with wood siding, and its outhouse and barn to resemble the way they were for turn-of-the-century settlers.
"The idea is to give people an idea of how the pioneers of North Dakota lived," Mrs. Eiseman said.
The money for the Welk project will come from a United States Department of Agriculture fund that is set aside for economic development in struggling rural areas. The people here note that while critics object to the grant few have called to console them about pending cutbacks in the agriculture budget that will affect the town's residents.
"Anybody who has been to Strasburg can see that they can use some help," said Jean Broadshaug, the spokeswoman for Senator Quentin N. Burdick, Democrat of North Dakota, who was instrumental in getting the grant.
 
Times Have Changed
 Conditions on the Dakota Plains today are not as favorable economically as they were when Mr. Welk was a boy. Farmers can get only about $2 a bushel for wheat these days, a steep drop from what they once got.
Many farmhouses stand empty, and the few storekeepers left along Main Street struggle to keep their doors open. The long drought here threatens to push even more farmers into economic ruin. A prayerful sign at the edge of town gives thanks for any rain, and begs, "Please send more."
Townspeople say Mr. Welk, who only went to school through the third grade, and who never lost his distinctive accent, symbolized the aspirations of many first-generation Americans when he hit the road with his accordian some 65 years ago.
"It wasn't necessarily my kind of music," said Emily Benz, 31, who had driven 75 miles from Bismarck to take her children to the Welk farmhouse, a tiny home at the end of a gravel road.
"But he was a poor boy from nowhere who had a dream. And his people watched him make it to the big time."

She sat near the childhood home of Lawrence Welk in Strasburg, which won Congressional approval for a $500,000 grant for a museum partially devoted to him. (Jeff Olson for The New York Times); Map: Strasburg, N.D.
