The Economy
Many U.S. companies are laying off workers now, rather than waiting to be hit by hard times as they have in the past. Some economists warn that this outburst of corporate preventive medicine increases the odds of a steep recession. Since June, the number of people laid off in the United States has increased sharply, reaching the levels of the early months of the 1981-82 recession. [Page A1.]
The Federal Reserve will probably respond to the new budget by reducing short-term interest rates, but credit market analysts say neither Congress nor the Bush Administration should expect a substantial reduction. [D1.]
Congress has approved a three-way attack on taxes. The intent is to get that money from the upper class and upper-middle class through higher taxes for Medicare, a variety of income tax changes and additional excise taxes. [D1.]
Washington is losing some of its enthusiasm for liberalizing its trade policies. The reason is political: some American industries are unhappy about giving up protection. [D1.]
Why won't Michael Milken testify? That question resounded throughout the former financier's presentencing hearing, in which the prosecution and defense both indicated last week that they had called all of their witnesses. [D2.]
Orders for U.S.-made machine tools dipped 4.6 percent in September, rate, according to a report to be released today. [D7.]
 
 Companies
Merrill Lynch is expected to announce a reorganization as soon as today that dissolves the firm's separate consumer and capital markets groups. The reorganization is expected to result in hundreds of layoffs. [D1.]
Government and corporate documents appear to support a whistleblower's accusations that Hughes Aircraft overcharged the Pentagon on programs to develop in-flight radar systems. [D2.]
The Daily News is encountering serious problems as its management tries to produce and distribute the New York paper three days into a strike. [B4.]
 
 The Media Business
Simon & Schuster has been a model of relative stability amid the recent turmoil in publishing. That low-profile approach seems to have paid off: with sales of $1.3 billion last year, six times those of 1983, Simon & Schuster is the largest U.S. publisher. [D1.]
Newsstands are disappearing in many cities as single-copy magazine sales decline. But a few well-stocked newsstands are bucking the trend. [D8.]
Publishers are taking a serious look at increasing book prices to bring their revenues in line with rising costs. Publishing. [D8.]

 International
The new leaders of Jaguar Cars are hoping to turn the antiquated British company into one of the world's biggest, most efficient makers of luxury cars. [D1.]

HEADLINE: LAYOFFS ARE RISING EVEN AT COMPANIES IN GOOD CONDITION

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Many American companies are laying off workers now, rather than waiting to be hit by hard times as they have in the past. Some economists warn that this outburst of corporate preventive medicine increases the odds of a steep recession.
The number of people laid off in the United States has increased sharply since June, reaching the levels of the early months of the 1981-82 recession. While some companies, including Citicorp, Digital Equipment and McDonnell Douglas, are acting because sales and profits have already begun to shrink, many others, including General Electric's appliance division and Nordstrom department stores, are only anticipating such a downturn. 
 "Businesses are scared and they are cutting costs in anticipation of what they think might happen," said Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. "That sort of cost-cutting keeps American companies competitive in the world marketplace. But pre-emptive layoffs can be self-fulfilling, frightening people into spending less, which further weakens the economy."
 
A Widespread Trend
 The layoffs, and a smaller number of outright dismissals, in recent months have come in the service sector as well as in manufacturing, reflecting a new interest in cost-cutting, particularly among retailers and financial-services companies. Manufacturers have practiced this sort of cost-cutting for a decade to make themselves more competitive.
"Recessions have become a good opportunity to improve productivity, often by dropping people and putting in automated equipment," said Martin N. Bailey, a senior fellow and productivity expert at the Brookings Institution. Such concerns about productivity have been cited in layoff announcements this month by Nordstrom, G.E., Saks Fifth Avenue and Burger King, among others.
Whatever the dynamics, the number of American workers who were temporarily laid off, as measured in Labor Department surveys, reached 1,127,000 in September, up from 918,000 in June. While September represented a particularly sharp jump, the total has been rising steadily from an average of 808,000 in the first half of 1989 -- the lowest level since the 1981-82 recession.
 
Defining Layoff
 While the more than seven million people who are unemployed include anyone 16 to 65 years of age who claims to be out of work and looking for a job, the number of layoffs is the number of people who say they are temporarily absent from work for reasons other than illness or vacation. They expect to be recalled to work, although whether the companies plan to do so is not considered in the Labor Department survey.
During the last recession, the number of people on layoff rose above one million in mid-1981, as the downturn was getting under way, and then climbed rapidly to a peak of 2.5 million in September 1982, swelling the ranks of the unemployed and pushing up the unemployment rate to more than 9 percent, a level that endured until a year after the recession had ended.
This time, the process seems to have begun earlier in the downturn and is proceeding more slowly. That is reflected in the unemployment rate, which has risen only gradually, reaching 5.7 percent last month, from 5.2 percent in June.
"Companies are managing their workers as they manage their inventories of unsold goods," said Leslie McNulty, research director of the United Food and Commercial Workers Union. "They are trying to keep both sets of inventories -- employees and merchandise -- as low as possible."
 
Working Fewer Hours
 Various tactics are being used to hold down payrolls without running up the number of people let go. A major one is reducing workers' hours. Tens of thousands of workers are being told, in effect, to choose between a layoff and a shorter schedule, said Jack E. Bregger, a Labor Department economist. The number of people falling into this "slack work" category jumped to 2.65 million in September, from an average of 2.45 million for the first eight months of the year, the Labor Department said.
Another strategy is not to fill vacancies. Many smaller companies are responding to the weak economy, particularly in the Northeast, by not hiring for jobs that a year or two ago these companies said they could not fill because of a shortage of qualified applicants. Orley Ashenfelter, a Princeton University labor economist, calls this failure to fill job openings a form of hidden layoffs, "in the sense that the openings disappear, rather than people in them," he said.
The reluctance to take on new workers is reflected indirectly in the Labor Department's data on temporary workers -- the workers supplied by companies like Manpower Inc. and Kelly Services Inc. Their numbers shot up to 1.2 million in 1989 from 400,000 in 1982. But in the last year, the total has remained at 1.2 million.
 
Greater Difficulty Finding Work
 Finally, the number of people laid off is also rising because those who have suffered this fate cannot find new work, either full time or part time. The result is that the median number of weeks that the unemployed are out of work has jumped to 6.2 weeks, from 5 weeks, where it had been all year until September.
"What is happening is that the number of people losing their jobs is going up slowly, but the total on layoff is rising more rapidly because people are staying out of work longer," said Thomas Plewes, a Labor Department official.
Across the nation, the staff reductions cut across business sectors but are heaviest among clerks, sales people, construction workers and lower-echelon supervisors and managers, according to Labor Department data. The department, in its monthly surveys of 60,000 households to determine fluctuations in employment levels, calculates people on layoff as a separate category within the nation's total unemployed.
During the long recovery after the 1982 recession, the total number on layoff rose above 1.1 million several times, mostly in response to widespread layoffs in the manufacturing sector. But in 1988, as cuts in manufacturing subsided, layoffs fell to an average of just over 800,000, the low point for the economic expansion that has lasted nearly eight years.
 
Effect on White-Collar Workers
 New cuts in manufacturing employment since mid-1989 have helped to reverse the layoff trend, but most of the people going on layoff now are clerical and administrative workers rather than blue-collar job holders.
"Blue-collar workers have a lot of job security built into their contracts, in trade-offs for wage freezes," Mr. Plewes said. "White-collar workers in manufacturing and the service sector don't have that security in the lower-echelon jobs, and they are getting hit now."
While most of the job cutbacks since June are showing up in the Labor Department data as temporary layoffs, there also has been a rise in the number of people who have been permanently terminated. The temporary layoffs since June total 319,000; over the same four-month period an additional 151,000 were terminated, the Labor Department reported, because of either corporate cutbacks or other reasons.
The pattern here has been the same as among those on layoff. The total number of people who were terminated, according to the Labor Department, rose during the corporate upheavals of the 1980's to about 2.3 million, fell to about 2 million in 1988 and in September of this year climbed to 2.4 million.
 
Giving 60 Days' Notice
 Aside from actual layoffs, the almost daily announcements of planned cutbacks make the problem seem worse to the public than it actually is. Many announcements are made in compliance with a recently enacted Federal law that requires 60 days' notice when more than 50 people are to be let go.
The Boeing Company, for example, gave notice in January that 2,500 workers would be laid off this year, mostly because of fewer military contracts. But so far only 400 layoffs have actually taken place, and by year's end the total will probably not be anywhere near the 2,500 goal, said Paul Binder, a Boeing spokesman. That is because, in the interim, resignations and retirements have produced the shrinkage that Boeing had originally planned to achieve through layoffs.
Similarly, General Electric met the 60-day requirement with its recent announcement that 500 workers will be laid off at its appliance factory in Louisville, Ky. But if the anticipated weakness in home appliance sales fails to materialize by the time the 60 days runs out, the 500 workers, or most of them at least, might keep their jobs.

HEADLINE: CONGRESS ADJOURNS;
Elderly Would Benefit From Curbs on Sale of Overlapping Health Insurance

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
The tough new Federal standards for private health insurance that Congress approved Friday would prohibit the sale of overlapping health insurance to people like Grace and John Kossow, an elderly California couple who were persuaded to buy 29 policies in a 30-month period and billed for $22,011 in first-year premiums, or more than twice the couple's annual income.
"We told Jerry Brecht, the salesman, that we were not interested," Mrs. Kossow, who is 86 years old, said in a telephone interview from her home in Watsonville, near Santa Cruz. "But before he left, we had five policies. He kept coming back, and he could always explain why we could take more." Mrs. Kossow said they have let all the policies lapse. 
 The new Federal standards were added to the 1991 budget bill, which President Bush has said he would sign. They are intended to protect 23 million elderly and disabled Americans, who spent $15 billion last year for insurance known as Medigap policies. Medigap helps with costs not covered by Federal Medicare like the first day of hospital charges and prescription drugs.
The law would prohibit the sale of more than one Medigap policy to an individual. Consumer advocates and insurance industry spokesmen say a single Medigap policy is adequate for most people. The new law would also prohibit selling Medigap policies to the three million low-income elderly people covered by Medicaid.
 
Surge in Sales
 Sales of Medigap policies surged after Congress repealed a law last November that would have expanded Medicare coverage for high-cost catastrophic illnesses.
The new Federal law would extend to all states the insurance standards that are already enforced, in varying degrees, in a few states like California, Minnesota, Wisconsin and New York.
In one recent civil case, the Standard Life and Accident Insurance Company of Oklahoma City was fined $150,000 earlier this month in the California Superior Court in Santa Cruz. Don Gartner, an assistant district attorney in Santa Cruz, said the company, a unit of the American National Insurance Company of Galveston, Tex., had encouraged its agents to "conceal a form of life insurance in the Medigap policies it was selling." He said that the life insurance was not subject to profit ceilings, which most states have required for Medigap.
A study for Congress by the General Accounting Office listed deficiencies in some existing Medigap policies: "They provide narrow coverage, pay fixed dollar benefit levels without protection against inflation, are conditioned on confinement in a hospital or contracting the specified disease."
 
A 92-Year-Old Woman's Case
 The Senate Committee on aging cited the case of a 92-year-old Riverside, Calif., woman as an example of misleading sales pitches. The committee said an agent had persuaded the woman, whom it did identify, to buy eight policies, including three from Standard Life. But when she needed assistance with walking and other care at home, the committee said the insurance agent told her that the policy would not pay for the kind of help she needed. "I can't understand why he didn't know that when he sold me the policy," she told the committee.
Under the new law, the 50 state insurance Commissioners would have nine months to draft 10 model Medigap policies. "Every insurer would have to offer a core package of standardized benefits," said Representative Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat and a sponsor of the legislation.
The bill would also authorize $10 million to encourage states to establish networks of elderly volunteers to provide free counseling on Medicare issues. Bonnie Burns, a Medicare specialist with California's Health Insurance and Advocacy Program, HICAP, said counselors had helped to assemble the facts in civil damage lawsuits against Medigap insurance salespeople. She said that in one case the Bedrossian Insurance Agency Inc., based in San Jose, agreed last year to pay $200,000 in damages and court costs.
 
Review Is Scheduled
 Carole Olson Gates, a staff lawyer with the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, said state officials and private insurers would review the new regulations on Tuesday in Chicago. She said that the associaiton had been discussing Medigap standards since March.
Carl Schramm, president of the Health Insurance Association of America, an insurers group in Washington, said the bill was "a good compromise" because it would would give the initial responsibility to the states, "with Federal regulation down the road, if they do not act."
Consumer advocates welcomed the Congressional action. Gail Shearer, a Washington policy analyst with Consumers Union, an advocacy group, said the law would "help people who turn 65 and are faced with very confusing choices among hundreds of Medigap policies."
James P. Firman, president of the United Seniors Health Cooperative, an advocacy group in Washington, said insurers would have to ask prospective customers whether they already had Medigap policies.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 30, 1990, Monday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about new Federal standards for health insurance for the elderly referred incorrectly in some editions to the timing of Congress's repeal of the law that expanded Medicare coverage for catastrophic illnesses. It was repealed in November 1989, not this year.

HEADLINE: Taunts but 'Good Money' for New Drivers at News

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
Obscenities, eggs and coffee cups bombarded a convoy of nine delivery trucks that roared past a phalanx of police officers in helmets and angry picketers early yesterday morning to deliver bundled copies of The Daily News.
Scores of strikers had gathered outside the paper's printing plant in Brooklyn, taunting the workers who had replaced them with cries of "Scab!" and "Mutt!" and worse as the paper tried to put out its Sunday issue. The war of nerves resumed whenever the police at the printing plant moved barricades to allow vehicles to enter or leave. 
 "Open up the pearly gates!" a striker shouted.
Since the strike began at The Daily News on Thursday night, delivery trucks have been firebombed or battered by bricks, buses carrying replacement workers have been ambushed by men in ski masks wielding bats, and several strikers have been arrested for carrying guns.
 
'It's Good Money'
 None of the drivers had been seriously injured, but each truck still carried a security guard as it left the plant early yesterday. As the convoy rumbled down Atlantic Avenue, the replacement drivers stared straight ahead.
"It's scary," said one replacement driver as he dropped off papers in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn. "But we're doing it for the same reason the union guys were doing it. It's good money and a good paper."
Some of the striking workers would agree with that. Many of them, who joined the paper when jobs in newspaper production were handed down like family legacies, speak of The News with a sort of love, though animosity often creeps into their speech. [Page B5]
The replacement driver is among the hundreds of people who responded last spring to advertisements for replacement workers at The Daily News. The applicants included many women and minorities, and those who were selected as delivery truck drivers and pressmen were trained earlier this year. They have been joined at their jobs since the strike began by nonunion workers from other newspapers owned by the Tribune Company, which owns The Daily News.
The driver, a lean young Puerto Rican with a baseball cap, looked warily at strangers and cast quick glances at the security guard who sat in the truck. The driver declined to identify himself or say how much he was being paid, but he said he was outraged at the strikers' attacks and resented the taunts that he thought portrayed the replacement workers as subhuman.
"They're the animals -- they've taken shots at us," he said. "What kind of animal deals like that?"
Before he was called by The Daily News, he was unemployed for six months after losing his job as a quality control engineer. Now, he said, he is on call constantly, although he manages to sleep at home, unlike some other replacement workers hired from out of town who are staying in hotels or sleeping overnight at the newspaper's production plants.
Seated inside the truck's cab with one foot dangling outside, he glanced at the web-like cracks in the windshield, the result of a rock tossed earlier in the week. Although he has escaped injury, he said his relatives are frightened for his safety, and he calls them regularly during the day to assure them he has made it through the night unscathed.
 
Fellowship Among Replacements
 He spoke of the camaraderie that has developed among the replacement drivers. "We got a great bunch of guys who are intelligent and decent enough to work together," he said, pausing with his arms spread wide for emphasis. "The union says they don't want to be bothered, so let them."
He said he did not feel any personal animosity toward the striking workers, saying the unions' complaints should be with management, not with the replacement workers who were just trying to earn a living. But he criticized the unions for their intransigence, saying they have doomed the paper to failure.
"Not all the drivers are bad guys," he said "But they're just killing the goose that lays the golden eggs."
As he sat parked outside a news dealer's storefront in Bensonhurst, several police officers stood nearby, watching a dozen workers tossing newspapers into vans. Other men trotted briskly down the street carrying bundles of papers on their shoulders to waiting cars. Four private security guards hired by The News sat in two cars, each of which had a video camera to record any unusual incidents.
 
Line of Police Cars
 Unlike on Friday night, when police cars escorted the delivery trucks out of the Brooklyn complex and into the streets for about half a mile, the trucks delivering the Sunday paper left in a close convoy without the police, although a line of eight squad cars sat parked along Atlantic Avenue, ready to respond if anyone stepped out of the darkness to attack the trucks.
About a mile down Flatbush Avenue, a dispatcher waved rental cars out of a restaurant parking lot. They carried plainclothed private security guards who would escort the trucks on their rounds. A few of the trucks made sudden turns, sometimes running through red lights.
The trucks assigned to Bensonhurst raced down the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, their security escorts following close behind.
"There's been nothing serious," said one security guard in a leather jacket, who declined to identify himself but whose thick drawl betrayed his Southern roots. He said he was a veteran of providing security to strikebound companies, especially in the coal industry, where strikes have been marked with violent clashes.
"This is mild," he said, as he squeezed his ample girth behind the steering wheel of his compact car. "There's less gunfire." Did he carry a gun underneath his fringed leather jacket? He stared straight ahead at the men unloading the trucks and said with a faint smile, "I take the Fifth."
There was no trouble, and the unloading in Bensonhurst went quickly.
As the returning trucks approached the plant's entrance, a half-dozen picketers perked up, and began their chorus. "Go ahead, you mutt!" the strikers screamed, their taunts eventually fading until the next truck arrived.

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Who's Singing the Blues? Just About Anyone Who Wants To

BYLINE: By PETER WATROUS

 BODY:
Two strange things happened at the Benson & Hedges Blues series in New York City several weeks ago. The first was the arrival of the standing ovation based on reputation, something not generally seen at blues shows. The second was that the festival featured much music only tangentially related to blues as a style; everything from gospel-based soul to rock-and-roll to rhythm-and-blues made an appearance.
The incessant standing ovations hinted at the increased popularity of blues music in the United States and the hagiography that has accompanied it. And in the diverse grouping of musical styles collected under the term blues, it was clear that the word has become synonymous with older styles of black music. 
 At the highest economic level, performers lumped under the label blues seem to be doing fairly well: their status as classics occasionally works in their favor. A Benson & Hedges bill featuring the soul singer Irma Thomas, the blues singer Koko Taylor, the rhythm-and-blues singer Ruth Brown and the soul singer Etta James sold out Avery Fisher Hall; 10 years ago the show wouldn't have been put on, and if it had been, it wouldn't have sold out.
Still, the performers working the blues circuit -- usually clubs, and not concert halls -- are often refugees. Playing exclusively to white audiences open-minded enough to listen to older music and recording on small budgets, these older black musicians have been left behind by the black pop-music industry and have found a haven in a new, younger and whiter audience.
 Consider this contrast. While older white performers like Eric Clapton, Rod Stewart, Steve Winwood, the Rolling Stones and Robert Plant are still guaranteed access to radio and arena-size audiences and are not sold as elder statesmen, older black popular performers are shut out of the pop process and relegated to blues shows in which they are viewed as legends instead of performers.
The increased popularity of blues and the use of the term blues to cover older forms of black music are related. Until the rise of hip-hop, black music, often derived from the gospel church, displayed a mastery of the rhetorical tools of passion. In addition, the amplified guitar-based blues tradition, as exemplified by Chicago and Texas blues, often favors exaggeration and excess, both lyrically and sonically, creating raw, loud and tough music.
In the 1950's, those elements were immediately picked up by white youth and translated into rock-and-roll, in which the cult of primitivism still reigns. Expressionism is the foundation of rock-and-roll: raw, loud and tough are words of praise.
But current popular music, with its lip-synching, dance routines and programmed music, is anything but raw, and audiences looking for all the signs of passion that music was supposed to deliver have been forced to search elsewhere. They find it in heavy metal, in hip-hop to a certain extent and in older black music. The rock-and-roll impulse, with all its elements of passion and hints of transcendence, originally a blues impulse, is now being found by white audiences in older forms of black music.
The new interest in blues, and in standing ovations, comes from the periodic re-emergence of values based on the idea of authenticity. Studio recordings by pop acts are often hard to reproduce onstage, and the acts are perceived as artificial.
But older black music, with its emphasis on live performances and improvisation, is perceived as authentic. The doubts that the pop group Milli Vanilli even performs on its own records and its lip-synching in live performance has its opposite in the standing ovation for Albert Collins, whose guitar improvisations boil to the point of anarchy. Though Mr. Collins's two shows at the Beacon Theater weren't well arranged, everything he played had a driving intensity, where knifelike phrases cut through his band; his improvisations thrilled the audience.
So the audience's appreciation of Mr. Collins comes both as an appreciation of his standing in American music, a perhaps premature feeling that he, at age 58, has reached classic status. And improvisation guarantees a visceral excitement not often found in pop music; it's no accident that like blues, jazz has become dramatically more popular in the last 10 years. To hear Miss James, for example, take a song and radically rewrite it on the spot, improvising swooping arabesques, only to take a gospel shout and land it between melody notes, is a thrilling experience. Whether she actually feels the passion is irrelevant: she knows how, like any good actor, to make an audience believe. And her improvisations can charge an audience with the brazenness of their imagination.
But at its worst, the hunger for authenticity allows the performers and audiences to fall into stereotypes, in which the audience expects the performers to behave a certain way, and the performers are more than glad to accommodate their expectations. That comes in Ms. Taylor's endless claims that she and the audience were "going to the basement" to get the blues, as if she had the secret to the real thing. The audience's willingness to be suckered by the most obvious of ploys implies a hunger for an emotional authenticity perceived as being an attribute of working-class black culture. And it shows in the artificiality of the good-time image many performers radiate or in the calculated primitivism of Bo Diddley.
Where the festival atmosphere promotes blues hagiography, there is another reality. That's the reality of the small blues clubs, where blues is often purely functional, a backdrop to a Saturday night party. At places like Manny's Carwash on the Upper East Side or Mondo Cane in Greenwich Village, weekend shows are packed regardless of who is performing.
The veteran traveling bands that work those clubs breeze in, run though several sets of Saturday night cliches to which the audience, intent on other diversions, doesn't always pay attention, and then they're off to the next city. There are no standing ovations, the dressing rooms are small, and the pay is not commensurate with their abilities. But it's work, just as loaded with the mythic and social implications of bigger shows.
 And though the bands, whether they be the Holmes Brothers or Phillip Walker, are lesser known than, say, Miss James or Mr. Collins, they supply the necessary intensity, the necessary crunch that audiences desire. For the time being, the blues, whether its performers are on the big stage or in a small club, famous or barely known, is playing a larger role in the American racial puzzle.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Major Immigration Bill Is Sent to Bush

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28

 BODY:
Congress has passed a major immigration bill that would increase legal permanent immigration to the United States by more than 35 percent, and White House officials said today that President Bush was eager to sign the measure.
The most notable feature of the bill is that it requires the State Department to admit more immigrants with job skills needed in the United States, a step long favored by free-market economists. 
 The number of visas granted on the basis of job skills, to workers and their relatives, would more than double, to 140,000 a year from 54,000.
But the increase implies no reduction in the number of immigrants admitted on the basis of family relationships. The number of such "family-sponsored immigrants," now 436,000 a year, would increase to 465,000 a year through Sept. 30, 1994, and would then rise to 480,000.
 
Section Defeated by Hispanics
 Under the bill, total immigration to the United States would initially increase 40 percent, to 700,000 from the current level of about 500,000. The ceiling would drop to 675,000 in 1995.
Those figures do not include refugees, who are admitted to the United States after showing "a well-founded fear of persecution" in their homelands. Mr. Bush has authorized the admission of up to 131,000 refugees in the current fiscal year, up from 125,000 last year.
The landmark immigration bill was passed late Saturday, a few hours before the 101st Congress ended. The Congressional Hispanic Caucus staged a brief revolt and forced the bill's sponsors to remove a section permitting several states to test more secure means of identification. Hispanic-American groups generally oppose the idea of a national identification card and resist any step that might lead to such a document.
Representative Bruce A. Morrison, Democrat of Connecticut, chief sponsor of the legislation in the House, said that Republicans who wanted to test the use of more secure identification documents quickly agreed to drop that section of the bill.
 
Worker Shortages Expected
 After complaining about an earlier version of the bill, which would have allowed higher immigration levels, the White House threw its support behind the legislation in the last few weeks.
The President's top domestic policy adviser, Roger B. Porter, said the Administration "strongly supports" the compromise measure because it would help relieve labor shortages and would contribute to economic growth in the 1990's.
Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said: "Numerous studies suggest that the long-run benefits of immigration greatly exceed any short-run costs. With projections of a rising demand for skilled workers in coming years, the nation can achieve even greater benefits from immigration by augmenting the traditional emphasis on family reunification with policies designed to increase the number of skilled immigrants."
Lawmakers said immigrants could, for example, fill job openings for scientists, engineers, computer specialists, nurses and medical technicians. Many Government and private researchers have concluded that there will be labor shortages in such areas in the 1990's. They see immigration -- the admission of permanent immigrants, not temporary workers -- as a way to correct the mismatch between labor supply and demand.
 
Two Groups Singled Out
 Hispanic groups support a section of the bill that provides 55,000 visas in each of the next three years for spouses and children of aliens who gained legal status under a 1986 law.
Another part of the bill, strongly supported by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, would make available up to 16,000 visas in each of the next three years for Irish citizens.
Some critics, including Doris M. Meissner, a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, say such provisions are reminiscent of "national origins" quotas that discriminated in favor of white Europeans. But Mr. Kennedy said the provisions were justified to increase the diversity of immigration.
"We are trying to level the playing field," Mr. Kennedy said, noting that eight countries now receive 52 percent of all immigrant visas.
 
Influence of Immigrants
 Asia, Latin America and the Caribbean now account for most legal immigration to the United States. Europe, which dominated such immigration from colonial times to the 1950's, now accounts for a small share of the total.
The selection criteria are important because immigration is expected to account for a growing proportion of the United States' population growth in the next two decades. The Census Bureau says that the proportion, now 27 percent, would rise to 35 percent by the year 2005 if current trends continue.
The House approved the immigration bill by a vote of 264 to 118. The margin in the Senate was 89 to 8.
The bill ranks in importance with the Quota Act of 1921, which established the first numerical restrictions on immigration, and the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952, the McCarran-Walter Act, which listed dozens of ideological and other reasons for excluding aliens. The new measure was described by its sponsors as a logical companion to the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986, which outlawed the hiring of illegal aliens, but made only a few small changes in legal immigration.
 
Salvadorans Protected
 Representative E. (Kika) de la Garza, Democrat of Texas, said he voted against the 1986 measure, but for the bill on Saturday. "It's as good a bill as we could have had," he said today in an interview.
Under the bill, Salvadorans already in the United States could stay in a "special temporary protected status" through June 30, 1992, after which the Attorney General could extend their stay. They would have to register with the Federal Government. Salvadorans and their advocates have long argued that it was unsafe for Salvadorans to return home because of the civil war in their country.
The bill also gives the Attorney General explicit new authority to offer a "temporary protected status" to certain aliens from countries where there has been an earthquake, flood, drought, epidemic or "other environmental disaster."

HEADLINE: CONGRESS ADJOURNS;
Final Votes in Congress on Key Measures

 BODY:

Crime
 Both the House and the Senate approved an anti-crime bill after negotiators removed death penalty provisions and curbs on semiautomatic assault weapons in an effort to make the bill more widely acceptable. Liberals had generally opposed the death penalty and conservatives opposed the gun curbs. The vote in the House was 313 to 1, with Representative George W. Gekas, Republican of Pennsylvania, opposing the measure. Other provisions address victim rights, juvenile justice and prisoner drug testing.
 
 National Endowment for the Arts
The House and Senate extended financing for the National Endowment for the Arts for three years after negotiators from both chambers reached agreement Friday night. Unlike current law, the bill includes no explicit prohibition against financing obscene art, leaving such judgments to the courts. The negotiators also dropped a proposed ban on support of artistic works that denigrate religion.
 
 Foreign Aid
Both houses passed a $15.5 billion foreign aid bill. It includes a provision sought by President Bush to forgive $6.7 billion of Egypt's military debt. The bill would also cut military aid to El Salvador by half, to $42 million, and provide Israel with $3 billion in cash, military and economic aid and $700 million worth of military aid from American stockpiles. The bill does not specify an amount of aid for Pakistan, normally the third-largest recipient of American military assistance. The United States has expressed concerns about nuclear weapons in Pakistan.
 
 Airport Noise
Congress instructed the Federal Aviation Administration to eliminate most of the airlines' noisier jets by the turn of the century. The action will also allow local governments to impose fees on passengers and to use the money for airport improvement.
 
 Offshore Oil
Congress agreed to keep vast tracts of coastal waters from Alaska to New England off limits to oil and gas drilling, rejecting arguments that domestic fuel production should be increased because of the crisis in the Middle East.
 
Appropriations
Congress passed all 13 of the bills that are needed each year to actually provide the money for Government activities. The 13 bills are: Agriculture, Rural Development and Related Agencies; Commerce, Justice, State, Judiciary; Defense; District of Columbia; Energy and Water Development; Foreign Operations; Interior and Related Agencies; Labor, Health and Human Services, Education; Legislative Branch; Military Construction; Transportation and Related Agencies; Treasury, Postal Service, General Government; Veterans Affairs, Housing and Urban Development, Independent Agencies.

HEADLINE: Machine Tool Orders Decline 4.6%

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Orders for American-made machine tools dipped 4.6 percent in September, from August's rate, according to an industry report to be released today. The decline is the second in as many months.
The report, which is being released by the Association for Manufacturing Technology, a trade association for the machine tool industry, stated that machine tool orders fell to $264.2 million in September, from $276.8 million in August. The September figures represented a 12.7 percent decline from September 1989. 
 Despite the decline, executives of machine tool companies said there were some bright spots.
"There have been some healthy gains in new orders from the auto companies domestically and from foreign customers," said Richard O. Priebe, a spokesman for the Cross & Trecker Corporation, a leading machine tool maker, based in Bloomfield Hills, Mich. "In September, we had a strong month because of a couple of automotive orders: an assembly system and an engine block line."
Automobile makers typically account for more than a third of the nation's machine tool orders. Sluggishness in that industry has caused machine tool orders to slow in several months this year.
 
Domestic Orders Fall
 Machine tool orders from domestic customers fell 9.1 percent in September, the report stated. Analysts said that figure pointed to the unwilingness of American companies to invest more robustly in new equipment and modernization at a time when corporate profits have been weakened.
"The figures make it clear that industry still needs a tremendous amount of modernization," said James J. Paper, an analyst with Kirkpatrick, Pettis, Smith Inc., in Omaha. "There is a global reindustrialization that needs to take place."
Orders from foreign customers increased by 66.4 percent in September. Mr. Paper said the increase was more likely a result of a one-time placement of large orders by a foreign customer than a harbinger of increased sales from overseas machine tool buyers.
Orders from foreign customers, he and other analysts pointed out, declined 2.7 percent in August from July's level.
 
'Globally Competitive'
 Albert W. Moore, president of the industry association, said the increase in orders from foreign customers served as "a good indication that America's machine tool builders are globally competetive."
"The need for process technology is growing, and so is the competition to fill that need," he said.
Machine tools are power-driven devices that cut or shape metal parts used in products ranging from appliances and vehicles to aircraft and construction materials.
The strength of tool orders generally reflects the strength of industrial production, and economists consider patterns of machine tool sales to be important indicators of capital spending by manufacturers.
Shipments of machine tools increased 29 percent in September, compared with August's rate. While shipments to foreign customers were up 6.1 percent, shipments to domestic customers increased 33.1 percent in September, from the previous month's level.
Orders for metal-cutting tools, which include boring mills and lathes, dropped 8.6 percent in September from August's level. That segment of the industry typically accounts for three-fourths of new orders. Orders for metal-forming tools increased 14.4 percent, helped by a surge in foreign orders.
The machine tool order backlog in September stood at $1.57 billion, down from August's $1.61 billion.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
No Talks on Hostages, European Leaders Vow

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, Oct. 28

 BODY:
European Community leaders said today that Iraq's selective release of foreign hostages would not erode their unity in the Persian Gulf crisis, and they pledged not to negotiate with Baghdad to bring their countrymen home.
The 12 Western European leaders also seemed to hold out the possibility of eventual military action, saying they were "prepared to consider additional steps" within a United Nations framework if the present economic embargo does not force Iraqi troops out of Kuwait. 
 But Italy's Prime Minister, Giulio Andreotti, who holds the community's rotating presidency, said, "Anyone with his head set properly on his shoulders agrees that military means should be only the final recourse."
On economic matters, 11 of the leaders decided o leave Britain behind by setting a timetable to achieve a single European currency in this decade. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told a television interviewer that the others were in "cloud-cuckoo-land," but they decided not to be deterred and simply noted her dissent in their statement.
 
Bush Urges Cohesion
 Before the leaders convened here this weekend for two rounds of talks, Italy had expressed concern that Western solidarity could be chipped away by President Saddam Hussein's offers to release selected groups of foreigners being held as "human shields" at strategic Iraqi locations. An Italian Government spokesman disclosed Saturday evening that President Bush had telephoned Mr. Andreotti to make a similar point and to urge "strong cohesion" among the Europeans.
The worried statements were issued after a week in which Iraq promised to free all 327 French hostages and allowed 33 Britons to fly home with former Prime Minister Edward Heath of Britain, who had led a private mission to Baghdad. Iraq continues to hold many hundreds of others, including an estimated 1,000 Americans.
French officials insist that in regard to the hostages Baghdad acted on its own, and President Francois Mitterrand said at a news conference here today that there was "no contact with Iraq, no delegation, no emissary" from France.
But to leave no doubt that they remain united, the community members issued a statement on the Middle East that contained nothing to suggest, as President Mikhail S. Gorbachev did in Spain on Saturday, that Iraq might be softening its position.
Referring to the hostages, the leaders said they "denounce the unscrupulous use which Iraq is making of them with the sole and vain purpose of trying to divide the international community," adding, "They affirm their determination not to send representatives of their governments in any capacity to negotiate with Iraq the release of foreign hostages and to discourage others from doing so."
 
'A Very Powerful Signal'
 After the meeting, Mrs. Thatcher said, "The unity of the 12 nations on this matter is a very powerful signal to Iraq."
At the same time, the European leaders warned Israel that the present situation in the West Bank and other occupied zones was "unsustainable," and they repeated a call for an international peace conference to take up the Arab-Israeli conflict. But they refused to link this issue with the Persian Gulf crisis. Mr. Andreotti, a strong supporter of the Palestinian cause, insisted that Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait remained the top priority.
While the Italian leader pronounced this weekend's results to be "excellent," the moves toward political and economic unity were as bumpy as ever, with Mrs. Thatcher once again making her displeasure plain.
She described plans for revamping European Community institutions as "a ragbag of proposals," and said she would never agree to a monetary plan that threatened the survival of the pound. "We will not have a single currency imposed upon us," she said at a news conference. "A common currency, yes, but a single currency, no."
 
Farm-Subsidy Cuts Argued
 Mr. Thatcher was similarly upset by the inability of community negotiators on Friday to agree on a program of farm-subsidy reductions that are to be put before the so-called Uruguay Round trade talks in December. Britain blamed France and Germany for blocking an accord, and rather than risk an open fight at the summit, Mr. Andreotti shifted discussions to a lower-level meeting this week.
On the monetary issue, 11 of the leaders agreed that starting Jan. 1, 1994, a year after their scheduled economic integration, they would move toward a central banking system with "full responsibility for monetary policy." That would pave the way for fixed exchange rates and a single currency that Jacques Delors, President of the European Commission, said was needed before the year 2000.
But Mrs. Thatcher, insisting that target dates should await the ironing out of all other details, told the British Broadcasting Corporation that "it seems to me cloud-cuckoo-land" to proceed as the others did today.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
U.S. Boards Iraqi Tanker That Ignored Shots

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, Oct. 28

 BODY:
United States marines boarded and searched an Iraqi tanker in the northern Arabian Sea today after it ignored warning shots fired by warships and low-level passes by American fighter jets.
The marines, from the amphibious transport ship Ogden, met no resistance from the Iraqi crew when they boarded the ship to check for possible violations of trade sanctions imposed by the United Nations against Iraq. 
 The ship, which was heading for Iraq, was allowed to proceed after no prohibited cargo was found on board, a United States Navy spokesman in the Persian Gulf said.
The spokesman said the Marines descended to the deck of the 157,000-ton tanker Amuriyah from helicopters.
Later, a Navy spokesman in Saudi Arabia, Comdr. J. D. Van Sickle, said the Australian guided missile frigate Darwin fired 200 rounds from its .50-caliber machine guns and the American frigate Reasoner fired two rounds from its five-inch guns during the interception.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Small Drop In Rates Predicted

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve Board will probably respond to the passage of the new Federal budget by reducing short-term interest rates, but credit market analysts said neither Congress nor the Bush Administration should expect a substantial reduction as a glittering prize for what the tortuous, confidence-shaking exercise has produced.
"The new budget is a step, but I don't think fiscal discipline has been re-established at all," said William H. Gross, a managing director of the Pacific Investment Management Company, a Newport Beach, Calif., money management firm with a portfolio of more than $16 billion in fixed-income investments. "Unless we can exert some discipline on spending, rather than taxation, we are probably not going to make much headway in reducing the deficit."
 
 No Comment From Fed
 As is their wont, neither the Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, nor other officials of the nation's central bank would speak on or off the record about their intentions on interest rates. Telephone calls to Mr. Greenspan and governors of the Federal Reserve on Friday found no one who would comment on Federal Reserve policies and how the budget agreement might affect them.
But through the summer and into the fall, Mr. Greenspan had offered Congress a carrot -- a drop in short-term interest rates -- if the credit markets responded positively to a budget package.
The message struck a chord with market participants, and in the last week short-term money market interest rates moved down in anticipation of a budget agreement and a subsequent reduction in the overnight Federal funds rate, the market rate controlled most directly by the Fed. The funds rate -- the overnight rate on bank loans-- has hovered around 8 percent since July.
 
 Drop in Prime Rate Unlikely
 While welcome, a minor cut in the funds rate would probably not lead to a decline in the prime lending rate charged by commercial banks, or in other prime-based consumer borrowing rates. With poor balance sheets, analysts said, commercial banks were not likely to consider lowering the prime rate, currently at 10 percent, until the funds rate fell to 7 1/2 percent.
Yet, even as short-term rates slipped, bond yields, which are the ultimate indicator of how a long-term budget package is judged by market participants, have not budged.
By the end of last week, yields on 8 1/8 percent two-year Treasury notes, securities which are very sensitive to changes in Fed policy, had fallen to 7.76 percent, well under the funds rate. But yields on the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds were stuck at 8.76 percent.
"The Fed might be able to cut the Federal funds rate by one-quarter of a percentage point without upsetting the market," said Jerry L. Jordan, a senior vice president at First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles. "But people who think there will be a big payoff on interest rates based on this budget package are in for a disappointment."
The Fed will be reluctant to move faster because market participants, especially long-term investors, see little reason to believe the budget package will generate the advertised $500 billion in savings over the next five years.
Moreover, with the dollar under pressure and fears about inflation still strong, the Fed would be running a substantial risk of pushing up long-term rates if it quickly cut short-term rates by more than a quarter of a percentage point, the analysts argued.
 
 Economic Reports Awaited
 A signal from the Fed that it has moved the funds rate lower may come almost immediately, but in order to calm nerves in the long-term bond market, analysts said, the Fed might well delay its move until after a string of important economic reports are released this week.
Those reports, coupled with the announcement late last week that a key measure of consumer confidence had plummeted in October, are likely to reassure bond investors that an easing of Fed policy is justified on economic grounds.
This week will provide a preliminary reading on how the economy fared in the third quarter and reports from the naton's purchasing managers and the Labor Department on how the fourth quarter began.
 
 Rise in Consumption Spending
 The Commerce Department's preliminary report on third-quarter growth could well show growth that is considerably above the increase of four-tenths of a percent recorded in the second quarter. But most analysts said a rise in third-quarter output should not be interpreted as a sign that the economy was regaining momentum. Much of the increase will probably be from a rise in consumption expenditures, a figure that tends to increase in the third quarter.
"I would hope people will look past the consumption number in the third quarter G.N.P. report," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank. "Consumption was stronger than it was in the second quarter, but on a year-over-year basis it continues to weaken."
Dimming the outlook for the fourth quarter was the announcement late last week of a record drop in the Conference Board's monthly survey of consumer confidence, which in October fell to its lowest level since the 1982 recession.
Gayle Fosler, chief economist at the Conference Board and an analyst who says the economy will avoid a recession, acknowledged that the results of the survey were troubling. "I would now be inclined to reduce my estimates on consumer spending somewhat," she said, "but I think this number has more to do with disenchantment over the budget negotiations than with economics."
 
 Manufacturers and Jobs
 Other analysts are not so sure. A report, due Thursday, from the nation's purchasing managers, will probably show that conditions among large manufacturers deteriorated further in October. October employment data from the Labor Department, expected the following day, will probably be weak, too.
"The data will show that the fourth quarter started off on a very weak note," Mr. Fine said. "I have no problem with a forecast which shows economic output declining in the fourth quarter."
Mr. Jordan of First Interstate said that weakness in the economy would ultimately lead to an aggressive easing in policy by the Federal Reserve. But constraints on the Fed will not be lifted until the crisis in the Middle East is resolved, he added, and the dollar regains some bouyancy.
"If they were not constrained by the Middle East crisis, the Fed would have already done more to help the economy," he said. "Assuming there is a solution, we think the funds rate will come down to 7 percent next year."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Communist Paper in U.S. Feels Capitalist Pressure

 BODY:
The People's Daily World, the American Communist newspaper whose legacy extends back to the 1920's, is trying to revive its sagging fortunes with some decidedly capitalist initiatives: aggressive marketing and prudent cost-cutting.
After years of incurring heavy debts, which were only erased through fund raising, the newspaper's management in June reduced its publication schedule from four issues a week to one and began a campaign to increase circulation. To reflect the changes, the newspaper early this month was renamed The People's Weekly World. 
 Barry Cohen, The World's top editor, is quick to point out that the newspaper's troubles are not related to the decline of Communism around the world. Instead, he said, The World is responding to the same pressures that are threatening many small newspapers and magazines in the United States.
 
 Circulation of 62,000
 Although The World says its circulation has remained stable in recent years, at about 62,000 copies a week, its costs have continued to rise.
To raise revenues, The World's management recently doubled the newspaper's cover price to 50 cents. But unlike other publications, The World would benefit little from raising advertising rates. In a recent 28-page issue, for example, there was only a half-page of advertising, mostly for left-wing booksellers.
"The economics of publishing are not very favorable to the little guy," said Mr. Cohen, who is a member of the committee of editors and business managers that runs the newspaper.
"Costs are going up all around," he said. "We are basically a reader-supported newspaper, so the difficulties of raising money for those costs are quite great. It just was a more sensible strategy for us to concentrate our resources on the once-a-week paper."
The changes come for a publication with a rich history dating back to the founding in 1924 of The Daily Worker, which for decades was the voice of the radical left in the United States.
The Daily Worker became a weekly in the 1950's. After a series of name changes and mergers, The People's Daily World was founded in 1986.
 
 An Advocacy Journal
 Closely allied to the Communist Party of the United States of America but not officially linked to it, The World bills itself as an advocacy journal for the working class and its coverage emphasizes labor issues.
The newspaper, which is based in New York and has correspondents around the country and in London, Moscow and Havana, also reports on general news with a left-wing slant.
The World receives praise from some union leaders who, though they may not subscribe to its Communist philosophy, appreciate its reporting on labor issues.
"It's the best coverage in the country," said Marshall Garcia, the executive vice president of Local 1199 of the Drug, Hospital and Health Care Employees Union in New York.
Mr. Garcia said he had been particularly impressed with The World's coverage of the bitter Pittston coal miners strike, which was settled early this year.
Mr. Cohen said that as a weekly, the newspaper will be able to rely less on reader-supported fund-raising campaigns, which in the past have covered nearly half its budget of slightly more than $1 million.
The People's Weekly World usually runs about 28 tabloid pages and includes more in-depth pieces than the daily paper did. The newspaper also features editorials, opinion pieces and a three-page section in Spanish.
 
 Aggressive Marketing
 Besides cutting costs, The World's management is marketing the publication more aggressively by retaining a distributor, which is placing 7,000 copies of the newspaper on New York City newsstands.
The newspaper is also sold at labor rallies and political meetings. Subscriptions cost $15 a year, although students, the elderly and unemployed people pay $7 a year.
As part of its search for additional revenues, the newspaper is seeking advertisements from unions and left-wing organizations and from publishers selling books that might interest a left-wing readership.
Joy Brock, The World's managing editor, said the move to a weekly had progressed smoothly, though she acknowledged that some readers were disappointed by the change.
"The real loss is that we are not able to reflect the breadth of activity that we once were," Ms. Brock said. "That can give people the feeling that less is going on."
 
 Editor Is Optimistic
 Despite The World's problems and the worldwide entrenchment of Communism, Mr. Cohen, a lifelong Communist who is 40 years old, said he was optimistic about the future of the newspaper.
He said he was looking forward to using The People's Weekly World to present the virtues of Communism to a public freed of many of the ideological constraints of the Cold War.
"Our experience is that the interest in socialism is greater, perhaps, than it's ever been in our country," he said. "When you look at the problems of this system, how could you not be curious about whether there is an alternative which would be better?"

HEADLINE: Campaign Trail;
Gains Seen for Women, but Not Without Fights

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28

 BODY:
This was billed as the year of the woman in politics, but nobody ever said it would be easy.
Women are now locked in tough, close races for governor in Texas, California, Oregon, Kansas and Alaska. Gov. Kay A. Orr of Nebraska, the only female incumbent running for re-election this year, is in a tight race, while women challenging incumbents in Pennsylvania and Wyoming are in uphill battles.. 
 "We could have everything from a terrific victory to a terrific defeat on election night," said Sharon Rodine, president of the National Women's Political Caucus.
Currently there are three female governors, and two of them, Madeleine M. Kunin of Vermont and Rose Mofford of Arizona, are not seeking re-election.
There is a strong possibility that the women's caucus in the Senate will increase by 50 percent, from two to three. Representative Patricia Saiki, Republican of Hawaii, is in a very close race against Senator Daniel Akaka. But two other Republican women from the House, Representatives Claudine Schneider of Rhode Island and Lynn Martin of Illinois, are running behind in their campaigns for the Senate. Josie Heath, a Democrat running for the open Senate seat in Colorado, is also behind Representative Hank Brown.
Voters are likely to send some new women to the House this year, but since five women are leaving (three to run for Senate, two to retire), neither party's Congressional campaign committee expects much of a big net gain in the number of female House members. Right now, there are 29 women in the 435-member House.
Groups like Emily's List, a fund-raising network for Democratic women who support abortion rights, are looking to the reapportionment year of 1992 to make significant gains in the House. Wendy Sherman, executive director of Emily's List, is already making recruiting trips into Florida and other states where House seats will be added in 1992, trying to line up women who are interested in running.
Some analysts had predicted that this year was particularly auspicious for women because the issues that were hot -- the environment, education, abortion rights -- were issues that voters often associate with women. But the agenda this fall has been dominated by the economy and the crisis in the Persian Gulf. "It came back to more macho issues, as opposed to the more domestic issues that women have articulated well," Ms. Rodine said.
Still, Ms. Rodine and others say that women have been holding their own on some tough playing fields, particularly in California, where Dianne Feinstein's race against Senator Pete Wilson seems almost deadlocked, and in Texas, where Ann Richards has confounded those who were writing her off just a few weeks ago and is now in a close contest with Clayton Williams.
Moreover, the number of women running for state offices, including lieutenant governor and state treasurer, continues to grow. "Most of them are running for high office after years of working their way up the political ladder," said a recent report by Ruth B. Mandel, director of the Center for the American Woman and Politics at Rutgers.
But Ann Lewis, a Democratic strategist, says there are still signs of a glass ceiling restricting the upward progress of women seeking the highest offices. Part of it, she argues, is the ability to break into the fund-raising circles that are critical for major statewide races like governor.
Wendy Sherman says, "Win or lose, the political landscape has changed for Democratic women."
Women's groups are accustomed to claiming psychological and symbolic victories after losing elections, but on Nov. 6 they would also like to see women claim some real power.
 
Comic Strip Satire And Helms Reality
 Doug Marlette's comic strip "Kudzu" often explores the clash between old values and modern life in the changing South, as represented by the mythical town of Bypass, N.C. Now, he is offering the view from Bypass of Senator Jesse Helms's campaign for re-election. But this is a subject of sensitivity in the real North Carolina.
Mr. Marlette, a native of the state who now works in New York for Newsday, produced a series of strips lampooning the Senator's struggle to come to grips with the end of the cold war.
"Nobody's out to get me," the Senator tells a psychiatrist in the strip, shortly before solving his problem by announcing a Senate hearing into the International Artistic Conspiracy, as well as a decision by the National Endowment for the Arts to suppress production of black velvet art.
As is often the case in politics, the line between reality and satire can blur. In "Kudzu," a mock Helms commercial attacks his opponent for holding fund-raising events "in places like New York and San Francisco, if you know what I mean." The real-life Helms campaign is using a television commercial saying that the Senator's opponent, Harvey Gantt, "has raised thousands of dollars in gay and lesbian bars in San Francisco, New York and Washington."
Some North Carolina newspapers got edgy. The Raleigh News and Observer suspended the comic strip until it stops lampooning Mr. Helms or until the election, whichever comes first. The Charlotte Observer and The Winston-Salem Journal moved the strip to the opinion pages.
 
Further Costs Seen For the White House
 Some Republicans privately say the White House may regret the blithe attitude toward the 1990 elections that many people detected in its handling of the budget talks. If Republicans lose a dozen seats in the House next week (they now has only 175), and a Senate seat, which many are now predicting, the White House may find the next two years less than pleasant.
One Republican strategist, who spoke only on condition of anonymity, noted that such losses would make it much more difficult to sustain a veto or pass legislation that the Bush Administration wants. It will mean, this strategist argued, that the Administration will have to be more accommodating with George J. Mitchell, the Senate majority leader, and Speaker Thomas S. Foley. And that, in the view of many Republicans, is exactly what is wrong with the Bush Administration today.

HEADLINE: The Bond Act: A Price Worth Paying

 BODY:
The spirits of Teddy Roosevelt, Averell Harriman and Nelson Rockefeller -- conservationists all -- must be restless. New York voters will vote next week on a $1.9 billion bond act to enhance the state's environment. New Yorkers have approved nine such measures in this century but this one is thought to be in trouble. Some critics call it a naked land grab. Others say it's an agreeable but frivolous luxury in a time of fiscal austerity.
It is neither. The act deserves support. But its critics have raised serious questions that deserve serious answers. 
 The act is not well understood. It is not exclusively or even largely a device to shield environmentally sensitive areas from developers. About $800 million is earmarked for the purchase of open and undeveloped land. But the rest -- $1.1 billion -- would be devoted to unglamorous, worthy capital projects that will have to be funded somehow.
There's $500 million for waste management -- closing unsafe municipal landfills and speeding municipal recycling. There's $175 million for sewage treatment, $100 million for an esplanade on New York City's West Side and substantial sums for parks and recreational facilities. The bill may end up funding a few projects of dubious value. But most will enhance the quality of everyday life.
Still, two big questions remain:
Is the act affordable? Two years ago the act would have had little trouble; today's a different story, given the state's fiscal problems. Comptroller Edward Regan, for one, argues that New York has enough debt as it is. But both the Business Council and the bond rating agencies say the ratio between New York's debt service and its tax receipts is within acceptable limits and won't be threatened by the bond act. Nor will the money be raised or spent all at once; the actual sale of bonds can be pegged to economic conditions. And the cost to each New Yorker over the bonds' life is estimated at $7 a year.
Is the $800 million for land acquisition necessary? To some environmentalists, that's the heart of the bill, its chief legacy to future generations. But some critics, including angry Adirondackers, fear that state purchases of open space will threaten their livelihoods and freedom. Others argue that New York's open space is not now in jeopardy, since the housing market is weak.
Three points. One: Open space money will be distribted statewide; only part, still undetermined, would be used to enlarge the Adirondack forest preserve. The rest would be used for projects like protecting underground drinking water supplies in crowded suburban areas like Long Island, or shielding the Catskills reservoirs from development.
Two: No land will be "seized." The funds would simply give authorities the ability to compete with developers by offering private landowners fair market value -- and then only after consultation with local residents. Three: Even if development is not a threat now, it could well be tomorrow.
This act is worthy of resounding support. And those who had planned to vote for it should urge their friends to join them.

HEADLINE: New York Needs the Environmental Bond Act

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As you suggest in an Oct. 18 news article, many residents of New York State are undecided about the merits of the proposed 21st Century Environmental Quality Bond Act, which will be on the ballot Nov. 6.
Is it wise to authorize the state to incur long-term debt in these times of economic uncertainty? On the surface, the answer to this question would seem to be no. But the facts tell another story.
Failure to pass the bond act would result in the loss of at least $700 million in Federal grants. This would break the fiscal backs of local communities now struggling to deal with polluting waste-water systems.
In testimony before a State Assembly committee this week, representatives of key local government associations estimated that dealing with the solid-waste crisis alone would cost local taxpayers billions.
Revenues from the environmental bond act may seem like a drop in the bucket compared with these costs. But over the next 10 years, this investment will pump, it has been estimated, $11.7 billion into the economy of New York State.
And we can finance the debt for 2 cents a day per citizen.
To paraphrase Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the next decade will determine the fate of New York's landscape. Without the necessary funds, state government will stand by helplessly as opportunities to preserve our special places and expand public access come and then are gone.
The bond act's foes have had center stage lately. Now it's time for the voters to have all the facts. New Yorkers need the environmental bond act.
 
BERNARD MELEWSKI
Executive Director
Adirondack Council
Elizabethtown, N.Y., Oct. 22, 1990

HEADLINE: Auto Racing;
Indy Takes a Worldwide View

BYLINE: By JOSEPH SIANO

 BODY:
JUST as the Disney theme parks have expanded overseas in recent years, the Indianapolis Motor Speedway is trying to create a worldwide network of Indy 500's through licensing agreements in Europe and Japan.
The plan could bring back the top international drivers, who haven't run in the Indianapolis 500 since the 1960's, when world champions such as Jim Clark, Graham Hill and Jackie Stewart made the race a true world-class event. 
 But the idea, which could benefit the entire Indy-car series in the United States as well as sharply increase speedway profits, may never escape the dense thicket of international racing politics.
Selling the Indianapolis Motor Speedway's name internationally is by far the most lucrative means for the speedway to increase income. The Indy 500 puts such a strain on local public services that the track cannot run a second event. And the track's seating capacity, 275,000, cannot be expanded much more.
These realities were the genesis of meetings that Tony George, the 30-year-old president of the speedway, and Bill Donaldson, the track's vice president and marketing director, had with officials of racing's international governing body, known as FISA, in March and July.
Simply put, the speedway would allow its name and the name of its race -- registered trademarks -- to be attached to a series of oval-track Indy-car races internationally, with the Indy 500 as part of that series. Along with the 24 Hours of Le Mans, the 500 is one of the world's most famous races, and such a series would tap into the wealthy markets of Japan and a united Europe.
The speedway wouldn't be the only party to gain. FISA's flagship series, the Formula One world championship, isn't very popular in the United States. An international oval-track series, which would use the same engines as Formula One cars, would deliver an American audience to Formula One sponsors.
By adopting the same rules as the new series, Championship Auto Racing Teams, which sanctions the 15 other Indy-car races in the United States and Canada (a separate group runs the Indy 500), would get an international audience for its sponsors and increased participation by auto manufacturers, the lifeblood of any racing series. Next year, Chevrolet and Alfa Romeo will be the only car companies building CART engines. Formula One will have engines from Ford, Honda, Porsche, Ferrari and Renault, with Mercedes-Benz rumored to be interested.
But George's plan is a hostage in a dispute between CART and FISA over CART's plans to run a race in Queensland, Australia, next March. FISA has declared the race illegal, saying its rules prevent a domestic series like CART's from holding races in foreign countries.
The loudest shot in the CART-FISA battle was fired Oct. 10, when FISA's World Council, meeting in Paris, announced plans for an international oval-track series, starting in 1992, with races at as-yet-unbuilt tracks in Japan and Europe and, presumably, the speedway.
Although that announcement made it seem as if George and FISA had come to an agreement -- one that froze out CART -- George said recently that FISA had announced the series without any promises from him to join.
"They haven't mentioned to us one way or another if they would like the speedway to be a part of it," George said a few days after FISA's announcement.
George expressed disappointment in CART and FISA. "Both sides, I think, are not really looking at all the issues," George said. "They are not willing to consider anything beyond their side of the equation."
George was asked if he thought FISA was using the announcement as a public-relations ploy against CART. "Yeah, I think they're notorious for that," he said.
But Bernie Ecclestone, vice president of FISA, said from London that FISA's announcement was not meant as a cudgel against CART. "This was in line with what we talked about in the past," Ecclestone said, alluding to the meetings with George.
"If he just wanted a conversation and didn't want anything to happen, he should have indicated that," Ecclestone said.
As for the CART race in Australia, Ecclestone said that FISA wasn't worried about economic competition. FISA, which last year forced cancellation of a CART event in Japan by threatening Japanese race officials with sanctions, believes that allowing CART to expand overseas would create organizational chaos, he said.
"Who issues the licences? Who do you make appeals to? Who has jurisdiction?" Ecclestone said, presenting some of the problems in maintaining international order.
It was suggested to Ecclestone that American racing officials view FISA's actions merely as trade barriers preventing the export of Indy-car racing.
"Nobody would want to come to America and do something against the laws of America," Ecclestone replied. "And in this case, it's probably the same thing."
William Stokkan, CART's chairman of the board, disagrees. "If there's one thing I've learned in 20 years in business," Stokkan said, "it's that when people tell me it's not the money, it's the principle, it's the money."
Stokkan said that CART has tried to play by FISA's rules.
"Every time we try to be the nice guys and try to play by the established rules, there is a tendency to change the rules," he said.
For example, a FISA rule that allowed CART to run about three races each year outside the United States was abolished about the time CART announced plans for the race in Japan.
For now, CART plans to hold the Australian race, even though FISA has threatened an international ban on all drivers, teams and officials who take part.
The Indy 500 is one of those races held under FISA approval. In 1979, during the battle that brought CART into existence, the United States Auto Club, which runs the Indy 500, tried to refuse the entries of several CART teams. A United States District Court enjoined U.S.A.C. and the Speedway from doing so, and it is unlikely that any future effort to ban entries from the 500 would survive a legal challenge.
And it is doubtful that George would want to run a race without anyone named Unser, Andretti or Mears.
 But FISA could gain the upper hand if Al Unser Jr. and Michael Andretti, CART's two biggest young stars, could be offered enough money to switch to Formula One, a form of racing that greatly interests the two second-generation racers.
Without those two drivers, and with the expected retirement of A. J. Foyt and Mario Andretti in the next few years, CART wouldn't have as much to offer the speedway.
