HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Newsstands Dwindle, But Some Still Thrive

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WAKEFIELD, R.I.

 BODY:
Magazine publishers nervously monitoring the decline in newsstand sales across the country might be cheered by a visit to the Healy News Store in this tiny New England town.
 People drive from as far as Massachusetts to buy the 3,000 different magazines stocked by Steve Davis, the manager and son-in-law of the owner, Freeman Healy. In 1962 Mr. Healy and his brother, Richard, bought the business, which had been run by one family for more than half a century at a time when newsstands and paper routes were an essential part of the American way of life. 
By the beginning of the 1980's, however, most newsstands had disappeared except in large cities and at airports and terminals. Even more important, the magazine-buying habits of Americans had drastically changed. Today, magazines are sold mostly in supermarkets and convenience stores.
 
Newsstand Sales Are Falling
 And single-copy magazine sales are on the decline as a result of rising cover prices, competing uses of leisure time and discounted subscriptions that reduce the cost of each issue to way below its cover price.
 By the first half of this year, 234 of the 421 magazines that reported their figures to the Audit Bureau of Circulations showed declines in single-copy sales from a year earlier. The biggest decline was felt by magazines with circulations of a million or more.
 "People are watching their spending more carefully, and we are theorizing that people who used to buy three magazines are now buying one or two," said Robert Cohn, a vice president at the Magazine Publishers of America.
People are also asking for a new type of magazine. Ten years ago, the average wholesaler sold 1,300 different magazines; today he sells more than 3,000. Withthe advent of desktop publishing, almost anybody can put out a magazine -- and many do. This has given rise to "niche" publishing, small magazines that sell maybe 100,000 to 150,000 copies and are devoted to single topics.
 
Healy's Advantage
 This is where the Healy News Store with its 60 feet of magazine racks has the edge over supermarkets and drugstores, where magazines compete for space with other products.
 The bulk of the sales in supermarkets take place at the checkout counter, where a handful of the most popular magazines and tabloids like The National Enquirer are available. In the larger supermarkets there are also "reading centers," which carry several hundred magazines.
 "Most supermarkets are going to have 500 or 600 titles, but Healy gets 3,000 titles, or basically every magazine we've got," said Charles Cellar, vice president and general manager of Ocean State News, who is Mr. Davis's distributor.
 John A. Cowley 2d, a distributor in Jefferson City, Mo., said supermarket chains were increasingly cutting back and limiting magazine sales to checkout counters.
 But Mr. Cowley is convinced that the industry has come full circle. "The last five to eight years have seen the re-emergence of small magazine newsstands in medium-sized cities," he said. "The time is right for the rebirth of that small hometown news center."
 For example, four years ago in St. Louis, he said, there were four newsstands. Today there are 14.
 What is on the cover of a magazine is, of course, a key element in newsstand sales. So is the price. Over the last 30 years, the price of magazines has risen about one and a half times the inflation rate. In 1960, the average magazine cost 39 cents. Last year it was $2.44, according to the Magazine Publishers of America.
 About half of the magazines on display are sold. Like most retailers, Mr. Davis gets 20 percent of the price of each magazine he sells from the distributor and an additional 10 percent from the publisher.
 
Single-Copy Share of Sales
 On average, single-copy sales represent about 30 percent of magazine sales while subscriptions account for the rest. Over all, taking into account both subscriptions and single-copy sales, 35 of the top 55 magazines reporting to the Audit Bureau of Circulations in the first six months of the year lost circulation.
 The downward trend in single-copy sales reported by the A.B.C. may not tell the full story because the bureau only tracks the larger magazines. A new study by the Periodicals Institute, the marketing arm of the single-copy sales industry, reports that when 3,000 magazines are taken into account, single-copy sales are flat, and not declining. Indeed, many niche publications are growing.
 One reason that Healy News Store has managed to hold its own is that it has been willing to change with the times. Originally, it sold stationery items until these stopped being profitable. In 1983, Mr. Healy began to sell drugstore items and groceries as well as magazines.
 "Over the last seven or eight years, most grocery stores started selling magazines," Mr. Davis said. "So now we sell groceries."
 While many publishers are worried about the downward trend in single-copy sales, Mr. Cowley, the Missouri distributor, is optimistic.
 "My Dad used to have a saying: 'This is a nickel-and-dime business. You don't make much on each item, but you sell a lot of items,' " he said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Yielding Its Police Role In Panama to a Rebuilt Force

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA

 BODY:
Marking the final stage of the military occupation that followed the American invasion here, the United States plans to end the last joint patrols of American and Panamanian police teams throughout the country by late November, officials say.
A senior officer of the United States Military Support Group, Col. Jack Pryor, said American officials were pleased with the progress of the restructured Panamanian Public Force and with its new civilian commander, Ebrahim Asvat. He said the American military police who have supervised all security operations since the invasion on Dec. 20 are no longer considered essential to preserve public order. 
 "We have been withdrawing out of the police business," Colonel Pryor said in an interview at his office in a former Panamanian intelligence headquarters. "By Nov. 11 we will have all our troops out of the city with the exception of Chorrillo and Colon, and those will be withdrawn by Nov. 28."
Chorrillo is a poor area of Panama City that was largely destroyed by combat and fire during the invasion. Colon, the country's main Atlantic port, was also a scene of heavy fighting and has suffered from high unemployment. Both are considered high-crime areas.
 
Police Commanders Replaced
 The withdrawal of the American police advisers, who for 10 months have ridden with Panamanian officers, comes after months of screening intended to rid the Public Force of officers considered ineffective or unreliable holdovers from the Government of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.
The change also follows a period of turmoil that has included the recent replacement of two successive police commanders, the retirement of 142 senior officers, and unsubstantiated rumors of a coup plot by disgruntled officers in an outlying province.
Those events, together with persistent problems of street crime, have been frequently cited by Panamanian politicians and editorial writers as evidence that the Public Force is neither effective nor mature enough to be left unsupervised.
But American officials described the incidents as minor distractions from the larger evolution of the restructured Panamanian force, which has been stripped of its military character and sharply reduced in size. They expressed confidence that the force could assume full responsibility for maintaining public order without posing a threat to the democratically elected Government of President Guillermo Endara.
 
U.S. Force Down to 10,000
 The ending of joint patrols also corresponds with the Bush Administration's strategy of reducing the broader American military presence here. A spokesman for the United States Southern Command, Col. Joseph S. Panvini, said the total number of American troops here had fallen to about 10,000, the lowest level since tensions between the United States and the Noriega Government began to rise in May 1989, and far below the peak of 25,000 or so during the invasion.
The new Public Force has about 10,000 men, who work in eight-hour shifts and return to their homes when off duty rather than remaining with their units in military barracks, as they did under General Noreiga.
Most are armed with only sidearms or shotguns, but some special-duty units have now been equipped with Taiwanese-made assault rifles modeled after the American M-16 to give the force greater firepower against drug traffickers or other organized criminals, American officers said.
Criticism of the new force's performance thus far has centered on the rapid growth of street crime in Panama City and other urban areas, including daring holdups like the robbery of more than 40 guests at a well-known Panama City restaurant recently. The victims at the restaurant, which is less than a block from the United States Embassy, included several embassy officials.
Concern has also grown over the Government's ability to fight a sharp increase in narcotics trafficking from neighboring Colombia through Panama's remote jungles and ragged coastline.
But diplomats, American military officers and Panamanian officials said those problems have been balanced against strong public mistrust of any police apparatus, especially one involving former members of the Noriega Government.
 
All Senior Officers Ousted
 According to American figures, all officers above the rank of major in General Noriega's force have been dismissed since the invasion. Fifty-seven percent of majors have been retired, 40 percent of captains and 28 percent of lieutenants.
The remaining force has gone through a mandatory three-week retraining course supervised by the United States Department of Justice, and the first class of 260 recruits is to begin training at a new national police academy on Nov. 6.
The Government announced recently that it was investigating several lower-ranking officers in the outlying province of Chiriqui, near the Costa Rican border, on suspicion of plotting a coup against President Endara.
But senior Government officials admitted that the evidence, which involved isolated bomb attacks on utility poles in the countryside, was "fuzzy." And American officials, noting that no Panamanian officers had the means or opportunity to try to seize power, categorically dismissed the rumors.
Asked whether Panamanians believed that the United States would permit a coup, the American Ambassador, Deane R. Hinton, said flatly, "We wouldn't -- and they know it."

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
German Terror Expert Says Iraqis Have Front Companies Across Europe

BYLINE: By FERDINAND PROTZMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Oct. 29

 BODY:
Iraq's intelligence service is operating a network of outwardly legitimate businesses across Western Europe, using them as bases for espionage, weapons procurement and possible terrorist attacks, a former senior West German intelligence official says.
The companies, mostly export-import companies and used-car dealerships, are also working to circumvent the United Nations trade ebargo against Iraq, said the former official, Hans Josef Horchem. He said he based his assertions on information from officials in German and foreign intelligence agencies. 
 Mr. Horchem, a former director of West Germany's domestic intelligence service who now runs the Institute for Terrorism Research near Bonn, said the network of roughly 10 main companies is under the direct command of the Iraqi secret service and closely linked to the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command.
The Popular Front, a terrorist organization led by Ahmed Jabril, is suspected of planting the bomb that destroyed Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in December 1988, killing 270 people.
 
 3 Companies in Germany
 Mr. Horchem said there were three Iraqi front companies in Germany and that they were operating in Hamburg and Hesse state. He declined to name them and said no action has been taken against them because of insufficient evidence. Other companies are operating in France and Britain, he added.
German Government officials confirmed that the matter was being investigated. "There is information coming out of special sources that is being checked on," said Roland Bachmeier, the spokesman for the German Interior Ministry. He declined to comment further. United States Embassy officials also declined to comment.
A Government official who spoke on the condition that he not be identified said that Mr. Horchem's sources "are of course the secret services."
"But the evidence so far is not enough for any kind of action," he said. "If we knew it for sure, something would be done. But as you can see, there is neither an investigation by police or by a state prosecutor yet. I would say that the matter is in a preliminary stage."
The official confirmed that companies serving as bases for the Iraqi secret service were not confined to Germany. "They are in all of Europe," he said. "And not every company in Germany with Iraqi connections is one of these bases. On the other hand, Iraq is a totalitarian country which certainly has some people on a tight leash."
The businesses are staffed by Iraqi secret service personnel, and some also employ members of the Popular Front, Mr. Horchem said. He said the companies were prepared to launch terrorist attacks should the situation in the Persian Gulf shift against Iraq.
"They are chained bloodhounds, waiting for orders from Saddam Hussein to set them into action," he said. "When people fly in the companies give them a base, providing an apartment, weapons and explosives and a number they can call, so they do not have to bring in weapons themselves. This also is the case elsewhere in Europe."
The French and the British are even more threatened than the Germans, he said, because of the active role their military forces are playing in the Persian Gulf crisis.
German Government officials disputed Mr. Horchem's contention that the companies are used as arms depots, and a spokesman for the Iraqi Embassy in Bonn dismissed the assertion as ridiculous. "It is just some statement that is popping up now and that will also pop up in the future," he said. Asked if Iraqi intelligence agents were active in Germany, he replied: "I don't know. I don't think that the world's secret services make their actions public anywhere, do they?"
 
 Iraq Rejects Terror Accusations
 The Iraqi spokesman also dismissed talk of terrorist attacks, calling it "absolute nonsense."
Suggestions that Iraq had built an extensive European network to obtain arms and weapons-related technology emerged publicly last spring, when British officials seized forged steel tubes, saying they were meant for use in the construction of an Iraqi "supergun." The investigation uncovered a network of legitimate European companies directly or partly owned by a group called the Al-Arabi Trading Company of Baghdad.
This month customs officers raided the British headquarters of Matrix Churchill, an Iraqi-owned engineering group, as part of an investigation into suspected illegal exports of machine tools to Iraq.
The French Government is investigating charges that some French companies are breaking the United Nations embargo.
Germany has been accused of taking an overly passive role in the military standoff in the gulf and in monitoring sensitive exports. Diplomats in Bonn suggested that the disclosures about the secret Iraqi network may have been made to deflect such criticism, by showing Germany as active behind the scenes.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl announced on Sept. 15 that Germany would provide $1.87 billion in military equipment for the international force confronting Iraq and in economic aid to nations like Jordan and Egypt whose economies have been hurt by the embargo. Mr. Kohl said the German Constitution prohibited Bonn from sending troops outside Europe.
German industry has been deeply involved in supplying Iraq with weapons-related technologies. In a secret briefing for the German Parliament's Committee on Economic Affairs several weeks ago, Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann listed five areas in which German companies have been involved in supplying industrial plants, technology or expertise to Iraq.
 
 Cannons and Missiles
 A member of the committee said Mr. Hausmann mentioned the supply of forging plants to build cannons; the involvement of German companies in the development of the "super gun;" the supply of missile technology; the modernization of the Soviet Scud missiles already in Iraq's arsenal and the supply of technology needed for nuclear arms production.
"He left out in his statement all the stuff about chemical plants, poison gas and the weapons exports over third countries, like France," the committee member said.
He added that Mr. Haussmann, in the face of criticism, insisted that Germany's existing arms export laws were sufficient.
He said the items on Mr. Haussmann's list were supplied to Iraq because "at that time Saddam Hussein was our friend. Others did the same thing, like the French."

HEADLINE: Needless Breast Cancer Deaths Reported Among New York's Poor

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
Poor women in New York City are dying of breast cancer unnecessarily, primarily because early detection is not widely practiced in the municipal hospital system, according to a report released yesterday by City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman.
The report said the Health and Hospital Corporation's policy of not performing routine mammograms had contributed to a death rate from breast cancer among its patients that was three times the national average of 24 percent. 
 About 65 percent of the breast cancers detected at city-owned hospitals are not spotted until the cancer has reached an advanced stage, the report said. Nationally 20to 25 percent of breast cancers are diagnosed that late, the Comptroller said.
Women whose breast cancer is detected early are generally believed to have a survival rate of 90 percent, meaning they are still alive five years later.
 
High Death Rates Reported
 The Comptroller's report said that at public hospitals like Kings County in Brooklyn more than 70 percent of breast cancer patients were dead within five years of detection. At Harlem Hospital, it said, the mortality rate is 78 percent.
"When all the available medical knowledge shows that early detection leads to high survival rates, it's appalling that H.H.C. does not have a stated policy or practice of performing routine screening techniques," Ms. Holtzman said. "It means that thousands of poor women will suffer and die needlessly from a very treatable disease."
More than 1,500 women died of breast cancer in New York City in 1988, a 5 percent increase over the total in 1987 and an 18 percent increase over the 1982 figure, the city's Department of Health has said. The city's 11 public hospitals, which make up the largest municipal health-care system in the country, are the primary health-care providers for many poor New Yorkers.
 
Gaps in Prevention
 Last year the American Cancer Society said poor people had failed to benefit from advances in cancer prevention, detectionand treatment. It reported pronounced differences in the outcome for patients, depending on race and socio-economic status.
Eight of the 11 city hospitals have no policy or program on breast cancer detection. The American Cancer Society suggests that women 35 to 39 years old receive mammograms every two years, women over 40 get them every one to two years and women over 50 get them every year.
Fred Winters, a spokesman for the hospital corporation, said yesterday that steps had already been taken to improve breast cancer treatment. Earlier this month Dr. J. Emilio Carrillo, the hospital corporation's president, announced formation of a task force to study breast health care. The panel is to report to him within 90 days.
Dr. Carrillo said there were many reasons for the breast-cancer problem, among them low educational levels among women using public hospitals and the hospitals' own lack of educational and screening programs.
 
Action Is Promised
 "This is a critical health-care issue for the women in the communities we serve," Dr. Carrillo said. "Even given the current round of budget cuts, H.H.C. will address this issue."
The Comptroller's report showed that most breast cancers were found in areas with older and more affluent populations -- the Riverdale section of the Bronx, the Upper East Side of Manhattan and Forest Hills, Queens. Most of the cancers are detected early, the report said. Late-stage detection occurs in poorer neighborhoods like Central Harlem, East New York and the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the Comptroller found.
The report also found that after cancer had been diagnosed, women who used city-owned hospitals failed to get follow-up care, including biopsies, 30 percent of the time.
The Comptroller said the breast cancer policies resulted in $323 million a year in unnecessary expenditures for the women admitted to city hospitals.

HEADLINE: Experts Disagree on Effects of Medicare Reduction

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Hospital executives said yesterday that the cuts in Medicare payments to hospitals and doctors in the 1991 budget bill may lower the quality of medical care for patients. But Bush Administration officials said the $34 billion in savings would be achieved mainly by eliminating wasteful practices by hospitals and cutting payments for hundreds of medical procedures that they say are overpriced.
Payments to hospitals would be reduced by $16.8 billion over five years under the terms of the bill, which President Bush has said he will sign. Physicians would lose $9.5 billion. About $6 billion would come from requiring private employers to pick up more of the costs of elderly and disabled employees and retirees eligible for Medicare. Reductions in other areas, like payments to clinical laboratories and for dialysis treatment, account for the rest. 
 The people who benefit from Medicare will have to pay $10 billion more in monthly premiums for physicians and deductible payments, for a total savings of $44 billion in spending.
 
Some Hospitals Fare Better
 But the budget softens the cuts for "teaching hospitals" that educate doctors, as well as for those that care for large numbers of poor people and those in rural areas.
The cuts will hit hardest at city and suburban hospitals that serve middle-class patients, said Michael D. Bromberg, a spokesman for investor-owned chains. "The people who suffer will be the patients," said Mr. Bromberg, the executive director of the Federation of American Health Systems. "There will be less money for new technology and staff. Hospitals may have to reduce some services."
But Gail R. Wilensky, who heads the Administration's Medicare program, said the cuts "should not be regarded as drastic."
Congressional aides said $11.3 billion, the largest part of the savings on hospitals, would come by reducing annual increases in payments so they do not keep up with inflation.
The bill would also reduce by $4 billion the Medicare payments to hospitals for capital spending, such as for new equipment and buildings.
But Congress left $1 billion extra to ease the cuts for 1,537 hospitals that have more than their share of uninsured patients unable to pay for their care. Hundreds of rural hospitals would also get a $1 billion break over the five years. And teaching hospitals would not be charged $485 million in assessments for earlier overpayments.
Doctors would lose $3 billion in annual increases tied to inflation; $2.5 billion in reduced payments on 1,400 procedures like cataract operations that are considered overpriced; $1.5 billion in reduced payments to radiologists, anesthesiologists and pathologists; $880 million in reduced payments to new doctors and for surgical assistants, and $725 million in payments made for interpreting simple electrocardiogram tests.
Some private employers were concerned that hospitals and doctors would try to make up their losses by raising fees to private insurers.
Donald Young, executive director of a Congressional advisory committee on hospital payments, said patient care may suffer from the budget cuts. But he said hospitals had been raising their Medicare charges by 4 percent to 5 percent beyond inflation, mainly by charging for "more tests, more surgery, more procedures per patient." He said savings may come by doing fewer tests on a patient who may be routinely checked with blood tests, X-rays, magnetic resonance imaging and computerized scans.

HEADLINE: Soviets to Let West Convert Ruble Profits

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 29

 BODY:
In a move aimed at easing one of the most formidable barriers to the Soviet market, Western business executives will be allowed to exchange their profits in rubles into foreign currency starting in January, bank officials said today.
Officials at the main state bank, Gosbank, and the foreign trading bank, Vneshekombank, said that all companies, including Western concerns, would be able to take their ruble earnings to new currency exchanges and bid on foreign currencies offered for sale by Soviet businesses and the Government. 
 But the bankers and foreign business executives said a number of crucial uncertainties remained, including the amount of foreign currency that would be available for sale, what the exchange rate would be in the highly competitive auctions, and whether the Soviet Government would even be ready to open the promised exchanges in January.
Westerners withheld their enthusiasm today, noting that this would not be the first Kremlin promise to disappear into the bottomless muck of Soviet reality.
"It's a good skeleton," said Mark S. Vecchio, a Moscow-based specialist in business law for the Coudert Brothers law firm. "Now let's get some meat on the bones."
One Western diplomat said the most important aspect of the promised new rules on foreign investment, which are intended to implement a broadly worded Presidential decree published on Friday, was the evidence that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is increasingly turning his attention to the role foreigners can play in his economy.
"Foreign investment is now an integral part of Gorbachev's program, rather than an addendum to the program," the diplomat said.
After an initial euphoria about the vast, untapped Soviet market, foreign investors have grown more frustrated by the realities of an investment climate with few coherent laws and little experience in Western business practices.
Even as the central Government gradually loosens the restraints on foreign investors, new obstacles crop up, like the disputes among central and local governments over ownership of natural resources.
 
Restriction on Profits
 One of the main annoyances has been the limitation on taking profits out of the country.
Foreign joint ventures can now repatriate dollars and other foreign currency profits only if they actually generate such profits.
Thus, an American company that sells pizza to foreign tourists in Moscow or that produces something here for export to Western Europe may take home a share of the profits. But companies that sell products to Soviet consumers find themselves awash in relatively worthless rubles.
Some firms have come up with creative schemes to swap the rubles for goods they can sell in the West -- from pickles to pianos to optical lenses. But many more simply throw up their hands and give up. The majority of Soviet-Western ventures never advance beyond the initial letter of intent.
 
Barrier to Be Removed
 Aleksandr Y. Voitenkov, the deputy chief of the Gosbank's foreign currency department, said in an interview that the current restrictions on exporting profits would be dropped and foreigners would be allowed to take home foreign currencies bought at the new exchanges.
He said most of the hard currency would be offered for sale by Soviet exporting enterprises with dollars and German marks on hand.
"The state may contribute some hard currency from its reserves," Mr. Voitenkov said. But this is "not certain."
The problem is that without the sale of some currency from the state reserves, the amount offered for sale will be extremely limited, and the price will skyrocket.
The Government has experimented with a few auctions of hard currency since 1988, open only to a limited number of Soviet enterprises. Now, the auctions will be held on a regular basis and open to any party.
 
Higher Rate at Auctions
 The dollar has fetched about 25 rubles at the auctions, far above the three official exchange rates maintained by the Government: 0.6 rubles to the dollar for international statistical comparisons, 1.8 rubles to the dollar for trade and investment transactions, and 6 rubles to the dollar for tourists.
"Just adding more people to the demand side for dollars won't help unless the state is going to ante up some money to keep rates from being overly ridiculous," said an economist at a Western embassy. "Under the best of circumstances, it's very difficult to make an investment if you can't calculate your rate of return."
Mr. Vecchio, the lawyer, said the Government would be strongly tempted to limit the amount of foreign currency put on sale to prevent its reserves from being drained.
"There's no way this country could throw open the borders to massive capital flight," he said. "It would be like an airplane at 30,000 feet when the window's blown open."

HEADLINE: Figuring the Tax Impact And Acting to Cut the Cost

SERIES: The New Tax Law: Calculating Its Effect on You - Second of Five Articles

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:
With a deficit-cutting plan finally in place, the first question most taxpayers want answered is whether their own income taxes are going up or down. The easiest way to figure that out is to look at a copy of last year's returns and apply the new rules to a few key numbers.
Few married couples with taxable income below $80,000 or single people with income below $50,000 need be concerned. Their taxes are not likely to be affected. For those above those levels, the difference will probably amount to only a few hundred dollars, unless they are really rich. 
 "The taxes are not that astronomical; no one is going to be made destitute by this," said George E. L. Barbee, who is in charge of personal financial planning for Price Waterhouse in Boston. "What is disturbing is that it is open season on tax rates and open season on deductions."
The new rules set a top rate of 31 percent, limit itemized deductions and phase out personal exemptions above certain thresholds. This will take just a few minutes to calculate. Once taxpayers see where they are headed, they can fine-tune their calculations. The new rules will take effect at the beginning of 1991, and by trying "what if" projections for both 1990 and 1991 taxpayers can see whether some shifts could lower their total tax bills.
For example, taxpayers could decide whether charitable contributions would give them the biggest deductions in 1990 or 1991.
The first number needed is on Line 31 of Form 1040, adjusted gross income. Next is Line 34, itemized deductions. Taxpayers with an adjusted gross income above $100,000 should multiply the difference by .03 to get their deduction limitation. Subtract that number from the itemized deductions to see what would be allowed under 1991 rules. Next, subtract that number and the amount for personal exemptions (Line 36) from the adjusted gross income to get the taxable income.
William J. Goldberg, national director of personal financial services for KPMG Peat Marwick in Houston, called the deduction limit "a hidden rate increase." Indeed, it puts those affected in a 31.93 percent tax bracket -- the additional 0.93 percent is the 31 percent rate times the 3 percent limit.
Although the Government has not yet released tax tables to be used under the new law, David A. Berenson, national director of tax policy for Ernst & Young in Washington, has done preliminary calculations to give taxpayers an idea of what the results would be. To figure their tax, he said, a married couple filing jointly should subtract $82,050 from taxable income, multiply that result by .31 and add that result to $18,560. (The capital gains portion should be figured at 28 percent.) Single taxpayers should subtract $49,200 from their taxable income, multiply the result by .31 and add that result to $11,130.
Next, those with taxable income between $150,000 and $272,500 need to add an amount to their taxes for the phaseout of personal exemptions. Above that, it is eliminated. This calculation is considerably more complicated than the 3 percent floor on itemized deductions.
"It's son of bubble," Mr. Berenson said. (The "bubble" refers to the 5 percent surcharge that now forces some people to pay a 33 percent marginal tax rate, the rate on the last dollar earned.) But, he added, the most anyone could lose would be $636 per exemption (that is, 31 percent of a $2,050 exemption, using the 1990 number) so adding that number times the number of exemptions to the tax owed will give a worst-case scenario. Exemptions, which are adjusted for inflation, will rise again next year.
 
A Closer Approximation

Couples in the 31 percent bracket who want a closer approximation can use this formula: adjusted gross income minus $150,000, divided by $122,500, times $636, times number of exemptions. Single taxpayers should use $100,000 in the formula instead of $150,000. The result should be added to the tax calculation. Taxpayers can compare the results with the tax on Line 38 of last year's return to see whether they win, lose or draw under the new income tax rules.
To see how else the new law hits them, wage-earners must calculate the additional Medicare tax of 1.45 percent for each dollar earned between $51,300 and $125,000, and consumers must figure the additional tax of a nickel a gallon on gasoline, 16 cents on a six-pack of beer, and 4 cents on a pack of cigarettes.
John L. Norman Jr., national director of taxation of Pannell Kerr Forster, in Washington, said, "The basic strategy has always been to try to accelerate your deductions, and that basic rule still applies, because you're getting it earlier," and those now taxed at 33 percent on their top dollar will be near that next year, or even above it, depending on their personal-exemption situation.
For the most affluent taxpayers, those now taxed at a flat 28 percent, itemized deductions like state and local taxes, mortgage interest and charitable contributions will be worth more next year, when they are in a 31 percent bracket, and even higher, considering the hidden effects of the deduction limit and the exemption phaseout. But Mr. Norman noted that the projected dollar gain must be offset by the delay in getting it and by the risk of having planning go awry if the taxpayer ends up being liable for the alternative minimum tax.
Joel S. Isaacson, a partner in Weber Lipshie & Company, in New York, cited the example of a client in the top 28 percent bracket who had received a large severance payment this year. He plans to pay all his state and local taxes before Dec. 31, so he can deduct them on his 1990 return, rather than risk waiting until April 15 to pay them, being thrown into the alternative minimum tax in 1991 and losing the value of the deduction.
Because the deduction limit is based on adjusted gross income, not on the size of the deductions, the amount to be lost in 1991 will not be changed by moving deductions from one year to the next. Only lowering the adjusted income will cut the loss.
 
Business Deductions Cited
 
 
Lorin D. Luchs, a tax partner in BDO Seidman's national tax office in Washington, advised people who could to "revisit the area of where things can be taken as a business deduction."
Partners who have unreimbursed partnership expenses or self-employed people who have legitimate home offices to which a portion of mortgage interest and real estate taxes can be allocated, for example, may be able to take business deductions, he said. Accountants call these "above the line" items because they keep down the adjusted gross income on page one of the 1040 form instead of being taken later as itemized deductions on Schedule A. Thus, they are more valuable.
Tomorrow: Capital gains.

HEADLINE: Chrysler Posts $214 Million Loss in Quarter

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 29

 BODY:
Hit by a softening economy, eroding car prices and lost production of its new mini-van, the Chrysler Corporation today posted a $214 million loss in the third quarter. That compared with a profit of $331 million, or $1.42 a share, in the period last year.
In addition, analysts speculated that Ford and General Motors would announce substantial quarterly write-offs this week, cutting into already weak earnings. [D4.] 
 Chrysler's announcement came as negotiators for Chrysler and the United Automobile Workers were still in talks at midnight about a new labor agreement. A union official who spoke on condition of anonymity said that important job security, pension and health-care issues remained unresolved, although the union told workers to report to their jobs until notified otherwise. The contract expiration deadline was tonight.
Local union representatives from around the country have been invited here for a meeting on Thursday, suggesting that union leaders expect a tentative agreement by then.
Talks between the U.A.W. and Chrysler have been the most difficult of all industry-labor negotiations, which started in July, because the auto maker says it must have a less expensive contract than those already signed at the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation. So far, the union has rejected Chrysler's position.
But Chrysler's third-quarter results were graphic evidence of the difficult conditions the company is encountering.
Last year's profit for the quarter was inflated by $309 million as a result of a one-time gain from the sale of 75 million shares of the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation. Chrysler continues to hold a minority stake in the Japanese car maker.
The financial results for Chrysler, the No. 3 American auto maker, were within the range projected for the last few weeks by most automotive analysts. On the New York Stock Exchange today, Chrysler's shares lost 12.5 cents each, to $11. Despite the loss, analysts said Chrysler's financial condition remained stable.
"It's comforting that the cash and marketable securities are at $3.7 billion, compared with $2.1 billion last year," said Scott Merlis, an automotive analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company in New York.
Ronald A. Glantz, an analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in San Francisco, agreed that Chrysler's financial condition was stable, but he noted that the company must repay $4 billion in debt by the end of 1991. "The economy better be in a recovery by the middle of next year or Chrysler will have a financial crisis," he said.
 
Looking to a Tough Year
 Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman and chief executive, said, "We anticipated 1990 would be a tough year for Chrysler and for the industry, so we launched our major cost-cutting program over a year ago."
Jerome B. York, the executive vice president for finance, estimated that Chrysler spent an average of $1,250 a vehicle in incentives during the quarter, compared with $850 in the period last year. The company expects to spend about $2.5 billion on incentives throughout 1990.
Chrysler's sales and revenues slipped by 14.6 percent, to $6.49 billion, from $7.6 billion last year.
Chrysler's consolidated earnings included record results from its finance subsidiary, which reported a profit of $83 million, up by 9.2 percent from the $76 million earned in the period last year.
 
Lost Van Production
 The auto maker said it had lost production of 56,000 mini-vans during the quarter because of the changeover to 1991 models from 1990 models at plants in Windsor, Ontario, and St. Louis. The mini-van, which has been extensively restyled to compete with domestic and foreign competitors, has been a leading source of profit.
Mr. Iacocca said he expected Chrysler to reverse its sliding share of the American vehicle market in the fourth quarter. He cited increased mini-van availability, the introduction of two low-priced subcompact models -- the Dodge Shadow America and Plymouth Sundance America -- and increased fleet business.
Earlier this year, Chrysler had said it was cutting back on its fleet business because it was not profitable. Mr. York said today that "the fleet business, at current market conditions, is more than marginally profitable." He said the resale values of used cars had been increasing since the third quarter of last year, improving the profitability of fleets sold to car-rental companies and leasing companies.
Total factory sales of Chrysler vehicles totaled 412,723 in the quarter, down by 14.7 percent from the 1989 quarter. The auto maker said its share of the North American retail vehicle market was 11.2 percent in the quarter, compared with 12.8 percent a year ago.

HEADLINE: Substantial Power on Spending Is Shifted From Congress to Bush Procedure Intended to Guarantee Cuts Are Made

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29

 BODY:
Congress has ceded substantial power over spending decisions to the Bush Administration's Office of Management and Budget under procedures approved as part of the $490 billion deficit-reduction package.
The procedures, intended to insure that spending cuts agreed to in the package are made, are a complicated variation on the existing Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law. Like that law, last revised in 1987, they would require automatic spending cuts if Congress fails to meet its deficit reduction commitments, but there are important differences. 
 The most important is the shift of emphasis to the actual level of spending on Federal programs, from an arbitrary deficit target, which can change dramatically depending on the state of the economy and the accuracy of economic assumptions. In addition, Congress will be monitored throughout the year to see whether it is meeting its targets. In the past such toting up was done at the end of the fiscal year.
 
Changes in Gramm-Rudman
 Gramm-Rudman utilizes a single target for the Federal budget deficit at the end of each fiscal year and makes the entire budget subject to automatic spending cuts if the year's deficit target is not met.
But the new system would use three spending caps -- one each for domestic programs, the military and foreign aid -- and Congress would not be obliged to meet a deficit target. Cuts would be made only in the category where the spending cap has been exceeded. Lawmakers and the White House have already agreed on the amounts of the caps.
Therefore, cuts in military spending could not be used to offset overruns in domestic programs. If Congress should decide, for example, that housing programs need more Federal dollars, the money would have to come from other domestic programs. Under the old law, the money could come from military spending, so long as the overall deficit target was met.
Under current budget procedures, the Congressional Budget Office and the Joint Committee on Tax, Congress's in-house budget experts, are responsible for the estimates of how much a particular spending program will cost or how much a particular tax increase will provide in new revenue.
 
More Authority for O.M.B.
 While Congress uses these estimates to devise the budget, it is the Administration's Office of Management and Budget that decides at the end of the year how much the budget has fallen short of the deficit target and therefore how much of an automatic spending cut is required to bring the budget back into line.
The new system will give the O.M.B. even more authority, in effect allowing the Administration to determine early in the budget process whether the spending and tax levels that Congress is working with are within the caps.
Politically, the new process provides something for everyone. The sponsors of the original budget-balancing bill get to say it is not dead. The Democrats are liberated from thinking about deficit targets that can sometimes be arbitrary. And the Administration can say it has put into place a true enforcement mechanism.
But Stanley E. Collender, a former House Budget Committee aide who is now a Federal budget specialist for Price Waterhouse, said the sheer amount of numbers and details that would have to be maintained by the O.M.B. to monitor Congressional spending action would give the Administration extraordinary power over decisions normally left to Congress.
"It may sound like green-eyeshade stuff," said a senior aide on the Senate Budget Committee, "but you're talking about potentially billions of dollars in how the costs of these programs are figured."
In addition, the budget office will be the agency deciding, for example, whether research on nuclear power is a military program or a domestic one. Including it under the domestic cap would leave less money for domestic programs and provide leeway for military programs.
Similarly, if the Congressional tax-writing committees decide they want to cut the Social Security tax, it is the O.M.B. that will decide how much money needs to be raised elsewhere to offset such a cut.
If the spending cap is exceeded in one of the three categories, the budget office would dictate how much money be cut, and Congress would have to comply within 15 days.
 
Dramatic Shift of Power
 "I don't think people realize just how much power has been shifted from one end of Pennsylvania Avenue to the other," said a senior Congressional aide involved in the negotiations on the new rules. Democrats promoted the changes in the summer budget negotiations at Andrews Air Force Base, as a way of warding off the White House insistence on a line-item veto, he said, "but I think we may find that in a subterfuge sort of way the White House actually got what it wanted."
In the new process, new Gramm-Rudman deficit targets for each of the next five years will remain on the books, but Congress will no longer be responsible for achieving them.
Rudolf G. Penner, a former director of the Congressional Budget Office, said the new enforcement system was far more practical than the across-the-board cuts stipulated under the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law.
"The problem with Gramm-Rudman," he said, "is that it was too severe. That's why we never had a full-fledged sequester," the automatic spending cuts.
"I can imagine, however, how this could work," Mr. Penner continued. "The new rules are subject to accounting gimmicks, too, but there should be less incentive for it."
 
Focus on Entitlement Programs
 Allen Schick, a professor of public policy at the University of Maryland and an author of the 1974 legislation that created the framework for the current budget system, is less convinced. The problem, he said, is that the new procedures focus too much on the wrong part of the budget and fail to deal sufficiently with the fundamental budget problem, the inexorable growth of entitlement programs, which remain separate from the three budget categories. The programs, which provide benefits to anyone who meets their criteria, include Social Security and Medicare and account for an increasing share of overall Federal spending.
By and large, entitlement programs were exempt from cuts under Gramm-Rudman, but the new procedures will make an introductory effort at containing their costs. If Congress chooses to add benefits in the programs, the additional benefits will be subject to a "pay as you go" system and lawmakers must offset them with cuts elsewhere in entitlement programs.
Given the difficulty that lawmakers had this year in restricting the growth in Medicare and the refusal to even consider limiting the growth of Social Security, many in Congress worry that it will continue to be impossible to make fundamental changes in entitlement programs.
But Senator Phil Gramm, the Texas Republican who was an author of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law, said he remained hopeful. "It may be that we can now start having the kind of debates on real policy that we have not been able to have," he said. "I think the next few years are going to be very interesting."
For Democrats who are concerned that the spending caps for military programs and foreign aid were set too high, there will be an opportunity to adjust the system for the 1994 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1, 1993. Under the enforcement system, the final two years of the budget agreement stipulate that spending for the military, foreign aid and domestic programs be consolidated under a single cap. This will permit lawmakers to reallocate money among the three divisions.
"We're almost certainly going to have to rethink everything after 1993," the Democratic budget strategist said, "because the deficit numbers are likely to be higher than is politically acceptable for either party. The weak economy virtually guarantees that."

HEADLINE: In Minnesota Politics, a Test of Character

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAUK CENTRE, Minn., Oct. 29

 BODY:
Sinclair Lewis, who grew up here and mocked the sanctimonious provincialism of rural Minnesota in his novels, would have been stunned by the antics of the state's politicians this year.
Arlan Stangeland, who has represented Sauk Centre and the rest of northwestern Minnesota in Congress since 1977, is in trouble because he made several hundred calls to or from the phone of a Virginia woman who is a lobbyist. He says it was all business. But in this land of lakes and birches and small towns, where politicians talk constantly about family values and villages of 400 people support three churches, his behavior has raised the suspicion that he was playing around, and has raised questions about the 60-year-old legislator's character. 
 "Stangeland's a strong family man," goes the damaging refrain in the coffee shops where farmers and shopkeepers gather to discuss the events of the day. "He likes families so much that he wants to have two of them."
 
Special Attention
 The revelations about Mr. Stangeland, a Republican, attracted special attention because Senator Dave Durenberger, also a Republican, had been the focus for months of news reports concerning allegations of improper financial behavior, and Mr. Durenberger was later censured by the Senate.
These are not the norms in Minnesota politics, which has had a reputation for almost painful high-mindedness since the days of Harold Stassen and Hubert H. Humphrey. The good times are supposed to roll in New Orleans, a hedonistic Creole city, not in Minneapolis, an earnest Scandinavian one.
Then, in the last couple of weeks, the character issue, a factor in several races around the country this year, took over Minnesota politics completely, in the person of Jon Grunseth, a conservative chosen as the G.O.P.'s nominee for governor.
 
Allegations Surface
 First, the Star Tribune of Minneapolis and St. Paul reported the charges of two women that Mr. Grunseth had swum naked with them in 1981, while they were still teen-agers, and that he had tried to yank down the swimsuit strap of one of them. He denied the charges, but another woman came forward to confirm the account in part.
Republicans saw their chances slipping away to elect Mr. Grunseth, and they worried that they would lose Mr. Stangeland's seat, suffer legislative setbacks and perhaps even see an upset of Senator Rudy Boschwitz, the party's powerhouse, who has also been hurt by President Bush's budget problems.
Mr. Boschwitz came bustling back to Minnesota, delivered a thoroughly confusing account of his position on the hiring discrimination bill and began trying to force Mr. Grunseth off the ticket. That brought him a lot of hostility from Republican conservatives and created still more confusion.
With Arne Carlson, a Republican moderate, planning a write-in campaign for governor, Mr. Grunseth called a news conference on Thursday to announce that he would pull out of the race. But he could not do it, and tore up his withdrawal statement.
"People have got to be thinking the Republican Party does not have its act together," said Bob Weinholzer, the party chairman, after hours of public indecision by Mr. Grunseth, "and they are probably right."
 
'Facing Disaster'
 "The Republican Party is just facing disaster," said former Gov. Elmer L. Anderson, a Republican.
Things couldn't get any worse, party loyalists said, but they did.
On Sunday, The Star Tribune reported the charges by Tamara Taylor that she had an intermittent affair with Mr. Grunseth from 1980 to 1989, during both of his marriages. On Sunday afternoon, the candidate abandoned his quest to unseat Gov. Rudy Perpich, who is seeking a fourth term, with the comment, "Man, it's just more than I can bear."
As of this morning, the Republicans were looking for a new candidate to head their ticket, with the election only eight days distant -- either Mr. Carlson, who is considerably more moderate than the party's executive committee, which will do the choosing, or one of two or three conservatives.
And as of this morning, Mr. Stangeland, who returned on Sunday at last after the lengthy budget and tax battle in Washington, was searching for some formula that would enable him, in the midst of all this chaos, to hold off the strong challenge of Collin C. Peterson. A Democratic former State Senator, Mr. Peterson has made no fewer than four previous attempts to oust him.
The seat has for many years been one of the few that is perennially closely contested, and the tightest contests have come in years, like this one, when there was no Presidential contest on the ballot. In 1982, Mr. Stangeland won with only 50.3 percent of the vote, and in 1986 Mr. Peterson, now 46, came within 121 votes of an upset.
 
A Close Race
 Recent polls show the two running neck and neck, but they give Mr. Stangeland less than 50 percent of the total with a large bloc of undecided voters. That is usually a bad omen for an incumbent who is as well known in his district as Mr. Stangeland is.
What was an apparent national swing to the Democrats, his own past vulnerability, the problem with the telephone calls and the beginnings of an economic downturn, Mr. Stangeland seems to analysts in Washington a prime candidate for defeat -- especially in the context of what former Vice President Walter F. Mondale calls "the loony-tune politics" that has hit Republicans in this state.
But even while he was stuck in Washington, Mr. Stangeland was mounting a strong defense, denouncing Mr. Peterson as an attack-and-spend liberal and driving home the point by voting against the final budget package that President Bush had endorsed.
If, as some local observers expect, the race is decided by television commercials, Mr. Stangeland may well have the edge, since he has outraced Mr. Peterson by more than 2 to 1.
In addition, Mr. Peterson has a rather racy reputation himself, which may help to blunt the character issue. He drives around in an old Porsche, leads a polka band and sometimes seems over-ambitious. That might count for little in most districts, but here in the bucolic countryside where Garrison Keillor planted his mystical Lake Wobegon, a man in too much of a hurry can raise a lot of eyebrows.
 
Late Sign of a Surge
 Still it is not easy to imagine how Mr. Peterson can miss this time, when Mr. Perpich, denounced for months as "Governor Goofy," has managed to get back into his race, and Mr. Boschwitz, seemingly untouchable a month ago, is under serious threat from Paul Wellston, an untested 46-year-old professor from Carleton College.
Pausing this weekend in his round of fish fries and ham dinners, Mr. Peterson said he sensed a surge in his effort in the last week or so.
"They don't ask me who I am anymore, and they don't ask what I stand for," he said. "They don't care about anything except whether you're 'in' or 'out.' I think it's going to be a little like Watergate and 1974, when all the Republicans in Minnesota, or most of them, just stayed at home.
"My only fear is I've run so often, people might think I'm the incumbent and vote against me."

HEADLINE: Experts Vary on Impact Of Plan to Trim Deficit

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29

 BODY:
Will the five-year deficit-reducing package of nearly $500 billion of spending cuts and tax increases voted by Congress on Sauturday help or hurt the economy?
 
Robert M. Solow, Nobel laureate, Massachusetts Institute of Technology:
The short-run impact of this package is almost certainly contractionary. It almost certainly adds to the 1989 impulse toward recession in the economy. It is very unlikely that the Fed will act fully and quickly enough to offset the contraction. I would not be able in five years to point to anything good from the agreement, the one exception being unless the package should induce the Fed and the world to allow substantially lower real interest rates. The longer-run impact over five to 10 years is probably favorable because then we could get more long-run growth, more investment in social infrastructure, more plant and equipment spending, more spending on research and development and a more skilled labor force.
 
Isabel V. Sawhill, senior fellow at the Urban Institute:
It will be good for the economy because it will untie Alan Greenspan's hands at the Fed to lower interest rates, and will have positive effects on the financial markets, and long-term rates hopefully will come down. The package buries "voodoo economics." Instead of assuming that we have to have low tax rates as a sure-fire tonic for the economy, it recognizes that big deficits are a greater threat than higher taxes. But it doesn't do much to control the growth in spending on the elderly, one of largest and fastest growting components of the budget. Social Security benefits weren't touched. Medicare benefits were only nicked. Medicare and Social Security represent 46 percent of domestic spending and slated to grow to 54 percent by the year 2000. There's also no effort to address the social deficit.
 
Sar Levitan, director of the Center for Social Policy at George Washington University:
For the short run, I don't think it will have much of an impact, particularly if the Fed follows it up with a mild reduction in interest rates. For the five-year period, it is more fiction than reality, because we can't project for five years from now, particularly since a recession may be looming on the horizon. To a large extent it is just a hope that we will reduce the budget deficit by $490 billion. Also, the projected deficits for the next five years will far exceed the $500 billion reduction that Congress has just voted. In case of recession or economic downturn, every 1 percent increase in unemployment will raise the deficit by another $40 billion. The average increase in each postwar recession was a 2 1/2 percent rise in unemployment. That would mean that if we have an average recession, the Fed budget deficit might actually increase by $100 billion. We don't know yet what will happen to the financial system in a recession.
 
John H. Makin, director of fiscal policy studies at the American Enterprise Institute:
The economy is weak and getting weaker. It is a modest package of deficit reduction. Everybody is celebrating because we're taking what we can get in these things. The previous largest was $25 billion after the 1987 stock market crash. This is of comparable scale. We are already so close to a recession that it's not worth arguing about. This is a very gentle tap further into a recession.
 
Alice M. Rivlin, senior fellow at the Brookings Institution:
The good things are: one, that it happened; two, that it's a five-year agreement, and three, that it is real. It is not smoke and mirrors. I also think it's about the right size for now. It's as big as they should have done, given the state of economy, though not enough for the long run. I don't think there will be any impetus for doing more next year, in what looks to be a fairly weak economy. Maybe in two or three years we will have courage to come back and say we have to do more. Forty billion dollars in the first year is in the small change of a $5 trillion economy.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

MARKETS
The Fed sent a clear signal that it had lowered interest rates, honoring a pledge that it indicated would be fulfilled once Congress passed a budget. But the message had little effect on the credit markets, where prices of Treasury securities fell. [Page D1.]

HEADLINE: A Scramble for New Bailout Funds

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29

 BODY:
The Bush Administration began scrambling today for ways to finance the bailout of the savings and loan industry in the wake of Congress's decision in its waning hours over the weekend not to supply any more money to the limping rescue effort.
A senior Treasury official, Deputy Secretary John E. Robson, said in an interview today that the department was considering use of an ambiguous provision in last year's bailout legislation that could permit the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency overseeing the bailout, to borrow an additional $18.8 billion. But he said it would probably be days or longer before a decision would be made as the Administration evaluated the political and practical consequences of borrowing without Congressional approval. He added that even if some funds were borrowed, the pace of the bailout would be forced to slow considerably. 
 "We will now have to fashion a low-calorie or no-calorie diet plan that will enable us to keep something going," he said.
 
Warnings Were Issued
 The Resolution Trust has virtually run out of cash. In the last two weeks, Administration officials and regulators, who sought $40 billion for the next 12 months, had warned that a failure of Congress to appropriate new money would halt the rescue.
While those warnings now appear overdrawn, the most conservative estimates by regulators are that the delay will increase the bailout costs by at least $2 million a day for the next three months and $6 million a day after that as sales of institutions slow and the savings and loans remain in Government hands.
Some experts predict that the cost of the financing delay could ultimately total more than $2 billion a quarter if the costs of delaying the seizure and sale of hundreds of institutions still under private management were included.
"The delay can now easily drag to six months and there is nothing good about it," said Bert Ely, an industry consultant, who predicted that it would now cost taxpayers $2 billion to $2.5 billion a quarter in extra financing because of the fund delay. "Coming into a recession, this is probably the worst time to be slowing down."
 
Move in House Blocked
 The effort to get more financing had been making headway in Congress, but just before the recess on Sunday morning a last-ditch effort by the House banking chairman, Henry B. Gonzalez, to authorize $10 billion in new financing until February was blocked by the second-ranking Democrat on the banking committee, Frank Annunzio of Illinois.
Mr. Annunzio, who has been critical of how the Administration has conducted the bailout, is facing a fierce race to retain his Chicago seat, in large part because of his close ties to the savings and loan industry. After his objection, the Senate went on to approve the interim financing measure by voice vote, but by then it was a dead issue in the House.
The tug-of-war between the Treasury Department and lawmakers is the most visible sign yet of how politically unpalatable the costly savings and loan bailout has become. While Democrats and Republicans have recognized that the financing is needed to keep the costs from increasing further, neither the Administration nor Congress wanted to be seen as taking the lead on authorizing new funds.
"Congress ran away from the problem," Mr. Robson said, continuing the political dispute between the Administration and lawmakers that developed after Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady refused repeated invitations to appear this month before Congress to justify the $40 billion request. "It doesn't help a bit to have Congress put a banana peel on the sidewalk right when we're rolling at a good pace."
Aides to Mr. Brady said he declined to testify because he saw it as little more than an attempt to haul him before the cameras and use him for political fodder just before the elections. His decision was harshly criticized by both Democrats and Republicans on Capitol Hill who maintained that he had a responsibility to testify and who used his refusal as a basis to oppose further appropriations.
Mr. Gonzalez continued today to blame the Administration, saying in a statement today, "The objections raised Saturday night to the consideration of additional funding are reflective of widespread concern about the cost of the savings and loan cleanup, the manner in which the program is being administered and the slow pace of resolutions and asset sales."
L. William Seidman, chairman of the Resolution Trust Corporation, said he expected the Administration to approve borrowing the $18.8 billion in financing quickly. "Assuming that it is available, we will be able to push forward, but it will cost extra money no matter what happens," he said, noting that the uncertainty over the agency's budget had already forced regulators to slow the pace of the rescue effort significantly in recent weeks.
But Mr. Robson said the Administration and the Resolution Trust's oversight board would not act hastily in interpreting the law to permit an additional $18.8 billion in borrowing.
"We have to decide whether it is appropriate to proceed in the face of some ambiguity and whether it is just the right thing to do," he said.
 
An Ambiguous Provision
 Because of what even its authors now consider an error in last year's bailout legislation, an ambiguous provision may permit Resolution Trust to exceed the cap limiting its borrowing authority and borrow up to an additional $18.8 billion, according to the General Accounting Office and some lawmakers, including Mr. Gonzalez. Before this week, Resolution Trust had said it believed the ambiguity would not permit such borrowings. The Treasury Department has not formally issued its interpretation of the provision.
William H. Roelle, director of the Resolutions and Operations Division of Resolution Trust, said the budget crunch would not affect the agency's ability to dispose of 65 savings associations with assets of less than $500 million each, but that it would make it difficult, if not impossible, to sell or close larger institutions whose plight is more costly to resolve.
"This program is like a supertanker," Mr. Roelle said. "Once you slow it down, it takes a lot to start up again."

HEADLINE: From President to Politician: Bush Attacks the Democrats

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 29

 BODY:
It is not easy to run against the Government you are running. It is not easy to carve up Democrats as "big taxers" when you've been huddling with the Democrats in Washington to raise taxes.
It is not easy to say you need more Republicans in Congress to help push your agenda when the White House-approved budget deal was passed mostly with Democratic votes. 
 But, as George Bush knows, consistency is the hobgoblin of politics. With a bipartisan budget agreement finally in place, President Bush came to the National Cowboy Hall of Fame today and declared that it was High Noon for Democrats.
 
'Class Warfare Garbage'
 With a sneer in his voice and the sort of Clint Eastwood-style "red meat lines" that have not been heard since the 1988 campaign, Mr. Bush began the scalding partisan attack on the "liberal" Democrats in Congress that he will be using till Election Day. He accused them of everything from stalling the economy and the budget agreement for partisan gain, to spreading "class warfare garbage," to turning their backs on police officers and the American dream, to pushing through "pork barrel bonanzas" like a Lawrence Welk tourist attraction in North Dakota.
Some Bush advisers feared that it would smack of cynicism to take a bitter and brutal tone toward the Democrats as the spend-and-tax party so soon after working with them on a budget deal that included new taxes, and that the tactic would backfire.
Some also wondered if it was dubious imagery to begin his cross-country message that the Republicans are the party of the working class by starting the day with a $25,000-per-couple fund-raising event for Senator Pete Wilson, the Republican candidate for governor of California, in San Francisco.
But Mr. Bush shrugged off questions today about his sagging popularity and about whether he has become a liability to Republican candidates.
The President grinned gamely as Bill Price, the Oklahoma candidate for governor for whom he was campaigning, introduced him with what would be considered faint praise in Republican circles. "George Bush on his worst day is a whole lot better than Michael Dukakis on his best day," Mr. Price told the crowd at the cowboy museum, adding supportively to the man who was supposed to be giving him a boost, "Your friends in Oklahoma are standing by you through thick and thin."
 
The Insider Is Outside
 Although the President's bipartisan budget deal-making has given him the image of the quintessential "inside-the-Beltway" President, Mr. Bush attempted to play the outsider. He invoked Harry S. Truman's name, complained about "inside-the-Beltway bickering" and commented at every chance: "God I'm glad to be out of Washington. I'm thrilled to be out of Washington."
In an all-out bid to give the wavering Republicans back their national voice, as he stumps around the country in the last eight days before mid-term elections, Mr. Bush lacerated liberals, who he said are "still peddling that tired old saw about Republicans and the rich."
"Well, you and I both know that that is hogwash, and we're not going to let them get away with that anymore," Mr. Bush said. "I'm taking this message all across the country: We are for the working people in this country."
Saying the various proposals to reduce the deficit were "the good, the bad and the ugly," Mr. Bush accused the Democrats of pushing him into tax increases -- even though the President himself issued the first explicit statement conceding that he would have to break his "no new taxes" pledge.
 
'We Had to Pay a Ransom'
 "To get an agreement, we had to pay a ransom to get the $350 billion in spending cuts," the President said. "And the American people have had to pay a price for divided government."
He tried to tar the Democrats, who believe they have regained their national voice as champions of the middle class and poor, as "big spenders" who tried to pack the budget agreement with pork.
"At the same time, this President and these Republican members were doing our level-best to curtail spending, Congress voted to spend a half a million dollars to create a Lawrence Welk tourist attraction," Mr. Bush said. "And we all like Lawrence Welk, 'dah-dee-dah,' you know how he is. But I cite this as a symptom of the problem." Mr. Bush was referring to Congress's approval last week of a $500,000 grant for Strasburg, N.D., to build a German-Russian museum at the farm where the famous band leader was born.
By not turning in a budget in April, the President said, the Democratic-controlled Congress put the country "on the brink of an economic downturn."
"The Democrats choked the throttle, pulled the throttle back of a slowing economy, while they hunted for every last morsel of partisan advantage," he said. "All in the name of politics and of higher taxes. And we're not going to let them get away with it."
 
'A House of Lords'
 He said that the Democrats in Congress had become "America's biggest and most entrenched special interest."
"The Democratic Congress is a confusion of committees and turf-conscious chaos," he said. "The House intended to be closest to the people has become a House of Lords."
Speaking with reporters at the San Francisco airport this morning, Mr. Bush was asked why Americans should not feel betrayed that he had caved in on raising taxes.
"Because I think people know that this Congress is controlled by the taxers, by the liberal Democrats," he said. "And they also know that we needed to try to get something done, and they also know that a President is elected to compromise at times, only rarely. But he's also elected to govern. American people are fair. They know I'm against taxes."
Mr. Bush also defended his chief of staff, John H. Sununu, and budget chief, Richard G. Darman, against criticism that they have rent the party and isolated the President.
"They are strong, and they are able," Mr. Bush said. "And any time you've got to do some heavy lifting on behalf of the President, you're bound to get caught up in a little crossfire."

Hetalked to reporters yesterday at the airport in San Francisco as he campaigned for Senator Pete Wilson, left, who is running for governor of California. (Associated Press)
