HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
U.N. COUNCIL HOLDS THE IRAQIS LIABLE ON KUWAIT DAMAGE

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 29

 BODY:
The United Nations Security Council overwhelmingly approved a resolution today laying the groundwork for a seizure of impounded Iraqi assets.
The latest resolution, intended to increase pressure on Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, warned that if the Iraqis continued to disregard Council demands, the world organization would take "further measures under the Charter." This could include the use of military force, but this was not explicitly mentioned. [Text, page A12.] 
 The new resolution declares Iraq responsible for all damage and personal injuries resulting from its occupation of Kuwait and asks nations to prepare claims for financial compensation and submit evidence of human rights violations by Iraqi forces there.
 
Yemen and Cuba Abstain
 The final vote showed 13 members in favor, while Yemen, the Council's only Arab member, and Cuba abstained. The vote was postponed from last Saturday while President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union sent a high-level envoy on another mission to Baghdad.
By voting for the resolution, the Soviet Union indicated that the trip to Baghdad by Mr. Gorbachev's envoy, Yevgeny M. Primakov, did not produce the kind of breakthrough that could forestall further Council action. Mr. Primakov said in answer to a question upon leaving Baghdad that his trip had been disappointing.
But Mr. Gorbachev in Paris still held out the possibility that President Saddam Hussein might yield to the United Nations demands. He said he had received fresh information from Mr. Primakov suggesting that "Iraq's leadership might at last heed the voice of the United Nations."
 
New U.S. Warnings
 While Mr. Gorbachev continued to urge a diplomatic solution, primarily through Arab nations, the Bush Administration stepped up its warnings that military power might be used to force Iraq out of Kuwait if nothing else works.
In a speech in Los Angeles, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d explicitly said that the use of military power was one option to pursue in getting Iraq to leave Kuwait. "We will not rule out a possible use of force if Iraq continues to occupy Kuwait," Mr. Baker said.
At the United Nations Arab diplomats said President Hussein appears to be seriously worried by the danger of an American-led attack on his forces in Kuwait and Iraq.
They said Mr. Hussein sent a message over the weekend to Mr. Gorbachev and President Francois Mitterrand of France in advance of their talks in Paris today, offering to release all the foreign hostages held by Iraq if those two leaders committed themselves to a political solution.
But the Gorbachev-Mitterrand meeting ended without such a joint statement. Yemen's Foreign Minister, Abdel-Karim al-Iryani, said in Sana, his nation's capital, today that he had learned of this Iraqi offer in a phone conversation with Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz.
The resolution approved by the Security Council today also requires Iraq to cease looting and hostage-taking in Kuwait and resupply the foreign embassies still holding out there. Only the United States and Britain have operating embassies in Kuwait. France ordered its remaining diplomats home today.
The resolution asked the Secretary General of the United Nations to try once more to find a peaceful way out of the crisis. But it warned that if Baghdad continues to reject its demands, the Council will take further unspecified "measures under the Charter" to enforce them.
 
Options Available to U.N.
 These could include tightening the trade embargo it has imposed, although the Council is reluctant to cut telecommunications links or break off diplomatic relations, the only remaining nonmilitary steps provided for by the Charter.
Thomas R. Pickering, the United States representative to the United Nations, hinted that the Council might soon consider paying compensation to victims of Iraq's aggression out of the country's assets frozen overseas.
But the Council might also threaten to oust Iraq from Kuwait by force, as the Charter allows if it decides that economic sanctions are not effective.
The five big powers with permanent Council seats sought to reinforce this implicit threat of force today by convening the Security Council's military advisory body at the highest level in United Nations history.
For the first time the United States sent a three-star general from Washington to represent the Joint Chiefs of Staff at a meeting of the Security Council's Military Staff Committee, called to review the situation in the Persian Gulf and the efforts there to enforce the trade embargo against Iraq.
 
Soviet and Chinese Generals
 Lieut. Gen. Michael Carns, Director of the Joint Staff at the Pentagon, was joined by Col. Gen. Bronislav A. Omelichev, First Deputy Chief of the Soviet General Staff, who came from Moscow for the talks and by Vice Adm. Alain Coatanea, a senior French naval officer from Paris.
China was represented by Maj. Gen. Du Guanyi, the head of its delegation to the committee, and Britain by Maj. Gen. Edwin H. A. Beckett, head of the British Defense Staff in Washington.
Several delegates addressed the Council in terms that suggested that a decision to use force might not be far away.
Mr. Pickering, after emphasizing that every government has a duty to protect its citizens held hostage by Iraq, said, "The United States will do that which is necessary to meet its obligations for its own citizens."
Canada's representative, Yves Fortier, said the Council "must not shy away" from enforcing its decisions. And Malaysia's representative, Ismail Razali, said, "The Council's ability to undertake futher enforcement measures should not be doubted."
Iraq's representative, Abdul Amir al-Anbari, made an hourlong speech in which he gave a preview of some of the difficulties the Council may face later this week by asking why it punished Iraq for occupying Kuwait but not Israel for occupying East Jerusalem, the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Security Council delegates voting yesterday to approve a resolution laying the groundwork for seizure of impounded Iraqi assets. (Bill Swersey for The New York Times) (pg. A12)

HEADLINE: Market Place;
California Banks: Bad Times Near?

BYLINE: By Michael Quint

 BODY:
REAL estate values in California, a bastion of strength compared with New England and other parts of the East Coast, are deteriorating rapidly and may become the next problem for the nation's banking industry, analysts say.
While California bankers and economists have predicted a mild downturn, other analysts have recently begun predicting more severe problems. When California's weakness hurts local banks and filters through to other sectors of the economy, as occurred in New England, the chances of a severe national recession are greatly increased, they said. 
 David Shulman, a real estate analyst at Salomon Brothers, told clients yesterday that the slowdown in home sales in California, declines in home prices there and high vacancy rates for commercial property all point to a market that is weaker than he expected a few months ago. He warned that a broad-based national decline in real estate prices would be steeper than he expected because of higher oil prices and an economy that is in recession.
"There is a one-in-three chance that the problems in California will be as bad as Texas," said George Salem, a banking analyst at Prudential Bache Securities. In Texas, the collapse of real estate after the decline in oil prices in the 1980's eventually led to the failure or acquisition of 9 of the state's 10 largest banking companies.
Mr. Salem did not predict the imminent collapse of California's four largest banks, but he said they face difficult times. With a third or more of their loans backed by real estate, a 25 percent decline in real estate prices is sure to cause defaults by developers who cannot sell new buildings and mustdefault on loans. He recommends that investors sell Wells Fargo, Security Pacific and First Interstate, and he rates BankAmerica a "hold."
Wells Fargo & Company, whose stock was as high as $87.375 a share in October 1989, fell $2.75 yesterday to $45.125; Security Pacific dropped 87.5 cents, to $17.75, from $50 in the same period, and First Interstate fell yesterday by $1, to $17.125, from $64.25 in October. The BankAmerica Corporation dropped 25 cents yesterday, to $18.50, and is down from a peak of $36.25.
While Wall Street analysts like Mr. Salem and Thomas Hanley at Salomon Brothers are predicting big problems for California banks, local bankers seem more confident that California is too healthy for debacles like those in Texas or New England.
At the San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank, economists said last week that the "most recent data provide no indication that the quality of either commercial or real estate loans has begun to deteriorate." In August, another article published by the San Francisco Fed concluded that California's "slowdown" was merely a return to normalcy after the boom years of 1988 and 1989. The Fed's economists said that with the slowdown in construction activity, there would not be the severe overbuilding that hurt New England.
Other analysts are not so sanguine. Mr. Salem noted that in downtown Los Angeles, the supply of office space would rise at least 30 percent by the end of next year, a glut that is causing developersto offer tenants two years of free rent on a 10-year lease. The glut is also greatly reducing the value of new and existing office buildings.
According to Mr. Salem, who recently published a 46-page study of the California real estate market, problems are looming for single-family mortgage loans, which bankers have long regarded as safe. He does not expect significant losses on such loans for banks by 1991, but warned that losses are possible in subsequent years, depending on how far home prices drop and how many homeowners lose their jobs.
Home prices in California have fallen much more than the decline of a few percentage points over the past year reported by the California Association of Realtors, Mr. Salem said. Based on interviews and a study of newspaper advertisements, he said existing home prices have already fallen by 10 to 20 percent from their peaks in mid-1989. By the end of next year, home prices might be down 25 percent or more from their peaks, he added.
The risk of losses for banks is greatest on loans made since the end of 1987, when real estate values and loan amounts were near their peaks. At the Bank of America, two-thirds of home mortgages were issued since the beginning of 1988, leading Mr. Salem to conclude that there is a danger that as economic weakness lingers, bankers will discover risk in their newer mortgages, while older mortgages are safer.
Even if defaults on owner-occupied, single-family homes are rare, Mr. Schulman said the economy would suffer if families in California and elsewhere were unable or unwilling to sell their existing houses because prices had fallen. He said many families had come to rely on profits from home sales to pay for the purchases of major appliances and automobiles, as well as for the down payment for a new, larger home.

HEADLINE: Oil Prices Move Above $34 a Barrel

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Oil prices increased to more than $34 a barrel in light trading on the futures market yesterday amid concerns that a Soviet peace effort in the Persian Gulf had failed.
"It was perhaps one of the last-ditch efforts to get a peaceful resolution," said Christian Gohler, a vice president with Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. "As a result, the market moved higher." 
 A barrel of crude for December delivery rose $1.67, to $34.68, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Contracts for later months also settled higher.
Traders said the session was one of the quietest they could remember since Iraq invaded Kuwait in August.
Although there was no strong news to move the market, prices opened higher and held their ground on reports of the unsuccessful Soviet efforts to find a diplomatic solution to the crisis.
"There was a lot of speculation over the weekend that there could be some progress made," said Peter Beutel, an oil analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. in Hoboken, N.J. "Whether it's true or not, people are saying this may be the last chance before some military action is necessary. The thinking is, If the Soviets can't get Iraq to change, who can?"
The Soviet Union and Iraq once had close ties, but the Soviets still lined up with the rest of the global community in condemning Iraq for its attack on Kuwait.
Soviet Middle East envoy Yevgeny M. Primakov met with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein in Baghdad on Sunday. After those talks, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said he saw no reason for optimism in the gulf.
Some traders stayed on the sidelines Monday as they waited to see an interview with Mr. Hussein that Cable News Network was to air Monday evening. Oil prices hit their lows for the day on the Merc when players learned from an excerpt of the interview that the Iraqi leader was apparently refusing to rule out the idea of a diplomatic resolution to the crisis.
"He was saying peace was still possible," said Ed Kevelson, a trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.
Crude's increase early in the day was mirrored in the futures prices for refined petroleum products. Home heating oil settled 3.11 cents higher at 91.36 cents a gallon for November delivery. Contracts for later months all closed higher.
Unleaded gasoline settled up .96 cent at 92.43 cents per gallon for November, with other delivery months trading higher.
Natural gas futures were off for the day, with the December contract falling 1.4 cents, to $2.434 per 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Popularizing Accounting For Students

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
IN this time of recession concerns, the accounting profession, like many others, is undergoing cutbacks in pay or staffing.
Yet accounting might be one of the best careers for the future. The Bureau of Labor Statistics, reporting on occupations with the largest growth prospects, says that the army of 963,000 accountants and auditors it estimated in 1988 needs to increase by 22 percent, to 1,174,000, by the year 2000 to meet growing needs from both accounting firms and businesses. 
 Last spring, graduates with accounting majors received job offers at salaries averaging $26,496, up 5 percent from the previous year, according to the College Placement Council.
 Too few college students, however, major in accounting and too few with graduate degrees are entering the profession, possibly because it is not considered glamorous. Also, many who earn master of business administration degrees with an accounting specialty tend to take jobs with businesses. To insure a better supply of talent, the half-dozen big accounting firms have been providing money for scholarships, professors and programs.
Dr. Ronald J. Patten cited this situation in a recent interview, saying part of his job is "making accounting popular" to attract more young people. As dean of the College of Commerce at De Paul University in Chicago, he heads one of the largest undergraduate business schools and the nation's fourth-largest graduate business program. There are 2,646 students in the daytime undergraduate business program and 1,174 in the evening program, plus 2,995 students in graduate programs working for master of business administration degrees or master of science degrees in accounting.
"The fact that fewer students major in accounting is a national phenomenon," he said. He added that De Paul was not experiencing it so much, however, " because our enrollment of accounting majors is down less than 1 percent in recent years." At the graduate level he called accounting enrollment at least "stable."
Many students, he said, had a perception that accounting courses could be "boring." To combat that, Dr. Patten said, "we're using the interactive mode -- case studies to supplement analytical techniques they must learn."
He added: "Students defend their judgments after reading case histories, and this results in more interaction with classmates and the professor. That's our prime tool."
For example, he explained, one case study he wrote involved a large Trinidad company that makes batteries in Barbados. To help increase sales, an incentive system was begun for salesmen.
In the United States, Dr. Patten said, a battery maker is such a large company that production workers do not come into contact with salesmen. But on a small island they did, and the incentive system created so much animosity it had to be revised. Salesmen continue to be rewarded for increased sales, while production workers are granted extra money based on decreasing warranty claims that indicate better-quality production.
De Paul uses a variety of cases, especially those published by the University of Virginia's business school, the Harvard business school and the business school of the University of Western Ontario, in London.
Like other deans, Dr. Patten faces another problem -- the weakness of students in communications. "It's a national problem," he said. To put corporate strategy into effect, managers must have skills in writing, speaking, reading and even listening to get the support of workers, he added. And so, after almost a year and a half in the De Paul post, he talks of redesigning the undergraduate curriculum to "integrate communications" into many required courses.
For ethics, the school uses video tapes provided by Arthur Andersen & Company, the big accounting firm. As for international accounting, Dr. Patten said textbooks had improved with the addition of more international case material.
The year 2000 presents a special worry for the profession. The American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, its ruling body, has decreed that new members at that time must meet a requirement of 150 hours of education. That means an undergraduate program of 120 hours, including core liberal arts courses, and 30 hours beyond, mostly in accounting.
To meet this, Dr. Patten said, "We have a program with some large accounting firms who offer employment to liberal arts graduates." He explained that individuals were hired by such a firm and spent their first salaried summer studying accounting full-time. Then they work full-time for the firm, taking additional courses at night, followed by a second full-time summer of study, and a fall term working and studying. The result: a master of science degree in accounting. "We graduate about 15 a year in this program and hope to double it to 30," he said.
Looking back at his education -- earning a master's degree in accounting followed by a doctorate -- Dr. Patten said a useful course for an accountant-to-be would include history.
"I continue to feel that history is important," he said. "A lot of what happens in the world has taken place before.
"We have an economic history course, not required. I would like to see it required, along with business and financial history."
Such courses have also been making a comeback at the business schools of New York University and Cornell University.

HEADLINE: Fiber-Optic Network Is Urged at Conference

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Oct. 29

 BODY:
Scientists, business executives and academic researchers meeting here today said the key to restoring United States competitiveness is to drop regulatory barriers to building a fiber-optic network to deliver electronic information to the nation's homes. The regulated Bell operating companies have argued that they need to be freed to provide electronic information services, including television, to justify the investment in building such a network.
The meeting came just two days after Congress failed to pass a bill that would have provided a half-billion dollars over three years for research and development to build a high-speed computer network to link the nation's supercomputer centers. 
 A computer network that would carry video, voice and data at speeds up to a thousand times faster than existing networks has been backed by both Congressional Democrats and the Bush Administration. But a bill introduced by Senator Albert Gore Jr., Democrat of Tennessee, failed to pass over the weekend.
 
Growing Consensus Seen
 Speakers here at a three-day meeting held to discuss whether the Government should play a role in fostering high-technology development said there is a growing consensus in the country that a fiber-optic network to carry voice and data for business and video for home entertainment would serve as a catalyst for American companies and revitalize the American microelectronics industry.
"The fiber-optic network should be looked at as a prolific tree and the fruit will be the new businesses it creates," said Dr. George A. Keyworth, a physicist who was science adviser to President Reagan and is now director of research at the Hudson Institute in Indianapolis. The institute, a conservative policy center, sponsored the three-day symposium.
Deregulation of the regional Bell operating companies that would permit local phone companies to sell information services and transmit video to the nation's home has been opposed by the cable industry and by newspapers.
 
Growing Impatience Cited
 But Dr. Keyworth said that there is a growing impatience in the country to move ahead with new technologies.
A number of researchers who spoke here argued that the revamping of the nation's communications infrastructure would yield unexpected benefits and new economic productivity.
"Whenever you make access to a resource like this, a number of new things that were unexpected will happen," said Dr. Carver Mead, a California Institute of Technology scientist who developed techniques that have made the rapid design of the most advanced semiconductors possible.
 
Warning on Japanese Project
 The researchers also warned that Japan is well under way in a project to spend as much as $250 billion on developing their own fiber optic network before the turn of the century. Dr. Keyworth said that on a recent visit to Japan he had been told that that nation expects to receive fully one-third of its gross national product from services carried by the fiber-optic network by the year 2015.
The participants at the conference did not agree on what kind of leadership the Government should provide in creating a public fiber-optic computer network. Richard J. Elkus, chief executive of the Prometrix Corporation, said that the Bush Administration needed to show more leadership in guiding the country toward renewed economic competiveness. Mr. Elkus said the nation was rapidly losing its manufacturing base to Japanese competitors.
"We are competing against a nation, Japan, that defines short-term as a year and long-term as forever," he said.
George Gilder, an author and economist at the Hudson Institute, said that if the Government's role was minimized, entrepreneurial companies would be freed to compete effectively against the Japanese.
Some of those present said that economic competition along national lines was increasingly less relevant. Peter J. Sprague, chairman of National Semiconductor Corporation, said that the definition of what an American corporation is has rapidly been blurring. "We are using Russian engineers living in Israel to design chips that are made in America and then assembled in Asia," he said.
